[Roy Belson]: Roy Belson, 2500 Mystic Valley Parkway, Medford, a longtime member of the Jewish community, and a former employee of the Medford Public Schools for 50 years.

[Roy Belson]: I'm here to speak tonight on the proposed ordinance that you did lay on the table, but I believe I have some words to say that I would like to have heard.

[Roy Belson]: So good evening, Mr. President, members of the council.

[Roy Belson]: The role of city government is to focus on the welfare and betterment of the community.

[Roy Belson]: As individuals, you always have the right to advocate for issues in the international arena.

[Roy Belson]: As a local governmental body representing a diverse community, you need to promote harmony, not create friction and fragmentation over an issue that is not your mandate and well beyond your capacity to significantly influence.

[Roy Belson]: Words carry meaning.

[Roy Belson]: The old saw that sticks and stones may break bones, but words will never harm me is very misleading.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes words are sharper than a sword.

[Roy Belson]: All you have to do is study social media or be bombarded with campaigns of disinformation to realize that words can lead to severe negative outcomes.

[Roy Belson]: To paraphrase, the road to disaster is often paved with good intentions.

[Roy Belson]: Do not let your zeal to advance your ideals blind you to adverse impacts your actions can and will create.

[Roy Belson]: The issues in the Middle East are not just contemporary, but are hundreds of years old.

[Roy Belson]: The causes and circumstances are complex, and the resolution has been defying even the most honorable peace brokers amidst the actions of multiple terrorist groups and partisan fanatics.

[Roy Belson]: You don't have to agree with all of Israeli policies and practices to recognize the Israelis' right to exist, but to recognize the urgent need to eliminate any possibility

[Roy Belson]: of anti-Semitism in our community.

[Roy Belson]: Recently, think about the young couple in Washington, Yaron and Sarah, who were gunned down leaving the Israeli embassy by a man screaming, free Palestine.

[Roy Belson]: And 11 days later, think about what happened in Boulder, Colorado, when a man yelling, free Palestine, threw a Molotov cocktail at peaceful marchers calling for the release of hostages.

[Roy Belson]: Think about Governor Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania, who barely escaped with his family a fire in his home started by another man calling to free Palestine.

[Roy Belson]: I could go on.

[Roy Belson]: Don't think for a moment it couldn't happen here in Medford.

[Roy Belson]: We are as vulnerable as any other Jewish American community.

[Roy Belson]: The proposed ordinances are performative at best.

[Roy Belson]: Passage will not alter the international reality.

[Roy Belson]: Any study of BDS has not proven effective.

[Roy Belson]: Massachusetts law and practice makes implementation of such a proposal impractical and not in the best financial interests of the community.

[Roy Belson]: You already passed a resolution in February of this year.

[Roy Belson]: Will you accept accountability if anti-Semitic violence happens in our community?

[Roy Belson]: Don't delude the Palestinian supporters in our community that such an ordinance can even be enforced.

[Roy Belson]: Don't subject the Jewish citizens in our community to a greater threat of hate and violence.

[Roy Belson]: It can happen here.

[Roy Belson]: Instead, demonstrate real leadership by rejecting performative votes.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, you can preserve and advance your values and concerns much better by promoting community dialogue,

[Roy Belson]: by bringing citizens together, by promoting understanding.

[Roy Belson]: Council business has many challenges and you know it.

[Roy Belson]: Focus on what you can do to better unify the community.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you for listening.

[Roy Belson]: William Ellison, 2500 Mystic Valley Parkway.

[Roy Belson]: You have a great opportunity.

[Roy Belson]: Bring people together, bring people together in small groups, bring people together to talk to each other and talk with each other and understand the history of the Middle East.

[Roy Belson]: Understand the tensions, understand all the peace treaties that were broken and not gone forward.

[Roy Belson]: So we can basically have a really good understanding of how to go forward.

[Roy Belson]: A performative ordinance

[Roy Belson]: that's going to get knocked down by legal issues, financial issues, and other things like that, doesn't really bring people together.

[Roy Belson]: Try to find ways so people can sit together and talk.

[Roy Belson]: I can tell you that last year or the year before, we had a book club at the temple, and we invited the imam from the cultural center.

[Roy Belson]: Great discussion, great discussion.

[Roy Belson]: We're as concerned about Muslims as we are about Jews.

[Roy Belson]: We understand that any number of people can be discriminated against.

[Roy Belson]: the way to bring things together, the way to build community, is not to put something out there that fragments, but to put in place processes that enable us to talk with each other, share viewpoints, and come to new understandings that allow us to move forward as a community.

[Roy Belson]: I appreciate your understanding, and I hope that you'll take that advice.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Nice to see everybody.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you for giving me an opportunity to say a few things.

[Roy Belson]: And hopefully, what I express will help you understand what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, I'm here to share my perspectives and my thoughts about the upcoming questions on the November ballot, especially those that affect public education.

[Roy Belson]: So while I'm no longer the superintendent of schools, I'm in my seventh year of retirement or semi-retirement, I still stay very aware of education items, both in the community, the state, nation, and it's very enlightening to see what people are doing around the commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: I spent 50 years in Medford public education, 23 years as superintendent,

[Roy Belson]: And I also served at different times as the budget director, the curriculum director, and the personnel administrator, as well as a teacher.

[Roy Belson]: So I care deeply about what happens in our schools and our community.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not here tonight to criticize the school administration.

[Roy Belson]: I know how hard they work.

[Roy Belson]: I know the challenges that they face.

[Roy Belson]: And I know that some of the things are beyond their control.

[Roy Belson]: I have always believed, and I still do, that schools deserve solid levels of funding and that the budget process must promote and support quality programming, stability, and predictability.

[Roy Belson]: Budget development must be resourceful and creative.

[Roy Belson]: It should not be a destabilizing force, exercise, and create uncertainty and conflict.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that's what's happened in the last couple of years.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, there will be from time to time differences among officials, educators, constituents, but at all times, they should be based on the facts, on available resources, best practices, and the needs of students and their families, as well as the community at large.

[Roy Belson]: The current override ballot questions, initiatives, and two of them in education, and one, a debt exclusion for the fire department,

[Roy Belson]: Call for, if you will, in the school department, a $7 million hike.

[Roy Belson]: You had a half a million dollars for the DPW at 7.5.

[Roy Belson]: This is a property tax levy.

[Roy Belson]: This request is based upon the argument that the school system has been perpetually in a structural deficit, and it's not true.

[Roy Belson]: The pertinent questions are these.

[Roy Belson]: Is it true that we're in a deficit?

[Roy Belson]: How does Medford compare with other communities around us?

[Roy Belson]: Are there good alternatives available to meet our needs?

[Roy Belson]: Is this a one-time request or will there be another one, a larger request in the near future?

[Roy Belson]: And I think you know the answer to that.

[Roy Belson]: What is the real impact on the Medford taxpayer?

[Roy Belson]: And does the voting public truly understand the pros and cons?

[Roy Belson]: And has there been sufficient information and time for the public to make an informed decision?

[Roy Belson]: So let's take a look and let's consider the following.

[Roy Belson]: The last two years relied heavily on the use of federal ARPA and ESSER funds.

[Roy Belson]: They were put out there because of the COVID crisis.

[Roy Belson]: It was well known that when these funds were used up, there would be a need for the city to sustain staff and programs with local and state revenues.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise, there would be undesirable cuts to program and personnel.

[Roy Belson]: So was this necessary?

[Roy Belson]: When the budget process took place in the last year, everybody knew that those funds had to be replaced.

[Roy Belson]: And those funds enabled the city to build up a free cash reserve that is three times what has ever been in place.

[Roy Belson]: Almost at this point in time, $35 million.

[Roy Belson]: And if that was the case, was it necessary?

[Roy Belson]: And did the mayor really fail to provide full funding consistent with the school committee's request?

[Roy Belson]: when there's a significant amount of free cash available to the city, much higher than the amount available in previous years.

[Roy Belson]: The school administration, by law, is required to ask, and the school committee as well, for an amount sufficient to support the schools under Proposition 2 1⁄2.

[Roy Belson]: It's their legal request to do that.

[Roy Belson]: The mayor or the city manager in the past, when 2 1⁄2 passed, had the bottom line, and the city council

[Roy Belson]: can only approve or cut what the mayor provides.

[Roy Belson]: So it's not simple.

[Roy Belson]: The amount of money reported to DOR of free cash was $25 million in 2004.

[Roy Belson]: And as I indicated, they added another $9 million or thereabouts in the current fiscal year.

[Roy Belson]: Why, given the often repeated

[Roy Belson]: mantra of the mayor, transparency.

[Roy Belson]: Interesting word.

[Roy Belson]: And the city's financial director, did they fail to provide a clean and complete report on the city's financial position to the city council and the school committee?

[Roy Belson]: I think the answer's simple.

[Roy Belson]: The answer is that they wanted to leverage a crisis to create

[Roy Belson]: a need for an override, because you're in a situation where you don't have it, you're threatening cuts to important services, and if you don't give me the money, we're gonna have to do drastic measures.

[Roy Belson]: This is not Proposition 2 1⁄2.

[Roy Belson]: In 1981, 1982, I was in the school system.

[Roy Belson]: I was working with the superintendent's office, and the budget of the city of Medford for the schools was $19.4 million.

[Roy Belson]: That year, we had to cut $3.2 million.

[Roy Belson]: That's a cut.

[Roy Belson]: 150 people got laid off.

[Roy Belson]: That was difficult, very difficult.

[Roy Belson]: We are not in that situation right now.

[Roy Belson]: We are not in that situation.

[Roy Belson]: When the 2024 DOR, Department of Revenue Tax Recap Report is studied, and I did that,

[Roy Belson]: There are clear underestimates of revenue amounts when compared with 2023, specifically by almost 15%.

[Roy Belson]: So in other words saying, if investment income was X, it was 14% less when they were projecting their revenue, almost $18 million.

[Roy Belson]: Why create a crisis?

[Roy Belson]: Before you ask the public for an override, should you not first use the obvious resources available?

[Roy Belson]: You can always go back later on and say, you know, we used up our resources.

[Roy Belson]: But when you have them, why won't you use them?

[Roy Belson]: Let's talk about the tax rate.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford tax rate is low.

[Roy Belson]: The residential tax rate is low comparatively to area communities.

[Roy Belson]: Nothing wrong with that.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think anyone feels like it has to be number one, the highest tax rate in the Commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: So it's not a bad thing when affordability for housing and other needs is challenging.

[Roy Belson]: If the overrides and debt exclusion pass, taxes will increase, I think, by at least 10%.

[Roy Belson]: especially when you include the 2.5% statutory increase that happens virtually every year.

[Roy Belson]: And what about the impact of re-evaluation?

[Roy Belson]: You know what's going on right now.

[Roy Belson]: They're checking your houses out.

[Roy Belson]: And by the way, if you haven't noticed, your house is worth more than it was when you bought it, in most cases.

[Roy Belson]: And when they reassess it, they're going to reassess it and the taxes are going to go up.

[Roy Belson]: And on top of that, you're probably going to pay a little bit more for water and sewer.

[Roy Belson]: And when you add it all together, if you have to take an equity loan, you're gonna pay a hell of a lot more interest than you might like.

[Roy Belson]: And if you're a new person wanting to buy a home, the mortgage rates are still at 6.2%, and even if it goes down to 5%, it's a hell of a lot higher than it was when people refinanced a few years ago.

[Roy Belson]: And what about renters?

[Roy Belson]: Some of these people will never have a chance.

[Roy Belson]: They just won't be able to

[Roy Belson]: to get in and the landlords are going to pass on the rent to their tenants.

[Roy Belson]: So, that affects people too.

[Roy Belson]: When you think about it, there's also a deduction, tax deduction limit.

[Roy Belson]: You used to be able to take your income tax and your house property tax and interest.

[Roy Belson]: You can't do that anymore in the current rule.

[Roy Belson]: So, you can't even deduct some of the stuff that you used to be able to do before.

[Roy Belson]: Some people can get around it for various reasons,

[Roy Belson]: Not everybody.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at the age factor in the community, 22% of Medford residents are over the age of 60.

[Roy Belson]: 14% are 70 or more.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of these people are on fixed incomes.

[Roy Belson]: They don't have another alternative to go to.

[Roy Belson]: And they're probably supporting their children, their grandchildren, and everything else like that as well.

[Roy Belson]: So a hit like this is really significant.

[Roy Belson]: By the way, as the high school project moves forward, and it's in a planning stage right now, undoubtedly there will be another override request, which isn't out there right now.

[Roy Belson]: That'll make three override requests.

[Roy Belson]: The two that are there now, and the one that might come up, plus the debt exclusion, in the very near future.

[Roy Belson]: Given the cost of a rebuild,

[Roy Belson]: or renovation, this will be the biggest number that you've ever seen.

[Roy Belson]: The SBA reimbursement rate is not known at this time.

[Roy Belson]: It will only cover certain costs.

[Roy Belson]: Not everything is eligible.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at high schools that have been built or renovated in recent times, you're talking somewhere in the vicinity of $200 million to $400 million to redo the high school.

[Roy Belson]: We've got vocational shops and other things like that that have to be preserved.

[Roy Belson]: That's an expensive thing.

[Roy Belson]: And if you maybe get 35, 40%, not getting the 90% that we got for the schools, the K through 12 schools that we got several years ago with Rick as the chairperson of the building committee at that time.

[Roy Belson]: And we, by the way, sold the old schools so that we actually made money.

[Roy Belson]: Don't tell anybody.

[Roy Belson]: You don't get that now.

[Roy Belson]: So you're gonna be talking about potentially 100 to $200 million of local assessment over and above.

[Roy Belson]: That will impact taxes on top of the early override assessments.

[Roy Belson]: And by the way, if the override passes in November,

[Roy Belson]: you will see the increase on your January 2025 tax bill.

[Roy Belson]: You're not gonna wait a year to build it up.

[Roy Belson]: You're gonna see it in January.

[Roy Belson]: It's only a few months away.

[Roy Belson]: Now one of the arguments that comes around is that somehow Medford salaries and cost per pupil are not competitive.

[Roy Belson]: Now as a educator, I think I started off with this, I want every nickel I can get for the schools.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, I'd be less than honest if I didn't tell you that I think the schools deserve every nickel we can give them, and we have plenty of needs.

[Roy Belson]: But no one gets everything they want, and no school system is able to do that, and no community is able to do that.

[Roy Belson]: Well, let's take a look at the Medford Public Schools financials.

[Roy Belson]: And this is according to the latest Department of Elementary and Secondary Education statistics.

[Roy Belson]: The state average per pupil is $19,714.

[Roy Belson]: Medford is currently spending $21,372.

[Roy Belson]: Arlington is spending $18,615.

[Roy Belson]: Malden is spending $17,428.

[Roy Belson]: Melrose is spending $15,540.

[Roy Belson]: Peabody is spending $16,996, and I can go on and on.

[Roy Belson]: Now, someone can say, well, there are, Mystic Valley, by the way, one of the charter schools that sucks away dollars from our budget, is paying, is spending $14,167.

[Roy Belson]: Now, there are places, Somerville 23958, we just built a building so you can see where,

[Roy Belson]: that's involved.

[Roy Belson]: And by the way, if you want to chase Cambridge, Cambridge is spending $36,712.

[Roy Belson]: Of course, Cambridge has got a property base that's incredible.

[Roy Belson]: And Burlington is $25,297.

[Roy Belson]: And by the way, if we were still sending kids to Minuteman, the cost would be $34,176.

[Roy Belson]: And if we continued to send 50 kids there like we did when we cut it off, we'd be pushing $2 million a year of money out of our pocket.

[Roy Belson]: And that's why we rebuilt the vocational school.

[Roy Belson]: And people argued about, why are you not sending the kids to Minuteman?

[Roy Belson]: Because they're sucking dollars out of Medford.

[Roy Belson]: And we had a right to rebuild our own school and run our own programs at a far less cost.

[Roy Belson]: So, then the question comes about teacher salaries.

[Roy Belson]: Where's Charlene?

[Roy Belson]: Charlene?

[Roy Belson]: All right, Charlene, don't take offense.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at the average salary for the Medford teachers, average salary, and this is latest numbers, you know, obviously it's gone up a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: The average salary is $88,179.

[Roy Belson]: That's the statistic.

[Roy Belson]: If you're on the top step, 10 years, a master's plus 60, this year fiscal 25, you're going to make $111,000.

[Roy Belson]: In Arlington, the top salary is $83,466.

[Roy Belson]: I mean the average salary.

[Roy Belson]: Melrose is $76,369.

[Roy Belson]: Beverly is $84,765.

[Roy Belson]: Malden is $83,366.

[Roy Belson]: Marblehead is $84,365.

[Roy Belson]: Mystic Valley, the charter school, is at $73,823.

[Roy Belson]: Prospect Hill at $78, another charter school.

[Roy Belson]: And so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: Our teachers deserve good pay, but they don't leave because they can make $2,000 or $3,000 more in another community.

[Roy Belson]: They leave because they're afraid they might get their job cut.

[Roy Belson]: They leave because they don't have good benefits.

[Roy Belson]: And in Medford, health benefits and other benefits contractually are outstanding.

[Roy Belson]: There are a lot of reasons why people stay in the Medford public schools or come to us.

[Roy Belson]: Because our benefits are good.

[Roy Belson]: They're very good, by the way.

[Roy Belson]: and our salary is competitive.

[Roy Belson]: There is a teacher shortage in the country, so, you know, Medford's gonna be affected by that.

[Roy Belson]: There are a lot of people not going into education right now because they're feeling that it's too challenging.

[Roy Belson]: But people will stay with us for stability.

[Roy Belson]: So the argument that somehow we're not competitive is not real.

[Roy Belson]: Now, what are the alternatives besides free cash?

[Roy Belson]: Well, first of all, Medford's new growth is in the tank.

[Roy Belson]: We're on any building permits currently in place at City Hall right now.

[Roy Belson]: And unless you're really big on a beer haul, that's the only thing that I know about.

[Roy Belson]: How much are we leaving on the table?

[Roy Belson]: How can we grow the tax base rather than increase taxes on residents?

[Roy Belson]: We're not doing it.

[Roy Belson]: We're not doing it.

[Roy Belson]: Don't penalize the school system operations by building up huge reserves in free cash.

[Roy Belson]: Don't underestimate revenues.

[Roy Belson]: Let's strive for affordability.

[Roy Belson]: And in the request for the override, there's these general categories, teacher salaries, this, that, and the other thing.

[Roy Belson]: Be specific.

[Roy Belson]: The people who are voting for this

[Roy Belson]: are voting against it, need to know where every dollar is going.

[Roy Belson]: They don't want to just hear it's going into a tank someplace that hopefully will support the kinds of things that we consider to be important.

[Roy Belson]: General categories don't cut it.

[Roy Belson]: The override vote is less than two months away.

[Roy Belson]: And residents, citizens, are already voting or are going to start voting very soon.

[Roy Belson]: So besides the general information on the web, so the city's web,

[Roy Belson]: What does the average citizen know about the need and the impact?

[Roy Belson]: Probably not a lot.

[Roy Belson]: Many of you will vote by mail at the general election for the president and senator, and local races are at a minimum.

[Roy Belson]: So there aren't a lot of people who might even come out because, you know, they'll vote for the president and that's it.

[Roy Belson]: The Secretary of State, I'm going to pull this out.

[Roy Belson]: Most of you probably got this.

[Roy Belson]: Secretary of State sends out this every year, every year there's an election.

[Roy Belson]: And in it, not only are the candidates identified, but the ballot issues, there's five ballot issues statewide.

[Roy Belson]: They're identified with pros and cons and research so that you as a voter can actually decide based on some information based on partisans born against and research whether to vote for a particular item.

[Roy Belson]: I haven't seen anything in this city that would even comes close to that.

[Roy Belson]: You have a lot of people who will go in there that day and they will not know the impact of what they're doing.

[Roy Belson]: Some of them will think they're voting for $7 million for a new high school.

[Roy Belson]: They're gonna be surprised.

[Roy Belson]: Many will vote by mail.

[Roy Belson]: So, is this the right way to request an override from our taxpayers?

[Roy Belson]: Our city deserves, our citizens deserve more transparency than we're currently seeing.

[Roy Belson]: Our citizens need more information on the city's finances.

[Roy Belson]: The city council needs more information on the city's finances.

[Roy Belson]: They don't have it.

[Roy Belson]: How many times, and we go to Rick or to anyone else, George, how many times have you asked the city's finance director, is he still reconciling some previous year?

[Roy Belson]: Well, they're working on it.

[Roy Belson]: No one wants to tell anybody what's really there.

[Roy Belson]: And that's a problem.

[Roy Belson]: So people will vote without really knowing.

[Roy Belson]: Our citizens need to know that there will be a likely third override coming to them in the future for that high school.

[Roy Belson]: Now, whether it's a rebuild or it's a renovation, it's going to be expensive.

[Roy Belson]: It's gonna be expensive.

[Roy Belson]: And SBA will not give us 90 cents on the dollar like they did way back when.

[Roy Belson]: And we will not have buildings to sell off to pick up the rest and make money.

[Roy Belson]: Our citizens need to be assured, need to be assured that the school budget will not be shortchanged.

[Roy Belson]: That any municipal service will not be shortchanged.

[Roy Belson]: When legitimate resources are available without an override.

[Roy Belson]: Let's not leverage the override.

[Roy Belson]: Let's not create a crisis in order to get an override through.

[Roy Belson]: If there's a need for more money down the road for operations, after the high school project becomes known and the reimbursement rate, well, okay, put it out there and people can talk about it.

[Roy Belson]: But right now, you haven't got all the information.

[Roy Belson]: Right now, you don't know

[Roy Belson]: the big ticket item coming down the road.

[Roy Belson]: You haven't got any idea.

[Roy Belson]: At least you don't, many of you don't.

[Roy Belson]: And it's important that you do.

[Roy Belson]: Because too many people out there are going to be pushed out of their homes.

[Roy Belson]: Too many people are going to not be able to afford to come to Medford.

[Roy Belson]: And our school system will be played with.

[Roy Belson]: You don't leverage the school system.

[Roy Belson]: You make sure, you don't leverage the fire department, the police department.

[Roy Belson]: You don't leverage the, you make sure they have what they need to do the job.

[Roy Belson]: And if you've got the resources available, then do it.

[Roy Belson]: And if you really, really need something, then you make the case for it.

[Roy Belson]: And in my opinion, the case hasn't been made.

[Roy Belson]: The case hasn't been made.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you for listening.

[Roy Belson]: Nice to see everybody.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you for giving me an opportunity to say a few things.

[Roy Belson]: And hopefully, what I express will help you understand what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: I spent 50 years in Medford public education, 23 years as superintendent,

[Roy Belson]: And I also served at different times as the budget director, the curriculum director, and the personnel administrator, as well as a teacher.

[Roy Belson]: So I care deeply about what happens in our schools and our community.

[Roy Belson]: I know how hard they work.

[Roy Belson]: And I know that some of the things are beyond their control.

[Roy Belson]: They were put out there because of the COVID crisis.

[Roy Belson]: It was well known that when these funds were used up, there would be a need for the city to sustain staff and programs with local and state revenues.

[Roy Belson]: And if that was the case, was it necessary?

[Roy Belson]: And did the mayor really fail to provide full funding consistent with the school committee's request?

[Roy Belson]: when there's a significant amount of free cash available to the city, much higher than the amount available in previous years.

[Roy Belson]: The school administration by law is required to ask, and the school committee as well, for an amount sufficient to support the schools under Proposition 2 1⁄2.

[Roy Belson]: It's their legal request to do that.

[Roy Belson]: The mayor or the city manager in the past, when 2 1⁄2 passed, had the bottom line, and the city council

[Roy Belson]: can only approve or cut what the mayor provides.

[Roy Belson]: So it's not simple.

[Roy Belson]: The amount of money reported to DOR of free cash was $25 million in 2004.

[Roy Belson]: And as I indicated, they added another $9 million or thereabouts in the current fiscal year.

[Roy Belson]: Why, given the often repeated

[Roy Belson]: mantra of the mayor, transparency.

[Roy Belson]: Interesting word.

[Roy Belson]: And the city's financial director, that they failed to provide a clean and complete report on the city's financial position to the city council and the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: I think the answer's simple.

[Roy Belson]: The answer is that they wanted to leverage a crisis to create

[Roy Belson]: a need for an override.

[Roy Belson]: Because you're in a situation where you don't have it, you're threatening cuts to important services, and if you don't give me the money, we're gonna have to do drastic measures.

[Roy Belson]: This is not Proposition 2 1⁄2.

[Roy Belson]: In 1981, 1982, I was in the school system.

[Roy Belson]: I was working with the superintendent's office.

[Roy Belson]: And the budget of the city of Medford for the schools was $19.4 million.

[Roy Belson]: That year, we had to cut $3.2 million.

[Roy Belson]: That's a cut.

[Roy Belson]: 150 people got laid off.

[Roy Belson]: That was difficult, very difficult.

[Roy Belson]: We are not in that situation right now.

[Roy Belson]: We are not in that situation.

[Roy Belson]: When the 2024 DOR, Department of Revenue Tax Recap Report is studied, and I did that,

[Roy Belson]: There are clear underestimates of revenue amounts when compared with 2023, specifically by almost 15%.

[Roy Belson]: So in other words saying, if investment income was X, it was 14% less when they were projecting their revenue, almost $18 million.

[Roy Belson]: Why create a crisis?

[Roy Belson]: Before you ask the public for an override, should you not first use the obvious resources available?

[Roy Belson]: You can always go back later on and say, you know, we used up our resources.

[Roy Belson]: But when you have them, why won't you use them?

[Roy Belson]: Let's talk about the tax rate.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford tax rate is low.

[Roy Belson]: The residential tax rate is low comparatively to area communities.

[Roy Belson]: Nothing wrong with that.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think anyone feels like it has to be number one, the highest tax rate in the Commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: So it's not a bad thing when affordability for housing and other needs is challenging.

[Roy Belson]: If the overrides and debt exclusion pass, taxes will increase, I think, by at least 10%.

[Roy Belson]: especially when you include the 2.5% statutory increase that happens virtually every year.

[Roy Belson]: And what about the impact of re-evaluation?

[Roy Belson]: You know what's going on right now, they're checking your houses out.

[Roy Belson]: And by the way, if you haven't noticed, your house is worth more than it was when you bought it, in most cases.

[Roy Belson]: And when they reassess it, they're gonna reassess it and the taxes are gonna go up.

[Roy Belson]: And on top of that, you're probably gonna pay a little bit more for water and sewer,

[Roy Belson]: And when you add it all together, if you have to take an equity loan, you're gonna pay a hell of a lot more interest than you might like.

[Roy Belson]: And if you're a new person wanting to buy a home, the mortgage rates are still at 6.2%, and even if it goes down to 5%, it's a hell of a lot higher than it was when people refinanced a few years ago.

[Roy Belson]: And what about renters?

[Roy Belson]: Some of these people will never have a chance.

[Roy Belson]: They just won't be able to

[Roy Belson]: to get in and the landlords are going to pass on the rent to their tenants.

[Roy Belson]: So, that affects people too.

[Roy Belson]: When you think about it, there's also a deduction, tax deduction limit.

[Roy Belson]: You used to be able to take your income tax and your house property tax and interest.

[Roy Belson]: You can't do that anymore in the current rule.

[Roy Belson]: So, you can't even deduct some of the stuff that you used to be able to do before.

[Roy Belson]: Some people can get around it for various reasons,

[Roy Belson]: Not everybody.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at the age factor in the community, 22% of Medford residents are over the age of 60.

[Roy Belson]: 14% are 70 or more.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of these people are on fixed incomes.

[Roy Belson]: They don't have another alternative to go to.

[Roy Belson]: And they're probably supporting their children, their grandchildren, and everything else like that as well.

[Roy Belson]: So a hit like this is really significant.

[Roy Belson]: By the way, as the high school project moves forward, and it's in the planning stage right now, undoubtedly there will be another override request, which isn't out there right now.

[Roy Belson]: That'll make three override requests.

[Roy Belson]: The two that are there now, and the one that might come up, plus the debt exclusion, in the very near future.

[Roy Belson]: Given the cost of a rebuild,

[Roy Belson]: or renovation, this will be the biggest number that you've ever seen.

[Roy Belson]: The SBA reimbursement rate is not known at this time.

[Roy Belson]: It will only cover certain costs.

[Roy Belson]: Not everything is eligible.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at high schools that have been built or renovated in recent times, you're talking somewhere in the vicinity of $200 million to $400 million to redo the high school.

[Roy Belson]: We've got vocational shops and other things like that that have to be preserved.

[Roy Belson]: That's an expensive thing.

[Roy Belson]: And if you maybe get 35, 40%, not getting the 90% that we got for the schools, the K through 12 schools that we got several years ago with Rick as the chairperson of the building committee at that time.

[Roy Belson]: And we, by the way, sold the old schools so that we actually made money.

[Roy Belson]: Don't tell anybody.

[Roy Belson]: You don't get that now.

[Roy Belson]: So you're gonna be talking about potentially 100 to $200 million of local assessment, over and above.

[Roy Belson]: That will impact taxes on top of the early override assessments.

[Roy Belson]: And by the way, if the override passes in November,

[Roy Belson]: you will see the increase on your January 2025 tax bill.

[Roy Belson]: You're not gonna wait a year to build it up, you're gonna see it in January.

[Roy Belson]: It's only a few months away.

[Roy Belson]: Now one of the arguments that comes around is that somehow Medford salaries and cost per pupil are not competitive.

[Roy Belson]: Now as a educator, I think I started off with this, I want every nickel I can get for the schools.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, I'd be less than honest if I didn't tell you that I think the schools deserve every nickel we can give them.

[Roy Belson]: And we have plenty of needs.

[Roy Belson]: But no one gets everything they want.

[Roy Belson]: And no school system is able to do that.

[Roy Belson]: And no community is able to do that.

[Roy Belson]: But let's take a look at the Medford Public Schools financials.

[Roy Belson]: And this is according to the latest Department of Elementary and Secondary Education statistics.

[Roy Belson]: The state average per pupil

[Roy Belson]: is $19,714.

[Roy Belson]: Medford is currently spending $21,372.

[Roy Belson]: Arlington is spending $18,615.

[Roy Belson]: Malden is spending $17,428.

[Roy Belson]: Melrose is spending $15,540.

[Roy Belson]: Peabody is spending $16,996.

[Roy Belson]: And I can go on and on.

[Roy Belson]: Now, someone can say, well, there are, Mystic Valley, by the way, one of the charter schools that sucks away dollars from our budget, is paying, is spending $14,167.

[Roy Belson]: Now, there are places, Somerville, 23,958, we just built a building so you can see where that's involved.

[Roy Belson]: And by the way, if you wanna chase Cambridge, Cambridge is spending $36,712.

[Roy Belson]: Of course, Cambridge has got a property base that's incredible.

[Roy Belson]: And Burlington is $25,297.

[Roy Belson]: And by the way, if we were still sending kids to Minuteman, the cost would be $34,176.

[Roy Belson]: And if we continued to send 50 kids there like we did when we cut it off, we'd be pushing $2 million a year.

[Roy Belson]: of money out of our pocket.

[Roy Belson]: And that's why we rebuilt the vocational school.

[Roy Belson]: And people argued about, why are you not sending the kids to Minuteman?

[Roy Belson]: Because they're sucking dollars out of Medford.

[Roy Belson]: And we had a right to rebuild our own school and run our own programs at a far less cost.

[Roy Belson]: So then the question comes about teacher salaries.

[Roy Belson]: Where's Charlene?

[Roy Belson]: Charlene, the room boy.

[Roy Belson]: All right, Charlene, don't take offense.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at the average salary for the Medford teachers, average salary, and this is latest numbers, obviously it's gone up a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: The average salary is $88,179.

[Roy Belson]: That's the statistic.

[Roy Belson]: If you're on the top step, 10 years, a master's plus 60, this year fiscal 25, you're gonna make $111,000.

[Roy Belson]: In Arlington, the top salary is $83,466.

[Roy Belson]: I mean the average salary.

[Roy Belson]: Melrose is $76,369.

[Roy Belson]: Beverly is $84,765.

[Roy Belson]: Malden is $83,366.

[Roy Belson]: Marblehead is $84,365.

[Roy Belson]: Mystic Valley, their charter school, is at $73,823.

[Roy Belson]: Prospect Hill at $78, another charter school.

[Roy Belson]: And so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: Our teachers deserve good pay, but they don't leave because they can make $2,000 or $3,000 more in another community.

[Roy Belson]: They leave because they're afraid they might get their job cut.

[Roy Belson]: They leave because they don't have good benefits.

[Roy Belson]: And in Medford, health benefits and other benefits contractually are outstanding.

[Roy Belson]: There are a lot of reasons why people stay in the Medford public schools or come to us, because our benefits are good,

[Roy Belson]: very good, by the way, and our salary is competitive.

[Roy Belson]: There is a teacher shortage in the country, so, you know, Medford's gonna be affected by that.

[Roy Belson]: There are a lot of people not going into education right now because they're feeling that it's too challenging.

[Roy Belson]: But people will stay with us for stability.

[Roy Belson]: So the argument that somehow we're not competitive is not real.

[Roy Belson]: Now, what are the alternatives besides free cash?

[Roy Belson]: Well, first of all, Medford's new growth is in the tank.

[Roy Belson]: We're on any building permits currently in place at City Hall right now.

[Roy Belson]: And unless you're really big on a beer haul, that's the only thing that I know about.

[Roy Belson]: How much are we leaving on the table?

[Roy Belson]: How can we grow the tax base rather than increase taxes on residents?

[Roy Belson]: We're not doing it.

[Roy Belson]: We're not doing it.

[Roy Belson]: Don't penalize the school system operations by building up huge reserves in free cash.

[Roy Belson]: Don't underestimate revenues.

[Roy Belson]: Let's strive for affordability.

[Roy Belson]: And in the request for the override, there's these general categories, teacher salaries, this, that, and the other thing.

[Roy Belson]: Be specific.

[Roy Belson]: The people who are voting for this

[Roy Belson]: are voting against it need to know where every dollar is going.

[Roy Belson]: They don't want to just hear it's going into a tank someplace that hopefully will support the kinds of things that we consider to be important.

[Roy Belson]: General categories don't cut it.

[Roy Belson]: The override vote is less than two months away.

[Roy Belson]: And residents, citizens, are already voting.

[Roy Belson]: They're going to start voting very soon.

[Roy Belson]: So besides the general information on the web, of the city's web,

[Roy Belson]: What does the average citizen know about the need and the impact?

[Roy Belson]: Probably not a lot.

[Roy Belson]: Many of you will vote by mail at the general election, or the president and senator, and local races are at a minimum.

[Roy Belson]: So there aren't a lot of people who might even come out, because, you know, they'll vote for the president and that's it.

[Roy Belson]: The Secretary of State, I'm going to pull this out.

[Roy Belson]: Most of you probably got this.

[Roy Belson]: Secretary of State sends out this every year, every year there's an election.

[Roy Belson]: And in it, not only are the candidates identified, but the ballot issues, there's five ballot issues statewide.

[Roy Belson]: They're identified with pros and cons and research so that you as a voter can actually decide based on some information based on partisans born against and research whether to vote for a particular item.

[Roy Belson]: I haven't seen anything in this city that would even comes close to that.

[Roy Belson]: You have a lot of people who will go in there that day and they will not know the impact of what they're doing.

[Roy Belson]: Some of them will think they're voting for $7 million for a new high school.

[Roy Belson]: They're gonna be surprised.

[Roy Belson]: Many will vote by mail.

[Roy Belson]: So, is this the right way to request an override from our taxpayers?

[Roy Belson]: They don't have it.

[Roy Belson]: Well, they're working on it.

[Roy Belson]: No one wants to tell anybody what's really there.

[Roy Belson]: And that's a problem.

[Roy Belson]: So people will vote without really knowing.

[Roy Belson]: Our citizens need to know that there will be a likely third override coming to them in the future for that high school.

[Roy Belson]: Now, whether it's a rebuild or it's a renovation, it's going to be expensive.

[Roy Belson]: It's gonna be expensive.

[Roy Belson]: And SBA will not give us 90 cents on the dollar like they did way back when.

[Roy Belson]: And we will not have buildings to sell off to pick up the rest and make money.

[Roy Belson]: When legitimate resources are available without an override.

[Roy Belson]: a budget document follow-up.

[Roy Belson]: One was in the auto shop and the other was part of the engineering program.

[Roy Belson]: Salaries would allow some gapping between what they would have made if they had stayed and what we will replace them at.

[Roy Belson]: So that gives us back $17,000.

[Roy Belson]: There was a few resignations from the special ed faculty, and that will yield another $3,339.

[Roy Belson]: So one area that you actually voted the other evening was the banned travel account.

[Roy Belson]: Is that applause or is that just a... The band travel account got $3,000 that you actually voted.

[Roy Belson]: Now, just so we understand, we have not changed the lines in your budget because until we make all the agreements tonight, we're not going to change things internally because once we change one page, we have to change five or six pages at least, minimum, because they all play off each other.

[Roy Belson]: So, we're putting $3,000 into the band account.

[Roy Belson]: The elementary textbook account is going to be increased by $1,500 per school for a total of $6,000.

[Roy Belson]: Now, we put it in textbooks.

[Roy Belson]: It can be used for educational materials.

[Roy Belson]: It can be used for supplies.

[Roy Belson]: Whatever the principal feels is important, but that gives them a little bit more back based on some of the discussion that was had the other evening.

[Roy Belson]: The crew athletic program is expanding rapidly.

[Roy Belson]: We've had several meetings outside of that.

[Roy Belson]: The mayor has hosted several meetings, and there's several things going on.

[Roy Belson]: They have two seasons.

[Roy Belson]: In order to supply the coaches, we are $8,400 short, so we added that to the athletic budget.

[Roy Belson]: So we would cover that situation going forward this year.

[Roy Belson]: And then there were two corrections to the principalships of the Andrews and the McGlynn Elementary that needed to be brought up to date.

[Roy Belson]: They were using older numbers.

[Roy Belson]: That required $1,463 to go to the Andrews and $1,692 to the McGlynn Elementary Principalship.

[Roy Belson]: So the total additions of recaptured funds evens out at $20,455.

[Roy Belson]: The above adjustments and corrections will be made tonight if they're approved by the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: And as we progress toward the school budget, the end of the school budget.

[Roy Belson]: There will be multiple changes based on personnel matters and non-salary costs.

[Roy Belson]: So there will be people that come and go, just like there are all year.

[Roy Belson]: And we will bring you up to date periodically in order to free up some funds, either to fill an account that might need a boost because of cost, or maybe to add something back that we couldn't add back in the first cut.

[Roy Belson]: So as I said, we're not changing budget lines because it would affect too many page changes.

[Roy Belson]: We'll make the line adjustments once all decisions are made regarding the budget and provide copies to the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: Additionally, the second page of what you've been handed has a report on union settlements.

[Roy Belson]: And as I reported the other evening, the only union settlement at this point in time is a union settlement with the administrators.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to recommend later on this evening to look at the unit building principles and other units are still being negotiated.

[Roy Belson]: We have some discussion tonight about the teacher's contract and we're meeting with the teachers tomorrow as well as the paraprofessionals.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll give you information in that executive session as part of negotiations.

[Roy Belson]: In addition, today we met extensively with Safe Havens,

[Roy Belson]: That's the group that is doing the comprehensive study of our security procedures.

[Roy Belson]: We went over a number of things with them.

[Roy Belson]: Another visit will be coming back.

[Roy Belson]: They've already had two visits now.

[Roy Belson]: And when that is ready, we will come back with them with some recommendations regarding security.

[Roy Belson]: In the interim, we have kept the security line in the budget.

[Roy Belson]: But that doesn't mean that that will be the way we expend it.

[Roy Belson]: It will be tied to the recommendations of Safe Havens and the wishes of the committee.

[Roy Belson]: So let's see what that report tells us.

[Roy Belson]: There are a number of things we talked about today that are non-cost items that we think could be very helpful.

[Roy Belson]: There's some repositioning things that could also be helpful, no-cost items.

[Roy Belson]: And there are some things that are low-cost items that they think would be very helpful.

[Roy Belson]: Let's let that report come out.

[Roy Belson]: In the interim, we have the line item in place.

[Roy Belson]: We're not going to spend against it until that report comes out, but we'll prepare ourselves to go in several directions and provide information to the committee so that we're ready to move once we see that report and once we reach some agreement.

[Roy Belson]: So that is that piece there.

[Roy Belson]: Again, one other item that came up the other evening that I think deserves some sort of mention tonight, and that's the Buildings and Grounds budget.

[Roy Belson]: We believe that the projects that will be most consistent with what the community is asking for and what we've seen must come from capital funding.

[Roy Belson]: What we have taken from that budget will not meet those needs.

[Roy Belson]: What we have taken from that budget reflects our savings in telephone, reflects our savings in various forms of energy, reflects our savings in other areas, in cleaning, that we believe we can absorb at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: And that allows the city

[Roy Belson]: to consider our capital requests, which I've given you some suggestions, but certainly others may be in order.

[Roy Belson]: And as a committee and the mayor, you can sit and decide what you think is most appropriate as opposed to anything that I might think is appropriate.

[Roy Belson]: And certainly Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent will weigh in as well.

[Roy Belson]: I should tell you this evening that she would be here except the fact that her son Elijah had his wisdom teeth pulled and she's home giving him some comfort.

[Roy Belson]: But I spoke to her and I've gone over the materials and I know that she's in support of what I'm giving him.

[Roy Belson]: So I feel comfortable with that.

[Roy Belson]: But that's what we've done so far since Thursday evening.

[Roy Belson]: And I would hope that the committee would support the budget as we've presented it.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of work has been done.

[Roy Belson]: Staff has worked very hard to make things fit.

[Roy Belson]: Budgets have contingencies in them, as we've talked about the other day.

[Roy Belson]: You never know when something new is going to pop up, and you never know when we're going to save something.

[Roy Belson]: But that's the process of managing a budget.

[Roy Belson]: And that's what we do every year.

[Roy Belson]: Let me try and answer some of these things.

[Roy Belson]: First of all, there's only one reduction in the vocational faculty, and that's for a program that only had one student in it.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, you can't sustain a program with one student, and the demand statewide has gone down.

[Roy Belson]: We just have to be realistic when a program is not

[Roy Belson]: going to attract students.

[Roy Belson]: We can't fund it just simply because we've always had it or had it for a number of years.

[Roy Belson]: Programs will come and go a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: New programs will emerge.

[Roy Belson]: And there may be that coming forward a year from now, there might be a plumbing program.

[Roy Belson]: There might be some other program that is more likely to attract students.

[Roy Belson]: You talked about landscaping the other night.

[Roy Belson]: It might be something that's more attractive than the program that has one student in it.

[Roy Belson]: So the only reduction is the one teacher from the program that had one student in it.

[Roy Belson]: You know what I mean?

[Roy Belson]: And that's usually an attraction for people in the trades when they can do that.

[Roy Belson]: We just simply need to pay attention to that.

[Roy Belson]: variances or the different adjustments that you want, this is a good way to go.

[Roy Belson]: But if a person costs more money, we'd go to undistributed to take that money from that account.

[Roy Belson]: You know what I mean?

[Roy Belson]: So there's ways to make that up, but we have to begin someplace.

[Roy Belson]: You take it where it exists initially, and then you move to cover it.

[Roy Belson]: Um, so, so recruitment is underway.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, we're certainly going to recruit people.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to make every effort to bring people in.

[Roy Belson]: No.

[Roy Belson]: And there are people out there who want to.

[Roy Belson]: These things happen.

[Roy Belson]: English teachers go.

[Roy Belson]: Social studies teachers go.

[Roy Belson]: People come and go.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll be at it.

[Roy Belson]: We'll be on it.

[Roy Belson]: And I just think we need to put a list together and see where we can go.

[Roy Belson]: You can't promise everybody everything all at once.

[Roy Belson]: But if people see progress, I think they'll be encouraged.

[Roy Belson]: And I think we can work from there.

[Roy Belson]: I'm just going to suggest to you, you might be more productive to refer it to the legislature.

[Roy Belson]: Because it's clearly not a legal issue.

[Roy Belson]: It's clearly a way that the legislature funds these things statewide.

[Roy Belson]: And there are reasons why they place people in different homes.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes there may be housing available in some communities, sometimes not in others.

[Roy Belson]: But maybe there could be an option that the legislature could put together.

[Roy Belson]: But I don't think that the solicitor can tell you

[Roy Belson]: that the legislature must do that.

[Roy Belson]: I think the solicitor can tell you that, you know, the possibility exists if they choose to do that.

[Roy Belson]: They technically are, but it's always subject to appropriation.

[Roy Belson]: The famous last words of subject to appropriation, which means if they don't appropriate the money, they don't have to reimburse us.

[Roy Belson]: I've been around a long time, as most of you know.

[Roy Belson]: And some people think too long.

[Roy Belson]: But nevertheless, I've seen a lot of budgets.

[Roy Belson]: If you get hung up on any one item,

[Roy Belson]: You're not helping because the budget is much bigger.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to be able to look at the budget in its totality.

[Roy Belson]: You can express your displeasure or your concern about an item or a particular thing, but you don't want to not vote for the things that you do care about, supplies for the kids, teachers, materials, all the kinds of things, services that kids need.

[Roy Belson]: I think, you know, if you have an objection to a particular item, express it.

[Roy Belson]: But don't not vote for the whole budget, because the budget probably has many things in it that you do want to support.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that's really something to say.

[Roy Belson]: You can come out and say what you don't like, but you certainly want to support all the resources, $60 million worth of resources going to young people and families in this community.

[Roy Belson]: That's the way you've got to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, that's the way I have to look at it every year, because there are many things that I would like to put in the budget that I can't.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, if I had, you know, an unlimited checkbook, you'd be a lot more things in this budget.

[Roy Belson]: But no one ever does.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, today, you should know that the Supreme Judicial Court of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts ruled against the Fair Share Amendment.

[Roy Belson]: That's the million dollars tax.

[Roy Belson]: That's 1.9 to 2 billion dollars worth of lost revenue that the Commonwealth will not... And the legislature is going to have to struggle, and the governor is going to have to struggle with how they are going to fund things.

[Roy Belson]: The discussion of the foundation budget is rife.

[Roy Belson]: Some of the offsets are rife, circuit breaker.

[Roy Belson]: We've talked about these things.

[Roy Belson]: Where are the resources going to come from?

[Roy Belson]: So no one, whether it's the state level or our level, gets to fund everything they believe should be in a budget.

[Roy Belson]: So I would just suggest that if there's a particular item that you feel needs more attention going forward, you express it.

[Roy Belson]: But don't withhold your support for a whole budget, because you're basically saying the other things aren't worth it.

[Roy Belson]: Of course they're worth it.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of things are worth it.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm gonna share this with our assistant superintendent for finance.

[Roy Belson]: Come on up, Christine.

[Roy Belson]: She did all the work in getting it together and out to, with Schaub and working together to get the stuff in.

[Roy Belson]: And we got back exactly what we expected to get back.

[Roy Belson]: because that's what we expected.

[Roy Belson]: But I think what's really significant beyond the work in here is the kinds of things that Lesley College is willing to do with us, and this is only the beginning.

[Roy Belson]: We've had some really productive discussions, they'll continue, and you know, Maurice has been involved and will continue to get more people involved.

[Roy Belson]: Are you looking at Minuteman or Milestones?

[Roy Belson]: Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: So Minuteman is a vocational technical chapter 74 program.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes the payments are grouped.

[Roy Belson]: And I think the instance on the 63, is that what you're asking?

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, the 63 and the 25.

[Roy Belson]: Not really, not really.

[Roy Belson]: It's changed.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, they have a lot of kids in horticulture, believe it or not.

[Roy Belson]: By next year, they're likely to have two or three kids.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: Because it's really going down.

[Roy Belson]: It went down from 50 kids.

[Roy Belson]: Probably, what, three or four?

[Roy Belson]: Seven right now, maybe?

[Roy Belson]: Nine at minimum, that's including Essex, no?

[Roy Belson]: Okay, all right.

[Roy Belson]: So there is none?

[Roy Belson]: So we don't have a full minute.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: Call upon our assistant superintendent to give this report.

[Roy Belson]: So as much as we're going to miss Rita, and we are going to miss Rita and her wonderful work, this week we begin the formal interviews of foreign language department directors starting Wednesday.

[Roy Belson]: So there'll be a team from the department.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Osborne is also participating.

[Roy Belson]: And we hope to have something in front of the committee very soon.

[Roy Belson]: She'll be involved.

[Roy Belson]: She'll get to see the people that the department screens out, and then she can make some decisions along with everyone else.

[Roy Belson]: I can't tie her up every day so I mean so when we get it down to a few people that people are comfortable with we'll have her involved.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: She'll give me a feedback as well and we'll move on.

[Roy Belson]: So it really depends on the parent.

[Roy Belson]: Some parents like the youngsters to stay with who they've grown up with or who they've gone with.

[Roy Belson]: And other parents want them back in their neighborhood.

[Roy Belson]: They may have siblings back in their neighborhood, and they want them back with the siblings.

[Roy Belson]: There may be daycare issues.

[Roy Belson]: The issues and the variables are tremendous.

[Roy Belson]: There's no perfect solution, and that's the issue.

[Roy Belson]: So when you talk to policymakers in town, what they tell you is focus on the child.

[Roy Belson]: What's best for the child?

[Roy Belson]: You don't want the child moving around any more than you have to.

[Roy Belson]: You don't want a lot of dislocation.

[Roy Belson]: And you can't just simply concentrate everything in one place all the time, especially elementary, because you will overload that school.

[Roy Belson]: In middle school, it becomes a little bit more believable because kids are a little bit older.

[Roy Belson]: And there's only two of them, whereas we've got four elementary schools.

[Roy Belson]: It's very tricky.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, the state makes rules.

[Roy Belson]: The state makes all kinds of policies.

[Roy Belson]: They've got a new pro look, which we'll have to see how that plays out.

[Roy Belson]: But sometimes they don't take into account space.

[Roy Belson]: They don't take into account adding additional staff.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, what Paul was telling you is that to move things over to the Andrews, he needs four additional people.

[Roy Belson]: I've got to tell you, that's over a quarter of a million dollars plus benefits.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, just for that alone.

[Roy Belson]: So, I mean, there's a lot of tradeoffs here.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, tonight as you're talking about different programs, you're talking about you want to add this, you want to do that.

[Roy Belson]: You're wiped out.

[Roy Belson]: You're wiped out if you're going to try and do some of this stuff.

[Roy Belson]: Originally, when the numbers were lower, the thought was always go back to your school, your neighborhood.

[Roy Belson]: But things have changed.

[Roy Belson]: It would be eight total.

[Roy Belson]: So one of the things that, listening to the whole discussion this evening, dealing with extra help and all the other things, we've got to begin to actively and more actively explore the use of software and technology.

[Roy Belson]: Because as long as something is labor intensive,

[Roy Belson]: You require more and more staff, more and more benefits.

[Roy Belson]: One, you can't afford it.

[Roy Belson]: Two, you can't schedule it.

[Roy Belson]: Three, you don't have enough space.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to find ways to use the technology more effectively and find those pieces that will attract youngsters, whether it's math or it's language arts or whatever the case may be.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to work with some people to see if there's technology assists we can use that also can go home with the youngsters to build language skills.

[Roy Belson]: Because we are just not going to have enough personnel, space,

[Roy Belson]: materials to do everything the state says we're supposed to do on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: And that's not just Medford, that's across the board.

[Roy Belson]: That's across the board.

[Roy Belson]: Well, what's the status of Title III right now?

[Roy Belson]: I mean, obviously, everything's up in the air federal.

[Roy Belson]: Do you have a sense of that?

[Roy Belson]: So last Thursday we had a committee of the whole.

[Roy Belson]: And at the conclusion of the committee of the whole, you voted 7-0 to approve the concept of the plan, but you wanted to understand procurement better and how we were able to do it under the rules so that we could move forward.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight I've handed you a

[Roy Belson]: sheet, two sides, which goes over that.

[Roy Belson]: And we've had substantial discussion, Christine, myself, Mark Rumley, Howard Greenspan, Howard's here, going over these various things and also phone calls into the AG and the IG and all these things as to what we could or couldn't do, and also with Lesley College.

[Roy Belson]: Now, we have to move forward if we're going to get this thing done.

[Roy Belson]: But in order to do it, we have to deal with it a little bit differently than we originally intended.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm gonna go over this a little bit as a partnership procurement plan.

[Roy Belson]: We have to develop an RFP, which is a request for proposals for the partnership that would include rental, renovation, and professional services between the Medford Public Schools and an area university, an area university, not necessarily any one.

[Roy Belson]: A request for proposals allows us to seek proposals from qualified vendors and to select the most appropriate respondents

[Roy Belson]: based on established criteria first and not price alone.

[Roy Belson]: It's not a price issue initially.

[Roy Belson]: This RFP cycle is a two-week posting process.

[Roy Belson]: That means once we generate the RFP, hopefully sometime this week with help, we would go out two weeks and put it out there and see who responds.

[Roy Belson]: The RFP would require the successful respondent to meet and agree to all the terms of the RFP specifications, everything we would put in.

[Roy Belson]: Funding for the project would be incorporated into the RFP, we would say what we're looking for, for negotiation between the successful respondent and the Medford Public Schools.

[Roy Belson]: The successful respondent would then be allowed to carry out the construction and renovation of the high school gymnasium facility with provisions for quality control.

[Roy Belson]: In other words, saying they would do it as opposed to we would do it, okay?

[Roy Belson]: Appropriate insurance coverage.

[Roy Belson]: would be in place to cover any unforeseen issues, any liabilities that would be involved.

[Roy Belson]: The plan would allow for a successful respondent to move quickly towards implementation this summer.

[Roy Belson]: Because they would be able to do things in the private sector, and we would insist on prevailing wage and things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: They would be able to move a lot faster than a public entity can move under these rules.

[Roy Belson]: Under the plan, Medford would reap all the benefits intended under the previous idea and still retain control.

[Roy Belson]: We believe it's an effective approach because it clearly spells out each expected item and it could be implemented without unnecessary delay.

[Roy Belson]: So I think it was a good discussion that we had.

[Roy Belson]: Christine did a great job working in town with people, Mark and Howard back and forth covering the issues legally.

[Roy Belson]: And with help from, you know, legal in town, I think we've come up with a plan that allows us to go forward and to get this in place.

[Roy Belson]: Take any questions you have.

[Roy Belson]: We put it in the RFP.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Sorry.

[Roy Belson]: Anything we put in there, the respondent has to accept.

[Roy Belson]: No.

[Roy Belson]: Well, one would think that if they're paying prevailing wage, there's no reason not to use.

[Roy Belson]: Of course.

[Roy Belson]: We've done all our projects that way.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, I did read in the emails that, you know, that like all these universities would

[Roy Belson]: Well, because in order for it to work, based on our concept of an interaction with an area university, we would want one in the area.

[Roy Belson]: Because if they weren't in the area, it would become very difficult to have the interaction that we want.

[Roy Belson]: It probably would not be attractive to a non-area university to want to rent one of our facilities.

[Roy Belson]: I would say you've got to have a radius of, you know,

[Roy Belson]: So many miles.

[Roy Belson]: because essentially they can work on it and we can work on the numbers with them.

[Roy Belson]: Oh yeah, absolutely.

[Roy Belson]: That's on the RFP.

[Roy Belson]: That's in the RFP.

[Roy Belson]: Well, it's a little bit different than we started out.

[Roy Belson]: It's not different.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, RFPs are generally a very interesting tool, because you're not stuck strictly on price.

[Roy Belson]: You're able to look at criteria, and you're able to look at who can provide what.

[Roy Belson]: And since this is a lot of qualitative interaction that's involved,

[Roy Belson]: You want to be able to look at the criteria rather than just strictly a dollar factor.

[Roy Belson]: For posting.

[Roy Belson]: But once it's out, it's two weeks.

[Roy Belson]: You have to be each week in the newspaper, in a prominent newspaper.

[Roy Belson]: If someone shows up that we haven't thought of, that's interesting.

[Roy Belson]: We may get surprised.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know.

[Roy Belson]: So let's walk through it a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: Sure.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: If an entity wants to use the item, they certainly want to play on something that's quality.

[Roy Belson]: They certainly don't want to play on something that's less than quality if they can help it, okay?

[Roy Belson]: Two, they have to meet NCAA standards, okay, which will immediately ensure a certain level of quality.

[Roy Belson]: And three, we'll have a clerk of the works.

[Roy Belson]: We'll make sure that they follow certain specifications.

[Roy Belson]: We would look at it.

[Roy Belson]: We would look at it.

[Roy Belson]: But again, because it's an RFP, we have a lot of factors with qualitative discretion in it.

[Roy Belson]: It's not just price.

[Roy Belson]: If you have a university that already has physical facilities, they're not coming to us for another one.

[Roy Belson]: If you have a university that doesn't provide certain programs in areas that we're interested in, they're not meeting another criteria.

[Roy Belson]: So let's answer it this way.

[Roy Belson]: You just heard Kathy Medaglio tell you that they've balanced special ed students.

[Roy Belson]: You heard Paul Teixeira tell you that they've also allocated EL students.

[Roy Belson]: Those students can't go into the partial lottery because they've already been balanced, okay?

[Roy Belson]: So what's left are the students who we'll call typically developing.

[Roy Belson]: Students who have, you know, just basically doing their thing and don't have a designation as either EL or special ed.

[Roy Belson]: They're not part of that balance.

[Roy Belson]: Now, you can look at it in different ways.

[Roy Belson]: You can say that three of the schools have done some of their job, and they've sent some people to the school, and one school didn't.

[Roy Belson]: That's partial lottery going to the school that didn't.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise, you encourage people, perhaps, to never send anybody, figuring, well, their chances are better if they don't send anybody.

[Roy Belson]: On the other hand, you can say that you have a school that

[Roy Belson]: that's a natural feeder into the McGlynn Elementary.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe you could take the 10, 15 kids that are still there and say, well, at least they're still in the same building.

[Roy Belson]: They know the building.

[Roy Belson]: That's another way of looking at it.

[Roy Belson]: A third way to do it would be to take all three of them, put them in the pot, and pull them out.

[Roy Belson]: Whatever you do, someone is probably not going to be happy.

[Roy Belson]: During the course of the year,

[Roy Belson]: We have heard repeatedly from you about some people that wanted to move from one school to the other, and because they had all kinds of issues with that.

[Roy Belson]: Now, you know, okay, I'm not going to argue that point.

[Roy Belson]: They had all kinds of issues with it.

[Roy Belson]: And it's incessant.

[Roy Belson]: So somebody who maybe doesn't get what they want is not going to be happy.

[Roy Belson]: The idea that we could move some people in cohorts was a good one, because they go with their friends, because that's one of the biggest reasons why

[Roy Belson]: people go to one school or the other and want to be with their friends.

[Roy Belson]: Now, that's another way of looking at the lottery.

[Roy Belson]: If you move the rest of the McGlynn over, they're all with their friends.

[Roy Belson]: If you, in fact, go with some of the other places, you've got to take a significant number of people from one school in order so they have friends.

[Roy Belson]: So if you put all three into the pot, there's a chance that

[Roy Belson]: and you're looking only for 15 kids, there's a chance that the school that doesn't send them might only have three friends, might only have two kids that anyone knows because the numbers could skew back to the other people.

[Roy Belson]: So no matter what you do, there's going to be a tradeoff someplace.

[Roy Belson]: There's going to be a tradeoff someplace.

[Roy Belson]: So we just got to decide.

[Roy Belson]: We just got to decide what's going to work.

[Roy Belson]: They're both good schools.

[Roy Belson]: They both have the same curriculum.

[Roy Belson]: They both have people that will give them leadership.

[Roy Belson]: It's up to us as a school system to work hard to rebuild some of the thinking and work at it.

[Roy Belson]: But we're gonna make a decision because we gotta get on with it.

[Roy Belson]: Because people are scheduling, there's resources that have to be allocated, we're working on a budget, and we gotta know what we're doing.

[Roy Belson]: That's stretching it.

[Roy Belson]: I think we've taken care of siblings at this point, haven't we?

[Roy Belson]: I think we took a good eye to look at siblings.

[Roy Belson]: And plus, there's going to be a few new people coming in, you know, between now and the end of the year, and a few people leaving.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to happen too.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I think that we've talked about all these things, Mike.

[Roy Belson]: This isn't like, you know, this is the first time we're discussing it.

[Roy Belson]: This has been going on for a year.

[Roy Belson]: And the reality is there are some dynamic forces in the background that created maybe some preferences that are there.

[Roy Belson]: Now, historically, balance has shifted between the places.

[Roy Belson]: We're hopeful with some changes at one school that this won't be a permanent situation.

[Roy Belson]: This will change.

[Roy Belson]: But at any one point in time, at any one point in time, is it necessary, what do you call it, to, you know, hang our heads and say we didn't do it?

[Roy Belson]: I mean, is choice more important right now than

[Roy Belson]: making sure the schools are balanced so the teachers have enough kids in the classroom, and we need to move forward.

[Roy Belson]: Let's have a reason for kids to go to one school versus the other.

[Roy Belson]: I think we want to be careful.

[Roy Belson]: The vast majority of people got their choice.

[Roy Belson]: It's just a percentage right now.

[Roy Belson]: Now you could use the NBA rule.

[Roy Belson]: You want to play the NBA game?

[Roy Belson]: Whereas some schools have a weighted number versus other schools.

[Roy Belson]: So you might say that a school that has no one going there would have to send more.

[Roy Belson]: A second school might send, you know, which has more kids going, might send less, a smaller percentage.

[Roy Belson]: And a third school, which has even more going, might send an even smaller percentage so that no school

[Roy Belson]: gets hit totally.

[Roy Belson]: The plan you approved when we put this in front of you was a partial lottery, and the partial lottery spoke to the issue of disproportionality.

[Roy Belson]: It actually listed the concept of disproportionality.

[Roy Belson]: If one place did not send anybody, then that place would be the partial lottery.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise, it's a total lottery.

[Roy Belson]: So you can get around it a little bit by saying, okay, we'll wait it a little bit with, you know, to some degree, because it's an experimental year.

[Roy Belson]: But at some point, you've got to deal with the concept of partial lottery, which is based on disproportionality.

[Roy Belson]: Because one other point you want to make is that if you send, let's say you only send two kids from the Brooks, then what are you going to hear?

[Roy Belson]: My kid has no friends.

[Roy Belson]: So if you send a group over there, at least you've got, the kid's got some friends.

[Roy Belson]: That's a, you know, that's a thought.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: And you're going to get some people walking into the 12th Tower.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, the summer, you're going to have some walk-ins, and you're going to have some people leaving.

[Roy Belson]: But the number's not going to be great.

[Roy Belson]: It's not going to change the balance.

[Roy Belson]: But you will get a few more.

[Roy Belson]: And anyone new coming in is going to the McGlynn.

[Roy Belson]: It's just that simple.

[Roy Belson]: So the number doesn't have to be perfect.

[Roy Belson]: It's never perfect one-to-one every year, even when it was working well.

[Roy Belson]: So if you get a number that brings it closer, you have less pain that you're inflicting on people that might not want it, you probably can live with 15.

[Roy Belson]: You probably could live with 15.

[Roy Belson]: And then there'll be other kids coming in during the summer.

[Roy Belson]: You know, that's probably a good compromise.
