[Roy Belson]: I mean, obviously, everything's up in the air federal.

[Roy Belson]: So last Thursday we had a committee of the whole.

[Roy Belson]: And at the conclusion of the committee of the whole, you voted 7-0 to approve the concept of your plan, but you wanted to understand procurement better and how we were able to do it under the rules so that we could move forward.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight I've handed you a

[Roy Belson]: sheet, two sides, which goes over that.

[Roy Belson]: And we've had substantial discussion, Christine, myself, Mark Rumley, Howard Greenspan, Howard's here, going over these various things and also phone calls into the AG and the IG and all these things as to what we could or couldn't do, and also with Lesley College.

[Roy Belson]: Now, we have to move forward if we're going to get this thing done.

[Roy Belson]: But in order to do it, we have to deal with it a little bit differently than we originally intended.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm going to go over this a little bit as a partnership procurement plan.

[Roy Belson]: We have to develop an RFP, which is a request for proposals, for the partnership that would include rental, renovation, and professional services between the Medford Public Schools and an area university, an area university, not necessarily any one.

[Roy Belson]: A request for proposals allows us to seek proposals from qualified vendors and to select the most appropriate respondents

[Roy Belson]: based on established criteria first and not price alone.

[Roy Belson]: It's not a price issue initially.

[Roy Belson]: This RFP cycle is a two-week hosting process.

[Roy Belson]: That means once we generate the RFP, hopefully sometime this week with help, we would go out two weeks and put it out there and see who responds.

[Roy Belson]: The RFP would require the successful respondent to meet and agree to all the terms of the RFP specifications, everything we would put in.

[Roy Belson]: Funding for the project would be incorporated into the RFP, we would say what we're looking for, for negotiation between the successful respondent and the Medford Public Schools.

[Roy Belson]: The successful respondent would then be allowed to carry out the construction and renovation of the high school gymnasium facility with provisions for quality control.

[Roy Belson]: I would say they would do it as opposed to we would do it, okay?

[Roy Belson]: Appropriate insurance coverage.

[Roy Belson]: would be in place to cover any unforeseen issues, any liabilities that would be involved.

[Roy Belson]: The plan would allow for a successful respondent to move quickly towards implementation this summer.

[Roy Belson]: Because they would be able to do things in the private sector, and we would insist on prevailing wage and things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: They would be able to move a lot faster than a public entity can move under these rules.

[Roy Belson]: Under the plan, Medford would reap all the benefits intended under the previous idea and still retain control.

[Roy Belson]: We believe it's an effective approach because it clearly spells out each expected item and it could be implemented without unnecessary delay.

[Roy Belson]: So I think it was a good discussion that we had.

[Roy Belson]: Christine did a great job working in town with people, Mark and Howard back and forth covering the issues legally.

[Roy Belson]: And with help from, you know, legal in town, I think we've come up with a plan that allows us to go forward and to get this in place.

[Roy Belson]: Take any questions you have.

[Roy Belson]: We put it in the RFP.

[Roy Belson]: Anything we put in there, the respondent has to accept.

[Roy Belson]: No.

[Roy Belson]: Or... Well, one would think that if they're paying prevailing wage, there's no reason not to use... Of course.

[Roy Belson]: We've done all our projects that way.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, I did read in the emails that, you know, like all these universities, they seem to think they have no money.

[Roy Belson]: Well, because in order for it to work,

[Roy Belson]: based on our concept of an interaction with an area university, we would want one in the area.

[Roy Belson]: Because if they weren't in the area, it would become very difficult to have the interaction that we want.

[Roy Belson]: And probably would not be attractive to a non-area university to want to rent one of our facilities.

[Roy Belson]: I would say you've got to have a radius of so many miles.

[Roy Belson]: We could come up with that, but I wouldn't expect it.

[Roy Belson]: We could specify.

[Roy Belson]: I just don't see us, the benefit to us is to have a university that's accessible to our teachers, accessible to our students, accessible to programs and the like.

[Roy Belson]: because they can go out and do it and attract a vendor without going through multiple layers of, you know, bidding and the like.

[Roy Belson]: And since the money will be the same, I mean, it's up to them.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, we might even do better because essentially they can work on it.

[Roy Belson]: We can work on the numbers with them.

[Roy Belson]: Oh, yeah.

[Roy Belson]: That's on the RFP.

[Roy Belson]: That's in the RFP.

[Roy Belson]: We've done RFPs before, and RFP is a standard operation.

[Roy Belson]: Well, it's a little bit different than we started out.

[Roy Belson]: It's not different.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, RFPs are generally a very interesting tool, because you're not stuck strictly on price.

[Roy Belson]: You're able to look at criteria, and you're able to look at who can provide what.

[Roy Belson]: And since this is a lot of qualitative interaction that's involved,

[Roy Belson]: You want to be able to look at the criteria rather than just strictly a dollar factor.

[Roy Belson]: For posting.

[Roy Belson]: It may take a little bit more time to actually construct the RFP.

[Roy Belson]: We have to go over it very carefully.

[Roy Belson]: But once it's out, it's two weeks.

[Roy Belson]: You have to be each week in the newspaper, in a prominent newspaper.

[Roy Belson]: If someone shows up that we haven't thought of, let's be interested.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, we may get surprised.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know.

[Roy Belson]: So let's walk through it a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: Sure.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: If an entity wants to use the item, they certainly want to play on something that's quality.

[Roy Belson]: They certainly don't want to play on something that's less than quality if they can help it.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: Two, they have to meet NCAA standards.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: Which will immediately ensure a certain level of quality.

[Roy Belson]: And three, we'll have a clerk of the works.

[Roy Belson]: We'll make sure that they follow certain specifications.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: We would look at it.

[Roy Belson]: We would look at it.

[Roy Belson]: But again, because it's an RFP, we have a lot of factors with qualitative discretion in it.

[Roy Belson]: It's not just price.

[Roy Belson]: If you have a university that already has physical facilities, they're not coming to us for another one.

[Roy Belson]: If you have a university that doesn't provide certain programs in areas that we're interested in, they're not meeting another criteria.

[Roy Belson]: So let's answer it this way.

[Roy Belson]: You just heard Kathy Medaglio tell you that they've balanced special ed students.

[Roy Belson]: You heard Paul Teixeira tell you that they've also allocated EL students.

[Roy Belson]: Those students can't go into the partial lottery because they've already been balanced, okay?

[Roy Belson]: So what's left are the students who we'll call typically developing.

[Roy Belson]: Students who have, you know, just basically doing their thing and don't have a designation as either EL or special ed.

[Roy Belson]: They're not part of that balance.

[Roy Belson]: Now, you can look at it in different ways.

[Roy Belson]: You can say that three of the schools have done some of their job, and they've sent some people to the school, and one school didn't.

[Roy Belson]: That's partial lottery going to the school that didn't.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise, you encourage people perhaps to never send anybody, figuring, well, their chances are better if they don't send anybody.

[Roy Belson]: On the other hand, you can say that you have a school that

[Roy Belson]: that's a natural feeder into the McGlynn.

[Roy Belson]: The McGlynn Elementary is a thing.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe you could take the 10, 15 kids that are still there and say, well, at least they're still in the same building.

[Roy Belson]: They know the building.

[Roy Belson]: That's another way of looking at it.

[Roy Belson]: A third way to do it would be to take all three of them, put them in the pot, and pull them out.

[Roy Belson]: Whatever you do, someone is probably not going to be happy.

[Roy Belson]: During the course of the year, we have heard repeatedly from you about some people that wanted to move from one school to the other.

[Roy Belson]: And because they had all kinds of issues with that.

[Roy Belson]: And I, you know, okay, I'm not going to argue that point.

[Roy Belson]: They had all kinds of issues with it.

[Roy Belson]: And it's incessant.

[Roy Belson]: So somebody who maybe doesn't get what they want is not going to be happy.

[Roy Belson]: The idea that we could move some people in cohorts was a good one.

[Roy Belson]: Because they go with their friends.

[Roy Belson]: Because that's one of the biggest reasons why people go to one school or the other and want to be with their friends.

[Roy Belson]: Now, that's another way of looking at the lottery.

[Roy Belson]: If you move the rest of the McGlynn over, they're all with their friends, okay?

[Roy Belson]: If you, in fact, go with some of the other places, you've got to take a significant number of people from one school in order so they have friends.

[Roy Belson]: So if you put all three into the pot, there's a chance that, and you're looking only for 15 kids, there's a chance that the school that doesn't send anybody might only have three friends, might only have two kids that anyone knows, because the numbers could skew back to the other people.

[Roy Belson]: So no matter what you do, there's going to be a tradeoff someplace.

[Roy Belson]: There's going to be a tradeoff someplace.

[Roy Belson]: So we've just got to decide.

[Roy Belson]: We've just got to decide what's going to work.

[Roy Belson]: They're both good schools.

[Roy Belson]: They both have the same curriculum.

[Roy Belson]: They both have people that will give them leadership.

[Roy Belson]: It's up to us as a school system to work hard to rebuild some of the thinking and work at it.

[Roy Belson]: But we've got to make a decision because we've got to get on with it.

[Roy Belson]: because people are scheduling, there's resources that have to be allocated, we're working on a budget, and we gotta know what we're doing.

[Roy Belson]: No.

[Roy Belson]: That's stretching it.

[Roy Belson]: That's stretching it.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I think we've taken care of siblings at this point, haven't we?

[Roy Belson]: I think we took a good eye to look at siblings.

[Roy Belson]: And plus, there's going to be a few new people coming in, you know, between now and the end of the year, and a few people leaving.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to happen, too.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I think that we've talked about all these things, Mike.

[Roy Belson]: This isn't like, you know, this is the first time we're discussing it.

[Roy Belson]: This has been going on for a year.

[Roy Belson]: And the reality is there are some dynamic forces in the background that created maybe some preferences that are there.

[Roy Belson]: Now, historically, balance has shifted between the places.

[Roy Belson]: We're hopeful with some changes at one school that

[Roy Belson]: This won't be a permanent situation.

[Roy Belson]: This will change.

[Roy Belson]: But at any one point in time, at any one point in time, is it necessary, what do you call it, to, you know, hang our heads and say we didn't do it?

[Roy Belson]: I mean, is choice more important right now than

[Roy Belson]: making sure the schools are balanced so the teachers have enough kids in the classroom, and we need to move forward.

[Roy Belson]: I think we want to be careful.

[Roy Belson]: The vast majority of people got their choice.

[Roy Belson]: It's just a percentage right now.

[Roy Belson]: Now you could use the NBA rule.

[Roy Belson]: You want to play the NBA game?

[Roy Belson]: Whereas some schools have a weighted number versus other schools.

[Roy Belson]: So you might say that a school that has no one going there would have to send more.

[Roy Belson]: A second school might send, you know, which has more kids going, might send less, a smaller percentage.

[Roy Belson]: And a third school, which has even more going, might send an even smaller percentage so that no school

[Roy Belson]: gets hit totally.

[Roy Belson]: It actually listed the concept of disproportionality.

[Roy Belson]: If one place did not send anybody, then that place would be the partial lottery.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise, it's a total lottery.

[Roy Belson]: From time to time in my role,

[Roy Belson]: Sure, I question certain things from time to time.

[Roy Belson]: That's my job.

[Roy Belson]: I didn't throw anyone else under the bus.

[Roy Belson]: I took all the heat myself and accepted full responsibility for it.

[Roy Belson]: that I thought was responsible for anything.

[Roy Belson]: But I took the blame.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if anyone feels offended or upset, or feels that I did finger them inappropriately, then you have my apology, because that is not my intent.

[Roy Belson]: My goal was to aid the police department.

[Roy Belson]: You know, it's tough enough some days for all of us in our very respective jobs.

[Roy Belson]: I didn't ask for any representation.

[Roy Belson]: So if in fact they did get hired, they could be replaced within that one year.

[Roy Belson]: That's what I do.

[Roy Belson]: As Mrs. DiBenedetto pointed out,

[Roy Belson]: I probably wouldn't work 25 hours a week.

[Roy Belson]: I'd probably work 80 hours a week or 60 hours a week.

[Roy Belson]: I can sit back, not do anything, but that means my successor

[Roy Belson]: is gonna have an awful lot to do.

[Roy Belson]: I would rather she comes in to a stable environment and have the opportunity to move her ideas and programs forward, and I will root for her.

[Roy Belson]: I can assure you that you'll be involved.

[Roy Belson]: I can assure you that she will be involved.

[Roy Belson]: I want to assure you that that's my intent.

[Roy Belson]: I appreciate you listening.

[Roy Belson]: The world is filled with rumortism, and that paralyzes everyone.

[Roy Belson]: Quick summary is that under school choice, people can

[Roy Belson]: come to our school district for a very low amount of money if we have open seats.

[Roy Belson]: And the cost that we would receive or the compensation received is not worth it to us.

[Roy Belson]: And we would have to educate people that would take seats from other people.

[Roy Belson]: It just doesn't work under the current rule.

[Roy Belson]: That's not our situation.

[Roy Belson]: We have to notify the state by a certain date.

[Roy Belson]: They don't have to be exactly even, but they have to be close enough.

[Roy Belson]: They have to be within 15, 20 kids.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, that's a reasonable differential.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight you saw some teachers come in from Lubbock Line.

[Roy Belson]: You have, you know, emailed me and other people have emailed me ad nauseum, no offense, about a person here and a person there.

[Roy Belson]: There are 12 people who wanted that shift.

[Roy Belson]: If we do it for one, you know, out of turn,

[Roy Belson]: It's going to send some other people unhappy.

[Roy Belson]: So we've got to look at that.

[Roy Belson]: But before we start taking any one person out of line, I think that's something else we need to be careful about.

[Roy Belson]: I would say the 21st we should be ready to make a decision.

[Roy Belson]: We should, you know, give you an idea towards the end of that week.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: You know, that it's either happening or it's not happening.

[Roy Belson]: That's there.

[Roy Belson]: So as you remember in the fall, there was a situation in which one of our players got hurt and there was an issue about whether the trainer at Beverly High School properly attended to this individual and what was going on.

[Roy Belson]: So subsequent to that, we've done a number of research items and we've talked about things and I want to read a statement so that the record is clear as to what we think happened and that Mrs. Simonides has some comfort as to her considerations.

[Roy Belson]: This email is intended to provide, or an email at the time, information regarding the soccer injury that occurred during the game at Beverly High School this fall.

[Roy Belson]: Consultation with the Massachusetts Interscholastic Athletic Association tells us that the organization considers the situation to be a local matter.

[Roy Belson]: The requirement to provide certified trainers does not cover all sports.

[Roy Belson]: Football and hockey do require a trainer to be present.

[Roy Belson]: but other sports do not.

[Roy Belson]: This includes soccer.

[Roy Belson]: The MIAA suggests that coaches and referees must take responsibility to determine if a player should not re-enter a game after an injury.

[Roy Belson]: The cost for certified trainers at every game would be prohibitive.

[Roy Belson]: As a result, Medford will intensify its training of our coaches and consider hiring an assistant trainer for certain sports to supplement our current staffing.

[Roy Belson]: Coaches will be instructed to exclude any Medford player who suffers a concussion or any other major injury unless the player is properly examined and cleared by a qualified trainer.

[Roy Belson]: Any student who suffers such an injury will require a written follow-up report and a subsequent examination by a qualified physician.

[Roy Belson]: It is also important to note that under MIA rules 56.4, that a trainer, if present, is responsible for both teams when the medical person for the visiting team is not on site.

[Roy Belson]: The Beverly Public Schools has indicated they will not be rehiring their current trainer going forward.

[Roy Belson]: They have advertised for contracted training service for next year.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford Public Schools will initiate a discussion with the Northeast Conference Schools on the issue of appropriate trainer coverage.

[Roy Belson]: I believe that the above steps are a significant response to the issue, and additional steps may emerge after those kinds of discussions.

[Roy Belson]: I'd like to thank Ms.

[Roy Belson]: Simonides for her diligence on this matter.

[Roy Belson]: Our on-field cameras, evidence, and subsequent investigation supports our interpretation of the events at Beverly.

[Roy Belson]: We appreciate her commitment to ensuring safety for student athletes.

[Roy Belson]: So I just would say that ultimately it doesn't need a problem because we'd be paying the bill.

[Roy Belson]: See, I think they could say, oh, you've got to have one.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is, is that how many sports do we have, Bob?

[Roy Belson]: 21 sports, and let's say in every season there's four or five sports.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, you'd have to have people at every event.

[Roy Belson]: There's JVs, there's freshmen, there's all kinds of activities.

[Roy Belson]: It would be difficult.

[Roy Belson]: So one way to do it is to differentiate staffing.

[Roy Belson]: We do that with education too in many ways, is to make sure that the people who are on site know enough to respond.

[Roy Belson]: to take youngsters out of games and not just listen to the kids saying, I want to go back in, I want to go back in.

[Roy Belson]: Or to call for medical help and get the youngster to medical help on site.

[Roy Belson]: Some sports are obviously more combative and more physical.

[Roy Belson]: There's a higher likelihood of injury.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a balance wheel here that we can think of.

[Roy Belson]: If we hire another assistant trainer or some of the time for some of the sports, we will have gone a long way.

[Roy Belson]: If we intensify our coaches training,

[Roy Belson]: And we worked with the trainers who from other communities will have gone a long way to at least cover the basics that need to be covered and then move from there.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, it's not like it's a, you know, a small investment.

[Roy Belson]: So typically the home team provides the trainer.

[Roy Belson]: But on that day, for example, there were at least three games going on simultaneously.

[Roy Belson]: So trainers on three different fields, moving back and forth.

[Roy Belson]: not putting a youngster back in the game, calling for medical help, doing what they have to do.

[Roy Belson]: Like in football, you have the ambulance on the field.

[Roy Belson]: The ambulance is there.

[Roy Belson]: Other sports, it's more of the, let's say, less, let's say, lethal.

[Roy Belson]: Did she already have it?

[Roy Belson]: No, because I gave it to her.

[Roy Belson]: Perfect.

[Roy Belson]: And then you'll get a full picture.

[Roy Belson]: An alpha listing.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: When we originally planned these programs, we looked to outsource them at the time.

[Roy Belson]: We found that the reliability of the outsourcing was not good.

[Roy Belson]: that they had the same issues in getting people and getting people trained the way we wanted them to.

[Roy Belson]: We also recognized that their costs were much higher and we would have to transmit that.

[Roy Belson]: We can control costs a lot better by keeping it inside.

[Roy Belson]: and to go on from there, because that's really the trick, to get them to move on.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll work on it.

[Roy Belson]: We've done pretty well so far, just that it is a difficult thing when people are working four or five hours and they want to get another job, or they can get something that pays a little better.

[Roy Belson]: We have to decide, you know, how much we're willing to pay based on what we're willing to charge as well.

[Roy Belson]: Want to begin by apologizing to everyone for any disruption that my actions may have caused.

[Roy Belson]: There are people in the community who obviously were concerned, and so I respect that.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll move forward, and in time, everything will heal.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to begin by apologizing to everyone for any disruption that my actions may have caused.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, a decision was made that people don't agree with, but it also set off a whole series of concerns in the community, and that never was my intent.

[Roy Belson]: I'm confident that Medford has a bright future for its school system.

[Roy Belson]: We have a lot of good things in place.

[Roy Belson]: We have a terrific faculty, terrific administrators, wonderful supporters, people that have worked hard to partner with our schools.

[Roy Belson]: And I know that we will get a lot done in the next several months.

[Roy Belson]: and that the new administration coming in will come and build on a firm foundation.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor's words.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that the reality for all of us is to get beyond, to work to learn from this situation, and to grow together, and to make sure that we do everything we can to protect the children and families of Medford.

[Roy Belson]: Additionally, we will work much more closely with the police department.

[Roy Belson]: We have for many years.

[Roy Belson]: This was an exception, but I have a lot of confidence in our police department and Chief Sacco and others.

[Roy Belson]: And I want to make sure that everyone realizes that we will do everything we can to keep our young people safe.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you for being here tonight.

[Roy Belson]: I appreciate your support and I appreciate your understanding.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Well, naturally, you know, I wouldn't like my career to end this way, but it's, you know, but I think that we've still been able to do a lot.

[Roy Belson]: Remember, this is 50 years, 23 as superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: A decision was made that people don't agree with.

[Roy Belson]: but it also set off a whole series of concerns in the community and that's never was my intent.

[Roy Belson]: Aye.

[Roy Belson]: President Roy Bellson, superintendent of schools.

[Roy Belson]: 2500 Mystic Valley Parkway, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, members of the council.

[Roy Belson]: Historically, the chief of police and the school system have worked very closely together on all security matters.

[Roy Belson]: In 1999, when Columbine hit, the chief and I were part of a group that formed

[Roy Belson]: the STARS program, School Threat Assessment and Response System.

[Roy Belson]: It was part of NMLEC, the Northeast Middlesex Law Enforcement Council.

[Roy Belson]: And since that time, we've worked very closely together to put together all kinds of security measures for our schools.

[Roy Belson]: And we communicate very regularly with each other.

[Roy Belson]: When we think there's a danger, we talk and we take action.

[Roy Belson]: Recently,

[Roy Belson]: Back in and around December 28th or 29th, I'm not 100% sure of that date, a cleaning service that's employed by the public schools at the McGlynn Complex, middle school and elementary, found in the rear of the Veterans Memorial Auditorium, in the back row under a seat, a magazine clip that contained some ammunition in it.

[Roy Belson]: It is unclear

[Roy Belson]: how much ammunition was in it.

[Roy Belson]: We know that it could have been, based on the chief's estimate, at least three to four rounds, but not necessarily a full clip.

[Roy Belson]: We can't tell that because we don't have the magazine.

[Roy Belson]: But from the picture that we were able to see, that's a reasonable estimate at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: The cleaning service turned it over to a custodian at the building.

[Roy Belson]: The custodian

[Roy Belson]: brought the magazine clip to the principal's office at the McGlynn Middle, and put it on a shelf.

[Roy Belson]: That's the report that I have.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, just a point of information.

[Roy Belson]: So,

[Roy Belson]: School went on Christmas break on the 22nd of December.

[Roy Belson]: To the best of our knowledge, at least at this point, we're checking on a couple of other things.

[Roy Belson]: Only one entity used the McGlynn during that weekend for a holiday service.

[Roy Belson]: The cleaning service has informed us that they did a thorough cleaning

[Roy Belson]: of the facility, including the auditorium, which they would typically do on Fridays, and found nothing at that time.

[Roy Belson]: The service was over sometime on Sunday, and the holiday commenced on Monday.

[Roy Belson]: Sometime around the 28th, the cleaning service went back into the theater, or the 29th, I'm not 100% sure.

[Roy Belson]: and they found under the seat in the back row this magazine clip that I just described.

[Roy Belson]: It was turned over to the custodian, in-house custodian, whose name is Daniel Tully.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Tully took that magazine clip, according to his report, and put it in the principal's office, Mr. Edwards' office, and he said on the shelf, along with some other things that were there,

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Edwards has told us that he came into his office in and around the 30th of December to do some work and to do some cleaning, at which point he alleges that he cleared away some things that were unnecessary and may have, he doesn't know, may have discarded the magazine clip.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I'm telling you what I know.

[Roy Belson]: And if you have other stories, I'll be happy to listen to them.

[Roy Belson]: But I'm telling you my latest.

[Roy Belson]: I'm telling you what I know.

[Roy Belson]: If I had a different story, I would say that also.

[Roy Belson]: I'm telling you what I know.

[Roy Belson]: I understand, but you have more information than I have then.

[Roy Belson]: So Mr. Edwards told me that he cleaned his office and he may have discarded the item.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if you know what a magazine clip looks like, it's about this long.

[Roy Belson]: It's black.

[Roy Belson]: Has some appearances that looks like it could be a small cell phone, small remote control, small other electronic device.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know what other items he had there and how it could have been confused.

[Roy Belson]: But that's the story that he provided to me.

[Roy Belson]: Now, we did not have any evidence of a magazine clip available to us.

[Roy Belson]: Sometime in early January, Mr. Tully came to my office during his shift and told me about what he had found.

[Roy Belson]: I asked him routine questions about where he found it, who was there,

[Roy Belson]: Those kinds of things.

[Roy Belson]: And he couldn't really fill in much more except the fact that he found it and put that in Mr. Edwards' office.

[Roy Belson]: We checked with different other people.

[Roy Belson]: And at this point in time, I'm unable to identify where the chain of custody took place after Mr. Edwards allegedly

[Roy Belson]: discarded the item, or did not see it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, subsequent to that, we try to make some decision as to whether we felt this rose to the level of a reportable incident.

[Roy Belson]: I'm told that Officer Ricciardi, who is the school resource officer, was also told at some point in early January.

[Roy Belson]: That's what I'm told.

[Roy Belson]: I want to be sure that I'm not 100% sure of that.

[Roy Belson]: At the time, we felt that it was an isolated incident, that it was something that was not dangerous in the sense because it wasn't a firearm.

[Roy Belson]: Bullets don't fire themselves, not a weapon.

[Roy Belson]: No weapon was found.

[Roy Belson]: we should take our time and not raise anxiety.

[Roy Belson]: However, subsequent to that, in conversations that I've had with people in recent times, indicates to me that even though we did not feel it presented a clear danger, that other people do, and that they would have preferred that we made a full report

[Roy Belson]: to the chief of police.

[Roy Belson]: And as I indicated earlier, the chief and I talk all the time.

[Roy Belson]: I have no problem telling the chief anything.

[Roy Belson]: And we've talked about a lot of difficult situations over the years.

[Roy Belson]: We don't hide things.

[Roy Belson]: But a judgment was made.

[Roy Belson]: And that judgment said, we don't see this as dangerous at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: So therefore, I take responsibility

[Roy Belson]: for not reporting it to the chief.

[Roy Belson]: But I did so, I believe, in good conscience.

[Roy Belson]: I believe that it was something that I needed to know more about before I raised it or elevated it.

[Roy Belson]: Over the years, I have reported any number of things the chief can verify to him that I thought were dangerous.

[Roy Belson]: I don't believe that Mr. Edwards

[Roy Belson]: would have any motive for not turning it in.

[Roy Belson]: After all, he wasn't there on the weekend, didn't belong to him.

[Roy Belson]: He has turned in many items, and Officer Ricciardi has indicated this, to him on multiple occasions.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't believe he had any reason not to turn it in if he knew he had it.

[Roy Belson]: At this point in time, since it has become an issue,

[Roy Belson]: especially in light of what's taken place in other communities around the country.

[Roy Belson]: We have authorized a full sweep today, full sweep of the McGlynn Complex, which was conducted by Medford Police, Somerville Police, Everett Police, and Arlington Police with dogs that are weapons and drug trained.

[Roy Belson]: and we found no trace of weapons, ammunition, or drugs in the complex.

[Roy Belson]: I'm comfortable that that building is clear.

[Roy Belson]: We have also initiated, in order to help the public feel comfortable, a sweep of all school buildings over the next few days to ensure that there is nothing there that would be of concern.

[Roy Belson]: We are also planning this week to put together material, media, and others to talk to the public about the nature of school security, what we have in place, without getting into sensitive items, but what we have in place, and also to address this issue.

[Roy Belson]: I have communicated with the Teachers Association President, Charlene Douglas, and

[Roy Belson]: It's possible that I will meet with the McGlynn faculty on Monday afternoon to answer any questions they have.

[Roy Belson]: We believe that our schools are safe.

[Roy Belson]: We believe that we do more than most school systems do to keep our schools safe.

[Roy Belson]: We believe that we will continue to review and upgrade what we have if we find that there is room here to do so.

[Roy Belson]: and we believe that we can go forward recognizing that the decision that I made with others in my employee needs to be upgraded in the future and that a lesson learned.

[Roy Belson]: I'm happy to take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: Yes.

[Roy Belson]: No, the chief of police was not involved.

[Roy Belson]: I did talk to the principal.

[Roy Belson]: I did talk to the custodian.

[Roy Belson]: I did talk to a couple of other people that I work with.

[Roy Belson]: And in my opinion, at that particular point in time, Officer Ricciardi did come in at some point, came to the conclusion that it was not something that warranted a full investigation at this point.

[Roy Belson]: I saw the picture last night.

[Roy Belson]: And the clip is, if you look at the clip, you can see one bullet at the top, and then there are holes on the side.

[Roy Belson]: The chief can describe this better than I can.

[Roy Belson]: But he can tell how many rounds might be in it.

[Roy Belson]: But the person's hand covered most of it, holding it.

[Roy Belson]: So he couldn't tell beyond a certain point whether there were additional bullets beyond

[Roy Belson]: the 3 to 4 that he was able to identify.

[Roy Belson]: We have notified people on all kinds of situations in the past.

[Roy Belson]: We've reported multiple situations over the years of all kinds.

[Roy Belson]: Certainly, you know, one can debate whether this rose to that level

[Roy Belson]: But given the consensus that I have- All due respect, there's no debate.

[Roy Belson]: I'd like to respond to the notification issue.

[Roy Belson]: If you're speaking about a couple of years ago when there was a bomb threat at the high school, the issue wasn't,

[Roy Belson]: notification, the issue was timing of the notification, whether it was soon enough.

[Roy Belson]: And the committee decided to make it a little bit faster.

[Roy Belson]: We notified the public about that.

[Roy Belson]: We just didn't do it immediately afterwards.

[Roy Belson]: We did it a few hours later.

[Roy Belson]: We felt that more people would be home.

[Roy Belson]: But the committee felt differently, and we modified.

[Roy Belson]: Now as far as this situation goes, it happened during a school vacation.

[Roy Belson]: It happened when no students were in the building.

[Roy Belson]: It didn't happen where there was a firearm anywhere near it.

[Roy Belson]: And there was a plausible thought as to how it may have gotten there.

[Roy Belson]: Now, since that time, we're all aware of what happened in Florida.

[Roy Belson]: And I'm sure that there's a heightened feeling that somehow that is the same situation.

[Roy Belson]: It's not.

[Roy Belson]: However, Massachusetts has tremendous gun laws, tremendous gun laws.

[Roy Belson]: We can't buy what that individual bought in Florida, in Massachusetts.

[Roy Belson]: You can't do that.

[Roy Belson]: From our standpoint, from my standpoint, I made a decision.

[Roy Belson]: In that decision, we have back and forth, and it was determined that that was the wrong decision.

[Roy Belson]: I accept responsibility for it, and we'll go forward from that.

[Roy Belson]: but I made the decision in good faith.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes, you know, we make decisions that people don't agree on.

[Roy Belson]: If I thought there was something live, if I thought that students were in the building, if I thought there was a weapon anywhere near the place, my decision would have been different.

[Roy Belson]: So I stand on that for the time being.

[Roy Belson]: I apologize to anyone who may feel that I did the wrong thing, but I certainly didn't do it with malintent or reason to

[Roy Belson]: let's say obfuscate any of the information from the public.

[Roy Belson]: I'll stand on that.

[Roy Belson]: Why didn't I think it was necessary in January?

[Roy Belson]: No, we don't think that's the case, because the cleaning service that found it cleans that area regularly and did not see it.

[Roy Belson]: It's clear to me that it landed there very recently in proximity to the time that it was found.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not gonna evaluate a principal in this forum.

[Roy Belson]: Let's understand that.

[Roy Belson]: I will take actions on personnel matters as we go forward into the spring, but I'm not gonna evaluate a person in this forum.

[Roy Belson]: That's not

[Roy Belson]: an appropriate way to do it.

[Roy Belson]: Individuals are entitled to due process.

[Roy Belson]: They're entitled to the protections of the law.

[Roy Belson]: So the reality is that we will be reviewing personnel.

[Roy Belson]: We will be reviewing policies and practices.

[Roy Belson]: We will be ramping up some of our drills.

[Roy Belson]: I've also told the principals that the week we come back, we're going to run a special drill

[Roy Belson]: I'm a little concerned about it in some ways because I don't want to heighten in the students' minds that this is somehow an emergency.

[Roy Belson]: But on the other hand, I think we should at least do one more drill at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: It might help the community understand that we're prepared.

[Roy Belson]: take everything that happens every day and send it out.

[Roy Belson]: And I just want to say that, you know,

[Roy Belson]: Normally, I tell the chief virtually everything because we have very good communication and have for many, many years.

[Roy Belson]: In this instance, I didn't do it.

[Roy Belson]: I failed in that regard.

[Roy Belson]: I don't believe our schools are unsafe.

[Roy Belson]: I don't believe

[Roy Belson]: that our children are in danger.

[Roy Belson]: I believe that the school committee, the council, by paying money for cameras and other things like that, have provided quite a bit.

[Roy Belson]: We work closely with the district attorney to determine what's happening on the street on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: There is a lot going on that heads off issues in our schools.

[Roy Belson]: If I made a mistake this time, not if I made, I made a mistake this time, I accept that responsibility.

[Roy Belson]: But I believe enough's in place.

[Roy Belson]: And I believe that if we, we dedicate ourselves to it, we'll be fine.

[Roy Belson]: I believe our schools are safe as any school in the Commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, there are no guarantees.

[Roy Belson]: There are no guarantees that I can give you or anyone of sound mind could give you.

[Roy Belson]: because we live in a society that is a little violent.

[Roy Belson]: We live in a society that does do unusual things at times, and we do have a lot of mental health out there, and there are guns on the street.

[Roy Belson]: And that requires even more, more from the people that make decisions, make decisions about these issues and these policies.

[Roy Belson]: But in this instance, I accept responsibility.

[Roy Belson]: I will put that on our calendar for Thursday evening.

[Roy Belson]: Yes.

[Roy Belson]: So let me ask a technical question of the clerk, if I may, through the chair.

[Roy Belson]: We've posted a meeting, Mr. Clerk.

[Roy Belson]: We've posted it at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: Can we make a modification if the chair agrees to make that modification under the open meeting law?

[Roy Belson]: So I'll communicate with your office tomorrow morning, and you can tell me whether we fall within the guidelines.

[Roy Belson]: OK?

[Roy Belson]: Yeah.

[Roy Belson]: Not at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: So a comment on that.

[Roy Belson]: Of all the letters in ALICE, the only one we don't do is confront.

[Roy Belson]: Because everyone alerts people if there's something going on.

[Roy Belson]: Everyone locks down if they have to.

[Roy Belson]: Everyone informs mutual aid or assistance when they do it.

[Roy Belson]: And everyone tries to evacuate if they can.

[Roy Belson]: It's the confront part that becomes of concern.

[Roy Belson]: And the reason it's of concern

[Roy Belson]: Think about young kids, little kids.

[Roy Belson]: Should they be trying to confront?

[Roy Belson]: Are all teachers, are all staff physically able to confront?

[Roy Belson]: Will they try to confront?

[Roy Belson]: Can we mandate that they confront?

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot to this that needs to be thought about.

[Roy Belson]: And what age group do you start?

[Roy Belson]: And when do you start?

[Roy Belson]: It's really an active shooter program.

[Roy Belson]: It's not just a general program for bomb threats or things like that.

[Roy Belson]: It's a program.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot to it.

[Roy Belson]: In that regard, who confronts and in what way, and who's able to confront, not everybody is going to be willing to do that.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to think about it.

[Roy Belson]: Chief and I have talked about starting maybe with the older kids and the higher grade levels.

[Roy Belson]: There's some issues with it.

[Roy Belson]: But look, I am more than willing to have the discussion and to have

[Roy Belson]: an active give and take on this subject.

[Roy Belson]: But we need all the players who are going to be expected to step up to tell us whether they're prepared to confront.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the other day when the Parkland situation took place, if you remember the sequence, the individual pulled a fire alarm to get people to evacuate the setting and then was going to pick them off with his gun.

[Roy Belson]: I've heard many times, why don't we evacuate this?

[Roy Belson]: And I've told you in previous occasions that evacuation isn't always the best drill because the explosive or the sniper could be on the outside of the building, not just on the inside of the building.

[Roy Belson]: It's all situation-specific.

[Roy Belson]: And it needs to be talked about, more than willing to talk about it.

[Roy Belson]: Let's not just put out alphabet soup, ALICE, and say that's a cure-all.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to get people to talk about it.

[Roy Belson]: But it's got to be adopted and committed to by the people who are going to implement it, or else it's just another training program that will go nowhere.

[Roy Belson]: Yes.

[Roy Belson]: It's been offered to the president of the MTA.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: And she hasn't confirmed it yet, but she thinks it's a good idea.

[Roy Belson]: But she has to confirm it.

[Roy Belson]: Well, that's a police investigation, so I leave that to the Chief to answer that one.

[Roy Belson]: STARS was set up to look at school threats, the acronym School Threat Assessment and Response System.

[Roy Belson]: So when a school threat is identified,

[Roy Belson]: or we believe it is identified, and we believe it requires additional resources above and beyond what we have, we would notify the STARS commanders.

[Roy Belson]: Chief Sacco once headed that group.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not sure who heads it now.

[Roy Belson]: We would notify them, and they would provide us with those resources.

[Roy Belson]: So let's say we needed a graphologist.

[Roy Belson]: They might have a graphologist.

[Roy Belson]: Let's say we needed a certain type of psychiatrist.

[Roy Belson]: They would help us with that.

[Roy Belson]: Let's say we needed a forensic help.

[Roy Belson]: There are certain police departments and entities in the state that have forensic, the bomb squads.

[Roy Belson]: They would coordinate the kind of specialized assistance that we need to make the appropriate threat assessment and then make the appropriate response.

[Roy Belson]: If we needed, unfortunately, a SWAT team, that would be the ultimate.

[Roy Belson]: But it's a coordinated response.

[Roy Belson]: And I want to make that point very clear.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of people out there selling products about,

[Roy Belson]: coordinating with schools and the like.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of money being made in the school security business right now.

[Roy Belson]: And part of it brings up the idea that we could have an uncoordinated response.

[Roy Belson]: And that's the last thing we wanted.

[Roy Belson]: The chief and I both agree that if we have a situation that requires mutual aid or specialized assistance, we want that coordinated.

[Roy Belson]: You may not know, but I think we will have said it many times, but maybe you don't remember.

[Roy Belson]: There are floor plans on the computers of the police cruisers.

[Roy Belson]: There are doors that are marked that people can go to.

[Roy Belson]: There's all kinds of pre-preparation in place for STARS to work and for our own police to respond strategically and specifically to areas which we believe require attention.

[Roy Belson]: What we don't want is we don't want what happened in 1992.

[Roy Belson]: Remember 1992?

[Roy Belson]: In 1992, there was a altercation at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: And at that time, people came from everywhere.

[Roy Belson]: Helicopters were flying over the building.

[Roy Belson]: People were coming in all different kinds of uniforms, not coordinating.

[Roy Belson]: And that only created more problems than it assisted in helping.

[Roy Belson]: So it's very important, and I thank the chief and his comrades at NMWEC for the work that they have put in to ensure that a response of that type through the STAR system is one that is coordinated, thorough, and strategic.

[Roy Belson]: Very different.

[Roy Belson]: Very different.

[Roy Belson]: If it occurred when students were there,

[Roy Belson]: would have been a full report and immediate response.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not going to blame anybody else.

[Roy Belson]: I knew about it.

[Roy Belson]: I have a relationship with the chief.

[Roy Belson]: I should have made the report.

[Roy Belson]: The next step is to continue to fortify and to continue to assess.

[Roy Belson]: I expect to be in front of you in and around March 6.

[Roy Belson]: I know you're looking forward to seeing me again.

[Roy Belson]: Attempted humor.

[Roy Belson]: to get funding for the upgrade to all the security cameras that we've put in place.

[Roy Belson]: We have upgraded all of them so that they're now capable to withstand some of the weather issues that previously they weren't.

[Roy Belson]: They have better visibility.

[Roy Belson]: They have better ability to pan.

[Roy Belson]: And we think it's a distinct improvement over what we've been able to have in the past.

[Roy Belson]: So I'll be in front of you for that, too.

[Roy Belson]: I think so.

[Roy Belson]: I think there are a lot of terrific groups that rent our schools.

[Roy Belson]: And every group from Cub Scouts to all kinds of groups all the way up rent our schools or use our schools in a meaningful way.

[Roy Belson]: This is an outlier situation.

[Roy Belson]: This is not something that's happened frequently.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe we didn't handle it.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe I didn't handle it well.

[Roy Belson]: But that doesn't mean we should deprive the community of the resources of the schools, which I think are very important to providing appropriate recreation and assistance.

[Roy Belson]: Look, shut down the pool, we just did it.

[Roy Belson]: You want to shut down the gymnasium?

[Roy Belson]: We can't do that.

[Roy Belson]: We can't live in fear.

[Roy Belson]: So I appreciate the observation.

[Roy Belson]: I can assure you that my conversations with certain individuals will be very direct and very thorough, and that decisions will be made about a lot of things in the next short period of time.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think it was a question of coordination.

[Roy Belson]: Not notifying.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I'll accept that.

[Roy Belson]: We don't brush things under the rug.

[Roy Belson]: We don't brush things under the rug.

[Roy Belson]: But from time to time, we make decisions.

[Roy Belson]: That's what decision makers do.

[Roy Belson]: We make decisions.

[Roy Belson]: And if I've made a decision that didn't square with everyone else, then I accept responsibility for that.

[Roy Belson]: But we don't brush things under the rug.

[Roy Belson]: And the chief will tell you that we have talked about some very tough items.

[Roy Belson]: And there will be some things you don't know about because they're personal and they're caught up in legal matters that you can't know and the school committee gets advised of because it's not a public matter.

[Roy Belson]: But that's the way it is.

[Roy Belson]: And that's what's required by law.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly on safety matters, safety matters, we don't brush things under the rug.

[Roy Belson]: Now as far as people using our facilities, we can cancel every basketball game, we can cancel every hockey game, let me finish, we can cancel every game where people come in who are visiting from some other place.

[Roy Belson]: We know, we know that in society today there are some people out there that do horrible things.

[Roy Belson]: And we can't just regulate everything that's going on all around us.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if you don't want to rent the school properties, if you don't feel that that revenue or that communication with the public is a good one, that can be a policy discussion with the school committee guided by some input that you want to make.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly, our schools

[Roy Belson]: Our schools are going to be places, they've been community schools for years.

[Roy Belson]: People have used them.

[Roy Belson]: And people come in visiting from other communities and the like.

[Roy Belson]: If we stopped everyone at the door, let me finish the point.

[Roy Belson]: If we stopped everyone at the door, the event would never happen.

[Roy Belson]: So I understand what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly, we don't hide anything.

[Roy Belson]: This was a situation, it's unfortunate.

[Roy Belson]: And as I've said before, I'm taking responsibility for it.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not sure how much more I can say that.

[Roy Belson]: That's my assumption.

[Roy Belson]: Investigation is undergoing.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not going to conclude anything until the police finish their work.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: These buildings, when they're rented of that type, like for example, the Japanese language school has two security guards there.

[Roy Belson]: They pay for them.

[Roy Belson]: They pay for coverage by custodians who function as security.

[Roy Belson]: So we have custodians that are now security guards.

[Roy Belson]: Are they paying a different rate?

[Roy Belson]: They provide us with coverage in those buildings.

[Roy Belson]: That's what we need.

[Roy Belson]: We have provided some security, have paid for some security of certain people in these large groups.

[Roy Belson]: I've mentioned the Japanese as an example.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, not every group is paying for security, so maybe we need to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: Maybe we need to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: So Mr. President, if I make one more comment, if I can.

[Roy Belson]: I've heard the word retaliation.

[Roy Belson]: There will be no retaliation.

[Roy Belson]: There are a couple of legal matters pending.

[Roy Belson]: And those legal matters are being represented by legal counsel of the city.

[Roy Belson]: and to indicate that somehow something is wrong because we defend ourselves in a legal setting in this public forum is wrong.

[Roy Belson]: Furthermore, if there was any evidence of retaliation, I would not allow it in any way, shape or form.

[Roy Belson]: I hope you realize that.

[Roy Belson]: And secondly, with regard to that,

[Roy Belson]: There are situations and decisions that are made that people don't always agree with in terms of educational assignments, programs, services, and the like.

[Roy Belson]: But they're made.

[Roy Belson]: Some people agree and some people disagree.

[Roy Belson]: And that's the nature of how we plan and how we go forward.

[Roy Belson]: And just because there's some disagreement doesn't necessarily mean that people are at risk of losing their jobs.

[Roy Belson]: People have professional status rights.

[Roy Belson]: They have all kinds of rights under their contract, all kinds of rights under the law.

[Roy Belson]: Nothing's going to happen that's inappropriate.

[Roy Belson]: If we disagree with someone on an issue, that can happen.

[Roy Belson]: But that happens in almost every forum and any place you go, in any operation, there may be some disagreements.

[Roy Belson]: But no one is in jeopardy of losing their job in that regard because they spoke up or said something.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, I appreciate it when people speak up.

[Roy Belson]: I like it when people speak to my face directly

[Roy Belson]: and call me on the phone when they've got something to say, rather than go to everybody else.

[Roy Belson]: Not everybody does that.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Well, there are people, Mr. President, there are people, Mr. President, who want to go and find out from the person responsible.

[Roy Belson]: And there are people that go around.

[Roy Belson]: I don't have a problem with that in this particular point.

[Roy Belson]: but it does speak to the issue.

[Roy Belson]: And as far as trust goes, it cuts two ways.

[Roy Belson]: This committee, the whole meeting, is already been posted.

[Roy Belson]: Posted, all right?

[Roy Belson]: Location, time, and 48-hour notice.

[Roy Belson]: So you just can't change it.

[Roy Belson]: It's a little easier to do, but this is our department.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know if that.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to call upon our Director of Finance and Administration to explain this report.

[Roy Belson]: So I've provided you a report on the state budget as it currently stands.

[Roy Belson]: Now, House 2 is the governor's proposal.

[Roy Belson]: The governor's proposal, with no disrespect to the governor, is generally dead on arrival in the legislature almost immediately because the legislature has its own view of what they want to do.

[Roy Belson]: Although, many elements in the governor's budget will be sustained by the legislature as well.

[Roy Belson]: And there are any number of things that have to go through.

[Roy Belson]: But we won't really get a final budget out of the state until June.

[Roy Belson]: We'll get a very good idea of where the House and the Senate are going with it.

[Roy Belson]: Primarily the Senate and the House, you know, when they get through the conference committee, probably in early June.

[Roy Belson]: Probably get a pretty good idea as to what's taking place.

[Roy Belson]: But we won't get a real vote on it until we're into June.

[Roy Belson]: But we work on estimates and we, a lot of these things are ideas and they're trends.

[Roy Belson]: But I want to go over some of them because they have an impact on us.

[Roy Belson]: And they also have an impact on what might happen at the federal level.

[Roy Belson]: and what might happen with regard to the new tax laws that may or may not take place, and also, in fact, the new tax law that's been passed by the federal government.

[Roy Belson]: So let's go over a couple of things so you're aware of it, because this informs our budget planning process.

[Roy Belson]: It also informs our lobbying efforts at the state level, as we talk to people and ask for certain supplementals and other budgets to be upgraded as we move forward through the budget process.

[Roy Belson]: So the process begins every year with a consensus budget revenue estimate, which is agreed upon by the governor and the House and Senate leadership.

[Roy Belson]: Now, that estimate this year went up about 3.5%.

[Roy Belson]: Now, that's nowhere near enough for all the things that people ask for, but that's where they're going right now.

[Roy Belson]: And the budget itself proposed a 2.6 increase to the budget of 40.9 million.

[Roy Belson]: The main source of education funding is Chapter 70.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 70 is done by formula.

[Roy Belson]: It's done by student population, by need, and all those other factors.

[Roy Belson]: Based on that, we are a budget, our school, city, that is above foundation.

[Roy Belson]: Most cities are, although there are a number of cities that are not.

[Roy Belson]: If you're above foundation, you get minimum aid.

[Roy Belson]: The governor's proposal is $20 per pupil, which is a robust $93,000, which goes nowhere very quickly.

[Roy Belson]: Before we even think about it, $93,000 is out the window.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate and the House tend to increase that either by $5 to $10 a year.

[Roy Belson]: which still doesn't do that much for us, but it's still a little bit better.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll be lobbying the House and the Senate to increase that particular amount.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the overall increase to Chapter 70 is $104.9 million.

[Roy Belson]: That's for 321 operating school districts.

[Roy Belson]: You can see that's not a lot of money going out.

[Roy Belson]: And you can imagine the big cities

[Roy Belson]: Boston, Worcester, Lawrence, Lowell, Fall River, New Bedford, places like that, with high need, get the bulk of those increases.

[Roy Belson]: If we move on a little bit, unrestricted local aid, which is not education aid, goes to the city, and that's up by 425,970.

[Roy Belson]: Don't clap yet.

[Roy Belson]: Don't clap yet.

[Roy Belson]: You see the next line tells you that before you're through,

[Roy Belson]: When you take away the assessments and you get a sheet here, we lose $17,000 in change.

[Roy Belson]: So we're getting $17,000 in change less based on the ins and outs of the cherry sheet, which is included here, the estimated cherry sheet and the governor's thing.

[Roy Belson]: So it's tricky.

[Roy Belson]: You might think you're getting your way.

[Roy Belson]: When you hear people say you're getting all this money, you're not.

[Roy Belson]: What you're getting is you're getting a balance between assessments and revenue.

[Roy Belson]: Now that doesn't include things like, you know, meals tax and things like that.

[Roy Belson]: And that's, that's a different ball game altogether, but direct aid to the city and to the schools.

[Roy Belson]: Um, we net loss of 17,000.

[Roy Belson]: Um, two major concerns in the governor's proposed budget that I want to mention is the underfunding of the charter school reimbursements.

[Roy Belson]: It's probably somewhere in the vicinity,

[Roy Belson]: of $70 million less across the commonwealth than the formula or the entitlement formula would otherwise provide.

[Roy Belson]: So when people still rail against charter schools and enrollment in charter schools, it's because it's underfunded.

[Roy Belson]: I have no problem with kids who want to go to charter school, go, but if you have an entitlement formula funded closer to the entitlement in every year, that hasn't increased for the last four or five years, that assessment.

[Roy Belson]: So that's something to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: And the other factor is the circuit breaker.

[Roy Belson]: The circuit breaker is for extraordinary special needs costs.

[Roy Belson]: The way the circuit breaker works is that four times foundation, which in this instance is probably about $44,000.

[Roy Belson]: Kathy, roughly?

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, someplace in there.

[Roy Belson]: It used to be $28,000.

[Roy Belson]: After you hit $44,000 on a placement,

[Roy Belson]: The state allegedly will give us 75% back on the remaining budget.

[Roy Belson]: So let's say the cost of this private school is $100,000.

[Roy Belson]: Based on that, the $56,000 delta would then be eligible for 75%.

[Roy Belson]: However, they funded it at 65% in this budget, which means that at this particular point in time, Medford will be short somewhere around $155,000.

[Roy Belson]: By the way, going back to the charter school thing, the reimbursement's about $400,000 lower than it should be to Medford, based on the actual formula.

[Roy Belson]: So it gives you an idea that, you know, we have entitlement formulas, but they don't get funded.

[Roy Belson]: Probably the saddest words in budget preparation is subject to appropriation.

[Roy Belson]: They pass a law, you have an entitlement, and then it's subject to appropriation.

[Roy Belson]: If the appropriation doesn't keep pace with the entitlement or the formula, you don't get what you think you're going to get.

[Roy Belson]: So that's always a tricky factor.

[Roy Belson]: There are multiple other variables that must be considered when planning a budget for fiscal 2019.

[Roy Belson]: Uncertainty in the federal budget, impacting grants of Medicaid distributions to state, city, and schools.

[Roy Belson]: We don't know what's going to happen.

[Roy Belson]: The costs of health care, always going up right now.

[Roy Belson]: The cost of negotiated salaries.

[Roy Belson]: We're in collective bargaining right now.

[Roy Belson]: Whatever we negotiate has to be accounted for.

[Roy Belson]: The impact of possible reduction in the sales tax through the initiative petition.

[Roy Belson]: There's an initiative petition that could make its way to the ballot if it does.

[Roy Belson]: It could be a reduction in the sales tax.

[Roy Belson]: And then there's the fair share tax, which is sometimes known as the millionaire's tax.

[Roy Belson]: If that were to go through, the estimate is that somewhere, the state might get $2 billion.

[Roy Belson]: But how it gets distributed back to the cities and towns will depend on the formula that's used.

[Roy Belson]: And when, okay?

[Roy Belson]: And then of course there's the increase in other service costs, whether it be transportation,

[Roy Belson]: energy or any of those things all have to be factored into budget planning.

[Roy Belson]: So this is intended to give you a little bit of a appetizer as to how we have to look at the budget as we go forward for next year.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, it's very important that we work very hard to secure our current and potential revenue.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of our budget is based on revenue.

[Roy Belson]: And we need to be aggressive about that.

[Roy Belson]: We have some good possibilities, but they have to be developed aggressively.

[Roy Belson]: to maintain and enhance them so our educational programs and services don't get cut by reductions in aid.

[Roy Belson]: The House and Senate will be preparing their budgets.

[Roy Belson]: The House begins in April, the Senate begins in May, typically, and the conference committee sometime towards the end of May, early June.

[Roy Belson]: And we typically do budget, full budget in June.

[Roy Belson]: We do pre-budgets as we go forward.

[Roy Belson]: In the next couple of months, you'll start seeing pre-budgets come out as the department heads

[Roy Belson]: and principals and school Councilors will come forward and tell you what they think their needs are.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll have to listen to that.

[Roy Belson]: We'll also be in collective bargaining discussions as to what we intend to do with our various unions.

[Roy Belson]: So this is a quick synopsis of the budget.

[Roy Belson]: I've also given you a couple of other articles to read in the back that you might find interesting with regard to budgets.

[Roy Belson]: They come from local publications.

[Roy Belson]: It's one of them state leaders are facing trickiest budget cycle in recent years.

[Roy Belson]: And there's another one back here that deals with the budget as well.

[Roy Belson]: So let me see if I can give you the title of that.

[Roy Belson]: So the challenges that the city faces, you know, in funding schools and other city services is really characterized by this type of funding.

[Roy Belson]: why don't we put it on an agenda for like community relations subcommittee meeting, which we can, and then possibly use our new media, you know, put it out there on the webpage and let people know the challenges the city faces.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, that's really, it's true of our virtually every city in town in the Commonwealth right now.

[Roy Belson]: And the good news is that Medford does do a lot of things locally to, to generate revenue, but it's a challenge more and more.

[Roy Belson]: The idea when two and a half came in was, is that the state would step in and pick up.

[Roy Belson]: We've intended to give people, you know, the inflation index numbers, you know, consumer price index, the other things.

[Roy Belson]: You give them an idea, but it really depends on what you're talking about, what the cost of a particular good and service is.

[Roy Belson]: Some things are inflationary, some things are deflationary.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, you have to really look at the item itself because the totality contains both inflationary and deflationary items.

[Roy Belson]: So it's not easy to just simply put a simple number, but you can give people an idea.

[Roy Belson]: Give people an idea.

[Roy Belson]: There's some Cambridge activities.

[Roy Belson]: Some people have gone to Advanced Science, a little bit further, Marlborough.

[Roy Belson]: There are a few that's better, but the big ones, Mystic Valley, Prospect Hill, and Cambridge are probably the biggest ones.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: We can give you a listing of those at this point.

[Roy Belson]: Again, let's just start off by saying, because I know it's a sensitive topic, is that not necessarily against charter schools per se, it's the funding formula that needs to be sustained.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, if you're going to say, well, this is going to happen, then it's got to happen.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise, it's just really just taking people down the road, and communities have to bear the cost.

[Roy Belson]: The state doesn't want to take on the structural deficit, so they pass it on to the community.

[Roy Belson]: That number, that $80 million, hasn't gone up in years.

[Roy Belson]: Is there a second?

[Roy Belson]: So just to cover that, I appreciate that Cheryl's done some research, but we need to be very careful of a few things.

[Roy Belson]: When people come in and give estimates, remember, we're a public entity.

[Roy Belson]: We have to go through a bid process.

[Roy Belson]: We have to pay prevailing wage.

[Roy Belson]: We have all number of things that we can't skirt around that maybe a contractor might say, you could do it for this, you could do it for that.

[Roy Belson]: We also have to concern ourselves about liability, things that are put together by people who mean well, but maybe are not professional.

[Roy Belson]: might actually get it done, but there might be something that goes wrong.

[Roy Belson]: And if it goes wrong, we could be liable.

[Roy Belson]: So the suggestions are good ones.

[Roy Belson]: We'll look into them, but there's no silver bullet on these things.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, people give us estimates all the time, some high, some low, but there are some other factors we have to pay attention to when we do procurement.

[Roy Belson]: So I just want to make sure everybody understands it's not just a simple thing.

[Roy Belson]: And when we have do things, even with the best intentions, we run into liability issues if they're not properly

[Roy Belson]: put together.

[Roy Belson]: So thanks for the ideas.

[Roy Belson]: Let's look into them, but let's be careful.

[Roy Belson]: You've got to be very careful because if you put this interlocking rubber on top of what you've got, you've got to make sure that what's below it is properly set up.

[Roy Belson]: If you have the best intentions and you do certain things, you may undercut the ability to put these things.

[Roy Belson]: There may be a shortcut or two that may seem plausible at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: I would want to make sure that it's done right because we're talking safety.

[Roy Belson]: You also have to make sure that the diameter of the rubber is at the proper thickness for the height of the structure.

[Roy Belson]: So that, I don't know what you quoted on the diameter of the rubber, but the rubber has to be a certain thickness in order to absorb shock.

[Roy Belson]: you know, that might take place.

[Roy Belson]: And we have some structures that are higher and some that are lower.

[Roy Belson]: All this should be thought through professionally, because the first time something goes wrong, there'll be some sharp lawyer out there who will take us down the street.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, well, you know, let's go over together.

[Roy Belson]: Let's go, you know No, but it doesn't have to be done by hand.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have to sign off on it.

[Roy Belson]: We sign off and send a letter of support.

[Roy Belson]: Paul Texera is working on different languages.

[Roy Belson]: But there's no reason why the English language one can't begin to be disseminated.

[Roy Belson]: When it's ready, we'll put it up as soon as it's ready to go.

[Roy Belson]: Great.

[Roy Belson]: We'll see.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to see Glenn this week anyway.

[Roy Belson]: Glenn's in Washington today, but he'll be back on this for the middle of the week.

[Roy Belson]: So Glenn is coming back from Washington.

[Roy Belson]: He wasn't sure how many nights we wanted to go with focus groups.

[Roy Belson]: He had set aside the 15th.

[Roy Belson]: or initially, but he's available on the 13th and the 14th.

[Roy Belson]: So when he comes back tomorrow, I'll have a discussion with him as to whether he thinks we can do two a night or two, you know, or, or three a night if it necessary or needs a couple of days to do it.

[Roy Belson]: Two a night?

[Roy Belson]: Well, you have, you know, an hour for one group, an hour for another group.

[Roy Belson]: You are an hour and a half for one group, an hour and a half for another group.

[Roy Belson]: Could be.

[Roy Belson]: Could be.

[Roy Belson]: But Glenn's going to be around.

[Roy Belson]: So Mayor and members of the committee, earlier in the minutes you heard that we approved

[Roy Belson]: retaining Massachusetts Association of School Committees to be our agent to advance the search.

[Roy Belson]: This afternoon, the mayor and I met with Glenn Kuchar, the executive director of MASC, and went over all the different functions and activities that they can assist us with.

[Roy Belson]: And it's quite substantial.

[Roy Belson]: And as you know, because we pay dues, we're not incurring an additional charge, which we might if we contracted with someone else.

[Roy Belson]: In the interim,

[Roy Belson]: We've put a pretty aggressive schedule together, as the mayor indicated, we'll clean it up tonight and get something out to you over the next day or so.

[Roy Belson]: But the first schedule was obviously the search committee, and the mayor's put something like that out.

[Roy Belson]: But in the interim, just to give you some information with regard to this particular activity,

[Roy Belson]: Glenn Kuchar indicated to us that he could distribute our brochure, he could distribute our applications, he could take in the applications as they came in, turn them around very quickly, give us a tiering as to who's eligible and not, just simply by licensure and a few things like that, get it over to the search committee, generally within a day, believe it or not.

[Roy Belson]: and create the circumstances in which this would go forward.

[Roy Belson]: We'd also work on creating focus groups and other aspects of this search site visits and other things that you may want to do or not want to do.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly this will take us into high gear with the idea being that a decision would be made sometime at the beginning of April.

[Roy Belson]: And this is the path we're on so

[Roy Belson]: The report I'm giving you right now gives you an idea that he'll get it out to a wide audience to help us screen the applicants to make sure the people are eligible.

[Roy Belson]: The search committee will get every applicant, whether they consider them eligible or not, in hard copy as well as electronically.

[Roy Belson]: The survey developed by the school committee, I want to talk to Mr. Rousseau about that.

[Roy Belson]: He will assist in getting that out and pulling those results together along with the focus groups.

[Roy Belson]: Again, pulling it together so that it takes the burden off any one member to do that or the administrations to keep it clean.

[Roy Belson]: He'll assist in the preparation of interviews, questions for you to help you develop questions and appropriate information so you can group them properly.

[Roy Belson]: I went through a process of how they do that.

[Roy Belson]: And then, of course, following up with contract negotiations with the successful candidate or the candidate that you select.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot here.

[Roy Belson]: Clearly, having an agent on board moves it forward, takes the burden off us to do it, and it keeps us on track to have a decision by April, hopefully.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the one thing we've got to understand is that when materials come in, it's confidential at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Just because you get something doesn't mean you go talking about who applied, because people are entitled to a certain amount of privacy.

[Roy Belson]: Once it reaches the final stage, privacy's off.

[Roy Belson]: And then people can see it, there'll be public interviews, there'll be all the kinds of things that will give the community total transparency as to the process.

[Roy Belson]: It's very extensive, and I think that based on the discussions we had today and based on what you will learn in the next few days, that you'll see this is a very, very wide open search.

[Roy Belson]: It's intended to bring in candidates around.

[Roy Belson]: He's in Lexington tonight.

[Roy Belson]: I think Lexington's about to make a decision tonight on its selection and a few other communities that'll be moving forward.

[Roy Belson]: And I think we'll be excited to see pools of candidates come into our program.

[Roy Belson]: So with that, I think that gives you an update on MASC's involvement.

[Roy Belson]: Quickly came to the table with us today.

[Roy Belson]: Remember, we only did it last week and quickly came to the table today to work out some details.
