[Roy Belson]: So the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education has launched an initiative which will celebrate Massachusetts and Massachusetts' achievements as leading the nation.

[Roy Belson]: Massachusetts, as you know, leads the nation in typical test scores and other kinds of indicators.

[Roy Belson]: Also, if you look at the PISA results, the international results, if Massachusetts counts itself as a nation, which we do in the rankings, we're always very close to the top, if not on top.

[Roy Belson]: Massachusetts has decided through the department to celebrate that and they've begun a project to provide a statewide platform for public schools in Massachusetts to celebrate their great achievements.

[Roy Belson]: We've already begun to pull together highlights and other things that are particular to us that go beyond testing.

[Roy Belson]: that highlight the kinds of educational programs that we're running, that we believe make Massachusetts not only tops in those categories of testing, but actually makes Massachusetts, in places like Medford, renowned for doing some terrific programs, whether it's Global Scholars, CCSR,

[Roy Belson]: or other things that you have heard about over the years.

[Roy Belson]: I want to make you aware of it, because we're going to start to ramp up very soon.

[Roy Belson]: And we hope that you'll all participate.

[Roy Belson]: And you can see some of the things that are going to go on statewide at the Statehouse and other activities, which will give us an opportunity to highlight our school systems.

[Roy Belson]: We'll also use our various media to talk about the things that are going well in our community and neighboring communities and the things we collaborate with.

[Roy Belson]: So that's just an informational piece for you right now to let you know and welcome any ideas that you may have.

[Roy Belson]: We've actually got some interviews going on, I believe, the end of this week.

[Roy Belson]: They'll be interviewing, they've narrowed it down to three finalists, a person who's a deputy commissioner in the state of New York, a person who's a deputy commissioner in the state of Texas, and the current superintendent of the Lawrence Public Schools have been designated as the three finalists.

[Roy Belson]: The board will interview them and potentially even next week, they'll make a decision and make their recommendation to the Secretary of Education, Mr. Pizer.

[Roy Belson]: will have an affirmation or a veto at his discretion.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully we'll have someone in place very soon in that role.

[Roy Belson]: When that person will actually take office, I don't know.

[Roy Belson]: It probably depends on their current contracts and their current obligations.

[Roy Belson]: But I assume that in the interim, Jeff Wilson will continue to be the acting commissioner until that person can actually assume the role.

[Roy Belson]: So we expect that to happen fairly soon.

[Roy Belson]: And I'll get you posted as soon as I know.

[Roy Belson]: They've named three finalists.

[Roy Belson]: So if I want to speculate, I might have thoughts, but it would be inappropriate.

[Roy Belson]: I'll keep you posted.

[Roy Belson]: So as our community becomes culturally and religiously diverse more so than

[Roy Belson]: It has been, although, you know, it's quite a change.

[Roy Belson]: In 1982, 4% of our school population were persons of color.

[Roy Belson]: Today, it's close to 38%.

[Roy Belson]: You have an idea of what's taken place over time.

[Roy Belson]: But as we become more culturally diverse and religiously diverse, it's incumbent upon us to actively ensure that our students, employees, citizens are treated with respect and dignity, and that they celebrate their personal cultures and religious observances.

[Roy Belson]: So adopting appropriate inclusive holidays, observances, protocols does not violate the establishment clause of the Constitution.

[Roy Belson]: There's a difference between establishing religion and just allowing people to celebrate.

[Roy Belson]: It's a distinct difference.

[Roy Belson]: Rather it protects it by recognizing the rich diversity of people's experiences.

[Roy Belson]: Massachusetts laws prohibit discrimination in all its forms.

[Roy Belson]: The best way to ensure that discrimination does not occur is to educate our students and community through positive learning and experience.

[Roy Belson]: We must always seek to move forward, to go beyond toleration to understanding, an enlightened understanding for both our diverse and common human heritage.

[Roy Belson]: The topic is far too involved to have a broad discussion this evening, but we need to invest more time through focus groups and additional sessions.

[Roy Belson]: In the interim, I've provided you with some materials in preparation for a more robust discussion.

[Roy Belson]: And we certainly will include people, and I've listed holidays and other things that deal with inclusive practices that have been put out by various agencies that are known for their expertise in this area.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, this is not only a local thing, it's a national thing, it's a statewide thing, and for us to be in the forefront of it is very important.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of good things happening in our community already, but the price of doing the right thing is eternal vigilance.

[Roy Belson]: You have to be diligent with it, you can't let it slip, and we have a lot of things going on.

[Roy Belson]: And different things will occur, and there'll be some people that perhaps don't understand it, but it's our job to make sure that everyone feels protected, feels safe, and that we don't have any situation where a person feels isolated because of the policies and practices of our school system.

[Roy Belson]: Well, what we do is you, I'll probably recognize the fact that if a person's out for those holidays and documents it as an excuse.

[Roy Belson]: We've actually had a practice of doing this.

[Roy Belson]: So every year we go through various stages of why we close school and why we keep open.

[Roy Belson]: And some people understand it, and some people agree, and some people don't agree.

[Roy Belson]: I found the last little while, the people who are more aggressively emailing me are generally students.

[Roy Belson]: High school students.

[Roy Belson]: Generally around 8 o'clock or the morning before a storm, I'm getting things being told that their life is being put in peril, and we're endangering them and their families.

[Roy Belson]: And I write back to them as courteously as I possibly can.

[Roy Belson]: But for the most part, people do understand it.

[Roy Belson]: But I want to take a little bit of opportunity in between storms, if you will, to go over a couple of things.

[Roy Belson]: So if people are listening, and we'll put it on our website again, they'll get an idea as to how we make these decisions.

[Roy Belson]: We want to keep open if we can.

[Roy Belson]: There are many youngsters out there who have no one supervising them if we close the schools.

[Roy Belson]: There are many youngsters out there who have no one feeding them if we close the schools.

[Roy Belson]: On the other hand, if conditions warrant it, having youngsters out in the cold and driving snow, possibly with vehicles sliding on the road, has to be balanced.

[Roy Belson]: with our decision to open the schools.

[Roy Belson]: Parents always have the opportunity to make a decision.

[Roy Belson]: And if they documented that they kept the youngster home because of the weather, and we have a reason to believe that the weather was that way, we will provide an excused absence.

[Roy Belson]: If, in fact, a youngster comes to us late on a day when conditions are such, rather than delay the whole day, which could mess up a number of things for a number of people,

[Roy Belson]: We won't mark them tardy to the extent that there's a reasonable arrival.

[Roy Belson]: If they come in two minutes before the closing, we might think that that's not reasonable.

[Roy Belson]: But if they're an hour or so late, that's not a bad problem for us to recognize that as part of travel conditions.

[Roy Belson]: So we're entering the winter season.

[Roy Belson]: We're in the winter season.

[Roy Belson]: And from year to year, we may have more or less closings because of weather, or cold, or any other number of reasons.

[Roy Belson]: Or for some reason that there's a building problem, or a safety problem that's different.

[Roy Belson]: We will use our media to inform people.

[Roy Belson]: We use all the television media.

[Roy Belson]: We use our own media to put things out.

[Roy Belson]: We use robocalls.

[Roy Belson]: We do everything we possibly can to let people know as soon as possible.

[Roy Belson]: Now this last storm,

[Roy Belson]: had to wait till almost six o'clock in the morning to take a good hard look to see what would come in.

[Roy Belson]: Now I knew in this area, we weren't going to get much snow.

[Roy Belson]: But a little to the west and a little to the north and the southeast, they got snow and they got bad conditions.

[Roy Belson]: So that was a tough one because we weren't sure what actually would happen, how we would track.

[Roy Belson]: The one before, people asked me, why didn't you call off school on that Tuesday when it was cold?

[Roy Belson]: If I had called off school on that Tuesday when it was cold,

[Roy Belson]: we would have been out Thursday and Friday anyway.

[Roy Belson]: We would have had one day of school that week because Monday was a holiday.

[Roy Belson]: So sometimes you just have to balance it a little bit and think about what's going to happen.

[Roy Belson]: You also have to think about the fact that teachers and others come from distance.

[Roy Belson]: And if they have young people of their own that have to stay home with, they may not come in.

[Roy Belson]: Or if they have the travel arrangements coming from the north or the south, it may not work for them to be in and on time.

[Roy Belson]: It may not be a productive day.

[Roy Belson]: So these are all kinds of considerations.

[Roy Belson]: We have to pay attention to whether DPW and the contractors can clear out lots, whether we think that the bus buses can actually make it up and go in the various routes, whether the bus stops and the sidewalks have had an opportunity to be cleared to the greatest extent possible, although it's never perfect.

[Roy Belson]: It's very rarely perfect.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of considerations that we have to look at.

[Roy Belson]: I do talk to area colleagues as we come into this kind of season and we take a look and see what's happening and we try to make decisions that way.

[Roy Belson]: But it's very important for people to understand that schools provide safety, it provides warmth, it provides nutrition to many youngsters.

[Roy Belson]: We don't take school closings lightly.

[Roy Belson]: But if we think that safety is an issue, if we think that we can't clear the lots, we don't think we're going to have a productive day, we will call it.

[Roy Belson]: And I will try to call it as early as possible, often the night before.

[Roy Belson]: But some days it's not, we don't know until five o'clock in the morning, just the way it is.

[Roy Belson]: I would just tell you that there are people who, not what you're telling me, we should talk in the long term, but there are people who rush to do what they call blizzard packs.

[Roy Belson]: I find that unproductive.

[Roy Belson]: We pay our teachers to teach 180 days of school.

[Roy Belson]: It's not a trade-off to give kids some homework.

[Roy Belson]: They're supposed to do homework anyway.

[Roy Belson]: The reality is that we want our teachers in front of students, and they don't want to trade days.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if we get hit like the storm of 1978, we're out a whole week or ten days or something like that, we could probably have a plan in place to send materials out, especially with today's electronics.

[Roy Belson]: I think we should be very careful that we start trading days for short-term days off.

[Roy Belson]: But I hear what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: If it's long-term, maybe we should consider it through a meeting.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah.

[Roy Belson]: We sent you out, you know, on that particular day, I sent you out attendance.

[Roy Belson]: And the high school was not badly attended that day.

[Roy Belson]: It was over 80% of the people that were there.

[Roy Belson]: That's pretty good since normal attendance is in the low 90s, you know.

[Roy Belson]: And so, you know, plus teachers, there weren't that many people.

[Roy Belson]: There were people out, but there weren't that many people out comparatively to what could have been out.

[Roy Belson]: As far as the cold goes, part of the issue was the fact that it came on so suddenly.

[Roy Belson]: Certain areas of the building were still trying to adjust.

[Roy Belson]: But we can work on the heating system.

[Roy Belson]: We can work on different aspects of it.

[Roy Belson]: But a lot of people were in school.

[Roy Belson]: And for the 80% plus of the people that were in school, I think it was good to have them there, as opposed to shut it down and then everyone's out.

[Roy Belson]: We'd end up making it up, and I think it was a day to have, especially that week.

[Roy Belson]: Because remember, again, if we called off school that day, we were in school potentially Wednesday.

[Roy Belson]: That was a whole week would have been gone.

[Roy Belson]: So at least we got a couple days in.

[Roy Belson]: I hear what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: We'll certainly work on that.

[Roy Belson]: John and I will check.

[Roy Belson]: We'll certainly have the principals review that as a practice so that they understand that, check the room out.

[Roy Belson]: Put them in the warmest place as possible.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor and members of the school committee, we had an extensive discussion in the committee of the whole.

[Roy Belson]: And again, just to briefly summarize it,

[Roy Belson]: The organizations that exist to support our schools are all good people.

[Roy Belson]: They're working hard.

[Roy Belson]: They give up a lot of their time.

[Roy Belson]: They generate a lot of support for our schools.

[Roy Belson]: We're very grateful and thankful.

[Roy Belson]: However, in order to optimize it, in order to make it more efficient and more effective overall across the city, and in order to tie it together with our own work, it's important for us to adopt some guidelines, adopt some training protocols, so that we can help these organizations do that much better.

[Roy Belson]: and to dovetail much better with us.

[Roy Belson]: So I've put together for you some recommendations to adopt oversight guidelines for PTOs, PTGs, and other 501c3 internal organizations.

[Roy Belson]: And I say internal organizations because I'm not talking about if a major corporation's 501c3 gives us money, I'm not going to ask them to audit their books.

[Roy Belson]: But I'm talking about groups that technically work with us or use our name.

[Roy Belson]: So if

[Roy Belson]: Michael Bloomberg gives us some money.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not going to ask him for his financials this week.

[Roy Belson]: I guess he probably wouldn't send them to me anyway.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, our Cummings Foundation, things like that, they give us money and I'm appreciative that they do.

[Roy Belson]: But I'm talking about the internal groups that are clearly ours.

[Roy Belson]: And so I've listed eight items and I would ask that you approve them.

[Roy Belson]: I can read them off or you can accept them as they're written.

[Roy Belson]: Let me know what you're... Would you like me to read them?

[Roy Belson]: Up to you.

[Roy Belson]: I can read them.

[Roy Belson]: One, all PTG, PTOs, and other internal 501c3 organizations affiliated with the Medford Public Schools must be registered with the superintendent's office annually.

[Roy Belson]: All registrations must be renewed by September 1st of each year.

[Roy Belson]: A registration is simply a process of recognizing that an organization exists, and if they're out in the street, that there's a number they can have, and if a person who's a member of the community wants to donate, they know this is a valid organization.

[Roy Belson]: And we also know that they exist, and they're using our name and raising money using our name.

[Roy Belson]: To all registered organizations.

[Roy Belson]: MPS 1234, whatever it is.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: Just a very simple thing, but I want to know they exist.

[Roy Belson]: Who they are.

[Roy Belson]: You'll see it as it comes down.

[Roy Belson]: Well, it'll come down.

[Roy Belson]: You'll see it.

[Roy Belson]: You'll see the things that will be on the form.

[Roy Belson]: Who the officers are, and so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: Where they're banking, and the likes of this.

[Roy Belson]: All registered organizations must submit bylaws, names of officers and board members, annual fundraising and expenditure plans, and a year-end financial statement.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, we want to know that every organization has some rules.

[Roy Belson]: We want to know that they have a plan, that it's not just something.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if they want to modify it, they can let us know they want to modify it.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not running around trying to second guess every move, but they should have a plan.

[Roy Belson]: And another reason for that is the fact that if everyone hits the same bank,

[Roy Belson]: And everyone hits the same business over and over again.

[Roy Belson]: We're working on our community pretty hard.

[Roy Belson]: And also, when the school department goes to them for various things, they might say, but I already gave.

[Roy Belson]: So it's important for us to know who

[Roy Belson]: is being asked for money, who is being repeatedly asked for money, who is being repeatedly asked for services, and whether or not it interferes with something that might be a larger project that the school department might be able to do for the greater benefit of all.

[Roy Belson]: You can modify it.

[Roy Belson]: You can make changes.

[Roy Belson]: It's a projection.

[Roy Belson]: It's like our budget.

[Roy Belson]: We project certain things and changes happen during the year.

[Roy Belson]: It's just nature.

[Roy Belson]: You can just send in a note, say we did something different or we added something.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe it doesn't have to be that tight.

[Roy Belson]: Let me keep going and then we can hit it all.

[Roy Belson]: Some of these things intersect with each other.

[Roy Belson]: Three, bylaws must clearly identify how a person becomes eligible for membership and how a person becomes a voting member.

[Roy Belson]: Distinct difference.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, a person comes to a meeting, they may be a member, but if they've been to one meeting in three years, do they have the right to make decisions for a group of people that have been working on it for an extended period of time?

[Roy Belson]: That's a decision people can make.

[Roy Belson]: Bylaws must identify what is a voting quorum.

[Roy Belson]: Some of them, three people in the room could be a voting quorum.

[Roy Belson]: Is that a voting quorum?

[Roy Belson]: Do you have to have so many members of the executive board to be a voting quorum?

[Roy Belson]: Do you have to have so many members of the established membership to make a major decision?

[Roy Belson]: Bylaws must provide detailed information how, when elections for officers and board members will be implemented.

[Roy Belson]: When is it going to happen?

[Roy Belson]: What is the process?

[Roy Belson]: What is the distribution of information so that people know that an election is coming?

[Roy Belson]: Expenditures of funds must be done in coordination with the principal to ensure that supported programs, activities, and materials are consistent with the school's program and do not distract from the main mission of the school.

[Roy Belson]: We can't have an organization decide to buy a new curriculum that is counter-indicative to the ones the school system has adopted.

[Roy Belson]: We can't have people planning trips that get in the way of testing or planning trips that

[Roy Belson]: come just as the testing season's about to begin.

[Roy Belson]: We're planning trips that are not tied to the curriculum in an important way.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe once in a while, but not all the time.

[Roy Belson]: Remember, we only have 180 days of school.

[Roy Belson]: We want to make sure all of them are used properly.

[Roy Belson]: The public schools through the superintendents offer training to each entity.

[Roy Belson]: We want to make sure they all know what forms they have to fill out, if they're raising funds, if they're a non-profit.

[Roy Belson]: We want them to understand regulations and ordinances, what they can do.

[Roy Belson]: If you pay somebody money, and you pay them a certain amount of money, guess what?

[Roy Belson]: You've gotta give them a form where technically you're paying them under the table.

[Roy Belson]: It's not acceptable.

[Roy Belson]: If you're giving people money as reimbursement, reimbursement for what?

[Roy Belson]: What are you requiring?

[Roy Belson]: I mean, tonight you asked about slips and things like that.

[Roy Belson]: It's all heavily documented when it comes through the school system.

[Roy Belson]: Are we documenting these things?

[Roy Belson]: Gives us an idea of those things.

[Roy Belson]: And if a person doesn't participate and doesn't become these things, then we maybe decertify them and say, look, we're not going to register you.

[Roy Belson]: You're not going to be an allowable organization because we can't track what you're doing.

[Roy Belson]: And then an annual report should be made to the school committee about all the organizations that exist.

[Roy Belson]: And the general thing, there may not be every expenditure they have, but it certainly should give you an idea of what started the year, what ended the year, and the main activities and the like that they had, and if they had an election, did they change officers, if there were special circumstances, was it reported.

[Roy Belson]: And I think if we do something like that, we'll have helped these organizations be that much better.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll help ourselves as we try to coordinate their activities with our initiatives as well.

[Roy Belson]: So I guess the floor is open for discussion.

[Roy Belson]: I think we're looking at people who don't have experience.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, if a person's been doing it and doing it successfully, you don't have to go to things.

[Roy Belson]: We don't have our teachers take courses that they've already passed and know.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes there's a refresher.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes there's new rules.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes there's new forms that need to be filed.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes there's changes.

[Roy Belson]: That may work.

[Roy Belson]: As far as the governance structure goes and elections, if there's no one running, you just simply certify it through the principal's office that we only have so many people.

[Roy Belson]: But you've got to let people know because, I mean, one of the complaints that we heard, rightly or wrongly, I'm not taking sides on this thing, was that people didn't know how you become an officer or how you participate.

[Roy Belson]: And theoretically, under the school councils, you're supposed to have that election every year.

[Roy Belson]: It's required.

[Roy Belson]: by the statute.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I know it doesn't always happen 100%, but it should.

[Roy Belson]: You know what I mean?

[Roy Belson]: Or at least there should be some declaration that the only people that applied for these offices or want to do it are a handful of people, but after a reasonable attempt.

[Roy Belson]: I think we've got to do that, or else people say, well, I'm not involved.

[Roy Belson]: I don't get involved.

[Roy Belson]: They don't consult me.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, what's part of the discussion?

[Roy Belson]: Are people consulted?

[Roy Belson]: Do they have a chance to participate?

[Roy Belson]: I mean, one of the issues I think you raised during the campaign was community engagement.

[Roy Belson]: Well, does the PTO engage the community that it represents?

[Roy Belson]: I don't know.

[Roy Belson]: So I think there's a balance there.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think we have to make it into a very rigorous process, but I do think there should be some notification that there are officers available, there are board positions available.

[Roy Belson]: Would you like to participate?

[Roy Belson]: Just a thought.

[Roy Belson]: Is that the appropriate subcommittee?

[Roy Belson]: Let's, you know, let's, let's understand what these subcommittees are supposed to do.

[Roy Belson]: Support services deals primarily with services that support the educational program.

[Roy Belson]: This is more rules of, this is more of the rules of the operation.

[Roy Belson]: You know, I'm just, you know, I'm just trying to clarify for you because I mean, if you want to keep some integrity to your subcommittee assignments, you can do what you want.

[Roy Belson]: Why don't we get it from the minutes, and then we'll move it over.

[Roy Belson]: I believe we made the adjustments you asked for.

[Roy Belson]: The amounts and thresholds in the area, so I'd ask that you approve it.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, let's keep it simple.

[Roy Belson]: Let's keep it simple.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, if there's a situation that requires an additional cost, we'll bring it back to you.

[Roy Belson]: But if there's no such, you know, cost, let's not make people come back and forth five times.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, the goal of this was to be inclusive and to provide appropriate care.

[Roy Belson]: If it turns out that we have a situation, we'll bring it back.

[Roy Belson]: Well, we'll move through it.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, there's some people that resist any,

[Roy Belson]: early this evening you're telling me that I'm making things too bureaucratic for the PTO.

[Roy Belson]: An inauguration is a ceremony that provides us with an opportunity to rededicate ourselves, our leaders, our citizens, to the promotion and achievement of a high quality of life for all.

[Roy Belson]: In Medford, we have a firm foundation of quality that can be built upon to meet the challenges and aspirations of the future.

[Roy Belson]: Go ahead.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah.

[Roy Belson]: So this evening, I passed out an update based on our discussions about what might be possible in order to provide additional assistance to students at the Columbus.

[Roy Belson]: In your packets, you have a much more comprehensive discussion about additional measures that we're doing, but apropos to some suggestions made from the outside, including Mrs. Ronay, I put this memo together to give you a clarification, an update of what additional things we're going to do, and if you'll permission, I'll read it publicly so everyone can hear it.

[Roy Belson]: Do you have a copy?

[Roy Belson]: As part of our plan to assist students at the Columbus with their mathematics preparation for MCAS 2.0, please note the following.

[Roy Belson]: Students in grades three, four, and five who require extra assistance to master the mathematics curriculum will be eligible to receive additional tutoring from paid Medford Public Schools teachers.

[Roy Belson]: Students will receive between one and two hours per week based upon their need.

[Roy Belson]: It depends on what the student's need is,

[Roy Belson]: you know, what kinds of recommendations their individual teachers make.

[Roy Belson]: We expect to hire six teachers for two hours each as tutors a week, who will be paid by the Medford Public Schools from our budget.

[Roy Belson]: This program is planned for 16 weeks starting in January, and the projected cost is an additional $6,200.

[Roy Belson]: We project that the cost of an extra afternoon bus at the Columbus will be paid approximately $150 a day for a total of $4,800.

[Roy Belson]: We're working with our current provider, Easton Bus, to arrange a schedule.

[Roy Belson]: We may have to find another provider since Easton's schedule is very tight and additional busing may not be possible through them, although we had discussions with them this afternoon and we think it is possible.

[Roy Belson]: But since there are three buses leaving the Columbus each day with different routes,

[Roy Belson]: We will have to devise a route that serves the majority of students in the program.

[Roy Belson]: And there may be a need to create a consolidated route.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, buses go in different directions.

[Roy Belson]: In order for us to create a consolidated route, there may have to be some different types of stops.

[Roy Belson]: The overall cost of transportation, we believe, will be about $4,800.

[Roy Belson]: Since there are, well, the overall cost then is projected between tutorial and busing to be about $11,200 for the 16 weeks.

[Roy Belson]: There are multiple logistical issues to be worked out and there may need to be some modifications.

[Roy Belson]: We'll make those adjustments based upon multiple factors.

[Roy Belson]: We'll keep the school committee informed as we progress with implementation.

[Roy Belson]: Things like which teachers volunteer to teach, which days are most appropriate, which days the buses can go and what routes and so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: That's the way we're planning it right now.

[Roy Belson]: That's a variable we should look at, but I don't want to make any commitments till I see exactly how many students are riding the bus for this particular program, because I just don't know.

[Roy Belson]: It could be concentrated in a full bus.

[Roy Belson]: It could be that we have a lot of room.

[Roy Belson]: So let us get into the weeds, and we'll see exactly what's possible.

[Roy Belson]: We'll sit with the teachers and the principal to look at which students clearly need it.

[Roy Belson]: If a student's doing exceptionally well, then chances are they don't want the help.

[Roy Belson]: If a student really needs it, we hope that they will want to participate.

[Roy Belson]: I can't make anybody participate.

[Roy Belson]: There's some people that maybe don't want to participate who could use the help.

[Roy Belson]: I think we've got to begin with, let's target the students that we're looking at, and then we can

[Roy Belson]: open it up a little bit more.

[Roy Belson]: But let's see exactly what kind of response we've got.

[Roy Belson]: And I've also got to make sure I've got six teachers that want to do it.

[Roy Belson]: And I feel they can actually do that particular work.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a few things that variables, like I say, the logistics have to be worked out.

[Roy Belson]: And until we actually talk to people specifically at the school and work out some of the details as to how many students would be on which days, there may be some students who want to come one day, some will want to come two days.

[Roy Belson]: Got to work it out.

[Roy Belson]: If I can just suggest that, what do you call it, that the update, I can give you a briefer update through email or through some process, but it may take an extra little time to work out some of the logistics.

[Roy Belson]: Because remember, next week is going to be a fairly, well this week rather, is going to be a fairly chopped up week with different things going on, and the logistics of getting commitments from people to do things may take a little bit of time in January.

[Roy Belson]: We'll keep you posted.

[Roy Belson]: That's our plan.

[Roy Belson]: outreaches to different people at different times because obviously philanthropy is an important piece of what we do in order to keep some of these programs going and to develop them into model programs that can then receive even greater sources of funding long term.

[Roy Belson]: And obviously the great work, I think, you know, they'll tell you that they're finalists already in some outside programs.

[Roy Belson]: We're already getting some great recognition.

[Roy Belson]: I won't spoil this at this particular thing, but I was told on Saturday night that another one of our programs is going to go national.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm excited about that, but you can't find out about it tonight because I can't tell you why.

[Roy Belson]: But these are the kinds of things we want to do.

[Roy Belson]: And as we do these things, we attract sources of funding that are extraordinary and support our efforts to keep

[Roy Belson]: meaningful projects moving in addition to our regular academic and educational program.

[Roy Belson]: We just need to develop it over time, you know what I mean, and develop other dimensions to it and create it in a certain way.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things that's happening, again something I'll tell you about,

[Roy Belson]: at a subsequent meeting, is the Commonwealth Department of Elementary and Secondary Education is launching what they call it Celebrating Massachusetts Leading the Nation.

[Roy Belson]: And we had a meeting with representatives from the department the other day and the purpose of it was to identify projects in our school system and some other school systems that would demonstrate how Massachusetts leads the nation beyond testing.

[Roy Belson]: Because obviously testing is something that

[Roy Belson]: we brag about as a nation, I mean, as a school system, not a school system, as a state, as a commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: But there are many other dimensions to education that Massachusetts leads the nation in.

[Roy Belson]: And this is a good example of it.

[Roy Belson]: And there's some other really terrific examples, our family networks, other things like that, that are really unique and model programs that other people should be trying to do.

[Roy Belson]: because they fill the gaps that many communities don't have.

[Roy Belson]: So this is one of them, and this will also bring in resources.

[Roy Belson]: This is how you do it.

[Roy Belson]: So we heard from the Massachusetts School Building Authority and the statement of interest that we put in place last year, last April, is not going forward in this round.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I had a good long chat with

[Roy Belson]: executives in the MSBA.

[Roy Belson]: And without going through the whole report, a year ago, 26 projects were approved based on available funding.

[Roy Belson]: This year, only 15 could be approved based on available funding.

[Roy Belson]: But we were strongly encouraged to go forward, to resubmit, to push the button, get it back in.

[Roy Belson]: And I have a feeling that a year from now, we'll be in the hunt.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, there's work to be done.

[Roy Belson]: We update a few more things that are in the proposal.

[Roy Belson]: But I think it's going to go forward, and I think it's just a year delay.

[Roy Belson]: Just one of those things happens, and sometimes

[Roy Belson]: The money coming from the pool is greater or smaller.

[Roy Belson]: It just happened to be one of those years.

[Roy Belson]: So from 26 to 15 projects, it is what it is.

[Roy Belson]: It hasn't been released yet, but when it's released, we'll know.

[Roy Belson]: I was told by the senior staff and their key people that the fact they came out and visited us on a full blown visit with architects and engineers, that we were very close.

[Roy Belson]: We're going for the core program.

[Roy Belson]: The core program is April.

[Roy Belson]: The accelerated repair, we already got money from boilers for that.

[Roy Belson]: It's really a much smaller and more targeted program.

[Roy Belson]: This is much more expansive.

[Roy Belson]: has longer term value to us.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to come back to you for approval.

[Roy Belson]: We're just going to look over the application to see if there's any changes we want to make, if there's anything we want to emphasize or modify a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: And then we go back to the council and ask them to certify as well.

[Roy Belson]: I think that they obviously prioritize by need, but they also prioritize by money.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have a project like ours, which could be a very expensive project, they had to be able to fit it in.

[Roy Belson]: So.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: There are projects we'll go forward with, and there are projects that we should try to match up with MSBA because they're very expensive projects.

[Roy Belson]: But there's plenty of projects we could go forward.

[Roy Belson]: We'll be going to the Council on Technology in January and a couple of other things.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to keep moving.

[Roy Belson]: It's just a question of trying to get somebody else's money to purchase our own resources.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, so this is a report you've asked for.

[Roy Belson]: The committee has a much more detailed report.

[Roy Belson]: I don't

[Roy Belson]: as a rule, issue anything on security that could lead to someone perhaps interfering with our operations.

[Roy Belson]: So the cover report speaks for itself.

[Roy Belson]: The committee, if you want to ask me specific questions at some point, please do.

[Roy Belson]: But for the general public, let's just simply say that we've spent approximately $200,000 on security camera upgrades and replacements at our schools.

[Roy Belson]: security cameras, especially external ones, are very fragile devices.

[Roy Belson]: Over the years they have been susceptible to adverse weather conditions, unpredictable power outages.

[Roy Belson]: The newer models are a little bit more resilient.

[Roy Belson]: but are not invincible, and they're not invulnerable.

[Roy Belson]: Placement of external cameras on metal poles outside of the buildings tend to make them susceptible to lightning strikes, so we want to minimize that as much as possible.

[Roy Belson]: There are a few cameras we have no choice but to put them on metal poles because of the angle, but we try to minimize that and reduce that.

[Roy Belson]: We've contracted with American Alarm to upgrade and replace various cameras district-wide.

[Roy Belson]: There's 154 cameras across the district in our nine schools.

[Roy Belson]: And believe at this time that we have sufficient coverage to

[Roy Belson]: ensure security.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously there's some cameras watching different things that aren't as essential as the main cameras that are watching entrances, exits, and main pathways in the school.

[Roy Belson]: And you know, some of those are still a little bit more work to do, but you can see from the backup report that most of it's being done and will be done very quickly.

[Roy Belson]: The maintenance of full security coverage will require that we annually budget significant funding.

[Roy Belson]: It's not something that we can just look at every once every five years or four years

[Roy Belson]: It may be prudent to set aside funding and a special account to ensure that it'll be used each year for upgrades and replacements, as well as other security equipment that's related to that, like the Raptor equipment and things like that, because those things wear out after a period of time.

[Roy Belson]: If it's not used in any given year, we can roll it over and use it in the year that we absolutely need it.

[Roy Belson]: Security cameras, I need to emphasize, are only one element of our overall school security and safety response system.

[Roy Belson]: We continue to interact with public safety agencies and to practice special situation drills at all of our schools.

[Roy Belson]: You have specifics, I would ask that the committee wants to talk to me about it and do it personally.

[Roy Belson]: I'd rather not be talking about anything specific about security that might lead someone to gain the system help.

[Roy Belson]: Cameras are two types.

[Roy Belson]: Cameras that move and pan an area.

[Roy Belson]: Cameras that are fixed on an area.

[Roy Belson]: The cameras that move are very expensive, but they're also more susceptible to needing more repair and upgrades.

[Roy Belson]: We have upgraded our cameras many times since they were first installed, since 2001 and 2003.

[Roy Belson]: The system's changed.

[Roy Belson]: They no longer run DVRs.

[Roy Belson]: They're now more digital.

[Roy Belson]: Other things are different than when they originally were installed.

[Roy Belson]: Cabling has to be different.

[Roy Belson]: They have to be locked into 911 right now.

[Roy Belson]: So all these things require upgrades.

[Roy Belson]: And they'll continue to require upgrades as we go forward.

[Roy Belson]: So we've got good coverage.

[Roy Belson]: Some cameras cover the same area, but they cover it from a little different angle.

[Roy Belson]: As we talk and we set up our meeting, perhaps we can go into an executive session allowable for security purposes, I'll give you more detail.

[Roy Belson]: But I think at this particular point, we're in good shape and I think we move forward.

[Roy Belson]: I appreciate the fact that the mayor has authorized us to spend.

[Roy Belson]: for the security cameras because this is a big expense.

[Roy Belson]: I also want to thank Christine because Christine did an awful lot of work putting it together with Alan Arena in my office to ensure that we did all the work that needed to be done.

[Roy Belson]: Let me provide you with an update rather than try to talk about it.

[Roy Belson]: It's a big discussion about doors because even though we lock doors, we have buzzer systems and the like, somebody from the inside could let somebody in.

[Roy Belson]: make sure that people know that that's not allowed.

[Roy Belson]: I'd like to set up, if I could, a special meeting for this purpose, because I don't want to talk about security in public.

[Roy Belson]: I just think if we start talking about security, if we start opening up what is and what isn't, it's not going to work.

[Roy Belson]: When do we make it?

[Roy Belson]: As soon as possible.

[Roy Belson]: It could be the beginning of February.

[Roy Belson]: We want to get the work done, and we want to get a lot of other things in place so we can be complete in our discussion.

[Roy Belson]: I mean sorry charge policy I'm going to call upon our director of finance and administration to talk to you about this.

[Roy Belson]: It's a requirement of the federal government.

[Roy Belson]: So I think it's important that you understand one fundamental point about all this.

[Roy Belson]: The federal government gives us money to subsidize lunches for free and reduced.

[Roy Belson]: If people are getting lunches who are not

[Roy Belson]: eligible because they haven't done the work or haven't, you know, filled out their work or actually been declared eligible, the federal government looks at that as us taking their money to subsidize people who otherwise should be paying.

[Roy Belson]: That's where the federal law comes into play.

[Roy Belson]: They're concerned, and by the way, there are communities in the commonwealth that have run up balances of 50, 60, $70,000, in fact,

[Roy Belson]: Was it Wellesley?

[Roy Belson]: Framingham, Wellesley, places like that really got slammed because people were taking lunches on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to have something, but it has to be reasonable so it can be defended with the feds when they come in and do the audit.

[Roy Belson]: But the reason behind it is when they give us a free lunch and they pay for it, they're saying that we want to pay the kid that's eligible.

[Roy Belson]: We don't want to pay for somebody who's just never paying.

[Roy Belson]: That's the way they look at it.

[Roy Belson]: So we've got to find some way to get something on the books.

[Roy Belson]: If not tonight, we certainly have to do it early in January.

[Roy Belson]: And if you want us to come back with something a little less, let's say, severe as far as we're looking at it, that's fine.

[Roy Belson]: But we've got to do something that's got to be on the books.

[Roy Belson]: So, Dr. Perreault is here.

[Roy Belson]: I gave you two reports tonight.

[Roy Belson]: One is on the bus situation and the other is on vaping.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think we need major discussion tonight, but I want to give you an opportunity to get up-to-date on this so you're aware of what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: And you can follow up and I'll give you additional information as we go forward.

[Roy Belson]: Dr. Perreault has met with us today, and we've met with the bus company, we've met with the police, we've done a whole pile of things.

[Roy Belson]: You know, is it?

[Roy Belson]: So let me answer that a little bit, because we had an interesting discussion with the police.

[Roy Belson]: It seems that preferred seating is the back of the bus.

[Roy Belson]: They shoved to get to the back of the bus, because that's where they can have a little more mischief, perhaps, in some cases.

[Roy Belson]: And I say that benevolently, but I mean, they want to get to the back of the bus and they're trying to get preferred seating.

[Roy Belson]: Normally you like to sit up close and get off the bus faster, but that's not the case.

[Roy Belson]: So obviously we have to have a meeting with the students.

[Roy Belson]: We have to make it very, very clear that behavior on this bus is really going to be monitored very closely because

[Roy Belson]: You just can't put buses on just simply to get more of the same, because if they're going to push and shove on an uncrowded bus, they're going to push and shove on the next uncrowded bus.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to make sure that they understand that this is something, it's a privilege to ride the bus.

[Roy Belson]: We're trying very hard to give them the transportation they want.

[Roy Belson]: But they've got to work with us.

[Roy Belson]: Everyone has to own this solution.

[Roy Belson]: We also worked with the bus company, Christine worked with the bus company this afternoon, that if in fact we needed a backup bus on a given day because it was particularly cold or we anticipated bad weather.

[Roy Belson]: So let's say it was a snowstorm and we know that everyone's going to want to ride the bus.

[Roy Belson]: We could get a backup bus.

[Roy Belson]: in that situation, but then it costs us to do that.

[Roy Belson]: So we wanna do these things, we wanna have contingency plans in place, but we need the students to cooperate with us.

[Roy Belson]: As the headmaster points out, we're gonna have a meeting with them, we're gonna make it very clear.

[Roy Belson]: And if you do things you're not supposed to do, you're not gonna ride that bus, we're gonna take you off.

[Roy Belson]: The other thing that's a situation for us is that people like to go with their friends.

[Roy Belson]: We can't be in a situation where people who don't need the ride home

[Roy Belson]: get on the same bus, it just is not workable for us.

[Roy Belson]: There's a major expense with that, especially now we're talking about adding a bus to the elementary schools, we're talking about other kinds of costs, we've had to add a bus to move some ELL students to the Brooks this year.

[Roy Belson]: Transportation costs are not inexpensive.

[Roy Belson]: It costs $375 a day for a bus, times 180 days, that's a lot of money.

[Roy Belson]: So if we're going to provide services, we expect people to be respectful and we expect them to work with us.

[Roy Belson]: So we've gotta keep working at it, no question about it.

[Roy Belson]: And the injury is obviously tragic and unfortunate and we've been in contact with the family and we'll continue to be supportive to them.

[Roy Belson]: But everyone's gotta own the solution.

[Roy Belson]: It just can't be, you know, whatever you do will be okay.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to say one thing, I want to thank Justin.

[Roy Belson]: For the first time in my career, someone said I was completely correct.

[Roy Belson]: I think that, you know, Dr. Perreault is expressing extremely well is that this is a community thing.

[Roy Belson]: Parents, everyone has to be involved.

[Roy Belson]: If you put enforcement in one place, they'll go to another place.

[Roy Belson]: They'll just move the location.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to change the outlook on the dangers about it and why it's not a good idea.

[Roy Belson]: It may be something that we can look at.

[Roy Belson]: So it makes it that much more difficult to acquire the materials.

[Roy Belson]: This is a comprehensive issue, but it's not going to be done by just having a person chase somebody down the corridor.

[Roy Belson]: nice for a particular situation, but not as a solution to the larger picture.

[Roy Belson]: But anyone who knows Bob Scurry knows that Bobby really cares about kids.

[Roy Belson]: He does a lot of things that he doesn't take credit for, just quiet on the side, takes care of a kid here, takes care of a family there, and just doesn't talk about it.

[Roy Belson]: But I know about it because I hear about it.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that that really reflects on your good heart and your caring.

[Roy Belson]: And even though sometimes it looks like you've got that bravado coming on, you're really a soft puppy.

[Roy Belson]: And you really care about people.

[Roy Belson]: Go ahead.

[Roy Belson]: This evening, I passed out an update based on our discussions about what might be possible in order to provide additional assistance to students at the Columbus.

[Roy Belson]: In your packets, you have a much more comprehensive discussion about additional measures that we're doing, but apropos to some suggestions made from the outside, including Mrs. René,

[Roy Belson]: I put this memo together to give you a clarification, an update of what additional things we're going to do, and with your permission, I'll read it publicly so everyone can hear it.

[Roy Belson]: Do you have a copy?

[Roy Belson]: Yes, thank you.

[Roy Belson]: As part of our plan to assist students at the Columbus with their mathematics preparation for MCAS 2.0, please note the following.

[Roy Belson]: Students in grades 3, 4, and 5 who require extra assistance to master the mathematics curriculum will be eligible to receive additional tutoring from paid Medford Public Schools teachers.

[Roy Belson]: Students will receive between one and two hours per week based upon their need.

[Roy Belson]: It depends on what the student's need is and what kinds of recommendations their individual teachers make.

[Roy Belson]: We expect to hire six teachers for two hours each as tutors a week who will be paid by the Medford Public Schools from our budget.

[Roy Belson]: This program is planned for 16 weeks starting in January and the projected cost is an additional $6,200.

[Roy Belson]: We project that the cost of an extra afternoon bus at the Columbus will be paid approximately $150 a day for a total of $4,800.

[Roy Belson]: We're working with our current provider, Easton Bus, to arrange a schedule.

[Roy Belson]: We may have to find another provider since Easton's schedule is very tight and additional busing may not be possible through them, although we had discussions with them this afternoon and we think it is possible.

[Roy Belson]: But since there are three buses leaving the Columbus each day with different routes, we will have to devise a route that serves the majority of students in the program.

[Roy Belson]: And then maybe you need to create a consolidated route.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, buses go in different directions.

[Roy Belson]: In order for us to create a consolidated route, there may have to be some different types of stops.

[Roy Belson]: The overall cost of transportation, we believe, will be about $4,800.

[Roy Belson]: Since there are, well, the overall cost then is projected between tutorial and busing to be about $11,200 for the 16 weeks.

[Roy Belson]: There are multiple logistical issues to be worked out and there may need to be some modifications.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll make those adjustments based upon multiple factors.

[Roy Belson]: We'll keep the school committee informed as we progress with implementation.

[Roy Belson]: Things like which teachers volunteer to teach, which days are most appropriate, which days the buses can go and what routes and so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a number of things to be worked out in the interim, but this is the basic plan and hopefully that addresses your issue.

[Roy Belson]: That's the way we're planning it right now.

[Roy Belson]: That's a variable we should look at, but I don't want to make any commitments till I see exactly how many students are riding the bus for this particular program, because I just don't know.

[Roy Belson]: It could be concentrated in a full bus.

[Roy Belson]: It could be that we have a lot of room.

[Roy Belson]: So let us get into the weeds, and we'll see exactly what's possible.

[Roy Belson]: We'll sit with the teachers and the principal to look at which students clearly need it.

[Roy Belson]: If a student's doing exceptionally well, then chances are they don't want the help.

[Roy Belson]: If a student really needs it, we hope that they will want to participate.

[Roy Belson]: I can't make anybody participate.

[Roy Belson]: There's some people that maybe don't want to participate who could use the help.

[Roy Belson]: I think we've got to begin with, let's target the students that we're looking at, and then we can open it up a little bit more.

[Roy Belson]: But let's see exactly what kind of response we've got.

[Roy Belson]: And I've also got to make sure I've got six teachers that want to do it.

[Roy Belson]: And I feel they can actually do that particular work.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a few things that variables, like I say, the logistics have to be worked out.

[Roy Belson]: And until we actually talk to people specifically at the school and work out some of the details as to how many students would be on which days, there may be some students who want to come one day, some will want to come two days.

[Roy Belson]: Got to work it out.

[Roy Belson]: If I can just suggest that, what do you call it, that the update, I can give you a briefer update through email or through some process, but it may take an extra little time to work out some of the logistics.

[Roy Belson]: I won't spoil this at this particular thing, but I was told on Saturday night that another one of our programs is going to go national, so I'm excited about that, but you can't find out about it tonight because I can't tell you.

[Roy Belson]: You know, we attract sources of funding that are extraordinary and support our efforts to keep meaningful projects moving in addition to our regular academic and educational program.

[Roy Belson]: We just need to develop it over time, you know what I mean, and develop other dimensions to it and create it in a certain way.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things that's happening and something I'll tell you about at a subsequent meeting is the Commonwealth

[Roy Belson]: Department of Elementary and Secondary Education, is launching what they call Celebrating Massachusetts Leading the Nation.

[Roy Belson]: And we had a meeting with representatives from the department the other day, and the purpose of it was to identify projects in our school system and some other school systems that would demonstrate how Massachusetts leads the nation beyond testing.

[Roy Belson]: Because obviously testing is something that we brag about as a nation, I mean as a school system, not a school system, as a state, as a commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: But there are many other dimensions to education that Massachusetts leads the nation in.

[Roy Belson]: And this is a good example of it.

[Roy Belson]: And there's some other really terrific examples, our family networks, other things like that, that are really unique and model programs that other people should be trying to do.

[Roy Belson]: because they fill the gaps that many communities don't have.

[Roy Belson]: So this is one of them, and this will also bring in resources.

[Roy Belson]: This is how you do it.

[Roy Belson]: So we heard from the Massachusetts School Building Authority and the statement of interest that was put in place last year, last April, is not going forward in this round.

[Roy Belson]: executives in the MSBA.

[Roy Belson]: And without going through the whole report, a year ago 26 projects were approved based on available funding.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, there's work to be done.

[Roy Belson]: But I think it's going to go forward, and I think it's just a year delay.

[Roy Belson]: Just one of those things happens.

[Roy Belson]: And sometimes the money coming from the pool is greater or smaller.

[Roy Belson]: It just happened to be one of those years.

[Roy Belson]: So from 26 to 15 projects, it is what it is.

[Roy Belson]: Hasn't been released yet, but when it's released we'll know.

[Roy Belson]: I was told by the senior staff and their key people that the fact they came out and visited us on a full blown visit with architects and engineers, that we were very close.

[Roy Belson]: We're going for the core program.

[Roy Belson]: The core program is April.

[Roy Belson]: The accelerated repair, we already got money from boilers for that.

[Roy Belson]: It's really a much smaller and more targeted program.

[Roy Belson]: This is much more expansive and has longer term values.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah.

[Roy Belson]: I think that they obviously prioritize by need, but they also prioritize by money.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have a project like ours, which could be a very expensive project, they have to be able to fit it in.

[Roy Belson]: Staff report, please, on file.

[Roy Belson]: There are projects we'll go forward with, and there are projects that we should try to match up with MSBA because they're very expensive projects.

[Roy Belson]: But there's plenty of projects we can go forward.

[Roy Belson]: We'll be going to the council on technology in January and a couple of other things.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to keep moving.

[Roy Belson]: It's just a question of trying to get somebody else's money to purchase our own resources.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, so this is a report you've asked for.

[Roy Belson]: The committee has a much more detailed report.

[Roy Belson]: I don't, as a rule, issue anything on security that could lead to someone

[Roy Belson]: you know, perhaps interfering with our operations.

[Roy Belson]: So the cover report speaks for itself.

[Roy Belson]: The committee, if you want to ask me specific questions at some point, please do.

[Roy Belson]: But for the general public, let's just simply say that we've spent approximately $200,000 on security camera upgrades and replacements at our schools.

[Roy Belson]: Security cameras, especially external ones, are very fragile devices.

[Roy Belson]: Over the years, they have been susceptible to adverse weather conditions, unpredictable power outages.

[Roy Belson]: The newer models are a little bit more resilient, but are not invincible, and they're not invulnerable.

[Roy Belson]: Placement of external calendars, cameras rather, on metal poles outside of the buildings tend to make them susceptible to lightning strikes, so we want to minimize that as much as possible.

[Roy Belson]: There are a few cameras

[Roy Belson]: We have no choice but to put them on metal walls because of the angle, but we try to minimize that and reduce that.

[Roy Belson]: We've contracted with American Alarm to upgrade and replace various cameras district-wide.

[Roy Belson]: There's 154 cameras across the district in our nine schools, and believe at this time that we have sufficient coverage to

[Roy Belson]: ensure security.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, there's some cameras watching different things that aren't as essential as the main cameras that are watching entrances, exits, and main pathways in the school.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, some of those are still a little bit more work to do, but you can see from the backup report that most of it's being done and will be done very quickly.

[Roy Belson]: The maintenance of full security coverage will require that we annually budget

[Roy Belson]: significant funding.

[Roy Belson]: It's not something that we can just look at every once every five years or four years.

[Roy Belson]: It may be approved to set aside funding and a special account to ensure that it will be used each year for upgrades and replacements, as well as other security equipment that's related to that, like the Raptor equipment and things like that, because those things wear out after a period of time.

[Roy Belson]: If it's not used in any given year, we can roll it over.

[Roy Belson]: and use it in the year that we absolutely need it.

[Roy Belson]: Security cameras, I need to emphasize, are only one element of our overall school security and safety response system.

[Roy Belson]: We continue to interact with public safety agencies and to practice special situation drills at all of our schools.

[Roy Belson]: You have specifics.

[Roy Belson]: I would ask if the committee wants to talk to me about any of it, you know, personally.

[Roy Belson]: I'd rather not be talking about anything specific about security that might lead someone to game the system at all.

[Roy Belson]: Cameras are two types.

[Roy Belson]: Cameras that move and pan an area.

[Roy Belson]: Cameras that are fixed on an area.

[Roy Belson]: The cameras that move are very expensive, but they're also more susceptible to needing more repair and upgrades.

[Roy Belson]: We have upgraded our cameras many times since they were first installed, since 2001 and 2003.

[Roy Belson]: The system's changed.

[Roy Belson]: They no longer run DVRs.

[Roy Belson]: They're now more digital.

[Roy Belson]: Other things are different than when they originally were installed.

[Roy Belson]: Cabling has to be different.

[Roy Belson]: They have to be locked into 911 right now.

[Roy Belson]: So all these things require upgrades.

[Roy Belson]: And they'll continue to require upgrades as we go forward.

[Roy Belson]: So we've got good coverage.

[Roy Belson]: Some cameras cover the same area, but they cover it from a little different angle.

[Roy Belson]: So, as we talk and we set up a meeting, perhaps we can go into an executive session, allowable for security purposes, I'll give you more detail.

[Roy Belson]: But I think at this particular point, we're in good shape, and I think we've moved forward.

[Roy Belson]: I appreciate the fact that the mayor has authorized us to spend.

[Roy Belson]: for the security cameras because this is a big expense.

[Roy Belson]: I also want to thank Christine because Christine did an awful lot of work putting it together with Alan Arena in my office to ensure that we did all the work that needed to be done.

[Roy Belson]: Let me provide you with an update rather than try to talk about it.

[Roy Belson]: It's a big discussion about doors because even though we lock doors, we have buzzer systems and the like, somebody from the inside could let somebody in.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got to make sure that people know that that's not allowed.

[Roy Belson]: I'd like to set up, if I could, a special meeting for this purpose, because I don't want to talk about security in public.

[Roy Belson]: I just think if we start talking about security, if we start opening up what is and what isn't, it's great.

[Roy Belson]: Why don't we make it as soon as possible?

[Roy Belson]: It could be the beginning of February.

[Roy Belson]: We want to get the work done and we want to get a lot of other things in place so we can be complete in our discussion.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to call upon our Director of Finance and Administration to talk to you about this.

[Roy Belson]: It's a requirement of the federal government.

[Roy Belson]: So I think it's important that you understand one fundamental point about all this.

[Roy Belson]: The federal government gives us money to subsidize lunches for free and reduced.

[Roy Belson]: If people are getting lunches who are not eligible because they haven't either done the work or haven't, you know, filled out their work or actually been declared eligible, the federal government looks at that as us taking their money to subsidize people who otherwise should be paying.

[Roy Belson]: That's where the federal law comes into play.

[Roy Belson]: They're concerned, and by the way, there are communities in the Commonwealth that have run up balances of $50,000, $60,000, $70,000.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, was it Wellesley?

[Roy Belson]: Framingham, Wellesley, places like that really got slammed because people were taking lunches on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to have something.

[Roy Belson]: But it has to be reasonable so we can be defended with the feds when they come in and do the audit.

[Roy Belson]: But the reason behind it is when they give us a free lunch and they pay for it, they're saying that we want to pay the kid that's eligible.

[Roy Belson]: We don't want to pay for somebody who's just never paying.

[Roy Belson]: That's the way they look at it.

[Roy Belson]: So we've got to find some way to get something on the books.

[Roy Belson]: If not tonight, we certainly have to do it early in January.

[Roy Belson]: And if you want us to come back with some, you know, something a little less, let's say, severe as far as you're looking at it, that's fine.

[Roy Belson]: But we've got to do something that's got to be on the books.

[Roy Belson]: You know, is it?

[Roy Belson]: So let me answer that a little, because we had an interesting discussion with the police.

[Roy Belson]: It seems that preferred seating is the back of the bus.

[Roy Belson]: they shoved to get to the back of the bus, because that's where they can have a little more mischief, perhaps in some cases.

[Roy Belson]: And I say that benevolently, but I mean, they wanna get to the back of the bus, so they're trying to get preferred seating.

[Roy Belson]: Normally you like to sit up close and get off the bus faster, but that's not the case.

[Roy Belson]: So obviously we have to have a meeting with the students, we have to make it very, very clear that behavior on this bus is really going to be monitored very closely, because

[Roy Belson]: You just can't put buses on just simply to, you know, get more of the same, because if they're going to push and shove on an uncrowded bus, they're going to push and shove on the next uncrowded bus.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to make sure that they understand that this is something, it's a privilege to ride the bus.

[Roy Belson]: We're trying very hard to give them the transportation they want, but they've got to work with us.

[Roy Belson]: Everyone has to own the solution.

[Roy Belson]: We also worked with the bus company, Christine worked with the bus company this afternoon, that if in fact we needed a backup bus on a given day because it was particularly cold or we anticipated bad weather.

[Roy Belson]: So let's say it was a snowstorm and we know that everyone's going to want to ride the bus.

[Roy Belson]: we could get a backup bus in that situation.

[Roy Belson]: But then it costs us to do that.

[Roy Belson]: So we wanna do these things, we wanna have contingency plans in place, but we need the students to cooperate with us.

[Roy Belson]: As the headmaster points out, we're gonna have a meeting with them, we're gonna make it very clear.

[Roy Belson]: And if you do things you're not supposed to do, you're not gonna ride that bus, we're gonna take you off.

[Roy Belson]: The other thing that's a situation for us is that people like to go with their friends.

[Roy Belson]: We can't be in a situation where people who don't need the ride home get on the same bus.

[Roy Belson]: It just is not workable for us.

[Roy Belson]: There's a major expense with that.

[Roy Belson]: Especially now, we're talking about adding a bus to the elementary schools.

[Roy Belson]: We're talking about other kinds of costs.

[Roy Belson]: We've had to add a bus to move some ELL students to the Brooks this year.

[Roy Belson]: Transportation costs are not inexpensive.

[Roy Belson]: They cost $375 a day for a bus.

[Roy Belson]: times 180 days, that's a lot of money.

[Roy Belson]: So if we're going to provide services, we expect people to be respectful and we expect them to work with us.

[Roy Belson]: So we've gotta keep working at it, no question about it.

[Roy Belson]: I doubt you're going to forget.

[Roy Belson]: So, as you probably know, the state legislature has approved an option for school districts to incorporate bilingual education into the existing SEI format.

[Roy Belson]: Now, 15 years ago, Ron Unz, who came from California, pushed an initiative petition, which previously had some success in Arizona and California, and Massachusetts decided that it would adopt it as well.

[Roy Belson]: It was given great support from John Silber at the time, and also Mitt Romney, who was a gubernatorial candidate, and it carried its way.

[Roy Belson]: Since the time it's been implemented, there's been mixed results.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't, but it comes with that whole idea that, you know, everyone should speak English, and we believe they should, but how to learn to speak English, especially to learn subjects that require deep cognitive knowledge, cognitive language, is not so easily done.

[Roy Belson]: And there are reasons for blending and doing things a little bit differently.

[Roy Belson]: We obviously are looking at that.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to be waiting for the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to give us the latest guidelines as they see them.

[Roy Belson]: And we haven't seen them yet.

[Roy Belson]: We probably won't see them until either late spring or perhaps even into the summer.

[Roy Belson]: So I doubt there's going to be much done in the next fiscal year.

[Roy Belson]: We are going to look at the blend of programs and that Paul is going to come up in a minute and talk about that and how it comes together so that we can take advantage of the law where it's appropriate while at the same time not lose track of situations which are best served by the current SEI.

[Roy Belson]: Also, as you probably know, our teachers have

[Roy Belson]: been working to get SCI endorsements, which are required now for teachers who work with students who have EL requirements, and the vast majority of faculty members do, especially in the core academic areas.

[Roy Belson]: However, there's still some gaps, and there's still a need to continue pushing that as people

[Roy Belson]: receive students who have this English language need to make sure that the teachers are fully prepared for them.

[Roy Belson]: We also have the issue of dealing with the distribution of students with EL and we're going to look at that.

[Roy Belson]: We did some distribution this year.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have some comment about that.

[Roy Belson]: It's not an easy subject.

[Roy Belson]: Because as you move people around, you solve one problem, you create another.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to provide some options for you in the beginning of the year, sometime in January, so you can look at what options are available to you and what it means financially and what it means programmatically.

[Roy Belson]: But tonight, we want to give you an idea about the law, the pros, the cons of it, and some of the other things that Paul has put together.

[Roy Belson]: So with permission, Paul, if you'd come on up and give us a

[Roy Belson]: A discussion on this topic.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to be tied into our discussion about options.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, sounds great.

[Roy Belson]: It's a larger picture and, you know, Paul and I have had some serious discussions about the pros and cons of any kind of movement of people.

[Roy Belson]: What it means for staff, what it means for transportation, what it means for siblings, what it means for, you know, language groupings.

[Roy Belson]: This is a very complex issue, and it requires a great deal of trade-off.

[Roy Belson]: You have to decide what's the most important thing to us, what are the most important issues to us, and how we're going to solve them, because there's no one perfect solution for any of this.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: At one time it should be noted that the courses were offered free, but that gate is now closed.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: So now we have to, if we have openings for new people, if they're not coming out of colleges with the SEL endorsement, we have to actually offer it if they have students.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to ask our deputy superintendent to Bernadette Bernadette to director of curriculum to tell us how we responded to some of the issues that were raised recently.

[Roy Belson]: That may be tough because sound payments are generally made well in advance.

[Roy Belson]: Right, okay.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll provide them to you, but at least you'll have something that's, you know.

[Roy Belson]: Because that's really what we're basically saying to people.

[Roy Belson]: And I think, you know, we've got professionals on staff, they've got to understand that that means give us the information in a timely way.

[Roy Belson]: We also had a full month where we didn't hold a meeting.

[Roy Belson]: And that's really, you know, that was really a circumstantial thing, but that's a typical.

[Roy Belson]: Simonides.

[Roy Belson]: He claims, and he gave me the name of the trainer, the certified trainer who was on the field at that time.

[Roy Belson]: He said that no trainer from Beverly did anything with the individual.

[Roy Belson]: As a result, he feels that it may have been somebody else who just simply helped out on the sidelines.

[Roy Belson]: So I have a lot more to do.

[Roy Belson]: But there is a distinct difference of opinion between what Beverly feels happened and what was reported to us.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a little bit going on right now, and I'll have more reports soon as I get a better chance to talk to all the parties.

[Roy Belson]: The feeling from Beverly was that somebody assisted the student, but not necessarily the trainer.

[Roy Belson]: the play was allowed to go forward without any reason to stop the play.

[Roy Belson]: So there's back and forth, but Beverly strongly refutes the idea that their trainer assisted our student, and also that the trainer was not licensed, and they gave me the name and showed me the licensure.

[Roy Belson]: You know, this is still going back.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, the latest communication was as late as today.

[Roy Belson]: I'm Stephen Hershey.

[Roy Belson]: So I've got a lot more work to do.

[Roy Belson]: I actually have it on my phone.

[Roy Belson]: According to the Beverly Public Schools,

[Roy Belson]: Since the referee didn't stop the play, obviously he didn't consider it serious enough.

[Roy Belson]: And that for some reason, the assistance was done on the sidelines.

[Roy Belson]: They suspect that somebody who maybe had a nursing background or something else like that may have helped on the sidelines.

[Roy Belson]: The question is, why did the youngster go back in the game too if he had a kick in the head?

[Roy Belson]: There are a couple of questions that still have to be answered.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, well, according to them, they didn't believe the referee needed to stop the game.

[Roy Belson]: And secondly, you know, and without casting any aspersions on anyone, as you know, Mississimini's was not at the game.

[Roy Belson]: And so as a result, we have a situation where people who were at the game have very different reports as to what took place there.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, but certainly blood is blood and if well, that's that's you know, an assumption that was made as to when the bleeding took place and who did what and where and I need more information.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, I just don't know when it happened, how it happened, and the like.

[Roy Belson]: I have two very different reports.

[Roy Belson]: I doubt they were filming the JV game.

[Roy Belson]: because I'm gonna put it on my cell phone, and it'll give you an idea of the strength of his comment.
