[Roy Belson]: Good afternoon.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sending you copies of what I have in addition.

[Roy Belson]: Your athletic director sent a letter to us.

[Roy Belson]: I spoke with several Beverly parents I know usually attend the games.

[Roy Belson]: While some of them remember the play, they do not report it as a significant injury.

[Roy Belson]: They note that there was no stoppage of play, nor the issuance of a card.

[Roy Belson]: Our trainer's name is Charla Berenas, and she has been with us for a long time without complaint.

[Roy Belson]: Beverly has taken this seriously from the start, but I have been unable to verify what has been reported.

[Roy Belson]: Our coaches and trainer are expected to deal with potential concussions with great caution.

[Roy Belson]: We perform ongoing training to ensure we are attending to the safety of all athletes under our own

[Roy Belson]: are players from other teams.

[Roy Belson]: I would like to find out what happened.

[Roy Belson]: Please forward me any information you have.

[Roy Belson]: So we have an ongoing investigation.

[Roy Belson]: I can't draw a conclusion without more discussion with people.

[Roy Belson]: This came through today.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got a little bit more to follow up.

[Roy Belson]: And I just don't want to draw conclusions until I'm comfortable that everyone has a chance to review the information back and forth.

[Roy Belson]: Yes.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, second.

[Roy Belson]: And you can add me to the meeting.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, I was present.

[Roy Belson]: Yes.

[Roy Belson]: It will be in the conference room.

[Roy Belson]: You've been handed a report tonight that was sent to us.

[Roy Belson]: Sure.

[Roy Belson]: It's probably another factor, too, in terms of busing.

[Roy Belson]: The more busing that takes place, the less likely they are to arrive.

[Roy Belson]: take it before the actual school starts.

[Roy Belson]: So let me just make one clarification.

[Roy Belson]: This is the breakfast program.

[Roy Belson]: This is not the total numbers of students on free and reduced.

[Roy Belson]: Not everybody comes in early enough for breakfast, especially at the high school and places like that.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll give you a report with the total numbers, because they're much higher.

[Roy Belson]: when you look at the school lunch program as opposed to the breakfast program, which is a more, let's say, niche program that not everybody participates in.

[Roy Belson]: It's one that we'd like to increase, and we've talked to Andrea Silbert over at EOS many times.

[Roy Belson]: But I think that the breakfast program doesn't give you a full accurate picture.

[Roy Belson]: If just at the high school alone, the number of youngsters who are in free and reduced, who don't pay a user fee for athletics, would tell you that it's much higher than this.

[Roy Belson]: So we're using the tobacco policy because vaping is sort of a derivative.

[Roy Belson]: But as we move forward, we'll obviously specify a little bit more completely.

[Roy Belson]: Well, we can just make one quick comment, as we've done this at this place every year for a long time now, and the reason we need to approve it so early is that if we have snow days,

[Roy Belson]: you know, we've locked in the date.

[Roy Belson]: So we don't have to have, you know, so many days.

[Roy Belson]: But if there are no snow days, we don't have to worry about it.

[Roy Belson]: And the other thing that I just will let you know is that Mr. William Cummings of the Cummings Foundation will speak at graduation in addition to the normal speakers.

[Roy Belson]: I think that it's really important to understand that cameras are fragile.

[Roy Belson]: And that every year, we're going to have to allocate money for this.

[Roy Belson]: Because lightning strikes, all kinds of things take place that are beyond our control.

[Roy Belson]: And we can go all year long and then find that we need cameras that have to be replaced going into the school year.

[Roy Belson]: I think the key thing, you know, apropos to your question is, is that are we covering the areas that people need to be, have covered, that people can see?

[Roy Belson]: The answer is yes.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll try to, you know, continually

[Roy Belson]: prioritize as we go forward.

[Roy Belson]: If a camera goes down, we certainly want to ensure that a key area is covered, so rather than one that might be a duplicate of an existing area.

[Roy Belson]: But for the most part, in the middle of December, we believe everything will be fixed.

[Roy Belson]: So let me answer that before we go too far down the road.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. O'Keefe did provide a substantial number, 30 additional cameras this year.

[Roy Belson]: Some of them are not compatible with what we need.

[Roy Belson]: Some of them can be used for limited purposes, but given what we're doing right now and given the upgrade in technology,

[Roy Belson]: Um, what's coming out of that institution that Bill gets it from, uh, is not necessarily compatible with what we've got.

[Roy Belson]: There's a few that can be.

[Roy Belson]: So, we've got to screen them out, but we really can't be overly dependent on that.

[Roy Belson]: We appreciate what Bill's done, but on the other hand, we've got to be careful that, uh, they're mostly inside cameras, and the things that deal with outside cameras are very different, and we're also dealing with a different way of, uh, of a transmission, uh, than we previously did.

[Roy Belson]: We can use them periodically, but it's not a one-to-one kind of application, but we do appreciate it.

[Roy Belson]: We do have expectations of coming forward with a proposal as the year progresses to enhance our human resources capacity.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, it's become a major, major area and you cannot continue to just simply treat it as a byproduct of everything else going on.

[Roy Belson]: So, that will come forward as a major proposal and we'll have that discussion.

[Roy Belson]: I doubt you're going to forget.

[Roy Belson]: So, as you probably know, the state legislature has approved an option for school districts to incorporate bilingual education into the existing SEI format.

[Roy Belson]: Now, 15 years ago, Ron Unz, who came from California, pushed a initiative petition, which he previously had some success in Arizona and California,

[Roy Belson]: and Massachusetts decided that it would adopt it as well.

[Roy Belson]: It was given great support from John Silbert at the time, and also Mitt Romney, who was a gubernatorial candidate, and it carried its way.

[Roy Belson]: Since the time it's been implemented, there's been mixed results.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

[Roy Belson]: But it comes with that whole idea that, you know, everyone should speak English, and we believe they should.

[Roy Belson]: But how to learn to speak English, especially to learn subjects that require deep cognitive knowledge or cognitive language, is not so easily done.

[Roy Belson]: And there are reasons for blending and doing things a little bit differently.

[Roy Belson]: We obviously are looking at that.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to be waiting for the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to give us the latest guidelines as they see them, and we haven't seen them yet.

[Roy Belson]: We probably won't see them until either late spring or perhaps even into the summer.

[Roy Belson]: So, I doubt there's going to be much done in the next fiscal year.

[Roy Belson]: We are going to look at the blend of programs, and Paul is going to come up in a minute and talk about that, and how it comes together so that we can take advantage of the law where it's appropriate, while at the same time not lose track of situations which are best served by the current SEI.

[Roy Belson]: Also, as you probably know, our teachers have

[Roy Belson]: We've been working to get SEI endorsements, which are required now, for teachers who work with students who have EL requirements, and the vast majority of faculty members do, especially in the core academic areas.

[Roy Belson]: However, there's still some gaps, and there's still a need to continue pushing that as people receive students who have this English language need, to make sure that the teachers are fully prepared for them.

[Roy Belson]: We also have the issue of dealing with the distribution of students with EL, and we're going to look at that.

[Roy Belson]: We did some distribution this year.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have some comment about that.

[Roy Belson]: It's not an easy subject, because as you move people around, you create, you solve one problem, you create another.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to provide some options for you in the beginning of the year, sometime in January, so you can look at what options are available to you and what it means financially and what it means programmatically.

[Roy Belson]: We do have expectations of coming forward with a proposal as the year progresses to enhance our human resources capacity.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, it's become a major, major area, and you cannot continue to just simply treat it as a, you know, byproduct of everything else going on.

[Roy Belson]: So that will come forward as a major proposal, and we'll have that discussion.

[Roy Belson]: I doubt you're going to forget.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you, Kirsten.

[Roy Belson]: So, as you probably know, the state legislature has approved an option for school districts to incorporate bilingual education into the existing SEI format.

[Roy Belson]: Now, 15 years ago, Ron Unz, who came from California, pushed an initiative petition, which previously had some success in Arizona and California, and Massachusetts decided that it would adopt it as well.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, it was given great support from John Silber at the time, and also Mitt Romney, who was a gubernatorial candidate, and it carried its way.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, since the time it's been implemented, there's been mixed results.

[Roy Belson]: Um, sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't, but it comes with that whole idea that, you know, everyone should speak English, and we, we believe they should, but how to learn to speak English, especially to learn subjects that have required deep cognitive knowledge.

[Roy Belson]: cognitive language is not so easily done.

[Roy Belson]: And there are reasons for blending and doing things a little bit differently.

[Roy Belson]: We obviously are looking at that.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to be waiting for the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to give us the latest guidelines as they see them.

[Roy Belson]: And we haven't seen them yet.

[Roy Belson]: We probably won't see them until either late spring or perhaps even into the summer.

[Roy Belson]: So I doubt there's going to be much done in the next

[Roy Belson]: uh, fiscal year.

[Roy Belson]: However, we are going to look at the blend of programs, and that Paul is going to come up in a minute and talk about that, and how it comes together so that we can take advantage of the law where it's appropriate, while at the same time not lose track of, uh, situations which are best served by the current SEI.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, also, as you probably know, uh, our teachers have

[Roy Belson]: I've been working to get SEI endorsements, which are required now for teachers who work with students who have EL requirements, and the vast majority of faculty members do, especially in the core academic areas.

[Roy Belson]: However, there's still some gaps, and there's still a need to continue pushing that as people receive students who have this English language need.

[Roy Belson]: to make sure that the teachers are fully prepared for them.

[Roy Belson]: We also have the issue of dealing with the distribution of students with EL, and we're going to look at that.

[Roy Belson]: We did some distribution this year.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have some comment about that.

[Roy Belson]: It's not an easy subject, because as you move people around, you create, you solve one problem, you create another.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to provide some options for you in the, um, beginning of the year, sometime in January, so you can look at what, what options are available to you and, uh, what it means financially and what it means programmatically.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, but tonight, uh, we want to give you an idea about the law, the pros, the cons of it, and, uh, some of the other things that, uh, Paul has put together.

[Roy Belson]: So with permission, Paul, if you come on up and, uh, give us a, uh, a discussion on, on this topic.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to be tied into our discussion about options.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, sounds great.

[Roy Belson]: It's a larger picture and, you know, Paul and I have had some serious discussions about the pros and cons of any kind of movement of people.

[Roy Belson]: What it means for staff, what it means for transportation, what it means for siblings, what it means for, you know, language groupings.

[Roy Belson]: This is a very complex issue, and it requires a great deal of trade-off.

[Roy Belson]: We have to decide what's the most important thing to us, what are the most important issues to us, and how we're going to solve them, because there's no one perfect solution for any of this.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: We'll call on our assistant superintendent to deliver this report.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor and members of the school committee, I think we all know that building maintenance, building condition, is a popular topic.

[Roy Belson]: The MSBA, Massachusetts School Building Authority,

[Roy Belson]: is the authority that's been put in place to assist with renovations, major renovations of schools, but they also try to keep track of where schools are.

[Roy Belson]: Now, we all know where the pimples are and where the tiles are missing in any one school in our own world.

[Roy Belson]: But when you look at the range of schools across the Commonwealth,

[Roy Belson]: We don't do badly.

[Roy Belson]: And the report I'm providing you is a report that it was done by MSBA.

[Roy Belson]: It was done by a field visit to our schools by MSBA.

[Roy Belson]: And they went to all the schools across the Commonwealth, virtually all of them, didn't get to everything.

[Roy Belson]: And they assessed and evaluated several key factors, including building condition, general environment, capacity, technology, security, and maintenance.

[Roy Belson]: The study was conducted by architectural engineers, engineers in general, and who visited each specific building.

[Roy Belson]: Now, school buildings that were slated for MSB upgrades, already slated in the pipeline, weren't visited because they already had been out there and done that.

[Roy Belson]: The buildings were rated on a four-point scale.

[Roy Belson]: the general condition and general learning environment.

[Roy Belson]: A rating of one was the best, and a rating of four was the lowest.

[Roy Belson]: And all buildings were rated for capacity utilization.

[Roy Belson]: Underutilization was considered to be 80% or less, below 80% rather, and overutilization was above 125% of the capacity of the building.

[Roy Belson]: So I provided you with selected pages of the MSBA report.

[Roy Belson]: It was 96 pages.

[Roy Belson]: I didn't think you wanted to read it all, but if you do, I can certainly provide it.

[Roy Belson]: I picked those pages I thought were relevant to us and would give us insights as to how they came up with these decisions.

[Roy Belson]: But you'll note if you go down to Medford schools and the building condition, all of our schools, with the exception of the high school and the vocational school, were rated one.

[Roy Belson]: The high school and the vocational school were rated two.

[Roy Belson]: But all our buildings,

[Roy Belson]: for general environment were rated one based on their study, not something we did for them, not something we told them to say.

[Roy Belson]: They came out and rated it with their people.

[Roy Belson]: Now, building capacity,

[Roy Belson]: We fall into the average range in every building, while Brooks, Columbus, McGlynn, and Roberts are considered average, the Andrews a little bit under, McGlynn under, high school under, vocational under, and the Curtis Tufts under, in terms of capacity, in terms of room.

[Roy Belson]: Now people talk to me about, is there capacity to absorb young people into our schools?

[Roy Belson]: I'd say yes.

[Roy Belson]: Because I've looked at this, I gave you a report not that long ago on the impact of development upon enrollment.

[Roy Belson]: I'm working on a report that deals with some of the smaller buildings, which there aren't that many with young people in it.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly, that is not changing anything as far as I can see so far.

[Roy Belson]: So I think it's important when people ask us about our building conditions to recognize that we have had them looked at.

[Roy Belson]: There's certainly room for improvement.

[Roy Belson]: No one's going to say that we do everything the way it should be done.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly, we're not bad compared to buildings, school buildings around the commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: We have put in an SOI to the state, statement of interest for the high school and the vocational school.

[Roy Belson]: We expect to hear before the first of the year whether or not we will be allowed to go to feasibility study.

[Roy Belson]: I believe we're now in a pool of 44.

[Roy Belson]: There were 88.

[Roy Belson]: We're now down to 44.

[Roy Belson]: It may be less than that now since their last visit to us.

[Roy Belson]: M-A-S-C.

[Roy Belson]: So in June 2016, the Medford school committee approved the succession plan for the position of superintendent of schools.

[Roy Belson]: I have attached a copy of that plan to my remarks this evening.

[Roy Belson]: While it's within your discretion to keep, modify, and change the plan, it is a fundamental blueprint to begin the processes of succession and transition.

[Roy Belson]: And that will continue on Monday evening with Glenn Kuchar, who is the executive director of the Massachusetts Association of School Committees.

[Roy Belson]: It has been my privilege and honor

[Roy Belson]: to be an educator in Medford, in the Medford Public Schools, for 50 years, and to serve as superintendent of schools, your superintendent of schools, for 23 years.

[Roy Belson]: I've greatly benefited from the high quality and diligence of professionals, support staff, school committee members, and citizens who have worked with me throughout my career.

[Roy Belson]: And I am internally grateful to them for making my tenure and responsibilities

[Roy Belson]: as productive and as rewarding as reasonably possible.

[Roy Belson]: I've been very fortunate to have seen former students become teachers, administrators, and staff in our schools.

[Roy Belson]: I've had the experience of enrolling children and grandchildren of former students.

[Roy Belson]: While no one does significant work alone, I've had the opportunity to build new schools, establish a full range of programs, acquire hundreds of millions of dollars in grants,

[Roy Belson]: for our community and school district.

[Roy Belson]: Understandably, there's room for improvement, but much has been done and more will be done in the months ahead.

[Roy Belson]: No one gets to finish everything, but we have put a lot in place and that will be a solid foundation for the future.

[Roy Belson]: Therefore, I am here informing the Medford School Committee

[Roy Belson]: that it's my intention to retire from the position of superintendent of schools, Medford Public Schools, at the completion of my contract on June 30th, 2018.

[Roy Belson]: This decision has been made without reference to any governmental change or any issues that are in our community.

[Roy Belson]: It is simply the right period of time for me to spend more time with my family and to pursue special causes and interests

[Roy Belson]: that have not been possible given the schedule and work responsibilities of an active school superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: It is my intent and plan to be fully engaged in the months ahead as your superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: We have a lot of positive opportunities, some of which we've talked about tonight, ahead of us.

[Roy Belson]: And I will do everything possible to optimize and achieve our goals.

[Roy Belson]: Furthermore, I will be committed to ensuring a smooth and effective transition to new senior leadership.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor and members of the committee, this report is in two parts.

[Roy Belson]: The Global Scholars Program is now in its fourth year.

[Roy Belson]: The program is integrated into the seventh grade geography curriculum.

[Roy Belson]: It's an initiative of the Global Cities

[Roy Belson]: program of Bloomberg Philanthropies out of New York.

[Roy Belson]: Medford has been a pioneer school system in Massachusetts with this program.

[Roy Belson]: We're the first to do it.

[Roy Belson]: Most of the involved cities are large metropolises around the globe.

[Roy Belson]: There are over 20 major metropolises around the globe participating.

[Roy Belson]: And as such, we've had the opportunity to help shape the curriculum and methodologies involved in the implementation and development.

[Roy Belson]: Our Curriculum Director, Dr. Bernadette Riccadeli, and our Director of Humanities, Dr. Nicole Chieser, have supervised the outstanding work of our seventh grade middle school teachers.

[Roy Belson]: This year, the program will focus on the global food system.

[Roy Belson]: really connects people you saw a little bit with the previous program, people talking to other students, peers around the world, talking to each other, solving social issues, talking about the kinds of things.

[Roy Belson]: Michael Bloomberg will keynote.

[Roy Belson]: coming to this symposium to discuss the outcomes.

[Roy Belson]: in Paris.

[Roy Belson]: and create some outcomes that are there.

[Roy Belson]: Well, he's already done that.

[Roy Belson]: That was earlier in the year.

[Roy Belson]: And his contributions were such that they felt that needed to be shared in a more, let's say, complete setting at the international symposium.

[Roy Belson]: One of the interesting things I just shared with you, and I think it's fascinating, is that virtually everybody from everywhere else speaks English.

[Roy Belson]: Whereas, you know, we don't typically speak all the languages that we'll be communicating with.

[Roy Belson]: It was interesting.

[Roy Belson]: I think one of our groups, we had some Greek students who were able to speak to the students in Athens in Greek last year.

[Roy Belson]: And a few other examples are where some of our students who come from other countries or non-native language speakers were able to communicate in the language to the communities they were at.

[Roy Belson]: But it's more likely that the communication will be in English.

[Roy Belson]: And our students will be able to speak their own language as opposed to a language that

[Roy Belson]: belongs to another country.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to tell you one quick, one quick cute story, which I'm not sure I should, I should, but I will anyway, is that several years ago when he was running for mayor,

[Roy Belson]: One of our assistant principals, submasters at the time, made a serious mistake and released his transcript from Medford High School.

[Roy Belson]: And it showed up in the Boston Herald and the gossip pages.

[Roy Belson]: And it turned out that he got a D in French.

[Roy Belson]: So one of the questions I won't ask him when I'll see him is, how's your French?

[Roy Belson]: So we'll call upon our assistant superintendent to tell you about the Buddy Bench donation.

[Roy Belson]: So earlier this evening, an individual came up and complained about the vocational advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 74 programs require us to have advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: They've existed over the years, but with the advent of Dr. Riccio, they became much more pronounced and much more involved and many more people

[Roy Belson]: were involved.

[Roy Belson]: They're supposed to meet a minimum of two times per year, and the committee members serve as resources to the school administration, the various shop instructors.

[Roy Belson]: And they're composed of a wide variety of expertise and experience categories, include business owners, managers, technicians, university instructors, engineers, teachers, students, and parents.

[Roy Belson]: They're also very helpful in finding co-op learning opportunities for our students.

[Roy Belson]: I've attached a public notice of the two meetings that will be held this year, and that's already posted so that there's no problem this year about the meeting being posted.

[Roy Belson]: Last year it was posted on the vocational website, but that did not meet the state requirement that it be posted at the city clerk and on our own website.

[Roy Belson]: So we're in violation, but

[Roy Belson]: This attorney general, and you can see I gave you a copy of that earlier in the front end, indicated just don't do it again.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: I've listed the number of members of each of these advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: That number can go up and down depending on who's available.

[Roy Belson]: I've also given you a listing of some of the co-op

[Roy Belson]: locations that our young people go to.

[Roy Belson]: At this point in time, it's still very early in the year.

[Roy Belson]: There'll be more as we get into the late fall.

[Roy Belson]: And I've also given you a listing of the various members of the various advisory committees so you see who's actually involved at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Now again, these people can change, they can come and go.

[Roy Belson]: But we feel that there's a great representation and we think that the co-op program is a tremendous asset to our vocational program.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that it gives young people some real world experience in their senior year, in some cases their junior year.

[Roy Belson]: You can be sure that our current administration at the vocational school uses them to learn about various things that

[Roy Belson]: are developing in the trades and the technical areas, and we get good feedback.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm very pleased with what's taken place with our advisory committee.

[Roy Belson]: There's 16 different working groups, although there are 20 curriculum areas.

[Roy Belson]: Some of them combine because of the affinity for each other.

[Roy Belson]: They're really crossover areas.

[Roy Belson]: So happy to take any questions you may have, but I think you have sufficient information to get an idea that

[Roy Belson]: We have posted the advisory committee meetings two times for this year, and we've also provided you with information about who's on them and what they do.

[Roy Belson]: We actually have students right now.

[Roy Belson]: We actually have students in their businesses right now.

[Roy Belson]: Right, well, construction, most of it is done through the laborers, and we've got activities over there, so it isn't really mostly a business activity, it's mostly with the laborers.

[Roy Belson]: I can't tell you right now, except the fact that I know that Jill is working on filling all these areas.

[Roy Belson]: There'll be expansions of this.

[Roy Belson]: It's very early in the year for this.

[Roy Belson]: Christine can comment on that, because we've done some work on that.

[Roy Belson]: And we can give you a quick idea, and then we'll give you a formal report.

[Roy Belson]: Kathy, you want to comment?

[Roy Belson]: At that meeting, you made a motion.

[Roy Belson]: Since that time, grievances were filed, the processes, legal matters were filed.

[Roy Belson]: And therefore, I want to discuss it with you in executive session because I believe it affects our legal status, and I believe that should be taken into account before any meetings are scheduled.

[Roy Belson]: That's the opioid grant.

[Roy Belson]: That was the expansion of the Michigan model.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Mayor and members of the committee, you have a report on the Nellie Mae Educators Foundation grant.

[Roy Belson]: With us this evening is our Director of Guidance, Amelia Jensen, along with Tim Kline, who's the recipient of the O2 award.

[Roy Belson]: It's a very significant award.

[Roy Belson]: It's done a lot of very good things for us.

[Roy Belson]: We'll do even more.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to let them explain it to you in great detail.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor and members of the committee, this report is in two parts.

[Roy Belson]: The Global Scholars Program is now in its fourth year.

[Roy Belson]: The program is integrated into the seventh grade geography curriculum.

[Roy Belson]: It's an initiative of the Global Cities Program of Bloomberg Philanthropies out of New York.

[Roy Belson]: Medford has been a pioneer school system in Massachusetts with this program.

[Roy Belson]: We were the first to do it.

[Roy Belson]: Most of the involved cities are large metropolises around the globe.

[Roy Belson]: There are over 20 major metropolises around the globe participating.

[Roy Belson]: And as such, we've had the opportunity to help shape the curriculum and methodologies involved in the implementation and development.

[Roy Belson]: Our Curriculum Director, Dr. Bernadette Riccardelli, and our Director of Humanities, Dr. Nicole Chieser, have supervised the outstanding work of our seventh grade middle school teachers.

[Roy Belson]: This year, the program will focus on the global food system.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to allow Dr. Riccadeli to tell you more about it, and then I need to come back and talk about the upcoming symposium that will take place in Paris, France.

[Roy Belson]: The program is a terrific program.

[Roy Belson]: It really connects people you saw a little bit with the previous program, people talking to other students, peers around the world, and talking to each other, solving social issues, talking about the kinds of things.

[Roy Belson]: This is cutting-edge activity, and there's going to be 50 cities represented in Paris this week.

[Roy Belson]: And there's going to be incredible exchanges.

[Roy Belson]: Michael Bloomberg will keynote.

[Roy Belson]: There will be professors from around the world, the London School of Economics, Moscow, Columbia, coming to this symposium to discuss the outcomes.

[Roy Belson]: And you have some of the materials in the brochure that I've provided to you.

[Roy Belson]: In order for me to be compensated under the ethics rules, I need your approval for Bloomberg Philanthropies to pay for my expenses to go.

[Roy Belson]: I've covered Mr. Zizzo because I'm his appointing authority, you're my appointing authority, so I need your approval for me, but Mr. Zizzo has my approval to attend.

[Roy Belson]: And we anticipate that this is about a $1,500 expense on the part of Bloomberg Philanthropies, the airfare, hotel, and the like.

[Roy Belson]: I also intend to stay for about a day and a half more, enjoy the city with my wife, and I will pay the expenses for anything associated with my private time in Paris.

[Roy Belson]: So I look forward to this activity, and I ask your approval to have Bloomberg Philanthropies allow me to attend at their expense.

[Roy Belson]: There's a representative from Boston, and there's a representative from the Everett Public Schools.

[Roy Belson]: We introduced the program to Boston and Everett at the request of Marjorie Bloomberg-Tiven.

[Roy Belson]: Oh, absolutely.

[Roy Belson]: It's, you know, obviously, they're looking for educational leaders.

[Roy Belson]: to discuss the impact of outcomes on these kinds of programs.

[Roy Belson]: This is an invitation on the part of Bloomberg Philanthropies.

[Roy Belson]: Marjorie Tiven, who is the executive of this particular program, selected Mr. Zizzo for his contributions.

[Roy Belson]: All the young people, all of our teachers did a good job doing things, but Mr. Zizzo added some technological capacity, advanced the concept a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: Remember, we were the first school system in Massachusetts to do this.

[Roy Belson]: they were looking at us for ideas.

[Roy Belson]: I provided them with some positions, papers on project-based learning and other things like that.

[Roy Belson]: So Mr. Zizza was selected for his contributions as opposed to being in a school, a particular school.

[Roy Belson]: But there are teachers and administrators and professors and business people from all walks going to this particular thing to have this symposium to trade ideas about how we can leverage international digital learning.

[Roy Belson]: and create some outcomes that are there.

[Roy Belson]: So it was a selection of the program.

[Roy Belson]: Well, he's already done that, but he'll come back and as I will too, and also meet with people to talk about the things that were discussed and how it can be advanced and where we can grow from it and what other people have suggested.

[Roy Belson]: It's really an attempt to exchange ideas and bring back advancements to the program.

[Roy Belson]: This is, remember, it's only in its fourth year.

[Roy Belson]: And as you might imagine with the revenues or the resources behind Bloomberg Philanthropies, it can grow substantially.

[Roy Belson]: And so we, you know, bring back some ideas and these are things that we'll try to do and try to advance and try to do even more than we're doing now, incorporate even more people.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Zizzo actually participated in a teleconference that was earlier in the year, and his contributions were such that they felt that they needed to be shared in a more, let's say, complete setting.

[Roy Belson]: One of the interesting things I just shared with you, and I think it's fascinating, is that virtually everybody from everywhere else speaks English.

[Roy Belson]: Whereas, you know, we don't typically speak all the languages that we'll be communicating with.

[Roy Belson]: And it was interesting.

[Roy Belson]: I think one of our groups, we had some Greek students who were able to speak to the students in Athens in Greek last year.

[Roy Belson]: And a few other examples are where some of our students who come from other countries or non-native language speakers were able to communicate in the language to the communities they were at.

[Roy Belson]: But it's more likely that the communication will be in English, and our students will

[Roy Belson]: be able to speak their own language as opposed to a language that belongs to another country.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to tell you one quick cute story, which I'm not sure I should, but I will anyway, is that several years ago when he was running for mayor,

[Roy Belson]: One of our assistant principals, submasters at the time, made a serious mistake and released this transcript from Medford High School.

[Roy Belson]: And it showed up in the Boston Herald and the gossip pages.

[Roy Belson]: And it turned out that he got a D in French.

[Roy Belson]: So one of the questions I won't ask him when I'll see him is, how's your French?

[Roy Belson]: So we'll call upon our assistant superintendent to tell you about the Buddy Bench donation.

[Roy Belson]: So earlier this evening, an individual came up and complained about the vocational advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 74 programs require us to have advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: They've existed over the years.

[Roy Belson]: But with the advent of Dr. Riccio, they became much more pronounced and much more involved, and many more people were involved.

[Roy Belson]: They're supposed to meet a minimum of two times per year, and the committee members serve as resources, the school administration, the various shop instructors, and they're composed of a wide variety of expertise and experience categories include business owners, managers, technicians, university instructors, engineers, teachers, students, and parents.

[Roy Belson]: They're also very helpful in finding co-op learning opportunities for our students.

[Roy Belson]: I've attached a public notice of the two meetings that will be held this year, and that's already posted so that there's no problem this year about the meeting being posted.

[Roy Belson]: Last year it was posted on the vocational website, but that did not meet the state requirement that it be posted at the city clerk and on our own website.

[Roy Belson]: where we're in violation, but this attorney general, and you can see I gave you a copy of that earlier in the front end, indicated just don't do it again.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I've listed the number of members of each of these advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: That number can go up and down depending on who's available.

[Roy Belson]: I've also given you a listing of some of the co-op locations that our young people go to.

[Roy Belson]: At this point in time, it's still very early in the year.

[Roy Belson]: There'll be more as we get into the late fall.

[Roy Belson]: And I've also given you a listing of the various members of the various

[Roy Belson]: advisory committees to see who's actually involved at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Now again, these people can change, they can come and go.

[Roy Belson]: But we feel that there's a great representation and we think that the co-op program is a tremendous asset to our vocational program.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that it gives young people some real world experience in their senior year, in some cases their junior year.

[Roy Belson]: You can be sure that our current administration at the vocational school uses them to learn about various things that are developing in the trades and the technical areas, and we get good feedback.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm very pleased with what's taken place with our advisory committee.

[Roy Belson]: There's 16 different working groups, although there are 20 curriculum areas.

[Roy Belson]: Some of them combined because of the affinity for each other, they're really crossover areas.

[Roy Belson]: So happy to take any questions you may have, but I think you have sufficient information to get an idea that we have posted the advisory committee meetings two times for this year, and we've also provided you with information about who's on them and what they do.

[Roy Belson]: We actually have students right now.

[Roy Belson]: We actually have students in their businesses right now.

[Roy Belson]: Right, well, construction, most of it is done through the laborers.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got activities over there, so it isn't really mostly a business activity, it's mostly with the laborers.

[Roy Belson]: I can't tell you right now, except the fact that I know that Joe is working on filling all these areas.

[Roy Belson]: Not necessarily.

[Roy Belson]: It could be outside.

[Roy Belson]: There'll be expansions of this.

[Roy Belson]: It's very early in the year for this.

[Roy Belson]: Christine can comment on that because we've done some work on that.

[Roy Belson]: We can give you a quick idea and then we'll give you a formal report.

[Roy Belson]: At that meeting, you made a motion.

[Roy Belson]: Since that time, grievances were filed.

[Roy Belson]: And therefore, I want to discuss it with you in executive session because I believe it affects our legal status.

[Roy Belson]: That's the opioid grant.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Mayor and members of the committee, you have a report on the Nellie Mae Educating Foundation Grant.

[Roy Belson]: It's a very significant award.

[Roy Belson]: It's done a lot of very good things for us.

[Roy Belson]: We'll do even more.

[Roy Belson]: We obviously lock in doors, put kids in places, put people in key strategic locations to watch doors and corridors and any other possible area where someone might get in.

[Roy Belson]: And everyone follow that exactly.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, may I?

[Roy Belson]: Roy Bellson, Superintendent of Schools, 2500 Mystic Valley Parkway, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, members of the council, I just want to clarify a couple of things.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 74 is the Vocational Education Act that governs vocational education.

[Roy Belson]: It has been around for a long time.

[Roy Belson]: Advisory committees have been part of Chapter 74 for a long time.

[Roy Belson]: It's not new.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford School Committee knows about Chapter 74 Advisory Committees, and many of you have participated on it, including Councilor Penter at one time, and others have been on these advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: It's not an unknown thing.

[Roy Belson]: There was one error that was made.

[Roy Belson]: It was made without thinking it was an error.

[Roy Belson]: It was simply that advisory committees meet and they go over the program that they were interested in, the Multimedia Center for Students.

[Roy Belson]: Their issue wasn't community access, their issue was the multimedia program for students, because it's required by Chapter 74.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 74 put out a manual and they increased the idea that the open meeting law should apply.

[Roy Belson]: The director at that particular time didn't see that, didn't pay attention to it at that particular time, put it on the website for the school thing and didn't think it needed to be posted.

[Roy Belson]: Typically a public body is a body that deliberates and then can make a decision.

[Roy Belson]: as opposed to a public body or a body that simply advises an administrator who then advises a governing body like a school committee what to do, so it was an error.

[Roy Belson]: That's all it was and it didn't necessarily affect anything to deal with community access.

[Roy Belson]: People ask the question, well, what does Ben Brown fit in this situation?

[Roy Belson]: Well, Ben Brown, if he's going to manage this place, is going to interact with the teaching staff of the vocational school.

[Roy Belson]: So his name is going to come up, or his position will come up in that process.

[Roy Belson]: There's no attempt to block anything.

[Roy Belson]: I think we all recognize that this space is a good space, and we hope that it will be a terrific space for the community and a terrific space for the young people.

[Roy Belson]: And the good news is that we can share it, and we can do a lot of good things together.

[Roy Belson]: As to the Corey check, what's to prohibit a program that's being jointly produced by young people along with community members?

[Roy Belson]: What if they're together?

[Roy Belson]: What if they do a program together?

[Roy Belson]: I think that's highly desirable that our young people do that.

[Roy Belson]: But if they do that, then it would be good for them to know that the people who are going to be doing it in this space are people that we have checked out.

[Roy Belson]: I think safety is always on our minds.

[Roy Belson]: I think we all agree on that.

[Roy Belson]: It doesn't hurt.

[Roy Belson]: If an individual feels that the Cori check has been unduly denied, they have the right to get it and appeal.

[Roy Belson]: Now, do you think that any of us would ever be able to stand up in front of you and say that a person who had an insurance violation is a reason for denying them the right to come in here?

[Roy Belson]: But if a person has been involved with molestation, or the person been involved with assault and battery, and a person's been involved with destruction of property, maybe we should know that.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe we should know that.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't think it's unreasonable.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's something that we should consider.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it's there.

[Roy Belson]: And I think as far as Chapter 74 goes, despite what the individual has to say, it was totally different than the community media thing.

[Roy Belson]: And it's really a part of us making sure that we're in compliance with the state.

[Roy Belson]: We can stick with the open meeting law.

[Roy Belson]: It won't happen again.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, we've posted all the meetings going forward to the advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: And every shop in the school has an advisory committee.

[Roy Belson]: Every shop.

[Roy Belson]: And some of you have participated.

[Roy Belson]: We appreciate that because it's important for the young people to get expertise, not only from Medford, but from practitioners around the Commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: We appreciate your listening.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: So if I may, just for a minute.

[Roy Belson]: So we have football games at Hormel Stadium.

[Roy Belson]: So everyone comes through the gate, should be quarry checked because they might sit next to a student.

[Roy Belson]: No.

[Roy Belson]: Hormel Stadium is the site of student activities.

[Roy Belson]: We have football kids there.

[Roy Belson]: We have cheerleaders there.

[Roy Belson]: We have other people there.

[Roy Belson]: Public access, public areas are not subject to the CORI.

[Roy Belson]: Now, it's direct, these key words, direct, unsupervised.

[Roy Belson]: If I'm working with you, if I'm in the area where I'm working directly with you that's direct and unsupervised.

[Roy Belson]: Indirect is not the issue.

[Roy Belson]: People in areas you could be anywhere and have people who are near students and the like or near young people.

[Roy Belson]: That's not the way the Corey statue has been interpreted and applied across the commonwealth, so

[Roy Belson]: You know, we could check everybody out everywhere they go.

[Roy Belson]: When you go to the state house, you have to empty your pockets, you have to take off your belt, and you check everything like that.

[Roy Belson]: You can keep going and going and going.

[Roy Belson]: But at some point in time, the terms are direct and unsupervised.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise, every public gathering where there are young people and families would require everyone to be quarry checked.

[Roy Belson]: It's not the same thing.

[Roy Belson]: It's just the way it's been interpreted across the Commonwealth, and I'm sure there are plenty of people that would comment on it.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, may I?

[Roy Belson]: Roy Bellson, Superintendent of Schools, 2500 Mystic Valley Parkway, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, members of the Council, I just want to clarify a couple of things.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 74 is the Vocational Education Act that governs vocational education.

[Roy Belson]: It has been around for a long time.

[Roy Belson]: Advisory committees have been part of Chapter 74 for a long time.

[Roy Belson]: It's not new.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford School Committee knows about Chapter 74 advisory committees, and many of you have participated on it, including Councilor Penter at one time, and others have been on these advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: It's not an unknown thing.

[Roy Belson]: There was one error that was made.

[Roy Belson]: It was made without thinking it was an error.

[Roy Belson]: It was simply that advisory committees meet and they go over the program that they were interested in, the Multimedia Center for Students.

[Roy Belson]: Their issue wasn't community access, their issue was the multimedia program for students, because it's required by Chapter 74.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 74 put out a manual and they increased the idea that the open meeting law should apply.

[Roy Belson]: The director at that particular time didn't see that, didn't pay attention to it at that particular time, put it on the website for the school thing and didn't think it needed to be posted.

[Roy Belson]: Typically a public body is a body that deliberates and then can make a decision.

[Roy Belson]: as opposed to a public body or a body that simply advises an administrator who then advises a governing body like a school committee what to do.

[Roy Belson]: So it was an error.

[Roy Belson]: That's all it was.

[Roy Belson]: And it didn't necessarily affect anything to deal with community access.

[Roy Belson]: People ask the question, well, what does Ben Brown fit in this situation?

[Roy Belson]: Well, Ben Brown, if he's going to manage this place, is going to interact with the teaching staff of the vocational school.

[Roy Belson]: So his name is going to come up, or his position will come up in that process.

[Roy Belson]: There's no attempt to block anything.

[Roy Belson]: I think we all recognize that this space is a good space, and we hope that it will be a terrific space for the community and a terrific space for the young people.

[Roy Belson]: And the good news is that we can share it, and we can do a lot of good things together.

[Roy Belson]: As to the CORI check, what's to prohibit a program that's being jointly produced by young people along with community members?

[Roy Belson]: What if they're together?

[Roy Belson]: What if they do a program together?

[Roy Belson]: I think that's highly desirable that our young people do that.

[Roy Belson]: But if they do that, then it would be good for them to know that the people who are going to be doing it in this space are people that we have checked out.

[Roy Belson]: I think safety is always on our minds.

[Roy Belson]: I think we all agree on that.

[Roy Belson]: It doesn't hurt.

[Roy Belson]: If an individual feels that the Cori check has been unduly denied, they have the right to get it and appeal.

[Roy Belson]: Now, do you think that any of us would ever be able to stand up in front of you and say that a person who had an insurance violation is a reason for denying them the right to come in here?

[Roy Belson]: But if a person has been involved with molestation or the person been involved with assault and battery and a person been involved with destruction of property, maybe we should know that.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe we should know that.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't think it's unreasonable.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's something that we should consider.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it's there.

[Roy Belson]: And I think as far as Chapter 74 goes, despite what the individual has to say, it was totally different than the community media thing.

[Roy Belson]: And it's really a part of us making sure that we're in compliance with the state.

[Roy Belson]: We can stay on the open meeting law.

[Roy Belson]: It won't happen again.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, we've posted all the meetings going forward to the advisory committees.

[Roy Belson]: And every shop in the school has an advisory committee.

[Roy Belson]: Every shop.

[Roy Belson]: and some of you have participated.

[Roy Belson]: We appreciate that because it's important for the young people to get expertise, not only from Medford, but from practitioners around the commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: So I appreciate you listening.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: So if I may, just for a minute.

[Roy Belson]: So we have football games at Hormel Stadium.

[Roy Belson]: So everyone comes through the gate, should be quarry checked, because they might sit next to a student.

[Roy Belson]: Hormel Stadium is a site.

[Roy Belson]: Hormel Stadium is the site of student activities.

[Roy Belson]: We have football kids there, we have cheerleaders there, we have other people there.

[Roy Belson]: Public access, public areas are not subject to the quarry.

[Roy Belson]: Now, it's direct, these key words, direct, unsupervised.

[Roy Belson]: If I'm working with you, if I'm in the area where I'm working directly with you, that's direct and unsupervised.

[Roy Belson]: Indirect is not the issue.

[Roy Belson]: People in areas, you could be anywhere.

[Roy Belson]: and have people who are near students and the like, or near young people.

[Roy Belson]: That's not the way the Corey statue has been interpreted and has been applied across the commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: You know, we could check everybody out everywhere they go.

[Roy Belson]: When you go to the statehouse, you have to empty your pockets, you have to take off your belt, and you check everything like that.

[Roy Belson]: You can keep going and going and going.

[Roy Belson]: But at some point in time, the terms are direct and unsupervised.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise, every public gathering, whether young people and families, would require everyone to be quarry checked.

[Roy Belson]: It's not the same thing.

[Roy Belson]: It's just the way it's been interpreted across the Commonwealth, and I'm sure there are plenty of people that would comment on it.

[Roy Belson]: Kirsten's not here, but I. Oh, maybe you can help me.

[Roy Belson]: other things they have to do, you know, FMLA, all the kinds of things that affect human development.

[Roy Belson]: We have over a thousand people that work for the school system.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, we've got to get to that point.

[Roy Belson]: At one time, none of this stuff had to be tracked.

[Roy Belson]: It just simply is a person's got a teaching license, great.

[Roy Belson]: Now we need all the kind of data.

[Roy Belson]: We need to look at things.

[Roy Belson]: We need to follow up things so that the people who are running the educational side of the operation concentrate on what they're doing.

[Roy Belson]: They're not chasing down the human resource pieces.

[Roy Belson]: So Tony is here and you know I want to talk a little bit about it to begin with.

[Roy Belson]: I gave you a handout tonight.

[Roy Belson]: It's in the globe about concussions and things like this and you know we have a trainer, we have a doctor, although the doctor is leaving we're gonna have a replacement doctor.

[Roy Belson]: You know we'll do this together and there's just a lot of factors about you see in the news today about

[Roy Belson]: the trauma caused by brain injuries.

[Roy Belson]: The Aaron Hernandez case brought a lot to the forefront as well.

[Roy Belson]: BU has a major department on this topic as well, and it's just important that we understand what our experience is.

[Roy Belson]: Now, sports, they played with passion, they played with great force.

[Roy Belson]: There's going to be injuries.

[Roy Belson]: Every year there are injuries in all the sports, and they range from broken bones to

[Roy Belson]: cuts into other kinds of bruises and strains and ankles and things like knees, ACLs and the like.

[Roy Belson]: But concussion is something that, you know, has long-term impact, real long-term impact.

[Roy Belson]: You can get a repaired knee and things like that.

[Roy Belson]: It may not be the best thing to get, but you can get one.

[Roy Belson]: But if you have brain injury,

[Roy Belson]: It may not be something that you can recover from.

[Roy Belson]: And these are things that we have to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: One of the interesting facts that I learned, and I think it's important to understand this, it often isn't just one hit.

[Roy Belson]: Most of the injuries come from the cumulative effect of multiple hits over time.

[Roy Belson]: And it's really that's what takes place.

[Roy Belson]: And then that one hit maybe throws it over the top.

[Roy Belson]: But it's really generally a buildup, an accumulation of things.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing that I learned a little bit is that females have been more likely to get concussions than males.

[Roy Belson]: And you would think, why is that?

[Roy Belson]: Because you think some of the male sports are more violent, seemingly.

[Roy Belson]: But part of it is because of the neck structure of a female, the shoulders, things like that, or maybe the leg structures.

[Roy Belson]: they're not quite as pronounced and strong in some instances.

[Roy Belson]: Not always, but I mean there are some instances that there are issues like that that anatomically might lead to that kind of injury.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot here.

[Roy Belson]: Right, and you know in a game like soccer, you might have, you're hitting the ball,

[Roy Belson]: You know, a lot of discussion about should you be wearing helmets, shouldn't you be wearing helmets.

[Roy Belson]: There's all kinds of discussion that's going to come up.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it was useful for us to at least have it in front of you so that we're talking.

[Roy Belson]: But we track this every year.

[Roy Belson]: And I gave you three years of experience.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that it's important for us to understand what's going on and we move on from there.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you might expect football was the leading one, but soccer, hockey, right up there.

[Roy Belson]: And believe it or not, cheerleading had eight.

[Roy Belson]: So it, you know, it sometimes surprises you where it can happen.

[Roy Belson]: I asked Tanya for that, but she didn't have it exactly that, but she'd have to go back and do the records.

[Roy Belson]: She just said it was slightly more female than male to me.

[Roy Belson]: A better identification.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing we should talk about is that it's not just playing getting back into sports.

[Roy Belson]: If a youngster has a concussion,

[Roy Belson]: Because the youngster might be dizzy and not able to complete their homework for a period of time.

[Roy Belson]: So there's communication on that level as well.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor and members of the school committee, teachers of the McGlynn, ladies and gentlemen.

[Roy Belson]: We respect the teachers of the McGlynn.

[Roy Belson]: We respect the McGlynn school.

[Roy Belson]: We have two very fine middle schools.

[Roy Belson]: We never said that we didn't.

[Roy Belson]: But we also said that there's a public perception out there that one school is more attractive than the other at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Several years ago, it was the other way around.

[Roy Belson]: One school drew more students than the other school.

[Roy Belson]: And this year there was a significant imbalance in grade six coming up based on parent perception, based on what parents were telling us about the program.

[Roy Belson]: Now, whether they're right or they're wrong, our goal was to restore that balance, and our goal was to bring everyone into the picture and create ownership so that we would all move forward and change that imbalance.

[Roy Belson]: That's not an indictment.

[Roy Belson]: That's an attempt to try and say, let's do something about it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the action plan, our suggestions and things that we put in place.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, there were some moves that we made by reassignment.

[Roy Belson]: We have the right to reassign people.

[Roy Belson]: Right now public perception is one school is more attractive than the other.

[Roy Belson]: And it was rebuilt one more time, and it's now being rebuilt for the third time.

[Roy Belson]: It's only been built three times.

[Roy Belson]: other things they have to do, you know, FMLA, all the kinds of things that affect human development.

[Roy Belson]: We have over 1,000 people that work for the school system.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, different aspects of what they do, are they properly trained for what they do, are they keeping up their licensure, all this stuff has to be tracked.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, we've got to get to that point.

[Roy Belson]: At one time, none of this stuff had to be tracked.

[Roy Belson]: You know, now we need all the kind of data.

[Roy Belson]: We need to look at things.

[Roy Belson]: Does Perry love concussion law?

[Roy Belson]: Tony is here, and I want to talk a little bit about it to begin with.

[Roy Belson]: I gave you a handout tonight.

[Roy Belson]: It's in the Globe.

[Roy Belson]: Fantastic, I got it.

[Roy Belson]: About concussions and things like this.

[Roy Belson]: We have a trainer, we have a doctor.

[Roy Belson]: Although the doctor is leaving, we're going to have a replacement doctor.

[Roy Belson]: Come on up, Tony.

[Roy Belson]: We'll do this together.

[Roy Belson]: And there's just a lot of factors about it.

[Roy Belson]: You see in the news today about

[Roy Belson]: The trauma caused by brain injuries, the Aaron Hernandez case brought a lot to the forefront as well.

[Roy Belson]: BU has a major department on this topic as well.

[Roy Belson]: And it's just important that we understand what our experience is.

[Roy Belson]: Now, sports, they played with passion, they played with great force, there's going to be injuries.

[Roy Belson]: And every year there are injuries in all the sports.

[Roy Belson]: They range from broken bones to cuts and to other kinds of bruises and strains and ankles and things like knees, ACLs and the like.

[Roy Belson]: But concussion is something that has long-term impact, real long-term impact.

[Roy Belson]: You can get a repaired knee and things like that.

[Roy Belson]: It may not be the best thing to get, but you can get one.

[Roy Belson]: But if you have brain injury,

[Roy Belson]: It may not be something that you can recover from.

[Roy Belson]: And these are things that we have to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: One of the interesting facts that I learned, and I think it's important to understand this, that often isn't just one hit.

[Roy Belson]: Most of the injuries come from the cumulative effect of multiple hits over time.

[Roy Belson]: And it's really that's what takes place.

[Roy Belson]: And then that one hit maybe throws it over the top.

[Roy Belson]: But it's really generally a buildup, an accumulation of things.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing that I learned a little bit is that females have been more likely to get concussions than males.

[Roy Belson]: And you would think, why is that?

[Roy Belson]: Because you think some of the male sports are more violent, seemingly.

[Roy Belson]: But part of it is because of the neck structure of a female, the shoulders, things like that, or maybe the leg structures.

[Roy Belson]: they're not quite as pronounced and strong in some instances.

[Roy Belson]: Not always, but I mean there are some instances that there are issues like that that anatomically might lead to that kind of injury.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot here.

[Roy Belson]: Right, and you know in a game like soccer, you know, might have, hitting the ball, you know,

[Roy Belson]: A lot of discussion about should you be wearing helmets, shouldn't you be wearing helmets.

[Roy Belson]: There's all kinds of discussion that's going to come up.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it was useful for us to at least have it in front of you so that we're talking about.

[Roy Belson]: We track this every year.

[Roy Belson]: And I gave you three years of experience.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that it's important for us to understand what's going on and we move on from there.

[Roy Belson]: EDUARDO By the way, over the three year period there were 58 different identifications of concussion.

[Roy Belson]: all the seasons, and well, you might expect football was the leading one, but soccer, hockey, right up there.

[Roy Belson]: And believe it or not, cheerleading had eight.

[Roy Belson]: So it, you know, it sometimes surprises you where it can happen.

[Roy Belson]: I asked Tanya for that, but she didn't have it exactly that, but she'd have to go back and do the records.

[Roy Belson]: She'd have to go through the records.

[Roy Belson]: She just said it was slightly more female than male to me.

[Roy Belson]: Exactly.

[Roy Belson]: A better identification.

[Roy Belson]: If a youngster has a concussion,

[Roy Belson]: counseling in the nurse's office, talk about accommodations made in the academic classroom as well, because the youngster might be dizzy and not able to complete their homework for a period of time.

[Roy Belson]: So there's communication on that level as well.

[Roy Belson]: But obviously, it would be good to communicate when things are close in nature, or there's a likelihood that the same people would be participating.

[Roy Belson]: So maybe by the next meeting, if someone can do it, we can do it.

[Roy Belson]: So in the teacher's contract, okay, we put in during the last negotiations a piece that allocated $30,000 in year one and $40,000 in year two for teachers to take individual courses and be reimbursed up to $1,000.

[Roy Belson]: What you're seeing in that line, in those line items, is reimbursement for that purpose.

[Roy Belson]: They apply for it through the deputy superintendent's office.

[Roy Belson]: He reviews it.

[Roy Belson]: It's first come, first serve.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor and members of the school committee, teachers of the McGlynn, ladies and gentlemen.

[Roy Belson]: We respect the teachers of the McGlynn.

[Roy Belson]: We respect the McGlynn school.

[Roy Belson]: We have two very fine middle schools.

[Roy Belson]: We never said that we didn't.

[Roy Belson]: But we also said that there's a public perception out there that one school is more attractive than the other at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Several years ago, it was the other way around.

[Roy Belson]: One school drew more students than the other school.

[Roy Belson]: And this year, there was a significant imbalance in grade six coming up based on parent perception, based on what parents were telling us about the program.

[Roy Belson]: Now, whether they're right or they're wrong,

[Roy Belson]: Our goal was to restore that balance, and our goal was to bring everyone into the picture and create ownership so that we would all move forward and change that imbalance.

[Roy Belson]: That's not an indictment.

[Roy Belson]: That's an attempt to try and say, let's do something about it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the action plan, our suggestions and things that we've put in place.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, there were some moves that we made by reassignment, but that's the right of the administration through the contract with the Teachers Association.

[Roy Belson]: We have the right to reassign people, and we did talk to union representatives, and we did try to negotiate something, but it broke down.

[Roy Belson]: My point right now is that I welcome your interest in working with us going forward.

[Roy Belson]: And I encourage it, because the only point we're trying to make right now is we have to own the issue.

[Roy Belson]: Right now, public perception is one school is more attractive than the other.

[Roy Belson]: Our goal is to change that perception, to let them know how much you are doing for their children, to work on the distribution of population, and to try and move it forward in a very positive way.

[Roy Belson]: So I welcome your involvement.

[Roy Belson]: That's all we ask for in our discussions with union representatives.

[Roy Belson]: Any piece of software requires constant training and updating of our personnel.

[Roy Belson]: And I think I just wanted to give you an idea.

[Roy Belson]: I know these things are hard to read, but it gives you an idea just how much our secretaries and our staff have to learn about how to use a complex piece of software so that we can get to that point in time where we can use data very, very effectively and be totally data informed about what's happening in our schools, what's happening in the community, and how it relates to our progress.

[Roy Belson]: So I just wanted to give you an idea of what was involved.

[Roy Belson]: And I know that, you know,

[Roy Belson]: You won't read every word of this in between, but you get an idea of what people have to go through in order to be effective.

[Roy Belson]: Sure, I can do that.

[Roy Belson]: The data is one aspect of it.

[Roy Belson]: human resources is a major field today and we have got to as a entity develop a human resources team because there's so many aspects to every aspect of an individual from licensure to professional preparation to ongoing preparation to

[Roy Belson]: other things they have to do, you know, FMLA, all the kinds of things that affect human development.

[Roy Belson]: We have over 1,000 people that work for the school system.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, different aspects of what they do, are they properly trained for what they do, are they keeping up their licensure, all this stuff has to be tracked.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, we've got to get to that point.

[Roy Belson]: At one time, none of this stuff had to be tracked.

[Roy Belson]: It just simply, you're saying a person's got a teaching license, great.

[Roy Belson]: You know, now we need all the kind of data.

[Roy Belson]: We need to look at things.

[Roy Belson]: We need to follow up things so that the people who are running the educational side of the operation concentrate on what they're doing.

[Roy Belson]: They're not chasing down the human resource pieces.

[Roy Belson]: So I think it may be a shift of some people as opposed to, you know, more people.

[Roy Belson]: I just think it may be just trying to develop a pattern that we have a human resource field, a field that ties into data, a field that ties into education, a field that ties into operations.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that will go a long way to bringing us completely into the modern age.

[Roy Belson]: It's just part of life today.

[Roy Belson]: Most operations have human resource operations today.

[Roy Belson]: And we're doing it with our existing people, and piece here, piece there.

[Roy Belson]: But I think it's getting to the point where it's advantageous to look at it in a more, let's say, cohesive way.

[Roy Belson]: So, but Tony is here and you know, I want to talk a little bit about it to begin with.

[Roy Belson]: I gave you a handout tonight, it's in the Globe, about concussions and things like this.

[Roy Belson]: And you know, we have a trainer, we have a doctor, although the doctor is leaving, we're gonna have a replacement doctor.

[Roy Belson]: Come on up Tony, you know, we'll do this together.

[Roy Belson]: And there's just a lot of factors about, you see in the notes today about,

[Roy Belson]: the trauma caused by brain injuries.

[Roy Belson]: The Aaron Hernandez case brought a lot to the forefront as well.

[Roy Belson]: BU has a major department on this topic as well.

[Roy Belson]: And it's just important that we understand what our experience is.

[Roy Belson]: Now, sports, they played with passion, they played with great force, there's going to be injuries.

[Roy Belson]: Every year there are injuries in all the sports and they range from broken bones to

[Roy Belson]: cuts into other kinds of bruises and strains and ankles and things like knees, ACLs and the like.

[Roy Belson]: But concussion is something that has long-term impact, real long-term impact.

[Roy Belson]: You can get a repaired knee, things like that.

[Roy Belson]: It may not be the best thing to get, but you can get one.

[Roy Belson]: But if you have brain injury,

[Roy Belson]: It may not be something that you can recover from.

[Roy Belson]: And these are things that we have to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: One of the interesting facts that I learned, and I think it's important to understand this, it often isn't just one hit.

[Roy Belson]: Most of the injuries come from the cumulative effect of multiple hits over time.

[Roy Belson]: And it's really that's what takes place.

[Roy Belson]: And then that one hit maybe throws it over the top.

[Roy Belson]: But it's really generally a buildup, an accumulation of things.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing that I learned a little bit is that females have been more likely to get concussions than males.

[Roy Belson]: And you would think, why is that?

[Roy Belson]: Because you think some of the male sports are more violent, seemingly.

[Roy Belson]: But part of it is because of the neck structure of a female, the shoulders, things like that, or maybe the leg structures.

[Roy Belson]: They're not quite as pronounced and strong in some instances.

[Roy Belson]: Not always, but I mean there are some instances that there are issues like that that anatomically might lead to that kind of injury.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot here.

[Roy Belson]: Right, and you know in a game like soccer, you know, might have, hitting the ball,

[Roy Belson]: A lot of discussion about should you be wearing helmets, shouldn't you be wearing helmets?

[Roy Belson]: There's all kinds of discussion that's going to come up, and I think it was useful for us to at least have it in front of you so that we're talking about.

[Roy Belson]: We track this every year, and I gave you three years of experience.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that it's important for us to understand what's going on and we move on from there.

[Roy Belson]: By the way, over the three-year period, there were 58 different identifications of concussion.

[Roy Belson]: all the seasons, and well, you might expect football was the leading one, but soccer, hockey, right up there.

[Roy Belson]: And believe it or not, cheerleading had eight.

[Roy Belson]: So it, you know, it sometimes surprises you where it can happen.

[Roy Belson]: I asked Tanya for that, but she didn't have it exactly that, but she'd have to go back and do the records.

[Roy Belson]: She'd have to go through the records.

[Roy Belson]: She just said it was slightly more female than male to me.

[Roy Belson]: Exactly.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing we should talk about is that it's not just playing getting back into sports.

[Roy Belson]: If a youngster has a concussion,

[Roy Belson]: Counseling and the nurse's office talk about accommodations made in the academic classroom as well.

[Roy Belson]: Because the youngster might be dizzy and not able to complete their homework for a period of time.

[Roy Belson]: So there's communication on that level as well.

[Roy Belson]: has been played into a different stratosphere.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sure over time we can but I'll tell you this is not a not a new topic Because there are so many meetings, you know schools have to meet they have to work them in Obviously, no one wants to meet on Friday nights very few people want to meet on Saturday or Sunday so I mean so you've really everything gets compressed and sometimes you just have to

[Roy Belson]: And it's been a topic for years, and it's always come up short in trying to do that.
