[Roy Belson]: So maybe by the next meeting, if someone can do it, we can designate.

[Roy Belson]: Name and address of the record, please.

[Roy Belson]: Roy Bellison, superintendent of schools.

[Roy Belson]: schools, 2500 Mystic Valley Parkway, Massachusetts.

[Roy Belson]: So I just want to comment a little bit that I think that the enrollment is good.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that between you and the school committee, it supported the schools very well.

[Roy Belson]: And I think we were able to maintain good class size.

[Roy Belson]: I gave you an updated report tonight, which reflected another week into the school year, which is usually the first time there's a bump from the previous numbers that I was able to give you.

[Roy Belson]: In that period of time, there were 94 more new students that came into the public schools, 56 in the elementary, 27 in the middle, and 11 at the high school, Volkin and Curtis, a total of 94 students.

[Roy Belson]: There's no significant change in class size.

[Roy Belson]: There's no significant change in space availability and the like.

[Roy Belson]: The distribution of the new numbers, the Brooks had 21, the Columbus had 13, the McGuinn had 10, and the Roberts had 3 in regular classes.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, the Brooks had 26, the Columbus had 13, the McGuinn Elementary had 10, and the Roberts had 7.

[Roy Belson]: Now, overall, I think we're in good shape.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, I continuously watch things, pay attention, but it doesn't appear that the development that you're bringing into the city is actually having an impact on enrollment because of the nature of the units and because of the cost factors and other things involved.

[Roy Belson]: We'll continue to track it and pay attention to it, but it doesn't look like it's doing that.

[Roy Belson]: The bigger issues for us are obviously the intensity of services that may be required.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes people come into the community with a tremendous need, and sometimes that's caused by the fact that the city provides really good services.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that's something that, you know, it's a double-edged sword.

[Roy Belson]: It's sort of like a

[Roy Belson]: you know, conundrum in the sense you want to provide the best services possible, you want to provide good special needs services, good ELL services, but the better you do, the more likely you are to attract people who are looking for good services and they may not get them in some other communities.

[Roy Belson]: Another factor that we've got to pay attention to a little bit is obviously transportation, because as we move people around, Medford provides 18 buses at free transportation.

[Roy Belson]: We also provide a lot of small vehicles to bring people around to different schools.

[Roy Belson]: And when we moved the young people from the Roberts this year in EL classes to the Brooks, we created a little extra transportation cost.

[Roy Belson]: So those are things we have to pay attention, take a look to.

[Roy Belson]: We also want to see if we can't redirect some students over to the Columbus because that's the lowest enrollment right now.

[Roy Belson]: But overall, we're in very good shape and we should continue to be in good shape and we'll continue to keep you updated.

[Roy Belson]: I think that's, you know, it's important that you know.

[Roy Belson]: It's also important that the public understands that development's going to be very important to the community because finances, whether you're talking about the federal government or the cutbacks coming through Washington, you're talking about the state government where there's continued a search for revenue, although September numbers look really good.

[Roy Belson]: But I don't know if it's sustainable.

[Roy Belson]: If we don't have development, we're not going to be able to sustain the level of services we want to provide to our young people, public safety or any other activity that you want to do because it appears to be that there's not a real appetite for other kinds of revenue around the state or in Washington.

[Roy Belson]: Those are the big concerns and I think the development it can go hand in hand without impacting the schools But naturally we always pay attention.

[Roy Belson]: So I appreciate you listening.

[Roy Belson]: I'm happy to take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: 21.5 at the McGlynn.

[Roy Belson]: I don't see that.

[Roy Belson]: At the McGlynn, if I look at the latest numbers.

[Roy Belson]: If you're looking at the actual number.

[Roy Belson]: Oh, you're looking at the numbers.

[Roy Belson]: Yes.

[Roy Belson]: That's by choice of the principal.

[Roy Belson]: Oh, okay.

[Roy Belson]: Principal might, from time to time, decide that certain classes should be a little larger because the youngsters in it are doing well, and there may be another class that wants to cut it down a little bit because there's a youngster or two that may be more of a challenge.

[Roy Belson]: I just think it's not the kind of developments that are going to.

[Roy Belson]: It's not the kind of developments that seem to be attracting young families that one, can afford it, and two, that might have sufficient space.

[Roy Belson]: It seemed to be they were looking for other things.

[Roy Belson]: So that's a factor that we need to keep in mind.

[Roy Belson]: There's no requirement for regular ed, except if you get into the elementary school up in the kindergarten, you'd have to be like 28, 29.

[Roy Belson]: Is that a contractual requirement?

[Roy Belson]: That's a contractual requirement.

[Roy Belson]: Actual class size typically is around, in the contract, 25 and up, in the contract.

[Roy Belson]: So there's no requirement for an aide until you get to like 29 in the elementary school system.

[Roy Belson]: Well, if you count special ed, we're pushing over 90.

[Roy Belson]: If you're talking about kindergarten, there's 16 kindergartens and there's 16 aides now.

[Roy Belson]: I believe, I'm gonna count them up, probably about 10 of them are full-time and the rest of them are not.

[Roy Belson]: They're all teachers.

[Roy Belson]: No paraprofessionals covering any classes.

[Roy Belson]: As I indicated, most of them come from special ed, but I would say there's over 100 because ELL has some and some other areas have some.

[Roy Belson]: Pretty much, yeah.

[Roy Belson]: It just depends what they do.

[Roy Belson]: So for example, you could have a person who's a tutor, you could have a person who's there assisting in a kindergarten classroom, you could have a person who's helping out in a special needs classroom on a one-to-one aid for a youngster who's physically disabled or has some other impairment.

[Roy Belson]: There's no limit to what it's like.

[Roy Belson]: It's really a need and budget related thing.

[Roy Belson]: And you know, it really depends.

[Roy Belson]: For example, today, you know, we talked about a particular student who has real needs and we added one.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, just it's a matter of trying to determine what the need is and dealing with it.

[Roy Belson]: And from time to time, I suggest to special ed and some of the others, is it necessary to keep an aide where they already are?

[Roy Belson]: Can we move somebody over?

[Roy Belson]: It's always a juggle because obviously everyone, once they get an aide, they want to keep it.

[Roy Belson]: You might see another 50 students in the schools across the board.

[Roy Belson]: at least the way it's normally the pattern is.

[Roy Belson]: We started before September, we got pre-Labor Day, and that has an impact on some families.

[Roy Belson]: Some families just want to take the extra days.

[Roy Belson]: And some people don't get wound until they actually hit September.

[Roy Belson]: So that first week is sort of that thing.

[Roy Belson]: But the next week, according to the Parent Information Center, the movement into the schools this past week is not as heavy as it was the week before.

[Roy Belson]: It's much lighter.

[Roy Belson]: The first big cut, a look at this thing is around October 1st.

[Roy Belson]: We take a look on October 1st, that's when we begin to file numbers with the state as to what our enrollment is.

[Roy Belson]: And that drives Chapter 70 funding and other things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: So we'd like to get a really good handle by October 1st because that tells us what funding we might be eligible for going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Name and address of the record, please.

[Roy Belson]: So I just want to comment a little bit that I think that the enrollment is good.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that between you and the school committee, it supported the schools very well.

[Roy Belson]: And I think we were able to maintain good class size.

[Roy Belson]: I gave you an updated report tonight, which reflected another week into the school year, which is usually the first time there's a bump from the previous numbers that I was able to give you.

[Roy Belson]: In that period of time, there were 94 more new students that came into the public schools, 56 in the elementary, 27 in the middle, and 11 at the high school, Volkin and Curtis, a total of 94 students.

[Roy Belson]: There's no significant change in class size.

[Roy Belson]: There's no significant change in space availability and the like.

[Roy Belson]: The distribution of the new numbers, the Brooks had 21, the Columbus had 13, the McGuinn had 10, and the Roberts had three in regular classes.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, the Brooks had 26, the Columbus had 13, the McGuinn Elementary had 10, and the Roberts had seven.

[Roy Belson]: Now, overall, I think we're in good shape.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, I continuously watch things, pay attention, but it doesn't appear that the development that you're bringing into the city is actually having an impact on enrollment because of the nature of the units and because of the cost factors and other things involved.

[Roy Belson]: We'll continue to track it and pay attention to it, but it doesn't look like it's doing that.

[Roy Belson]: The bigger issues for us are obviously the intensity of services that are maybe required.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes people come into the community with a tremendous need and sometimes that's caused by the fact that the city provides really good services.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that's something that, you know, it's a double-edged sword.

[Roy Belson]: It's sort of like a

[Roy Belson]: you know, conundrum in the sense you want to provide the best services possible, you want to provide good special needs services, good ELL services, but the better you do, the more likely you are to attract people who are looking for good services and they may not get them in some other communities.

[Roy Belson]: So we do quarry checks on everyone who has unsupervised contact with students.

[Roy Belson]: we check it out a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: As far as other groups go, we've rented properties for years, and we haven't required it because generally they're under the supervision of people, and the people there are on a volunteer basis.

[Roy Belson]: So it really isn't exactly the same thing, but it doesn't hurt to have the extra measure of precaution.

[Roy Belson]: Our students are here.

[Roy Belson]: So if we had a coach, and they were coaching on the field, they'd be quarried.

[Roy Belson]: If we have a rental out there, they're not our students.

[Roy Belson]: So it's not unsupervised contact with students.

[Roy Belson]: That's the requirement of the court.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, but access to the building isn't the standard.

[Roy Belson]: There are people who have access to the building.

[Roy Belson]: A parent comes up here.

[Roy Belson]: get checked in, but they're not quarried.

[Roy Belson]: So access to the building is one thing.

[Roy Belson]: The standard for quarrying is unsupervised contact with students.

[Roy Belson]: Look, you can have a person walking on the street and have them contact with someone who's inappropriate.

[Roy Belson]: In this building,

[Roy Belson]: When we have a rental, and we have a situation where people, let's say the Japanese language school, because that's the sanity reference you're making, they have their own students, they have their own people, they have their own coverages, they supervise their students.

[Roy Belson]: We're not responsible for their students.

[Roy Belson]: But anyone who works with our students, if we had an athletic team, if we had a club that met on the weekend, whoever is a supervisor has a glory check.

[Roy Belson]: But you're making two different things.

[Roy Belson]: So, for example, on parents night, parents come up for curriculum night, we don't quarry every parent who comes in the door.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not talking about parents.

[Roy Belson]: You're talking about a type of person in the building, but there's all kinds of people who come into this building who are not quarried.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: I understand what you're saying, but that's not the standard of Corey.

[Roy Belson]: The Corey check requires when a person has unsupervised contact, a frequent visitor kind of thing, so if a person's going to use the media studio, and they're going to come up here more than once, I assume they're going to try to use the studio more than once, they're not becoming a member to only have one production or one activity.

[Roy Belson]: So they're a frequent action person up here, and so it doesn't hurt to know who they are.

[Roy Belson]: That's all.

[Roy Belson]: They could walk into the front of the building.

[Roy Belson]: They go out the main door of the studio.

[Roy Belson]: Rentals and parents.

[Roy Belson]: including everybody sitting around the table tonight.

[Roy Belson]: and have access to a particular area of the building.

[Roy Belson]: All right, look, it's obviously a discussion.

[Roy Belson]: All right, thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Roy Belson]: President, let me just make a couple quick comments on CORI so everyone understands how CORIs work, okay?

[Roy Belson]: First of all, a CORI check is very quick.

[Roy Belson]: You fill out the paperwork, you bring in your material.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, identification is required to ensure that you are actually the person who is being CORI checked.

[Roy Belson]: That's just a safeguard.

[Roy Belson]: You get it back in about 24 hours or less.

[Roy Belson]: It's that quick, right?

[Roy Belson]: Now, if you're denied employment or volunteer status on a Cori check, what happens is you then can be told why you're denied, and you have a right to appeal it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I can't share a Cori.

[Roy Belson]: If I get a Cori, and I'm the person who reviews Coris in the school department, I can't share that Cori with anybody.

[Roy Belson]: I have to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: I'll give you an example.

[Roy Belson]: insurance violation, failure to register your car.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of those things that show up.

[Roy Belson]: Those things are not terribly important to me unless, in fact, you're driving a bus or you're doing something that might be related to the particular offense.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, substances, things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: And when it happened, how it happened, did it happen last week, last year, or did it happen 20 years ago when you were a kid?

[Roy Belson]: I mean, those things are different.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, you look at those things.

[Roy Belson]: But let's say you're denied.

[Roy Belson]: You have a right to get your Cori checked.

[Roy Belson]: You have a right to make it public yourself.

[Roy Belson]: And if you're denied for something stupid or something you think is discriminatory, you can make that public.

[Roy Belson]: I can't, but you can.

[Roy Belson]: So any issuing authority has to keep it quiet, has to look at it that way.

[Roy Belson]: But an individual who's affected by it has every right to protest that, in fact, their Cori was denied for some superficial reason.

[Roy Belson]: So it's important to know that.

[Roy Belson]: So you can't discriminate just simply because, you know, I don't like you because you're a person who says things that I don't like.

[Roy Belson]: It has to be a substantive reason or a person has a right to appeal it.

[Roy Belson]: And oftentimes, people come in and they say, you know, that happened so many years ago.

[Roy Belson]: I've been this way for so many times.

[Roy Belson]: Can you give me a chance?

[Roy Belson]: That happens.

[Roy Belson]: So I just want you to understand how that process works.

[Roy Belson]: Now, within the school system, everybody has to be fingerprinted as well.

[Roy Belson]: It's an FBI check.

[Roy Belson]: Not volunteers, but people who are employees.

[Roy Belson]: Think of it.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a whole series of things that have to go on in our world.

[Roy Belson]: So it's the nature of society today.

[Roy Belson]: People are very concerned about safety.

[Roy Belson]: They're very concerned about who's there, who's in contact with their young people.

[Roy Belson]: And there's a lot of steps involved.

[Roy Belson]: But you do have a right to protest an adverse decision on your car for each other.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to refer to the report that was given last night, because I think that's the most relevant one right now.

[Roy Belson]: It talks about the impact of real estate development on class size, class enrollment in the Metro Public Schools.

[Roy Belson]: And we picked eight

[Roy Belson]: units or eight different developments in the city with 150 or more units in it and looked at the class size impact, looked at the impact of student enrollment by school, by grade.

[Roy Belson]: by different development to give you an idea of what the impact is.

[Roy Belson]: And if you read it closely, you'll find that there's 105 students in eight developments that come to our public schools, 105.

[Roy Belson]: Two of them are in outside placements.

[Roy Belson]: Two of them are in outside placements.

[Roy Belson]: And if you spread them out and look at it, the average class size in the elementary schools is 18.3.

[Roy Belson]: That's the best in the commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: Almost the best in the commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: You should be proud of that.

[Roy Belson]: You support the schools.

[Roy Belson]: The school committee supports the schools.

[Roy Belson]: You should be proud of that.

[Roy Belson]: Because you've got good class size.

[Roy Belson]: Because you've asked the question about class size over and over again at the various meetings that I've attended on budget.

[Roy Belson]: So I think you should have that as you go into the campaign.

[Roy Belson]: I think you should know that.

[Roy Belson]: But there is a rumor going around that somewhere development is overrunning the schools.

[Roy Belson]: The schools are overwhelmed.

[Roy Belson]: It's not true.

[Roy Belson]: It's not true.

[Roy Belson]: Go over the report.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not going to go over it with you now because it's late and you can read.

[Roy Belson]: But I think it's important that you know this as you move around the city and people ask you about development.

[Roy Belson]: Development is important to support the various initiatives, to reduce the tax rate, to do all the things that you want to do in the community.

[Roy Belson]: And at the same time, it's a legitimate concern to determine whether or not it's going to cost you more money in your public schools.

[Roy Belson]: Well, right now, we're doing just fine.

[Roy Belson]: Right now you could add 155 seats to the elementary schools and still be below 20 students in a class on average.

[Roy Belson]: You could add 500 seats and still have decent class size at this particular point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Now there may be some need for some looking at distribution.

[Roy Belson]: One school maybe has a little bit less than another.

[Roy Belson]: That's always the case.

[Roy Belson]: You work on that.

[Roy Belson]: But you should know as a city council, you should know as the people that help to fund the budget and do development in the city, that your schools have sufficient capacity to handle additional students right now.

[Roy Belson]: And we can move forward.

[Roy Belson]: You should also know

[Roy Belson]: that our schools are doing just fine.

[Roy Belson]: The School Building Authority will be in Medford

[Roy Belson]: on October 5 to begin their site visit to determine whether or not we can receive funding for that purpose.

[Roy Belson]: So we can look at that as another possibility of developing our schools, our programs, and moving things forward.

[Roy Belson]: So a lot of good is going on.

[Roy Belson]: I welcome the opportunity to share that tonight.

[Roy Belson]: That's the requirement of the court.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, but access to the building isn't the standard.

[Roy Belson]: There are people who have access to the building.

[Roy Belson]: A parent comes up here.

[Roy Belson]: They're checked in, but they're not quarried.

[Roy Belson]: So access to the building is one thing.

[Roy Belson]: The standard for quarrying is unsupervised contact with students.

[Roy Belson]: Look, you can have a person walking on the street and have them contact with someone who's inappropriate.

[Roy Belson]: In this building,

[Roy Belson]: When we have a rental, and we have a situation where people, let's say the Japanese language school, because that's the sanity reference you're making, they have their own students, they have their own people, they have their own coverages, they supervise their students.

[Roy Belson]: We're not responsible for their students.

[Roy Belson]: But anyone who works with our students, if we had an athletic team, if we had a club that met on the weekend, whoever is a supervisor has a quarry check.

[Roy Belson]: And on top of that, most instances has a fingerprint check.

[Roy Belson]: But you're making two different things.

[Roy Belson]: So, for example, on parents night, parents come up for curriculum night.

[Roy Belson]: We don't quarry every parent who comes in the door.

[Roy Belson]: But they could.

[Roy Belson]: You're talking about a type of person in the building, but there's all kinds of people who come into this building who are not chlorinated.

[Roy Belson]: I understand what you're saying, but that's not the standard of Corey.

[Roy Belson]: The Corey check requires when a person has unsupervised contact, a frequent visitor kind of thing.

[Roy Belson]: So if a person's going to use the media studio, and they're going to come up here more than once, I assume they're going to try to use the studio more than once, they're not becoming a member to only have one production or one activity.

[Roy Belson]: So they're a frequent action person up here, and so it doesn't hurt to know who they are.

[Roy Belson]: That's all.

[Roy Belson]: Right, but it would be supervision, correct?

[Roy Belson]: They could walk into the front of the building.

[Roy Belson]: They go out the main door of the studio.

[Roy Belson]: You can't tell who's who's a problem on a given day.

[Roy Belson]: It could be anybody.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think it's unreasonable if a person is going to be up here frequently.

[Roy Belson]: have access to a particular area of the building.

[Roy Belson]: They're not working with our students directly.

[Roy Belson]: They're working with their population.

[Roy Belson]: All right, look, it's obviously a discussion.

[Roy Belson]: Right, thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Roy Belson]: President, let me just make a couple quick comments on CORI so everyone understands how CORIs work, okay?

[Roy Belson]: First of all, a CORI check is very quick.

[Roy Belson]: You fill out the paperwork, you bring in your material, obviously identification is required to ensure that you are actually the person who is being CORI checked.

[Roy Belson]: That's just a safeguard.

[Roy Belson]: You get it back in about 24 hours or less.

[Roy Belson]: It's that quick, right?

[Roy Belson]: Now, if you're denied employment or volunteer status on a Cori check, what happens is you then can be told why you're denied, and you have a right to appeal it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I can't share a Cori.

[Roy Belson]: If I get a Cori, and I'm the person who reviews Coris in the school department, I can't share that Cori with anybody.

[Roy Belson]: I have to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: I'll give you an example.

[Roy Belson]: Typically, DUI.

[Roy Belson]: insurance violation, failure to register your car.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of those things that show up.

[Roy Belson]: Those things are not terribly important to me unless, in fact, you're driving a bus or you're doing something that might be related to the particular offense.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, substances, things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: And when it happened, how it happened, did it happen last week, last year, or did it happen 20 years ago when you were a kid?

[Roy Belson]: I mean, those things are different.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, you look at those things.

[Roy Belson]: But let's say you're denied.

[Roy Belson]: You have a right to get your Cory check.

[Roy Belson]: You have a right to make it public yourself.

[Roy Belson]: And if you're denied for something stupid or something you think is discriminatory, you can make that public.

[Roy Belson]: I can't, but you can.

[Roy Belson]: So any issuing authority has to keep it quiet, has to look at it that way.

[Roy Belson]: But an individual who's affected by it has every right to protest.

[Roy Belson]: that, in fact, that Corey was denied for some superficial reason.

[Roy Belson]: So it's important to know that.

[Roy Belson]: So you can't discriminate just simply because, you know, I don't like you because you're a person who says things that I don't like.

[Roy Belson]: It has to be a substantive reason or a person has a right to appeal it.

[Roy Belson]: And oftentimes, people come in and they say, you know, that happened so many years ago.

[Roy Belson]: I've been this way for so many times.

[Roy Belson]: Can you give me a chance?

[Roy Belson]: That happens.

[Roy Belson]: So I just want you to understand how that process works.

[Roy Belson]: Now within the school system, everybody has to be fingerprinted as well.

[Roy Belson]: It's an FBI job.

[Roy Belson]: Not volunteers, but people who are employees.

[Roy Belson]: Fingerprinted.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a whole series of things that have to go on in our world.

[Roy Belson]: It's the nature of society today.

[Roy Belson]: People are very concerned about safety.

[Roy Belson]: They're very concerned about who's there, who's in contact with their young people.

[Roy Belson]: And there's a lot of steps involved.

[Roy Belson]: But you do have a right to protest an adverse decision on your car for each other.

[Roy Belson]: by different development to give you an idea of what the impact is.

[Roy Belson]: If I can just answer that a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: I think the thing that you've got to remember

[Roy Belson]: this is the first full year that MCAS 2.0 was out there.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result, as a new test, it really, in order to be fair to people, they had to see the kinds of questions, you know, they had to see what it was about, whether it really, you know, the questions were proper and the like, and they have to do that analysis with their own testing company.

[Roy Belson]: So

[Roy Belson]: rather than it's like a new product, it's really in a pilot phase.

[Roy Belson]: So the second year, they're saying, OK, you had a year to try it out.

[Roy Belson]: We've had a year to work out the bugs.

[Roy Belson]: Now we'll start to look at it for real.

[Roy Belson]: So that's really part of it.

[Roy Belson]: It isn't really an attempt to hide anything, because I think some people in the state would love to issue accountability ratings.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, I think part of it is because you can't just do that with new stuff.

[Roy Belson]: You'd have to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: We always do.

[Roy Belson]: I just look at schedules.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, there's a lot of things you want to talk about.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight was a good example.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll get a meeting.

[Roy Belson]: It's not something, you know, we obviously have those meetings.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to say one thing.

[Roy Belson]: I've been talking to Senator Jalen, who's about to file a bill in the legislature, in the Senate, looking to modify the accountability system in a substantial way, where it goes, how it goes.

[Roy Belson]: But you can clearly tell that the debate is very strong these days about academic proficiency not being the only way you measure a school.

[Roy Belson]: And two polls were out, the Gallup poll and the Phi Delta Kappan poll, both of which sampled parents across the country, all of whom were saying there's more to school than testing.

[Roy Belson]: And the pushback is becoming very, very strong.

[Roy Belson]: The Massachusetts Board of Education tends to be very protesting.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll have to see where that plays out.

[Roy Belson]: But there's an awful lot of ferment out there right now about the implications of just simply evaluating schools only on test results.

[Roy Belson]: So I've seen portions of Senator Jalen's bill.

[Roy Belson]: I'll introduce it to you at some point in the near future when she's ready to release it.

[Roy Belson]: Because I think there's a lot of good material in there looking at how to look at schools in a more comprehensive way.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about social and emotional learning.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about career and technical education.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about health.

[Roy Belson]: All those things are important in a school.

[Roy Belson]: We're developing youth that have transitioned to adulthood.

[Roy Belson]: We're not just developing test takers.

[Roy Belson]: So a good school in a community like, you know, in Boston, where you've got 26 schools that someone decided was underperforming, there's a lot of things that go on in some of those demographies out there that are far more complex than just simply a test score.

[Roy Belson]: So how we look at our young people, how we look at schools and what we do, needs more scrutiny.

[Roy Belson]: And I think Senator Jalen and others are starting to raise that question in a very, very powerful way in the state.

[Roy Belson]: So let me give you an example of something that was an interesting one last year.

[Roy Belson]: Fascinating kind of thing.

[Roy Belson]: A student who came to this country, booked a test, but didn't take the English language arts test because it was his first year in the country.

[Roy Belson]: However, because he had a SASID number when he was in the first grade, he had been in the country for a short period of time, the state decided that he was, in fact, not a first year student.

[Roy Belson]: We had to petition and clean that out.

[Roy Belson]: Now, how would we know, coming from another district someplace else, that this wasn't his first year?

[Roy Belson]: That's an example of a discrepancy.

[Roy Belson]: Medicals, people that are out on a medical who somehow don't get coded out of the thing.

[Roy Belson]: All of a sudden, you have to go back and say, well, this kid's been in the hospital for the last six months.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, how can you count them?

[Roy Belson]: They couldn't possibly take the test in the setting they were in.

[Roy Belson]: So those are some of the things that happen.

[Roy Belson]: And you have to pay attention to those, because otherwise, you have 100 kids and five or six kids don't take the test for various reasons.

[Roy Belson]: All of a sudden, you're below a certain threshold.

[Roy Belson]: And that's not what you're going to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: And with subgroups, it's even less, because the subgroups are even smaller numbers.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have 25 kids, one kid could be four percentage points.

[Roy Belson]: OK, Beverly's going to do this.

[Roy Belson]: So we have a return visit from Emily, straight from Market Basket.

[Roy Belson]: Before you go down that road, our schools were built on a racial balance plan.

[Roy Belson]: Schools were built with choice as one of the options.

[Roy Belson]: And if we have to change that, we need to change the plan and get approval for it.

[Roy Belson]: No, you could choose elementary.

[Roy Belson]: See, one of the things is that people don't realize is when the schools were built,

[Roy Belson]: The essential part was, first of all, the Andrews and McGuinn were the first two schools that were built.

[Roy Belson]: So people, you know, it was a, let's say a progressive movement of youngsters.

[Roy Belson]: But you could have chosen certain schools after the other schools were built.

[Roy Belson]: So there are plenty of people that have chosen schools outside of their geographical area.

[Roy Belson]: It's happened all the time.

[Roy Belson]: But now people are getting settled.

[Roy Belson]: They're getting comfortable.

[Roy Belson]: And to some degree, things have sort of settled in.

[Roy Belson]: People sort of stay in their own geographic area for the most part, although there are some people that want to go to another school.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things that we've got to deal with is that we may want to look at redistricting to some degree, because the Columbus is somewhat under-enrolled compared to some of the others.

[Roy Belson]: And if we change a few lines, we'd get a few more people over there.

[Roy Belson]: Just got to look at those things.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, it's all part of it.

[Roy Belson]: Choice was part of the plan in getting 90 cents on the dollar.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, we get plenty of requests.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe we don't see it.

[Roy Belson]: We grant a lot of them.

[Roy Belson]: But you don't see them because you didn't make that request.

[Roy Belson]: But we grant a lot of requests.

[Roy Belson]: We take a look at class size first.

[Roy Belson]: We take a look at whether we think the trends are too much in one direction or the other.

[Roy Belson]: We look at the balance between different populations.

[Roy Belson]: But we have granted quite a bit.

[Roy Belson]: Diane, what would you say?

[Roy Belson]: Because Diane handles the elementaries.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I guess it's been less of a drive for people to do that, but over the years, I can assure you people came in frequently asking to go to one school or the other.

[Roy Belson]: Well, then you would have a situation where certain sections of the city would populate one school and some would populate the other school.

[Roy Belson]: Well, then no one gets a choice.

[Roy Belson]: This trade-off, so all of these systems, for the most part, it's worked.

[Roy Belson]: This is a year where we have one real aberration.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at the rest of the enrollment at the Andrews and the McGlynn, it's within a few students of each other.

[Roy Belson]: Not at this level.

[Roy Belson]: This is an aberration this particular year.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I think that there were a few situations where we were concerned about class size.

[Roy Belson]: And so there was some desire that maybe we should move people to one school or the other.

[Roy Belson]: In some cases, it could be transportation situations that were in there.

[Roy Belson]: But Diane, you may want to.

[Roy Belson]: Long time ago, long time ago.

[Roy Belson]: There was one redistricting that took place probably three or four years in and that's it.

[Roy Belson]: Let me give you a little bit on that too, just to think about it.

[Roy Belson]: When the schools were built,

[Roy Belson]: The two schools that sort of had a lock on the Brooks were the Dame and the Irving and Gleason.

[Roy Belson]: Those were the three.

[Roy Belson]: But there was a whole portion of people that went to the Dame.

[Roy Belson]: that we needed to take to the Columbus, because we would have had the Columbus even more underpopulated than it is today.

[Roy Belson]: So there was a need to make a division on that side of the river and move it towards the Columbus, or else we would have had an underpopulated school in South Medford and an overpopulated school in West Medford.

[Roy Belson]: So that was the sort of divide there.

[Roy Belson]: And of course, with busing transportation,

[Roy Belson]: we felt it was very doable.

[Roy Belson]: That was the thinking at the time.

[Roy Belson]: So I know that some people might disagree with this, but I'm going to say it anyway.

[Roy Belson]: This is that when one school draws a little bit more than the other school,

[Roy Belson]: The other school has to want to compete.

[Roy Belson]: The other school has to want to pick up the energy and to try and find ways to bring people, because they should take pride in their development and making some things happen instead of saying, oh, I don't know what was made.

[Roy Belson]: I think there's a certain amount of that.

[Roy Belson]: And I've said this to some of you as we've talked.

[Roy Belson]: The culture at one place is not as energetic as the culture at the other.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got to change that.

[Roy Belson]: And that's part of the reasons why we made some of the changes we made.

[Roy Belson]: Sending a message.

[Roy Belson]: And that's the way you do it.

[Roy Belson]: You have to do it.

[Roy Belson]: You know, when we talked about in the past, McGlynn was taking over the place and the Andrews was falling backwards after a number of years.

[Roy Belson]: And we sent a message and we changed some things.

[Roy Belson]: So it's not perfect, but it's an attempt to send a message and say, come on, you want to be

[Roy Belson]: the school of choice, you want to bring people to you, then you've got to step it up a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: And that happens, it happens in sports, it happens in the arts, it happens in academics.

[Roy Belson]: I don't believe in competition as the only way of doing it, but sometimes there's a little competition that's useful.

[Roy Belson]: It didn't have to be the same population, it had to be within ranges.

[Roy Belson]: It's a change.

[Roy Belson]: And because part of it is the growth of the Yale population has changed a lot.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, that was not as significant years ago.

[Roy Belson]: Well, they were defaulted to McGlynn now because that was the school that was essentially under enrolled in the sixth grade.

[Roy Belson]: This is a report you asked for, and it's timely because I'll be at the City Council tomorrow night and there's at least three motions on the agenda to ask me these questions, okay?

[Roy Belson]: But I think you should be very pleased when you look at the details here, so I'm going to go through it a little bit because I think it's really a significant report.

[Roy Belson]: So it's designed to show school enrollment impact of new real estate development in Medford.

[Roy Belson]: This report looks at eight real estate complexes that contain 150 units or more.

[Roy Belson]: We didn't look at the baby ones here and there because that would be too small.

[Roy Belson]: The attached chart identifies each complex and provides information on the total number of enrolled students and their distributions across each of our schools.

[Roy Belson]: The overall initial enrollment in our schools is 4,257 students, which is 54 students higher than last year at this time.

[Roy Belson]: This number is going to grow moderately as we get to October, because that's the way things happen.

[Roy Belson]: The total number of students living in these eight complexes is 105.

[Roy Belson]: Two of the students are in outside placements.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, the enrollments from these eight complexes is 2.4% of our total school population.

[Roy Belson]: Given existing class sizes and space capacity, the enrollment from these developments has no significant effect.

[Roy Belson]: The average class size of our elementary schools is 18.3 students in the regular education classrooms.

[Roy Belson]: I provided a chart that details the grade level distribution, another chart that looks at each school, a third chart that shows enrollment distribution by complex in school, and a fourth chart that shows the enrollment percentage by school.

[Roy Belson]: Our elementary schools could enroll an additional 500 students and still be within our contractual limits for class size.

[Roy Belson]: We could enroll an additional 155 students and still maintain an average class size below 20 students, given normal distributions.

[Roy Belson]: Our middle schools were built for 1,200 students.

[Roy Belson]: We currently have 937.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, our middle school class size in the four major course subjects is around 20 students.

[Roy Belson]: So again, our class size is excellent, but we have plenty of capacity.

[Roy Belson]: People are saying there's no capacity anymore.

[Roy Belson]: The new developments are going to swamp the schools.

[Roy Belson]: Not true.

[Roy Belson]: The high school vocational program has room to grow.

[Roy Belson]: Space utilization could be adjusted if necessary to increase enrollment substantially.

[Roy Belson]: For example, moving the pre-K programs and offices would open up additional space in the future.

[Roy Belson]: If necessary, we can consider some redistricting to shift enrollment to the Columbus.

[Roy Belson]: The allocation of specialized spaces for small groups and services could be revisited to create more sections or more options as well.

[Roy Belson]: In conclusion, the data clearly indicates that the impact of major residential real estate development has not adversely impacted our schools.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to take you to the first chart.

[Roy Belson]: You're looking at the eight big complexes.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at them and you see the numbers of families in the first column,

[Roy Belson]: So a family might have more than one kid, so that there would be less than the total number.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have 16 number students in 100 Rivers Edge Drive, you only have 11 families.

[Roy Belson]: Some families have more than one child.

[Roy Belson]: And so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: And some of these complexes have existed for some time.

[Roy Belson]: They're not brand new.

[Roy Belson]: They've been here for a while.

[Roy Belson]: So when you look at it, you're looking at 105 students impacting us at this point in time, and two of them are in outside placements, and the distribution's pretty good.

[Roy Belson]: So let me go to the next chart for a minute.

[Roy Belson]: No.

[Roy Belson]: OK, Lumiere.

[Roy Belson]: All right, so you go to the next chart, and you look at grade level class sizes.

[Roy Belson]: All right, kindergarten, there are 16 teachers district wide, and the average class size is 18.4.

[Roy Belson]: And grade one, 18.8.

[Roy Belson]: In grade 2, 18.

[Roy Belson]: In grade 3, 17.7.

[Roy Belson]: In grade 4, 19.3.

[Roy Belson]: In grade 5, 17.7.

[Roy Belson]: Those class sizes are private school class sizes.

[Roy Belson]: There are very few school districts in this area that have class sizes that good.

[Roy Belson]: You've done an excellent job supporting that.

[Roy Belson]: is misleading everyone.

[Roy Belson]: We're not.

[Roy Belson]: Is that near?

[Roy Belson]: But when their families grow, they move out.

[Roy Belson]: They don't stay in these developments.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll get a meeting.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to say one thing.

[Roy Belson]: I've been talking to Senator Jalen, who's about to file a bill in the legislature, in the Senate, looking to modify the accountability system in a substantial way.

[Roy Belson]: Where it goes, how it goes, but you can clearly tell that the debate is very strong these days about academic proficiency not being the only way you measure a school.

[Roy Belson]: And two polls were out, the Gallup poll and the Phi Delta Kappan poll, both of which sampled parents across the country, all of whom were saying there's more to school than testing.

[Roy Belson]: And the pushback is becoming very, very strong.

[Roy Belson]: The Massachusetts Board of Education tends to be very protesting.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll have to see where that plays out.

[Roy Belson]: But there's an awful lot of ferment out there right now about the implications of just simply evaluating schools only on test results.

[Roy Belson]: So I've seen portions of Senator Jalen's bill.

[Roy Belson]: I'll introduce it to you at some point in the near future when she's ready to release it, because I think there's a lot of good material in there looking at how to look at schools in a more comprehensive way.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about social and emotional learning.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about career and technical education.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about health.

[Roy Belson]: All those things are important in a school.

[Roy Belson]: We're developing youth that have transitioned to adulthood.

[Roy Belson]: We're not just developing test takers.

[Roy Belson]: So a good school in a community like in Boston where you've got 26 schools that someone decided was underperforming, there's a lot of things that go on in some of those demographies out there that are far more complex than just simply a test score.

[Roy Belson]: So how we look at our young people, how we look at schools and what we do needs more scrutiny.

[Roy Belson]: And I think Senator Jalen and others are starting to raise that question in a very, very powerful way in the state.

[Roy Belson]: So let me give you an example of something that was an interesting one last year.

[Roy Belson]: Fascinating kind of thing.

[Roy Belson]: A student who came to this country, booked a test, but didn't take the English language arts test because it was his first year in the country.

[Roy Belson]: However, because he had a SASID number when he was in the first grade,

[Roy Belson]: OK, he had been in the country for a short period of time.

[Roy Belson]: The state decided that he was, in fact, not a first year student.

[Roy Belson]: We had to petition and clean that out.

[Roy Belson]: Now, how would we know, coming from another district someplace else, that this wasn't his first year?

[Roy Belson]: That's an example of a discrepancy.

[Roy Belson]: Medicals, people that are out on a medical who somehow don't get coded out of the thing, all of a sudden you have to go back and say, well, this kid's been in the hospital for the last six months.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, how can you count them?

[Roy Belson]: They couldn't possibly take the test in the setting they were in.

[Roy Belson]: So those are some of the things that happen.

[Roy Belson]: And you have to pay attention to those, because otherwise, you have 100 kids and five or six kids don't take the test for various reasons.

[Roy Belson]: All of a sudden, you're below a certain threshold.

[Roy Belson]: And that's not what you're going to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: And with subgroups, it's even less, because the subgroups are even smaller numbers.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have 25 kids, one kid could be four percentage points.

[Roy Belson]: I have Anthony with me tonight.

[Roy Belson]: So we have a return visit from Evely.

[Roy Belson]: Stop and shop.

[Roy Belson]: Before you go down that road, our schools were built on a racial balance plan.

[Roy Belson]: Schools were built with choice as one of the options.

[Roy Belson]: And if we have to change that, we need to change the plan and get approval for it.

[Roy Belson]: No, you could choose elementary.

[Roy Belson]: See, one of the things is that people don't realize is when the schools were built,

[Roy Belson]: The essential part was, first of all, the Andrews and McGuinn were the first two schools that were built.

[Roy Belson]: So people, you know, it was a, let's say, a progressive movement of youngsters.

[Roy Belson]: But you could have chosen certain schools after the other schools were built.

[Roy Belson]: So there are plenty of people that have chosen schools outside of their geographical area.

[Roy Belson]: It's happened all the time.

[Roy Belson]: But now people are getting settled.

[Roy Belson]: They're getting comfortable.

[Roy Belson]: And to some degree, things have sort of settled in.

[Roy Belson]: People sort of stay in their own geographic area for the most part, although there are some people that want to go to another school.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things that we've got to deal with is that we may want to look at redistricting to some degree, because the Columbus is somewhat under-enrolled compared to some of the others.

[Roy Belson]: And if we change a few lines, we'd get a few more people over there.

[Roy Belson]: Just got to look at those things.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, it's all part of it.

[Roy Belson]: Choice was part of the plan in getting 90 cents on the dollar.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, we get plenty of requests.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe we don't see it.

[Roy Belson]: We grant a lot of them.

[Roy Belson]: But you don't see them because you didn't make that request.

[Roy Belson]: But we grant a lot of requests.

[Roy Belson]: We take a look at class size first.

[Roy Belson]: We take a look at whether we think the trends are too much in one direction or the other.

[Roy Belson]: We look at the balance between different populations.

[Roy Belson]: But we have granted quite a bit.

[Roy Belson]: Diane, what would you say?

[Roy Belson]: Because Diane handles the elementaries.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I guess it's been less of a drive for people to do that, but over the years, I can assure you people came in frequently asking to go to one school or the other.

[Roy Belson]: Well, then you would have a situation where certain sections of the city would populate one school and some would populate the other school.

[Roy Belson]: Well, then no one gets a choice, you know what I mean?

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, this trade-off, so all of these systems, you know, for the most part it's worked.

[Roy Belson]: This is a year where we have one real aberration.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at the rest of the enrollment at the Andrews and the McGlinn, it's within a few students of each other.

[Roy Belson]: Not at this level.

[Roy Belson]: This is an aberration this particular year.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I think that there were a few situations where we were concerned about class size.

[Roy Belson]: And so there was some desire to maybe we should move people to one school or the other.

[Roy Belson]: Some cases, it could be transportation situations that were in there.

[Roy Belson]: But Diane, you may want to.

[Roy Belson]: Long time ago, long time ago.

[Roy Belson]: There was one redistricting that took place probably three or four years in and that's it.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sure it was just a miscommunication.

[Roy Belson]: So let me give you a little bit on that too, just to think about it.

[Roy Belson]: When the schools were built,

[Roy Belson]: The two schools that sort of had a lock on the Brooks were the Dame and the Hervey and Gleason.

[Roy Belson]: Those were the three, but there was a whole portion of people that went to the Dame.

[Roy Belson]: that we needed to take to the Columbus because we would have had the Columbus even more underpopulated than it is today.

[Roy Belson]: So there was a need to make a division on that side of the river and move it towards the Columbus or else we would have had an underpopulated school in South Medford and an overpopulated school in West Medford.

[Roy Belson]: So that was the sort of divide there.

[Roy Belson]: And of course, with busing transportation,

[Roy Belson]: we felt it was very doable.

[Roy Belson]: That was the thinking at the time.

[Roy Belson]: So I know that some people might disagree with this, but I'm going to say it anyway.

[Roy Belson]: This is that when one school draws a little bit more than the other school, the other school has to want to compete.

[Roy Belson]: The other school has to want to

[Roy Belson]: pick up the energy and to try and find ways to bring people, because they should take pride in their development and making some things happen instead of saying, oh, I don't know what was made.

[Roy Belson]: I think there's a certain amount of that.

[Roy Belson]: And I've said this to some of you as we've talked.

[Roy Belson]: The culture at one place is not as energetic as the culture at the other.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got to change that.

[Roy Belson]: And that's part of the reasons why we made some of the changes we made.

[Roy Belson]: Sending a message.

[Roy Belson]: And that's the way you do it.

[Roy Belson]: You have to do it.

[Roy Belson]: You know, when we talked about in the past, McGlynn was taking over the place and the Andrews was falling backwards after a number of years.

[Roy Belson]: So this is a report you asked for and it's timely because I'll be at the City Council tomorrow night and there's at least three motions on the agenda.

[Roy Belson]: to ask me these questions, okay?

[Roy Belson]: But I think you should be very pleased when you look at the details here.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm going to go through it a little bit because I think it's really a significant report.

[Roy Belson]: So it's designed to show school enrollment impact of new real estate development in Medford.

[Roy Belson]: This report looks at eight real estate complexes that contain 150 units or more.

[Roy Belson]: We didn't look at the baby ones here and there because that would be too small.

[Roy Belson]: The attached chart identifies each complex and provides information on the total number of enrolled students and their distributions across each of our schools.

[Roy Belson]: The overall initial enrollment in our schools is 4,257 students, which is 54 students higher than last year at this time.

[Roy Belson]: This number is going to grow moderately as we get to October, because that's the way things happen.

[Roy Belson]: The total number of students living in these eight complexes is 105.

[Roy Belson]: Two of the students are in outside placements.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, the enrollments from these eight complexes is 2.4% of our total school population.

[Roy Belson]: Given existing class sizes and space capacity, the enrollment from these developments has no significant effect.

[Roy Belson]: The average class size of our elementary schools is 18.3 students in the regular education classrooms.

[Roy Belson]: I provided a chart that details the grade level distribution, another chart that looks at each school, a third chart that shows enrollment distribution by complex in school, and a fourth chart that shows the enrollment percentage by school.

[Roy Belson]: Our elementary schools could enroll an additional 500 students and still be within our contractual limits for class size.

[Roy Belson]: We could enroll an additional 155 students and still maintain an average class size below 20 students, given normal distributions.

[Roy Belson]: Our middle schools were built for 1,200 students.

[Roy Belson]: We currently have 937.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, our middle school class size in the four major course subjects is around 20 students.

[Roy Belson]: So again, our class size is excellent, but we have plenty of capacity.

[Roy Belson]: People are saying there's no capacity anymore.

[Roy Belson]: The new developments are going to swamp the schools.

[Roy Belson]: Not true.

[Roy Belson]: The high school vocational program has room to grow.

[Roy Belson]: Space utilization could be adjusted if necessary to increase enrollment substantially.

[Roy Belson]: For example, moving the pre-K programs and offices would open up additional space in the future.

[Roy Belson]: If necessary, we can consider some redistricting to shift enrollment to the Columbus.

[Roy Belson]: The allocation of specialized spaces for small groups and services could be revisited to create more sections or more options as well.

[Roy Belson]: In conclusion, the data clearly indicates that the impact of major residential real estate development has not adversely impacted our schools.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to take you to the first chart.

[Roy Belson]: You're looking at the eight big complexes.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at them and you see the numbers of families in the first column,

[Roy Belson]: So a family might have more than one kid, so that there would be less than the total number.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have 16 number students in 100 Rivers Ed Drive, you only have 11 families.

[Roy Belson]: Some families have more than one child.

[Roy Belson]: And so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: And some of these complexes have existed for some time.

[Roy Belson]: They're not brand new.

[Roy Belson]: They've been here for a while.

[Roy Belson]: So when you look at it, you're looking at 105 students impacting us at this point in time, and two of them are outside placements, and the distribution's pretty good.

[Roy Belson]: So let me go to the next chart for a minute.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, Lumiere.

[Roy Belson]: All right, so you go to the next chart, and you look at grade level class sizes.

[Roy Belson]: And grade one, 18.8.

[Roy Belson]: In grade 2, 18.

[Roy Belson]: In grade 3, 17.7.

[Roy Belson]: In grade 4, 19.3.

[Roy Belson]: In grade 5, 17.7.

[Roy Belson]: So that's really part of it.

[Roy Belson]: It isn't really an attempt to hide anything because I think some people in the state would love to issue accountability ratings.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, I think part of it is because you can't just do that with new stuff.

[Roy Belson]: You'd have to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight was a good example.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll get a meeting.

[Roy Belson]: It's not something, you know, we obviously have those meetings.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to say one thing.

[Roy Belson]: I've been talking to Senator Jalen, who's about to file a bill in the legislature, in the Senate, looking to modify the accountability system in a substantial way.

[Roy Belson]: Where it goes, how it goes, but you can clearly tell that the debate is very strong these days about academic proficiency not being the only way you measure a school.

[Roy Belson]: And two polls were out, the Gallup poll and the Phi Delta Kappan poll, both of which sampled parents across the country, all of whom were saying there's more to school than testing.

[Roy Belson]: And the pushback is becoming very, very strong.

[Roy Belson]: The Massachusetts Board of Education tends to be very protesting.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll have to see where that plays out.

[Roy Belson]: But there's an awful lot of ferment out there right now about the implications of just simply evaluating schools only on test results.

[Roy Belson]: So I've seen portions of Senator Jalen's bill.

[Roy Belson]: I'll introduce it to you at some point in the near future when she's ready to release it.

[Roy Belson]: Because I think there's a lot of good material in there, looking at how to look at schools in a more comprehensive way.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about social and emotional learning.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about career and technical education.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about health.

[Roy Belson]: All those things are important in a school.

[Roy Belson]: We're developing youth that have transitioned to adulthood.

[Roy Belson]: We're not just developing test takers.

[Roy Belson]: So a good school in a community like in Boston, where you've got 26 schools that someone decided was underperforming, there's a lot of things that go on in some of those demographies out there that are far more complex than just simply a test score.

[Roy Belson]: So how we look at our young people, how we look at schools, and what we do needs more scrutiny.

[Roy Belson]: And I think Senator Jalen and others are starting to raise that question in a very, very powerful way in the state.

[Roy Belson]: So let me give you an example of something that was an interesting one last year.

[Roy Belson]: Fascinating kind of thing.

[Roy Belson]: A student who came to this country, booked a test, but didn't take the English Language Arts test because it was his first year in the country.

[Roy Belson]: However, because he had a SASID number when he was in the first grade,

[Roy Belson]: Okay, he had been in the country for a short period of time.

[Roy Belson]: The state decided that he was, in fact, not a first year student.

[Roy Belson]: We had to petition and clean that out.

[Roy Belson]: Now, how would we know, coming from another district someplace else, that this wasn't his first year?

[Roy Belson]: That's an example of a discrepancy.

[Roy Belson]: Medicals, people that are out on a medical, who somehow don't get coded out of the thing, all of a sudden you have to go back and say, well, this kid's been in the hospital for the last six months.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, how can you count them?

[Roy Belson]: They couldn't possibly take the test in the setting they were in.

[Roy Belson]: So those are some of the things that happen, and you have to pay attention to those, because otherwise, you have 100 kids, and five or six kids don't take the test for various reasons.

[Roy Belson]: All of a sudden, you're below a certain threshold.

[Roy Belson]: And that's what you've got to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: And with subgroups, it's even less, because the subgroups are even smaller numbers.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have 25 kids, one kid could be four percentage points.

[Roy Belson]: So we have a return visit from Evely.

[Roy Belson]: Straight from Market Basket.

[Roy Belson]: Stop and shop.

[Roy Belson]: Stop and shop.

[Roy Belson]: Schools were built with choice as one of the options.

[Roy Belson]: And if we have to change that, we need to change the plan and get approval for it.

[Roy Belson]: See, one of the things is that people don't realize is when the schools were built,

[Roy Belson]: The essential part was, first of all, the Andrews and McGuinn were the first two schools that were built.

[Roy Belson]: So it was, let's say, a progressive movement of youngsters.

[Roy Belson]: But you could have chosen certain schools after the other schools were built.

[Roy Belson]: So there are plenty of people that have chosen schools outside of their geographical area.

[Roy Belson]: It's happened all the time.

[Roy Belson]: But now people are getting settled.

[Roy Belson]: They're getting comfortable.

[Roy Belson]: And to some degree, things have sort of settled in.

[Roy Belson]: People sort of stay in their own geographic area for the most part, although there are some people that want to go to another school.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe you don't see it.

[Roy Belson]: But you don't see them because you didn't make that request.

[Roy Belson]: But we grant a lot of requests.

[Roy Belson]: We take a look at class size first.

[Roy Belson]: We take a look at whether we think the trends are too much in one direction or the other.

[Roy Belson]: We look at the balance between different populations.

[Roy Belson]: But we have granted quite a bit.

[Roy Belson]: Diane, what would you say?

[Roy Belson]: Because Diane handles the elementaries.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I guess it's been less of a drive for people to do that, but over the years, I can assure you people came in frequently asking to go to one school or the other.

[Roy Belson]: Well, then you would have a situation where certain sections of the city would populate one school and some would populate the other school.

[Roy Belson]: Well, then no one gets a choice.

[Roy Belson]: You know what I mean?

[Roy Belson]: So, this trade-off, so all of these systems, for the most part it's worked.

[Roy Belson]: This is a year where we have one real aberration.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at the rest of the enrollment at the Andrews and the McGlynn, it's within a few students of each other.

[Roy Belson]: Not at this level.

[Roy Belson]: This is an aberration this particular year.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I think that there were a few situations where we were concerned about class size.

[Roy Belson]: And so there was some desire that maybe we should move people to one school or the other.

[Roy Belson]: Some cases, it could be transportation situations that were in there.

[Roy Belson]: But Diane, you may want to.

[Roy Belson]: Long time ago.

[Roy Belson]: Long time ago.

[Roy Belson]: There was one redistricting that took place probably three or four years in and that's it.

[Roy Belson]: So let me give you a little bit on that too, just to think about it.

[Roy Belson]: When the schools were built,

[Roy Belson]: The two schools that sort of had a lock on the Brooks were the Dame and the Irving and Gleason.

[Roy Belson]: Those were the three, but there was a whole portion of people that went to the Dame.

[Roy Belson]: that we needed to take to the Columbus because we would have had the Columbus even more underpopulated than it is today.

[Roy Belson]: So there was a need to make a division on that side of the river and move it towards the Columbus or else we would have had an underpopulated school in South Medford and an overpopulated school in West Medford.

[Roy Belson]: So that was the sort of divide there.

[Roy Belson]: And of course with busing transportation, we felt it was very doable.

[Roy Belson]: So that was the thinking at the time.

[Roy Belson]: So I know that some people might disagree with this, but I'm going to say it anyway.

[Roy Belson]: This is that when one school draws a little bit more than the other school, the other school has to want to compete.

[Roy Belson]: The other school has to want to

[Roy Belson]: pick up the energy and to try and find ways to bring people, because they should take pride in their development and making some things happen instead of saying, oh, I don't know what was made.

[Roy Belson]: I think there's a certain amount of that.

[Roy Belson]: And I've said this to some of you as we've talked.

[Roy Belson]: The culture at one place is not as energetic as the culture at the other.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got to change that.

[Roy Belson]: And that's part of the reasons why we made some of the changes we made.

[Roy Belson]: Sending a message.

[Roy Belson]: And that's the way you do it.

[Roy Belson]: You have to do it.

[Roy Belson]: You know, when we talked about in the past, McGlynn was taking over the place and the Andrews was falling backwards after a number of years.

[Roy Belson]: And we sent a message and we changed some things.

[Roy Belson]: So it's not perfect, but it's an attempt to send a message and say, come on, you want to be

[Roy Belson]: The school of choice, you want to bring people to you, and you've got to step it up a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: And that happens, it happens in sports, it happens in the arts, it happens in academics.

[Roy Belson]: I don't believe in competition as the only way of doing it, but sometimes there's a little competition that's useful.

[Roy Belson]: Not federal.

[Roy Belson]: It didn't have to be the same population, it had to be within ranges.

[Roy Belson]: It's a change.

[Roy Belson]: And because part of it is the growth of the Yale population has changed a lot.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, that was not as significant years ago.

[Roy Belson]: It's now significant.

[Roy Belson]: It's now emerged and it will continue to emerge.

[Roy Belson]: So that's a new challenge for us.

[Roy Belson]: It's a new challenge for us.

[Roy Belson]: But again, you know, we work at these things.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, every year there's going to be challenges.

[Roy Belson]: This is one of them.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll make it work.

[Roy Belson]: We'll get on it.

[Roy Belson]: We've got a lot of things moving.

[Roy Belson]: We've talked about a lot.

[Roy Belson]: We're certainly not being satisfied about it.

[Roy Belson]: We're saying, let's go make it happen.

[Roy Belson]: But we need everybody on board.

[Roy Belson]: It can't be, woe is me, you know, they did something to me.

[Roy Belson]: They've got to step up too.

[Roy Belson]: Well, they were defaulted to the McGlynn now because that was the school that was essentially under-enrolled in the sixth grade.

[Roy Belson]: So this is a report you asked for and it's timely because I'll be at the City Council tomorrow night and there's at least three motions on the agenda.

[Roy Belson]: to ask me these questions, okay?

[Roy Belson]: But I think you should be very pleased when you look at the details here.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm gonna go through it a little bit because I think it's really a significant report.

[Roy Belson]: So it's designed to show school enrollment impact of new real estate development in Medford.

[Roy Belson]: This report looks at eight real estate complexes that contain 150 units or more.

[Roy Belson]: We didn't look at the baby ones here and there because that would be too small.

[Roy Belson]: The attached chart identifies each complex and provides information on the total number of enrolled students and their distributions across each of our schools.

[Roy Belson]: The overall initial enrollment in our schools is 4,257 students, which is 54 students higher than last year at this time.

[Roy Belson]: This number is going to grow moderately as we get to October, because that's the way things happen.

[Roy Belson]: The total number of students living in these eight complexes is 105.

[Roy Belson]: Two of the students are in outside placements.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, the enrollments from these eight complexes is 2.4% of our total school population.

[Roy Belson]: Given existing class sizes and space capacity, the enrollment from these developments has no significant effect.

[Roy Belson]: The average class size of our elementary schools is 18.3 students in the regular education classrooms.

[Roy Belson]: I provided a chart that details the grade level distribution, another chart that looks at each school, a third chart that shows enrollment distribution by complex in school, and a fourth chart that shows the enrollment percentage by school.

[Roy Belson]: Our elementary schools could enroll an additional 500 students and still be within our contractual limits for class size.

[Roy Belson]: We could enroll an additional 155 students and still maintain an average class size below 20 students, given normal distributions.

[Roy Belson]: Our middle schools were built for 1,200 students.

[Roy Belson]: We currently have 937.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, our middle school class size in the four major course subjects is around 20 students.

[Roy Belson]: So again, our class size is excellent, but we have plenty of capacity.

[Roy Belson]: People say there's no capacity anymore.

[Roy Belson]: The new developments are going to swamp the schools.

[Roy Belson]: Not true.

[Roy Belson]: The high school vocational program has room to grow.

[Roy Belson]: Space utilization could be adjusted if necessary to increase enrollment substantially.

[Roy Belson]: For example, moving the pre-K programs and offices would open up additional space in the future.

[Roy Belson]: If necessary, we can consider some redistricting to shift enrollment to the Columbus.

[Roy Belson]: The allocation of specialized spaces for small groups and services could be revisited to create more sections or more options as well.

[Roy Belson]: In conclusion, the data clearly indicates that the impact of major residential real estate development has not adversely impacted our schools.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to take you to the first chart.

[Roy Belson]: You're looking at the eight big complexes.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at them and you see the numbers of families in the first column.

[Roy Belson]: So a family might have more than one kid, so that there would be less than the total number.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have 16 number students in 100 Rivers Ed Drive, you only have 11 families.

[Roy Belson]: Some families have more than one child.

[Roy Belson]: And so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: And some of these complexes have existed for some time.

[Roy Belson]: They're not brand new.

[Roy Belson]: They've been here for a while.

[Roy Belson]: So let me go to the next chart.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, Lumiere.

[Roy Belson]: So, we have been talking about a merger of the high school and the vocational school for multiple years.

[Roy Belson]: This is not a new topic.

[Roy Belson]: The fact that it's starting to happen obviously brings about change.

[Roy Belson]: And change is sometimes difficult for everyone to understand what it means.

[Roy Belson]: The vocational school has its own identity by virtue of the fact it's governed by Chapter 74.

[Roy Belson]: And youngsters will get occupational proficiency certificates and other aspects that are purely vocational.

[Roy Belson]: The opportunity for the high school students to explore programs at the vocational school was one of our goals.

[Roy Belson]: Americans overwhelmingly support investments in career preparation and personal skills.

[Roy Belson]: We must continue on that path.

[Roy Belson]: Another key concern is media literacy.

[Roy Belson]: We must help our students to develop the media literacy necessary to counteract the hateful ideas, the rhetoric, and the behaviors that are emerging unchallenged in our society.

[Roy Belson]: The late Senator Patrick Moynihan, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said, you are entitled to your own opinion, but you are not entitled to your own facts.

[Roy Belson]: Opinion has become as true as facts today.

[Roy Belson]: The September edition of the Atlantic Monthly explained it this way.

[Roy Belson]: The internet and competing media outlets allows us to create communities that reinforce our preconceived beliefs with or without evidence.

[Roy Belson]: Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel said, the opposite of love is not hate, it is indifference.

[Roy Belson]: Our most important curriculum will always be a curriculum of caring.

[Roy Belson]: As we begin a new school year, we must rededicate ourselves to truth, to love and human development, as well as academic proficiency.

[Roy Belson]: But we have, despite of what you've heard, and I'll refer to our attorney in a moment, we have a court order that has not been rescinded by the Essex court and Essex probate court.

[Roy Belson]: I'm just going to read the plain language of what it says.

[Roy Belson]: It was issued on May 18th, and I have nothing that contradicts it.

[Roy Belson]: I've asked repeatedly, if you've got something that contradicts it, I'll honor it.

[Roy Belson]: But I don't have anything.

[Roy Belson]: And I'm not going to be in contempt of court for myself or for the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: It says, at review of judgment of modification memorandum of decision dated March 30th, that's what they're referring to, 2017, the plaintiff's motion dated April 10th, 2017, the court enters the following order.

[Roy Belson]: Order.

[Roy Belson]: Plaintiff's request for an order to enroll the children in the Medford Public Schools is denied.

[Roy Belson]: Look, I can't argue with you.

[Roy Belson]: I can't argue with you.
