[Roy Belson]: So maybe Mr. Greenspan can come up and clarify what we're talking about.

[Roy Belson]: Well, if I can, if I can, let me try and go through the sequence that I'm faced in this situation.

[Roy Belson]: I understand everybody is sympathetic to children being in school, and so am I, even though it doesn't seem that way to the parents right now.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is, is that on March 30th, there was a hearing.

[Roy Belson]: And then Lisa Greenberg, who represents Ms.

[Roy Belson]: Knowles, made a request to the court

[Roy Belson]: and you have it in your packet, as to where the children should attend school.

[Roy Belson]: And I'm going to read it.

[Roy Belson]: In denying the plaintiff's request to sole legal custody regarding education decisions, the court has made no decision nor given either party, either party, the right to enroll the children in school.

[Roy Belson]: So if either party does not have the right to enroll them in school, who does?

[Roy Belson]: And then you go on to the next letter,

[Roy Belson]: which says, by the way, it says this only can result in contempt to be filed by one of the parties against the other.

[Roy Belson]: And then the next document that we have denies their request for an order to enroll them in the Medford Public Schools.

[Roy Belson]: Right now, it's between them.

[Roy Belson]: Now why the court has not acted and intervened and made a decision, I don't know.

[Roy Belson]: It is my problem because I represent a city and I cannot be in contempt of court.

[Roy Belson]: That's your opinion.

[Roy Belson]: That's your opinion.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sorry I have a legal counsel.

[Roy Belson]: It's your opinion.

[Roy Belson]: Because there's nothing in their- Because there's no forward.

[Roy Belson]: Look, they don't have the same, if you read the thing, they don't say you can't enroll them in the North Andover public schools, it says the Medford public schools.

[Roy Belson]: It doesn't say they can't enroll them in the Medford public schools.

[Roy Belson]: I'm referring to my legal counsel.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not a lawyer, so I'll refer to my legal counsel.

[Roy Belson]: And so I'm going to take that as advice to me, not to place myself or the school committee in contempt.

[Roy Belson]: I am very.

[Roy Belson]: Look, I'm waiting for a decision.

[Roy Belson]: I called the court.

[Roy Belson]: I called the court and asked the people.

[Roy Belson]: I called the court.

[Roy Belson]: We asked the people to go over the records and interpret it for us.

[Roy Belson]: They told me that my interpretation was correct.

[Roy Belson]: I've asked my legal counsel to tell me what is my interpretation.

[Roy Belson]: He tells me I'm doing the right thing.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if you can get the court to act, or you can agree with your ex-partner on where the child is going to school, we will expedite that enrollment.

[Roy Belson]: And we will even give you compensatory services, because I think it would be in the best interest of the child.

[Roy Belson]: But I certainly can't, in this point, given what I know, act on it.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Greenspan, let me ask you one question.

[Roy Belson]: Is it acceptable protocol for us to petition a judge?

[Roy Belson]: I'm not 100% sure, but if we take jurisdiction of the children and approve a homeschooling plan, it's tantamount to doing the same thing.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, and I'm just using my logic, which may or may not be 100% correct, I have to admit that.

[Roy Belson]: But I'm using my logic to say that what the judge wants to have happen is the parties to agree on something so there won't be an ongoing conflict between the parents, which may affect the child.

[Roy Belson]: And apparently that hasn't happened for whatever reason, and I'm not going to weigh in on that.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, we're in a situation right now where we need a decision, and we don't have one.

[Roy Belson]: There's one other piece that I'll introduce.

[Roy Belson]: Ms.

[Roy Belson]: Knowles has filed a

[Roy Belson]: complaint with the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.

[Roy Belson]: And I saw that today.

[Roy Belson]: I put a phone call into them asking them for some guidance.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe they can intercede with the court.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know.

[Roy Belson]: But I put a phone call into them asking them for guidance.

[Roy Belson]: You have another piece of information in your folder about when we talked about the B-1, B-2 visa situation.

[Roy Belson]: And finally the AG, and finally the DESE ruled on something and told us

[Roy Belson]: what they prefer, even though it was ambiguous.

[Roy Belson]: And I got a phone call from Rhoda Schneider, who is the general legal counsel from the state, saying thank you for asking that question.

[Roy Belson]: Because there are things, there are gray areas that we're caught in the middle of.

[Roy Belson]: And I'm sure it's going to get even grayer as we deal with DACA and other considerations in the weeks and months ahead.

[Roy Belson]: I would love to enroll the children if it's possible.

[Roy Belson]: I have no reason not to want to educate them.

[Roy Belson]: They're two young children that we want to help families.

[Roy Belson]: We have no reason not to want to.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know you.

[Roy Belson]: Do you have any animus toward you?

[Roy Belson]: But I do have paper in front of me that leads me to believe I'm not allowed to.

[Roy Belson]: And I would like it resolved as much as you would.

[Roy Belson]: We call on our assistant superintendent to make this report.

[Roy Belson]: I'll call upon our deputy superintendent to address this issue.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to call on our Director of Administration and Finance to explain this revision mandated by the state.

[Roy Belson]: So this report is a comprehensive report on how school brain software is implemented in the Medford School District during this

[Roy Belson]: 2016-2017 first full year.

[Roy Belson]: We converted from the I-pass system, which was the system we used for multiple years, to school brains.

[Roy Belson]: It was a major undertaking.

[Roy Belson]: And it's still reasonable to expect that some bumps will be in the road as you make that kind of conversion, especially since there's many more complex elements to school brains.

[Roy Belson]: And there's much more that the state expects us to keep track of than ever before.

[Roy Belson]: The interaction between a management software package and the myriad of longstanding specific policies and practices doesn't get untangled overnight.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, the school brain software system has been a major improvement.

[Roy Belson]: Based upon our experience during year one, we are making adjustments that will address the issues that emerged in year one.

[Roy Belson]: And there'll be certain policy decisions that we will have to make to avoid other concerns going forward, and I listed some for our consideration going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Should a weighted GPA system be continued in any format?

[Roy Belson]: A lot of places have discontinued it.

[Roy Belson]: Should special awards for achievement be based upon GPA-related ranking?

[Roy Belson]: Or are there other ways to make these determinations?

[Roy Belson]: How can we allow optimum access to student records and still provide optimum privacy and security?

[Roy Belson]: Because the more people that can use the records for good purpose also opens up the door for what they know about individuals.

[Roy Belson]: How can we promote advanced student learning that is not driven by GPA style ranking?

[Roy Belson]: There are other things, I referenced it in my opening remarks, that we want our young people to be able to do, and the GPA doesn't necessarily reflect that.

[Roy Belson]: And how can we systematically increase parental participation in the communication opportunities offered by school brains?

[Roy Belson]: Because it's not easy to get people to use a new system, which can be a little bit daunting at times.

[Roy Belson]: But nevertheless, that's what happens when it gets complex, and there are a lot of things you can do with it.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to try to address many of these questions in the next few months as we seek to effectively assess student learning and properly value their achievements.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the report that's attached was generated primarily by Curtis Tootin.

[Roy Belson]: Curtis, are you in the room?

[Roy Belson]: Yeah.

[Roy Belson]: In conjunction with myself and other members of the administration to

[Roy Belson]: give you some in-depth understanding of the strengths, weaknesses, and some of the issues associated with school brains.

[Roy Belson]: And there's a lot of data here.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm going to have Curtis go through some of it.

[Roy Belson]: And I don't want to dwell on every item tonight because I think it's too long and too much in depth.

[Roy Belson]: But I want you to get an idea of some of the strengths and some of the things we have to work on.

[Roy Belson]: And the headmaster is here also to give you some feedback as to these types of issues.

[Roy Belson]: So go ahead, Curtis.

[Roy Belson]: It's important to everyone understand

[Roy Belson]: We are in an age where there are so many data points that are now being collected, and so much information that has to be cross-validated between student information, teacher licensure, course selection, student discipline, across the board, and it's all getting reported in, and it's cross-validating.

[Roy Belson]: And as a result, the need to be precise has been exponentially created, so therefore,

[Roy Belson]: You know, there's a lot of learning to go on as people want more and more data.

[Roy Belson]: So it takes a period of time for everyone to get used to it and also to be diligent about it.

[Roy Belson]: You can't go into it and say, Oh, well, three weeks ago I should have made that change.

[Roy Belson]: You've got to do it when it happens.

[Roy Belson]: So it's a process in the long run.

[Roy Belson]: It'll work out in the short run.

[Roy Belson]: There'll be a few bumps in the road and there'll be a few situations where some people aren't as

[Roy Belson]: diligent or as good at doing it, but we'll continue to stay on it.

[Roy Belson]: So when we negotiated the last contract, this was one of the items that was specified in the contract.

[Roy Belson]: And the teachers obviously indicated that they didn't want to be putting stuff in every day and so on and so forth in different levels.

[Roy Belson]: For example, the elementary school didn't really apply as much, with much more broad based information.

[Roy Belson]: At the middle and high school, probably once a week.

[Roy Belson]: Every couple weeks that they would update that material, that was sort of the way they were thinking.

[Roy Belson]: And towards the end of the quarter again, there would be some of the drop off from that because they were concentrating on consolidating the grades.

[Roy Belson]: But I'll do some talking to some teachers and get a sense and get you another report because I think it's something that's going to grow.

[Roy Belson]: Because people will use so many different systems for so long, they're comfortable with those.

[Roy Belson]: And now they're switching to this.

[Roy Belson]: And we've also got to get parents to really use it because you can't motivate someone to use something if no one is looking at it.

[Roy Belson]: So we've got to find a way to bring them both together.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that's sort of where we're coming from.

[Roy Belson]: But overall, it's the right direction to head in, albeit it's not a perfect system.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, members of the council, the Medford School Committee approved an appropriated budget of $56,431,000.

[Roy Belson]: buttressed by revenue of $2,071,107 of generated revenue, grants and other sources of revenue as well.

[Roy Belson]: It's a 3.65 increase over last year.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, the budget increases a number of activities which are positive for the schools.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to increase our vocational program.

[Roy Belson]: We're bringing in revenue from the outside.

[Roy Belson]: We're now up to 20 programs as opposed to 11 a few years ago.

[Roy Belson]: The vocational school is really moving.

[Roy Belson]: There are a number of ADA improvements that will meet all compliance requirements.

[Roy Belson]: A grant from the Commonwealth, there was a half a million dollar grant from the Commonwealth as well.

[Roy Belson]: Technology has been increased.

[Roy Belson]: We've assigned probably 50 to 60 Chromebooks to each new school, each school rather, to increase their technology capability.

[Roy Belson]: We've increased our E-rate funding to support infrastructure improvements.

[Roy Belson]: We're increasing our nursing staff to improve health services as well.

[Roy Belson]: We have a grant from the Commonwealth on opiate education through our Michigan model.

[Roy Belson]: We're adding two additional ELL students, ELL teachers rather, that will help to meet the needs of youngsters who do not speak English as a first language.

[Roy Belson]: We're adding, our class size is really very good.

[Roy Belson]: There's no class in the elementary schools above 22.

[Roy Belson]: And in fact, they're all below 22.

[Roy Belson]: For those who are interested, we added a fifth, fourth grade at the Roberts through interest that people had.

[Roy Belson]: We...

[Roy Belson]: are adding additional money into the maintenance account so that every school will have additional dollars for that.

[Roy Belson]: There's $200,000 of additional maintenance money with each school getting a grant, direct grant of $20,000 in addition to general maintenance costs that we will carry through the central office that will allow them to attack certain issues that they feel are important to them.

[Roy Belson]: The middle schools and the high school will get additional dollars for student activity stipends.

[Roy Belson]: The special education program will need some additional money

[Roy Belson]: tuition and transportation, but that's covered.

[Roy Belson]: And we think that we were able to reduce enrollment at Minuteman, which saves hundreds of thousands of dollars and increase our additional revenue from that area.

[Roy Belson]: The social studies program will continue to textbook replacement in U.S.

[Roy Belson]: history.

[Roy Belson]: The math department has completed its purchase of the Envision program at the elementary level, and they will add

[Roy Belson]: additional textbooks to the high school math program.

[Roy Belson]: The science department is gonna receive $30,000 additional for science materials for the elementary school program while they pilot additional textbooks at that level.

[Roy Belson]: The foreign language department will acquire a new teacher from middle school to ensure that all students can take Spanish and Italian if they want.

[Roy Belson]: The fine arts program has a new director in Tony Sickney.

[Roy Belson]: As he assumes his role, we'll add 1.2 teachers to that program.

[Roy Belson]: The PE and health department will receive a new teacher.

[Roy Belson]: which will be transferred over from one of the programs to help with the Michigan model.

[Roy Belson]: The library media program continues to add programs and services.

[Roy Belson]: Every library in the schools will now be covered, either by paraprofessionals or professional libraries.

[Roy Belson]: We have a new director of technology, Molly Layden.

[Roy Belson]: And we will be adding additional dollars to our online learning programs that we have now added a program called Edumentum this year.

[Roy Belson]: which helps with credit recovery, helps junctures take additional courses which they couldn't possibly take in this schedule.

[Roy Belson]: So I think it's been a very good budget.

[Roy Belson]: I have to thank my staff, all the people that are working with us for the work that they do.

[Roy Belson]: I believe we are in good shape and we'll finish this year in the black strongly and we'll also go into next year with a solid budget.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you, Mr. Belson.

[Roy Belson]: Yes.

[Roy Belson]: And can you tell me what that vote was?

[Roy Belson]: 7-0.

[Roy Belson]: I appreciate what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: You know, we have talked about this.

[Roy Belson]: We continuously review security issues.

[Roy Belson]: We do have security during the day and we think that we've enhanced that quite a bit.

[Roy Belson]: We added a Raptor system, as you know, to have a professional ID system of anyone entering the buildings during the school day.

[Roy Belson]: We do have a resource officer assigned to us at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: We have resource officers assigned to us throughout the city through the police department.

[Roy Belson]: which helps with that as well.

[Roy Belson]: The building is 550,000 square feet.

[Roy Belson]: And a single individual moving around, I don't believe, is a particularly effective tool.

[Roy Belson]: We have a lot of adult personnel there, custodians, cleaning crew, coaches, advisors, teachers, and others, all of whom have been equipped with communication devices from time to time.

[Roy Belson]: They can call 911 very quickly.

[Roy Belson]: However, I understand what you're asking.

[Roy Belson]: And in the spirit of trying to come to some sort of agreement, let me bring it to the attention of the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: And if the school committee believes that we should add a person who is in that particular assignment, then we'll bring that up.

[Roy Belson]: But I will actively bring it to their attention and we'll talk about that and give you a report.

[Roy Belson]: I think that's a reasonable compromise given the fact that we've gone back and forth on this for a few years.

[Roy Belson]: One school did not have anyone there specifically, except one member who's actually a member of the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: But other than that, each school did introduce people, and there are like seven members on a council, so it isn't like there's 50 people on a council.

[Roy Belson]: I would hope that the councils would actually consult with the parents more completely, but it's a seven-member council.

[Roy Belson]: We call upon our director of English Language Arts and Humanities, Dr. Nicole Chiesa.

[Roy Belson]: Dr. Chiesa.

[Roy Belson]: Call upon our deputy superintendent to present this report.

[Roy Belson]: So one of the discussions we've had recently is the concentration of students who are ELL in any one elementary school.

[Roy Belson]: And the newcomers program has historically been at the Roberts, but the numbers have become very substantial.

[Roy Belson]: And one of the discussions that we had was how can we

[Roy Belson]: spread them out, redistribute them a little bit more.

[Roy Belson]: In earlier discussions, we talked about splitting, let's say, grades 1 and 2 at one school and 3, 4, and 5 at another.

[Roy Belson]: And so this particular report tells you that next year it's our plan to send grades 1 and 2 to the Brooks School for two reasons.

[Roy Belson]: One, it will redistribute the newcomers program, not all ELL students, but the newcomers program.

[Roy Belson]: And also, it will create more

[Roy Belson]: of a balance between the two schools because the population at the Brooks is lower than the population at the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: Put the two together, they'll come up with a similar population and the diversity level at the Brooks will increase substantially and that will be helpful as well.

[Roy Belson]: So that's our goal, that's what we're doing and we plan to move ahead unless there's an objection.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's very important for us to maybe make a statement at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: We talked about this the other night at the middle schools.

[Roy Belson]: We can't make everybody happy all the time.

[Roy Belson]: There's going to be decisions that are going to be made that are going to require people to accept certain kinds of things for distribution purposes.

[Roy Belson]: Now this year we'll do it with the elementary, but as we go into next year we're going to have to take a very strong look at the middle school and redistribute students because otherwise one school will be very heavy with certain types of students who require certain services.

[Roy Belson]: Other schools will be less populated and have other challenges.

[Roy Belson]: So people ask for certain things.

[Roy Belson]: We do our best to accommodate them.

[Roy Belson]: From time to time, we have to make a decision, and not everybody's going to be happy with that decision, but that's the nature of trying to be fair to everybody.

[Roy Belson]: And sometimes in transition, there are a few people that feel like we didn't consider their particular situation, but we'll try to consider as many situations as we can.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things we'll do after tonight is we'll actually reach out to the families that will be affected by school transitions this week.

[Roy Belson]: and start to let them know what our plans are.

[Roy Belson]: And then we do have after school programs and other things like that that we can work out some arrangements for people who have particular needs that really are under stress.

[Roy Belson]: But we've got to be very careful that we don't just assume that everybody is going to get everything that they want because if we do that, we give ourselves an unbearable goal, an unattainable goal.

[Roy Belson]: So from time to time, you make a decision.

[Roy Belson]: You do it in the vast majority of people involved.

[Roy Belson]: You try to work on the edges with the people that may be affected adversely.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully by third grade they're no longer a newcomer.

[Roy Belson]: So they can go back to their school of origin or their geographical school.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: They would go back to their school of origin.

[Roy Belson]: So the goal is to get them out of the newcomers program as soon as possible.

[Roy Belson]: A couple years should do it.

[Roy Belson]: And that would hope that they wouldn't have to go to the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: They could go back to the School of Archer.

[Roy Belson]: So all those things have an impact on you, and I just want to make sure you're aware of it.

[Roy Belson]: Congratulations.

[Roy Belson]: Dear members of the school committee, ladies and gentlemen, as you look around, you see the incredible achievements of our young people.

[Roy Belson]: But also very important, two things that I want to highlight.

[Roy Belson]: One, the diversity of our student body and the achievements of this diversity.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that's one of the factors that makes Medford so great and a great place to grow up.

[Roy Belson]: Because you get to grow up and experience a lot of different cultures and work together.

[Roy Belson]: And the second key thing is that all of these achievements come through collaboration.

[Roy Belson]: working together with your teachers, working with each other, working as a team.

[Roy Belson]: And that's the secret to success in almost anything.

[Roy Belson]: Very few people do anything alone by themselves without good help.

[Roy Belson]: And so congratulations to all of you, to your parents.

[Roy Belson]: They've collaborated with you.

[Roy Belson]: You've collaborated with them.

[Roy Belson]: You've collaborated with each other.

[Roy Belson]: And you make Medford very proud of the way you represent us, both as a diverse community and as a community that cares about its people.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: And so undoubtedly this is reimbursement for product that he had to buy on behalf of that activity.

[Roy Belson]: That's undoubtedly to support the woodwind orchestra activities.

[Roy Belson]: On Saturday, we actually, everything was sold at auction.

[Roy Belson]: And I believe that, um, pre discount pre, you know, the auctioneer's price, which is 10% that they brought in about $20,000.

[Roy Belson]: Great.

[Roy Belson]: Happened on the Saturday.

[Roy Belson]: So we need a little more time.

[Roy Belson]: Trying to, where is this again?

[Roy Belson]: I'll just have to look that up when we get back to the office.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor and members of the committee, this is the Committee of the Whole that we held last Wednesday on the school councils.

[Roy Belson]: It's here.

[Roy Belson]: Rather than read it in totality, if anyone has any particular questions, if there's anything in it, you can certainly respond to it, but I think it's self-explanatory and we'll just enter it into the record with your approval.

[Roy Belson]: So I just would comment on that.

[Roy Belson]: The parents participated in the council development.

[Roy Belson]: The attendance at the presentation on Wednesday evening,

[Roy Belson]: was dependent on the school itself.

[Roy Belson]: And several parents were there and were introduced.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, one school did not have anyone there specifically except one member who's actually a member of the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: Yes.

[Roy Belson]: But other than that, each school did introduce people and there are like seven members on a council.

[Roy Belson]: So it isn't like this, like there's 50 people on a council.

[Roy Belson]: It's in the report.

[Roy Belson]: I would hope that the councils would actually consult with the parents more completely, but it's a seven-member council.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, theoretically the report reflects them.

[Roy Belson]: The high school and the voc have students on it, but the other

[Roy Belson]: are strictly parents and community members.

[Roy Belson]: The appointment letters are now in process and probably will go out either this week or the beginning of next.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: We call upon our Director of English Language Arts and Humanities, Dr. Nicole Chiesa.

[Roy Belson]: 2017 Mr. Superintendent call upon our deputy superintendent to present this report.

[Roy Belson]: So one of the discussions we've had recently is the concentration of students who are ELL in any one elementary school.

[Roy Belson]: And the newcomers program has historically been at the Roberts, but the numbers have become very substantial.

[Roy Belson]: And one of the discussions that we had was how can we,

[Roy Belson]: spread them out, redistribute them a little bit more.

[Roy Belson]: In earlier discussions, we talked about splitting, let's say, grades one and two at one school, and three, four, and five at another.

[Roy Belson]: And so this particular report tells you that next year it's our plan to send grades one and two to the Brooks School for two reasons.

[Roy Belson]: One, it will redistribute the newcomers program, not all ELL students, but the newcomers program.

[Roy Belson]: And also, it will create more

[Roy Belson]: of a balance between the two schools, because the population at the Brooks is lower than the population at the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: Put the two together, they'll come up with a similar population, and the diversity level at the Brooks will increase substantially, and that will be helpful as well.

[Roy Belson]: So that's our goal, that's what we're doing, and we plan to move ahead unless there's an objection.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's very important for us to maybe make a statement at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: We talked about this the other night at the middle schools.

[Roy Belson]: We can't make everybody happy all the time.

[Roy Belson]: There's going to be decisions that are going to be made that are going to require people to accept certain kinds of things for distribution purposes.

[Roy Belson]: Now this year we'll do it with the elementary.

[Roy Belson]: But as we go into next year, we're going to have to take a very strong look at the middle school and redistribute students.

[Roy Belson]: Because otherwise, one school will be very heavy with certain types of students who require certain services.

[Roy Belson]: Other schools will be less populated and have other challenges.

[Roy Belson]: So people ask for certain things.

[Roy Belson]: We do our best to accommodate them.

[Roy Belson]: From time to time, we have to make a decision.

[Roy Belson]: And not everybody's going to be happy with that decision.

[Roy Belson]: But that's the nature of trying to be fair to everybody.

[Roy Belson]: And sometimes in transition, there are a few people that feel like we didn't consider their particular situation.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll try to consider as many situations as we can.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things we'll do after tonight is we'll actually reach out to the families that will be affected by school transitions this week and start to let them know that what our plans are.

[Roy Belson]: And then we do have after school programs and other things like that we can.

[Roy Belson]: work out some arrangements for people who have particular needs that really are under stress.

[Roy Belson]: But we've got to be very careful that we don't just assume that everybody is going to get everything that they want.

[Roy Belson]: Because if we do that, we give ourselves an unbearable goal, an unattainable goal.

[Roy Belson]: So from time to time, you make a decision.

[Roy Belson]: You do it in the vast majority of people involved.

[Roy Belson]: And you try to work on the edges with the people that may be affected adversely.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully by third grade, they're no longer a newcomer.

[Roy Belson]: So they can go back to their school of origin or their geographical school.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: They would go back to their school of origin.

[Roy Belson]: So the goal is to get them out of the newcomers program as soon as possible.

[Roy Belson]: A couple of years should do it.

[Roy Belson]: And that would hope that they wouldn't have to go to the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: They could go back to school of origin.

[Roy Belson]: We are just a couple of announcements.

[Roy Belson]: The rest of you just weren't paying attention.

[Roy Belson]: No, I'm just kidding.

[Roy Belson]: Communication requires we have finely tuned, robust, and reliable capacity to meet our obligations.

[Roy Belson]: And under this program, we can access $398,100 of federal funds with a $265,000, $400 match.

[Roy Belson]: We will seek capital funding to meet this infrastructure need in the weeks ahead.

[Roy Belson]: It's clear that other things need to be done in terms of devices and equipment, but that's not part of this particular activity.

[Roy Belson]: If we don't do it this year, I have a feeling some of this stuff may not be available to school systems or libraries next year because of some of the domestic cutbacks that are being considered in Washington.

[Roy Belson]: you know, a funding request in every year, the general E-rate.

[Roy Belson]: This is Tier 2.

[Roy Belson]: Tier 1, we generally get $50,000 to $60,000.

[Roy Belson]: It's changed a little bit because of the change from telecommunications to other things.

[Roy Belson]: We generally, that's independent of this, okay?

[Roy Belson]: Tier 2 is a special infrastructure type funding that's designed to give us more robust capability.

[Roy Belson]: We'll put this in on May 11th, and then we've got to wait for the federal government to actually formally approve it.

[Roy Belson]: But if we don't put it in on May 11th, and we don't put this in, we won't be eligible to ask for the money later on.

[Roy Belson]: So the actual spending process will take place after we have more of a discussion on the details.

[Roy Belson]: You just want to get an authorization to move forward if you can because you know otherwise what you lose the opportunity to access it and I'm willing to bet, not willing to bet, but I think it's a pretty good bet that this funding will start to disappear with the next federal budget and I think if we don't you know act we won't have this opportunity.

[Roy Belson]: People using.

[Roy Belson]: It's use.

[Roy Belson]: Correct.

[Roy Belson]: Some places will be more technologically involved than other places.

[Roy Belson]: McGlynn is two schools in one, remember?

[Roy Belson]: Well, just the way it is.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, some places use technology.

[Roy Belson]: We're talking about an attempt to find out the

[Roy Belson]: capacity of the network to handle traffic.

[Roy Belson]: And it just happens this is what's coming through.

[Roy Belson]: So it gives us an idea of what

[Roy Belson]: Traffic would look like on maybe a normal day, but maybe it doesn't totally reflect everyday.

[Roy Belson]: So, John, where are you?

[Roy Belson]: Now appearing on our stage, John.

[Roy Belson]: You know, buildings and grounds obviously is a big area for us.

[Roy Belson]: And you have a lot of interest in this, and I just want to comment before John talks about his specifics.

[Roy Belson]: But as I told you in a prior meeting, that it's my intent to augment the building repair line by 200,000, which would then be distributed among the schools for the various projects that we've all been talking about.

[Roy Belson]: Because quite frankly, the budget that we have will get used up for

[Roy Belson]: general maintenance and it will be used up for things that go boom in the night.

[Roy Belson]: So this would give us some flexibility in doing some of the repairs.

[Roy Belson]: Now the major piece for the high school, we want to see where the SOI takes us.

[Roy Belson]: And there's some other aspects of the high school, which John will address.

[Roy Belson]: But the SOI is what we submitted to the MSBA and see where that goes.

[Roy Belson]: Because obviously, if we get money from them, that's going to be a lot bigger amount than we would be able to fund ourselves internally.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot going on, but I wanted to have a chance to take a look at some of the things moving through this area.

[Roy Belson]: And John, do you have your copy of your report?

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: So why don't you talk a little bit about what's in your report, and I'll be happy to augment it as we go.

[Roy Belson]: The $200,000 that you're adding to the budget this year, is that going to be annually from this point on?

[Roy Belson]: Well, I don't know.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, we have to sit down and have that discussion.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, I think that that particular line item should grow.

[Roy Belson]: Whether it should grow $200,000, $300,000, or $150,000 is something we can look at.

[Roy Belson]: It also depends to some degree on what else we can get funding for.

[Roy Belson]: So I think the concept is to put a few more dollars in this thing so we can address very specific topics that you have an interest in.

[Roy Belson]: uh... and we can do it with assurance rather than have to wait to see how many things go bum in the night uh... you know which we have to deal with emergency funding uh... like we did get a couple of pipes this year and the year before and so on and so forth so it would give us more flexibility but how much it really depends on you know the projects we identify and where we go with it Mr. McLaughlin Good evening Mayor Burke, Superintendent Dawson, committee

[Roy Belson]: Whatever it is, you'll get a chance to vote on it.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: So this is a good opportunity for me to wrap a few things together and also talk about some of the things that just came up.

[Roy Belson]: The Massachusetts House of Representatives passed its initial version of the FY 2018 state budget last Tuesday, April 25th.

[Roy Belson]: The House version will now go to the State Senate for their deliberations, ways and means, and then the floor.

[Roy Belson]: And we would expect the Senate version to emerge sometime in late May.

[Roy Belson]: Since there will be differences between the two legislative bodies, there will be a joint conference committee consisting of three members from each chamber.

[Roy Belson]: And they'll try to reconcile their differences and then go to the full body in each chamber to get an up or down vote.

[Roy Belson]: They can't make changes once it comes out of conference committee.

[Roy Belson]: And the changes, once it comes out from the full legislature, will go to the governor.

[Roy Belson]: The governor undoubtedly will veto some line items.

[Roy Belson]: The legislature historically will override most of his vetoes, give or take a few here and there.

[Roy Belson]: and the state budget should be completed sometime by the end of June.

[Roy Belson]: However, we have to start doing our budgets well in advance of that, so we start to look at what the House and the Senate will do, because typically there are pretty good guidelines as to what will happen.

[Roy Belson]: But we don't know.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate tends to be a little bit more financially generous than the House, although items vary from area to area.

[Roy Belson]: For the first time, the initial budget from the House exceeds $40 billion.

[Roy Belson]: It's actually less than what the Governor proposed, slightly, but it still exceeds $40 billion to support the various line items and any new programs and services.

[Roy Belson]: But most of the new money goes to mass health, pensions, and a modest increase in local aid.

[Roy Belson]: Very limited.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: We'll go into some of that in a way, but 40% of the budget typically or more right now is mass health.

[Roy Belson]: So it gives you an idea of, you know, it may be $40 billion, but so much of it is eaten up by certain entitlements that, uh, there isn't a lot of discretionary funding.

[Roy Belson]: So the main limitation on the budget is the availability of money, uh, to support the various line items.

[Roy Belson]: any new programs and services, just like we're talking about right now.

[Roy Belson]: How much money is going to be available to do all the things that you think should be done?

[Roy Belson]: Most of the new money, as I say, goes for certain items.

[Roy Belson]: During FY 2016, the state found the budget was initially short $455 million.

[Roy Belson]: And this year, revenue at the end of March is running $220 million below estimates.

[Roy Belson]: April receipt should be higher.

[Roy Belson]: April is usually a very good month.

[Roy Belson]: The beginning of the month was good, but until we get the final figures, we don't know.

[Roy Belson]: But typically, we should be able to close a good portion of that gap.

[Roy Belson]: But closing that gap doesn't give us any surplus, doesn't give any excess.

[Roy Belson]: It just gives us a gap close.

[Roy Belson]: And there's no guarantee that, you know, how much money will come in actually in June, in May and June.

[Roy Belson]: Originally,

[Roy Belson]: The projection for this year was a 3.1% growth factor at the state level.

[Roy Belson]: And through March, it's 1.7%.

[Roy Belson]: Gives you an idea.

[Roy Belson]: And that's nationally, too.

[Roy Belson]: A 2% growth is sort of like, you know, a hallmark.

[Roy Belson]: A study by the Federal Reserve explained that while Massachusetts unemployment was down, there was a significant drop in wages and hours worked.

[Roy Belson]: And that means that the overall personal income was lower.

[Roy Belson]: Spending was higher, most notably in the health sector.

[Roy Belson]: Additionally, a sales tax on merchandise was affected by increased online buying, for which there is no tax.

[Roy Belson]: Furthermore, it's impossible that the income tax rate will drop again because of the automatic trigger built into the state.

[Roy Belson]: The drop in the income tax cost the Commonwealth more of a billion dollars a year since that trigger was put in place.

[Roy Belson]: There appears to be no appetite for increased taxation, although there may be some proposal out of the Senate, as Senate President Rosenberg seems to put this forward a little bit, although tax proposals have to emanate from the House first.

[Roy Belson]: Lastly, we can expect some cutbacks from Washington on domestic spending, including various education items.

[Roy Belson]: So the following items are things to think about in the House budget.

[Roy Belson]: And again, they haven't printed the whole House budget, so I can't get every nickel and dime figured out 100%, but I've gone behind the numbers as much as I can.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 70 is $30 per pupil in the House budget.

[Roy Belson]: Last year it was $55 per pupil.

[Roy Belson]: The governor is proposing $20 per pupil.

[Roy Belson]: That's approximately $145,000.

[Roy Belson]: Unrestricted municipal aid is up statewide by 40 million, but when it's distributed, it isn't that much.

[Roy Belson]: The special education circuit breaker was level funded in the House budget.

[Roy Belson]: It could be short somewhere between 10 and 15 million dollars for full funding.

[Roy Belson]: And as more students qualify, there's a greater demand on this account.

[Roy Belson]: We're projecting less funding in fiscal 2017 than we were in there in 2016.

[Roy Belson]: We've already given you some of those numbers in the last financial report.

[Roy Belson]: And there could be a further reduction in fiscal 2018, and that's for extraordinary special ed costs.

[Roy Belson]: So you have to pay attention to that.

[Roy Belson]: Charter school funding is level funded.

[Roy Belson]: We expect the statewide entitlement to be $60 million below need, maybe more, depending on how much expansion.

[Roy Belson]: Depending on the number of students who opt for charter schools, we could see an increase

[Roy Belson]: in our local cost, although I think we've leveled pretty well and we're bringing people back.

[Roy Belson]: But we also know that Washington is very heavy on pro-choice with Secretary DeVos, and we'll see what comes out of there for choice issues in support of charter schools.

[Roy Belson]: Homeless transportation is level funded, 50% of what we think entitlement would be, if that.

[Roy Belson]: No funding, new funding came back for kindergarten.

[Roy Belson]: We lost $143,000 last year and there's nothing in that line item this year.

[Roy Belson]: Out of district, non-resident transportation is cut.

[Roy Belson]: Could lose about $30,000 in that particular line item.

[Roy Belson]: And there's no new funding for technology that we've seen outside of what I presented this evening.

[Roy Belson]: We will be able to get some significant federal dollars as I explained.

[Roy Belson]: The Department of Public Health funding should be reasonably stable.

[Roy Belson]: That funds a nurse and some of the work that's done on health prevention.

[Roy Belson]: Early childhood funding through the grant account is expected to lose 30% of current level as priorities shift from programs to workforce development support.

[Roy Belson]: In other words, increasing the salaries of people in the

[Roy Belson]: non-profit sector and providing additional training for them because they're well underfunded.

[Roy Belson]: And it's certainly a worthy priority.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, they didn't say we'll do both.

[Roy Belson]: They said we'll take the money from the programs and move it over there.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a little bit more there, but it's not clear.

[Roy Belson]: So we just got through talking a little bit about maintenance and things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: There's a finite pot of gold out there.

[Roy Belson]: And you just can't say we'll just do everything.

[Roy Belson]: We'll try to provide you with options across the board so you can select, and hopefully we'll continue to search out new sources of funding like we have with the vocational school and other things and opiate prevention to augment what we have.

[Roy Belson]: But the general distributions coming from the state place a tremendous burden on the locality.

[Roy Belson]: The cost of health care keeps going up, and we just don't know, you know, where it's coming.

[Roy Belson]: We don't know what Washington's going to do and what's going to happen to that situation yet.

[Roy Belson]: It goes back and forth.

[Roy Belson]: And there are a lot of other factors that have to come into play.

[Roy Belson]: So we also have to carry at least a 2.5% increase in salary negotiations, which isn't outrageous, but it's money.

[Roy Belson]: And then you also have step increases that people who are starting the young teachers move up the steps.

[Roy Belson]: That's on top of the 2.5.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of factors.

[Roy Belson]: It would be easy for me to get up and say, sure, tell me whatever you want me to fix, tell me whatever you want me to do, go add this, add that.

[Roy Belson]: It's not that simple and you know it.

[Roy Belson]: You know, what it is is that we have to lay it all out and decide what's most important to us and move forward with that.

[Roy Belson]: I think there's a lot of great things going on in this community and a lot of great things going on in the school system.

[Roy Belson]: I should be very proud of the work you've done, very proud of the administration and City Hall supporting us.

[Roy Belson]: You know, there will be some limitations, and we'll have to make some tough choices, forced choices.

[Roy Belson]: We'll keep watching the Senate.

[Roy Belson]: We'll go up and lobby, you know, for other things.

[Roy Belson]: But still, it's got to be spread out.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: So this is a good opportunity for me to wrap a few things together and also talk about some of the things that just came up.

[Roy Belson]: The Massachusetts House of Representatives

[Roy Belson]: passed its initial version of the FY 2018 state budget last Tuesday, April 25th.

[Roy Belson]: The House version will now go to the State Senate for their deliberations, ways and means, and then the floor.

[Roy Belson]: And we would expect the Senate version to emerge sometime in late May.

[Roy Belson]: Since there will be differences between the two legislative bodies, there will be a joint conference committee consisting of three members from each chamber.

[Roy Belson]: And they'll try to reconcile their differences and then go to the full body in each chamber to get an up or down vote.

[Roy Belson]: They can't make changes once it comes out of conference committee.

[Roy Belson]: Then the changes, once it comes out from the full legislature, will go to the governor.

[Roy Belson]: The governor undoubtedly will veto some line items.

[Roy Belson]: The legislature historically will override most of his vetoes, give or take a few here and there.

[Roy Belson]: and the state budget should be completed sometime by the end of June.

[Roy Belson]: However, we have to start doing our budgets well in advance of that, so we start to look at what the House and the Senate will do, because typically there are pretty good guidelines as to what will happen.

[Roy Belson]: But we don't know.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate tends to be a little bit more financially generous than the House, although items vary from area to area.

[Roy Belson]: For the first time, the initial budget from the House exceeds $40 billion.

[Roy Belson]: It's actually less than what the governor proposed, slightly, but it still exceeds $40 billion to support the various line items and any new programs and services.

[Roy Belson]: But most of the new money goes to mass health, pensions, and a modest increase in local aid.

[Roy Belson]: Very limited.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: We'll go into some of that in a way, but 40% of the budget typically or more right now is mass health.

[Roy Belson]: So it gives you an idea of, you know, it may be $40 billion, but so much of it is eaten up by certain entitlements that, uh, there isn't a lot of discretionary funding.

[Roy Belson]: So the main limitation on the budget is the availability of money, uh, to support the various line items.

[Roy Belson]: any new programs and services, just like we're talking about right now.

[Roy Belson]: How much money is going to be available to do all the things that you think should be done?

[Roy Belson]: Most of the new money, as I say, goes for certain items.

[Roy Belson]: During FY 2016, the state found the budget was initially short $455 million.

[Roy Belson]: And this year, revenue, as the end of March, is running $220 million below estimates.

[Roy Belson]: April receipt should be higher.

[Roy Belson]: April is usually a very good month.

[Roy Belson]: The beginning of the month was good.

[Roy Belson]: But until we get the final figures, we don't know.

[Roy Belson]: But typically, we should be able to close a good portion of that gap.

[Roy Belson]: But closing that gap doesn't give us any surplus, doesn't give any excess.

[Roy Belson]: It just gives us a gap close.

[Roy Belson]: And there's no guarantee that how much money will come in, actually, in June, in May and June.

[Roy Belson]: Originally, the projection for this year was a 3.1%

[Roy Belson]: growth factor at the state level.

[Roy Belson]: And through March, it's 1.7%.

[Roy Belson]: Gives you an idea.

[Roy Belson]: And that's nationally, too.

[Roy Belson]: 2% growth is sort of like, you know, a hallmark.

[Roy Belson]: A study by the Federal Reserve explained that while Massachusetts unemployment was down, there was a significant drop in wages and hours worked.

[Roy Belson]: And that means that the overall personal income was lower.

[Roy Belson]: Spending was higher, most notably in the health sector.

[Roy Belson]: Additionally, a sales tax on merchandise was affected by increased online buying, for which there is no tax.

[Roy Belson]: Furthermore, it's impossible that the income tax rate will drop again because of the automatic trigger built into the state.

[Roy Belson]: The drop in the income tax cost the Commonwealth more of a billion dollars a year since that trigger was put in place.

[Roy Belson]: There appears to be no appetite for increased taxation

[Roy Belson]: Although there may be some proposal out of the Senate, as Senate President Rosenberg seems to put this forward a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: Although tax proposals have to emanate from the House first.

[Roy Belson]: Lastly, we can expect some cutbacks from Washington on domestic spending, including various education items.

[Roy Belson]: So the following items are things to think about in the house budget.

[Roy Belson]: And again, they haven't printed the whole house budget, so I can't get every nickel and dime figured out a hundred percent, but I've gone behind the numbers as much as I can.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 70 is $30 per pupil in the house budget.

[Roy Belson]: Last year it was $55 per pupil.

[Roy Belson]: The governor's proposing $20 per pupil.

[Roy Belson]: That's approximately $145,000.

[Roy Belson]: Unrestricted municipal aid is up statewide by 40 million, but when it's distributed, it isn't that much.

[Roy Belson]: The special education circuit breaker was level funded in the house budget.

[Roy Belson]: It could be short somewhere between 10 and $15 million for full funding.

[Roy Belson]: And as more students qualify, there's a greater demand on this account.

[Roy Belson]: We're projecting less funding in fiscal 2017.

[Roy Belson]: We're in there in 2016.

[Roy Belson]: We've already given you some of those numbers in the last financial report.

[Roy Belson]: And there could be a further reduction in fiscal 2018.

[Roy Belson]: And that's for extraordinary special ed costs.

[Roy Belson]: So you have to pay attention to that.

[Roy Belson]: Charter school funding is level funded.

[Roy Belson]: We expect the statewide entitlement to be $60 million below need, maybe more, depending on how much expansion.

[Roy Belson]: Depending on the number of students who opt for charter schools, we could see an increase

[Roy Belson]: in our local cost, although I think we've leveled pretty well and we're bringing people back.

[Roy Belson]: But we also know that Washington is very heavy on pro-choice with Secretary DeVos, and we'll see what comes out of there for the choice issues in support of charter schools.

[Roy Belson]: Homeless transportation is level funded, 50% of what we think entitlement would be, if that.

[Roy Belson]: No funding, new funding came back for kindergarten.

[Roy Belson]: We lost $143,000 last year, and there's nothing in that line item this year.

[Roy Belson]: Out of district, non-resident transportation is cut.

[Roy Belson]: Could lose about $30,000 in that particular line item.

[Roy Belson]: And there's no new funding for technology that we've seen outside of what I presented this evening.

[Roy Belson]: We will be able to get some significant federal dollars, as I explained.

[Roy Belson]: The Department of Public Health funding should be reasonably stable.

[Roy Belson]: That funds a nurse and some of the work that's done on health prevention.

[Roy Belson]: Early childhood funding through the grant account is expected to lose 30% of current level as priorities shift from programs to workforce development support.

[Roy Belson]: In other words, increasing the salaries of people in the nonprofit sector and providing additional training for them because they're well underfunded.

[Roy Belson]: And it's certainly a worthy priority

[Roy Belson]: But they didn't say we'll do both.

[Roy Belson]: They said we'll take the money from the programs and move it over there.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a little bit more there, but it's not clear.

[Roy Belson]: So we just got through talking a little bit about maintenance and things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: There's a finite pot of gold out there.

[Roy Belson]: And you just can't say we'll just do everything.

[Roy Belson]: We'll try to provide you with options across the board so you can select.

[Roy Belson]: And hopefully, we'll continue to search out new sources of funding

[Roy Belson]: like we have with the vocational school and other things and opiate prevention to augment what we have.

[Roy Belson]: But the general distributions coming from the state place a tremendous burden on the locality.

[Roy Belson]: The cost of health care keeps going up.

[Roy Belson]: We just don't know, you know, where it's coming.

[Roy Belson]: We don't know what Washington's going to do and what's going to happen to that situation yet.

[Roy Belson]: It goes back and forth.

[Roy Belson]: And there are a lot of other factors that have to come into play.

[Roy Belson]: So we also have

[Roy Belson]: to carry at least a 2.5% increase in salary negotiations, which isn't outrageous, but it's money.

[Roy Belson]: And then you also have step increases that people who are starting, the young teachers move up the steps, that's on top of the 2.5.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of factors.

[Roy Belson]: It would be easy for me to get up and say, sure, tell me whatever you want me to fix, tell me whatever you want me to do, go add this, add that.

[Roy Belson]: It's not that simple and you know it.

[Roy Belson]: You know, what it is is that we have to lay it all out and decide what's most important to us and move forward with that.

[Roy Belson]: I think there's a lot of great things going on in this community and go a lot of great things going on in the school system.

[Roy Belson]: Should be very proud of the work you've done.

[Roy Belson]: Very proud of the administration and city hall supporting us.

[Roy Belson]: However, you know, there will be some limitations and we'll have to make some tough choices, forced choices.

[Roy Belson]: So the budget process is beginning at the state house.

[Roy Belson]: We'll keep watching the Senate.

[Roy Belson]: We'll go up and lobby, you know, for other things.

[Roy Belson]: We'll talk to people about things.

[Roy Belson]: We'll look for additional grants, look for additional revenue.

[Roy Belson]: We've recaptured some revenue through the minute man activity, the revenue coming in through the vocational school, but still it's going to be spread out.

[Roy Belson]: So just wanted to give you a quick snapshot of the state budget so far.

[Roy Belson]: We'll keep you posted and we'll keep talking budget as we go forward and try to set priorities.

[Roy Belson]: OK, that's the Minuteman bus.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: So in another year from now, we won't have a bus going to Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to try and get a smaller vehicle, which may cost less.

[Roy Belson]: But if I lose the reimbursement for non-resident last year, two years ago, it was almost $3 million.

[Roy Belson]: Then it went down to half of that.

[Roy Belson]: And this year in the House budget, it's $250,000 for that line item.

[Roy Belson]: This year, there's about 16 students.

[Roy Belson]: Next year, I would expect eight.

[Roy Belson]: You could do it.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, hey, listen, if you can't go one way, we'll must own the other way.

[Roy Belson]: How's that?

[Roy Belson]: OK?

[Roy Belson]: Very good.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: You're welcome.

[Roy Belson]: What else?

[Roy Belson]: No, it's definitely an issue.

[Roy Belson]: Just so you know, the Medicaid funding is generated by students who are eligible through disabilities and the like.

[Roy Belson]: The money comes back.

[Roy Belson]: Short Collaborative is our

[Roy Belson]: broker, if you will, it comes back through it, but it goes into the city treasury.

[Roy Belson]: And as the mayor points out, it adds to the total pie that's then available for redistribution to the schools, to the city and other things.

[Roy Belson]: So it's factored into the overall who gets what kind of thing.

[Roy Belson]: You know, there's some people that say they wanted to come to them, but

[Roy Belson]: quite frankly, it's the same pot of gold we just simply work with.

[Roy Belson]: But it could be $400,000, $500,000 that we could lose.

[Roy Belson]: And the state could lose that much more because they're dependent on it as well.

[Roy Belson]: And that could drive the cost of health care right through the roof, which will also impact our employees as they have to pay more for health insurance and the like.

[Roy Belson]: And of course, that

[Roy Belson]: would bring them to the bargaining table, because next year, while we're covered for next year, bargaining for the successor contracts will start all over again.

[Roy Belson]: And as they lose money in terms of the health care costs and things of that type, they're going to be looking for something to make it up in salary.

[Roy Belson]: So all this stuff has triggers that are going to be thought about, planned.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to understand what it means.

[Roy Belson]: When we commence something going forward, we've got to realize it might have ripple effect

[Roy Belson]: multiple years down the road.

[Roy Belson]: It's not just, you know, any one year.

[Roy Belson]: It's that year, maybe, but then there's more going on down the road.

[Roy Belson]: And as it, as it stands now, we're, you know, we're using a lot of generated revenue to support our operations.

[Roy Belson]: Some point in time that generated revenue will hit a wall.

[Roy Belson]: We can only make so much at any given time.

[Roy Belson]: So there's all kinds of issues, but Washington, you know, is a, is a real black hole.

[Roy Belson]: You really don't know a lot of the programs.

[Roy Belson]: 150,000 go into salaries.

[Roy Belson]: That could disappear, you know, for class size reduction.

[Roy Belson]: Other programs like that for supplies, materials, bilingual, you know, money could come down.

[Roy Belson]: And as you can see, our population is significantly growing in that area.

[Roy Belson]: I think, you know, I think the issue of, and I know it's unpopular, the millionaire's tax is out there someplace, whether that actually goes through in a year from now certainly would be helpful.

[Roy Belson]: to the revenue pie, but then again, if that money gets generated, who will get it?

[Roy Belson]: The issue of any money generated through the marijuana bill, sales taxes, other things like that, all up in the air.

[Roy Belson]: There's a whole group out there that want to cut the sales tax.

[Roy Belson]: You don't want to bring it back down again.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of discussions that are going on right now.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, members of the council, good evening.

[Roy Belson]: I'm here tonight with Dr. Heidi Riccio, the principal director of the Medford Vocational Technical School.

[Roy Belson]: And she's going to go into some detail for you with regard to this particular capital skills program.

[Roy Belson]: The money was awarded by the governor recently.

[Roy Belson]: Contract was just signed the end of March.

[Roy Belson]: And there is going to be approximately $1.3 million of altogether between the state grant and in-kind contributions from various vendors and others of their money.

[Roy Belson]: But we need a $250,000 capital match to advance our culinary arts and hospitality program and our advanced manufacturing program.

[Roy Belson]: If you go up the technical school now, you'll see that the old print shop is now being deconstructed and being made into a first class hospitality and restaurant center.

[Roy Belson]: And you're also going to see the advance of the advanced manufacturing activity going on with robotics and engineering going on, things that were never really considered likely in a vocational technical school years ago.

[Roy Belson]: Dr. Riccio has done a terrific job putting all this together.

[Roy Belson]: We're very pleased that the governor saw his way to give us a half million dollars, and I'm going to let her go into details.

[Roy Belson]: You have some materials that we've given you previously, but also tonight she's added some supplementals that she can discuss with you so that you have an idea of what we're investing in.

[Roy Belson]: We think this is a terrific project.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to advance our activities technically.

[Roy Belson]: It's also going to help us partner with some very significant area individuals and corporations.

[Roy Belson]: And we think it's one of the best things we've ever done.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm going to turn it over to Dr. Riccio.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you, Mr. Belson.

[Roy Belson]: So before Heidi goes on a little bit, tonight she came down, she left school, left 200 members of the advisory committees, all 20, 10 per advisory committee up there, working on

[Roy Belson]: doing additional contributions and the like.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah.

[Roy Belson]: It's incredible up there.

[Roy Belson]: They're working up there, developing all kinds of ways to assist the school moving forward.

[Roy Belson]: It's incredible.

[Roy Belson]: It's absolutely incredible.

[Roy Belson]: No, we have a- No, meaning leave tonight.

[Roy Belson]: We have a bracelet on us.

[Roy Belson]: So what you have is you have a situation in which if a school district does not have a particular vocational program, a student from our community could opt to go to a regional vocational school which has the program.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the program that has absorbed most of our youngsters who have gone out of the district is Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: And there's some to Essex Aggie and places like that for agricultural programs.

[Roy Belson]: But Minuteman has been the main thing.

[Roy Belson]: And there was as many as 50 youngsters out there a few years ago.

[Roy Belson]: And given their tuition rates and the like, with special ed assessments on top of it, we're pushing $1 million a year.

[Roy Belson]: Next year, we'll have, what, eight people out?

[Roy Belson]: We have eight people out, and the year after, there'll be zero.

[Roy Belson]: There were no applications that came in from Minuteman this year because we have programs that can't touch our young people because we have the programs in-house.

[Roy Belson]: In addition to that, with the expansion of what we're doing and working with Everett and some other communities that need a vocational program, we're actually going to be bringing in hundreds of thousands of dollars each year on tuition.

[Roy Belson]: So the turnaround in a short period of time could be close to $2 million.

[Roy Belson]: And that goes back to reinvesting in a school, because when you talk about technical education, you have to reinvest all the time.

[Roy Belson]: And you can't just simply say, well, the equipment is there, and it's going to be there for the next 50 years.

[Roy Belson]: It's not like bricks.

[Roy Belson]: It's got to be the state of the art.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got to be able to reinvest on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: And that's going to give us that capacity.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to give us that capacity to hire people who have a great deal of experience, rather than people who are starting out in careers.

[Roy Belson]: And that's going to change.

[Roy Belson]: the entire way we look at the future.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that sort of, I hope that answers your question.

[Roy Belson]: If you need more, I can tell you more.

[Roy Belson]: Well, the cost difference at eight students, probably a couple hundred thousand dollars, the most 150, you know, thousand dollars down from that in a year from now, that'll be gone altogether.

[Roy Belson]: The other thing that's probably very significant is that Minuteman is looking to rebuild its facility.

[Roy Belson]: They want to build a 628-pupil facility.

[Roy Belson]: They don't have 628 pupils to put in it.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result, the cost of that is going to be absorbed by the remaining towns.

[Roy Belson]: There were 16 communities that were in the Minuteman district.

[Roy Belson]: There are now nine, as seven communities opted to leave because they didn't want to be part of the capital plans.

[Roy Belson]: that Minuteman was going to assess.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to guess that some community is going to pay $40,000, $50,000 per pupil to go to Minuteman, because there's going to be a capital charge to go there.

[Roy Belson]: And we think it's not a very workable kind of thing.

[Roy Belson]: I think the state's going to have to intervene.

[Roy Belson]: But in the short term, we're out of that.

[Roy Belson]: We're gone.

[Roy Belson]: Because they were going to get the ability to assess a capital fee on top of the tuition fee, which could have been $10,000 on top of the tuition, which would have gone up to over $20,000.

[Roy Belson]: $35,000 per kid.

[Roy Belson]: Unrealistic.

[Roy Belson]: We got ahead of the curve.

[Roy Belson]: We saw it coming.

[Roy Belson]: That's why we were pushing back on the Minuteman issues a few years ago.

[Roy Belson]: And we're also saving transportation, because we won't be sending youngsters there.

[Roy Belson]: That's another $65,000 to $75,000 a year in transportation.

[Roy Belson]: So a lot of positives in that.

[Roy Belson]: And then, of course, the evening school programs that Dr. Riccio has started, bringing people in from the community to learn trades and other things like that.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to be another major thing.

[Roy Belson]: for not only revenue, but also to give our people a chance to gain the skills they need.

[Roy Belson]: You know, one of the discussions about jobs and creating jobs is giving people skill training, because you can't necessarily protect an industry which is no longer viable in this country by just simply saying, let's hope it comes back.

[Roy Belson]: You have to give people skill training so they can move on to the next industry.

[Roy Belson]: And another thing that she's done, which I think is particularly significant, she's clustered and created programs so that you're cross-trained.

[Roy Belson]: So if you're an HVAC in some of these other areas, you're learning multiple skills.

[Roy Belson]: So if one industry goes south, you've got capacity to move to other industries.

[Roy Belson]: And that's exciting.

[Roy Belson]: Not only is hospitality, you know, the restaurant, but it's the back of the house, it's the front of the house, it's all the maintenance of the house that goes with it.

[Roy Belson]: So it's a major, major industry that produces all kinds of jobs and allows people to move across the lines as they cross trains.

[Roy Belson]: You may want to tell them about the cooperative ed statistics.

[Roy Belson]: I mentioned the laborers, Lou Mandarini's shop has been incredible, training the youngsters in Hopkinton and developing things and guaranteeing jobs for them.

[Roy Belson]: As you know, the construction industry is booming right now, and they're being guaranteed some incredible opportunities right now.

[Roy Belson]: A couple of quick points on going outside, just to augment what Dr. Riccio said, is that we have to pay attention to Davis-Bacon Law, can't compete.

[Roy Belson]: with certain kinds of activities out there, because that's, it violates certain laws.

[Roy Belson]: We also have to be careful, because remember, a high school student can be 14, 15 years old, so certain power equipment that they use has to be regulated.

[Roy Belson]: There's all kinds of child labor laws and things like that that we have to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: So anytime we cooperate with someone or look for a job project, we have to all take all that in consideration.

[Roy Belson]: And anyone who wants to work with us has to get CORI checked and all kinds of other kinds of

[Roy Belson]: investigations to make sure that we're not sending somebody into a place where there's problems, whether they're alcohol, drugs, or, you know, safety issues and so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of little things that you've got to pay attention to, but Heidi's on top of it and she's, she's been terrific.

[Roy Belson]: And Lisa has been terrific as has a whole group of them.

[Roy Belson]: They've really got a spirit of esprit de corps over there that's,

[Roy Belson]: It should also be noted too that next year, every ninth grader at the high school will explore shops at the vocational school.

[Roy Belson]: So we've set it up as one of their options.

[Roy Belson]: They will go through with that as an elective.

[Roy Belson]: It will take some time to see a shop in a rotation.

[Roy Belson]: We're working out the schedule right now.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not sure how many days or how many weeks you're going to put them in, but that's going to be part of their electives.

[Roy Belson]: They have a chance to see that and see it from, for example, when they take something like biotech or environmental science, it just crosses over.

[Roy Belson]: It just crosses over.

[Roy Belson]: There are kids who are going to go from the vocational tech

[Roy Belson]: MIT because of their ability to put it together.
