[Roy Belson]: In addition to that, with the expansion of what we're doing and working with Everett and some other communities that need a vocational program, we're actually going to be bringing in hundreds of thousands of dollars each year on tuition.

[Roy Belson]: So the turnaround in a short period of time could be close to $2 million.

[Roy Belson]: And that goes back to reinvesting in a school, because when we talk about technical education, you have to reinvest all the time.

[Roy Belson]: And you can't just simply say, well, the equipment is there, and it's going to be there for the next 50 years.

[Roy Belson]: It's not like bricks.

[Roy Belson]: It's got to be the state of the art.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got to be able to reinvest on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: And that's going to give us that capacity.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to give us that capacity to hire people who have a great deal of experience, rather than people who are starting out in careers.

[Roy Belson]: And that's going to change.

[Roy Belson]: the entire way we look at the future.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that sort of, I hope that answers your question.

[Roy Belson]: If you need more, I can tell you more.

[Roy Belson]: Well, the cost difference at eight students, probably a couple hundred thousand dollars, the most 150, you know, thousand dollars down from that in a year from now, that'll be gone altogether.

[Roy Belson]: The other thing that's probably very significant is that Minuteman is looking to rebuild its facility.

[Roy Belson]: They want to build a 628-pupil facility.

[Roy Belson]: They don't have 628 pupils to put in it.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result, the cost of that is going to be absorbed by the remaining towns.

[Roy Belson]: There were 16 communities that were in the Minuteman district.

[Roy Belson]: There are now nine, as seven communities opted to leave because they didn't want to be part of the capital plans.

[Roy Belson]: that Minuteman was going to assess.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to guess that some community is going to pay $40,000, $50,000 per pupil to go to Minuteman, because there's going to be a capital charge to go there.

[Roy Belson]: And we think it's not a very workable kind of thing.

[Roy Belson]: I think the state's going to have to intervene.

[Roy Belson]: But in the short term, we're out of that.

[Roy Belson]: We're gone.

[Roy Belson]: Because they were going to get the ability to assess a capital fee on top of the tuition fee, which could have been $10,000 on top of the tuition, which would have gone up to over $20,000.

[Roy Belson]: $35,000 per kid.

[Roy Belson]: Unrealistic.

[Roy Belson]: We got ahead of the curve.

[Roy Belson]: We saw it coming.

[Roy Belson]: That's why we were pushing back on the Minuteman issues a few years ago.

[Roy Belson]: And we're also saving transportation, because we won't be sending youngsters there.

[Roy Belson]: It's another $65,000 to $75,000 a year in transportation.

[Roy Belson]: So a lot of positives in that.

[Roy Belson]: And then, of course, the evening school programs that Dr. Riccio has started, bringing people in from the community to learn trades and other things like that.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to be another major thing.

[Roy Belson]: for not only revenue, but also to give our people a chance to gain the skills they need.

[Roy Belson]: You know, one of the discussions about jobs and creating jobs is giving people skill training, because you can't necessarily protect an industry which is no longer viable in this country by just simply saying, let's hope it comes back.

[Roy Belson]: You have to give people skill training so they can move on to the next industry.

[Roy Belson]: And another thing that she's done, which I think is particularly significant, she's clustered and created programs so that you're cross-trained.

[Roy Belson]: So if you're an HVAC in some of these other areas, you're learning multiple skills.

[Roy Belson]: So if one industry goes south, you've got capacity to move to other industries.

[Roy Belson]: And that's exciting.

[Roy Belson]: Not only is hospitality, you know, it's the restaurant, but it's the back of the house, it's the front of the house, it's all the maintenance of the house that goes with it.

[Roy Belson]: So it's a major, major industry that produces all kinds of jobs and allows people to move across the lines as they cross trains.

[Roy Belson]: You may want to tell them about the cooperative ed statistics.

[Roy Belson]: I mentioned the laborers, Lou Mandarini's shop has been incredible, training the youngsters at Hopkinton and developing things and guaranteeing jobs for them.

[Roy Belson]: As you know, the construction industry is booming right now, and they're being guaranteed some incredible opportunities right now.

[Roy Belson]: A couple of quick points on going outside, just to augment what Dr. Riccio said, is that we have to pay attention to the Davis-Bacon law.

[Roy Belson]: Can't compete.

[Roy Belson]: with certain kinds of activities out there, because that's, it violates certain laws.

[Roy Belson]: We also have to be careful, because remember, a high school student can be 14, 15 years old, so certain power equipment that they use has to be regulated.

[Roy Belson]: There's all kinds of child labor laws and things like that that we have to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: So anytime we cooperate with someone or look for a job project, we have to all take all that in consideration.

[Roy Belson]: And anyone who wants to work with us has to get CORI checked and all kinds of other kinds of,

[Roy Belson]: investigations to make sure that we're not sending somebody into a place where there's problems, whether they're alcohol, drugs, or, you know, safety issues and so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of little things that you've got to pay attention to, but Heidi's on top of it and she's, she's been terrific.

[Roy Belson]: And Lisa has been terrific, as has the whole group of them.

[Roy Belson]: They've really got a spirit of esprit de corps over there that's,

[Roy Belson]: Incredible.

[Roy Belson]: It should also be noted, too, that next year, every ninth grader at the high school will explore shops at the vocational school.

[Roy Belson]: So we've set it up as one of their options.

[Roy Belson]: They will go through with that as an elective.

[Roy Belson]: It will take some time to see a shop in a rotation.

[Roy Belson]: We're working out the schedule right now.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not sure how many days or how many weeks you're going to put them in, but that's going to be part of their electives.

[Roy Belson]: They have a chance to see that and see it from, for example, you know, you take something like biotech or environmental science, it just crosses over.

[Roy Belson]: It just crosses over.

[Roy Belson]: There are kids who are going to go from the vocational tech school

[Roy Belson]: MIT because of their ability to put it together.

[Roy Belson]: So I'll tell you one quick story.

[Roy Belson]: I went to the Roberts Junior High School.

[Roy Belson]: Well, what can you do?

[Roy Belson]: I went to Roberts Junior High School.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to read from a phone book next.

[Roy Belson]: And Ken Peck was the woodworking teacher.

[Roy Belson]: And I may remember the name Ken Peck.

[Roy Belson]: But he was well before you.

[Roy Belson]: You're all too young.

[Roy Belson]: And Ken Peck was the woodworking teacher.

[Roy Belson]: And the goal was to make a game with a spinner on it, you know, a block of wood with different things on it.

[Roy Belson]: And I invented the first mini game.

[Roy Belson]: I could never get the block of wood to be square so the block could get smaller and smaller and smaller until the spinning just went beyond the wood.

[Roy Belson]: There was no wood left.

[Roy Belson]: It'd take off, right?

[Roy Belson]: Take it off.

[Roy Belson]: Al Johnson, who became the vocational director years ago, remember Al?

[Roy Belson]: Al became the vocational director.

[Roy Belson]: Kicked me out of sheet metal at the Roberts one year because he said, you'll ruin everything here.

[Roy Belson]: And I never got beyond the lazy brown

[Roy Belson]: The dog jumped all the way, the red fox jumped over the lazy brown dog in front of me.

[Roy Belson]: So that wasn't my skill.

[Roy Belson]: Just one last comment, Mr. President, which is simply this, is that a couple weeks ago I was here, and you voted to submit the SOI.

[Roy Belson]: That plays into this, too.

[Roy Belson]: There's going to be some incredible things moving out in the next little while.

[Roy Belson]: You're part of it.

[Roy Belson]: You've been part of it.

[Roy Belson]: The whole science labs, fields, other things that were done, all contributed.

[Roy Belson]: In the next period of time, you're going to see something that you probably couldn't have envisioned because of people like Dr. Riccio and others who are investing themselves, bringing real talent to the place, and with real vision, and with real, let's say,

[Roy Belson]: aggressive and assertive ways to get funding to augment what we get from the city.

[Roy Belson]: So, uh, thank you for your support because you've been there supporting it.

[Roy Belson]: We have to come to you for city money and we appreciate what you do to support us as well.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Minuteman, this year's rate was something like $17,500 plus $4,500 for special education.

[Roy Belson]: That rate will go up and the capital fee gets added.

[Roy Belson]: We project it's going to be at $30,000 in another couple of years.

[Roy Belson]: We're using a rate that is around $12,000 plus $4,500 or $4,000 for

[Roy Belson]: special needs plus an administrative fee of about $1,500.

[Roy Belson]: So we're probably $15,000, $16,000 variety altogether.

[Roy Belson]: So it's definitely a good deal for our neighbors.

[Roy Belson]: At the same token, it provides us with substantial revenue.

[Roy Belson]: You understand the term marginal utility.

[Roy Belson]: When you've got so much space, it's already paid for.

[Roy Belson]: Everything else is extra.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, we're not costing ourselves money by adding staff.

[Roy Belson]: We're just filling in where we could.

[Roy Belson]: get value with existing operations.

[Roy Belson]: Well, for a particular... Well, it depends on how many youngsters we have there, but, you know, with... Well, if we have a hundred students, okay, in the building, when that actually is realized, we'll be seeing a hundred times maybe a million and a half to two million.

[Roy Belson]: Hasn't started yet.

[Roy Belson]: I thought vocational students were already coming here from.

[Roy Belson]: They are, but there's, they are, but there's, I believe that's true.

[Roy Belson]: They are, but there's about 30 of those right now.

[Roy Belson]: They don't have to necessarily

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: So in case something happens and someone is not there with it.

[Roy Belson]: But since we have trainers and coaches going to every game, I'm not sure we're in a critical stage yet.

[Roy Belson]: But in the future, obviously we want to be in a situation where these things are automatically there.

[Roy Belson]: The downside to that is they have to be checked fairly frequently to make sure the battery's loaded.

[Roy Belson]: And that means people have to go to these places early to check them in advance.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of logistical work that's associated with that.

[Roy Belson]: How long is the actual battery charge good for, Tony?

[Roy Belson]: So in other words saying it's, you know, generally should be in good shape.

[Roy Belson]: But again, you know, we certainly wouldn't want to malfunction to be the outcome of anything.

[Roy Belson]: If we go to their school, do they have things in place?

[Roy Belson]: If we're at other places, do they have things in place?

[Roy Belson]: Just like we're talking about the nurses on field trips and the like.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to be asking that question wherever we go.

[Roy Belson]: If there's something major going on, do you have facilities on site?

[Roy Belson]: So I don't know if you know this, but one of our former nurses used to get paid to go to the theater shows in Boston to sit in the audience just in case a nurse was necessary.

[Roy Belson]: The theaters didn't have their own medical staff, so they wanted someone there who was medically trained to intervene should a situation take place.

[Roy Belson]: I suspect we're going to have this conversation since the law not only affects Medford, but it affects every school district and every community across the commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to be one of those discussions, do you have the right equipment?

[Roy Belson]: Roy Bellison, Superintendent of Schools, 2500 Mystic Valley Parkway, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, members of the Council, thank you for hearing us this evening.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford School Committee recently approved a statement of interest to the Massachusetts School Building Authority, the purpose of which is to be very proactive and to find out, under the core program,

[Roy Belson]: that is funded by MSBA, what projects would be fundable for Medford High School, Medford Vocational Technical High School going forward?

[Roy Belson]: This particular SOI does not bind the city financially in any way.

[Roy Belson]: What it does is it enables the process to begin and to bring out a team from MSBA

[Roy Belson]: to sit with us to go over the various projects that may be possible and to determine what they would be considered eligible for possible funding going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if, in fact, they identify projects that are eligible for going forward, we would then have to come back to you and talk to you about the possibility of doing a feasibility study, which would then possibly lead to design and then later construction documents, which would then

[Roy Belson]: lead to an actual implementation.

[Roy Belson]: But at this point, all we're asking you for is approval to submit to the state an opportunity to meet with their team, to review what we have at our schools, and determine what is eligible for funding under their current funding structure.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's a very proactive thing.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's consistent with what I just heard about being part of a plan rather than simply asking for an item at a time.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that it's the kind of thing that we want to do to know what we can go forward with on our own or what we should go forward with on our own and what we clearly need support from the state for or could be eligible for support from the state.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's particularly significant since as we look at the future, inflation of construction costs certainly goes up.

[Roy Belson]: and the possibility of the reduction of reimbursement goes down as the city's wealth increases and our eligibility for a higher reimbursement rate might decrease.

[Roy Belson]: This is clearly something that would, if it goes forward, would be a two to three year activity.

[Roy Belson]: It wouldn't be something that would happen overnight, but it would be something that enables us to get into the discussion range with the MSBA.

[Roy Belson]: So with that, I just ask that the city council

[Roy Belson]: approve what the school committee has already approved, allow us to submit a statement of interest to MSBA so that we can begin the process of exploring what might be helpful to us in Medford and what we could have the state share the cost of.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: So there are two programs at MSBA that take place.

[Roy Belson]: One is called Accelerated Repair.

[Roy Belson]: That's not the program we're applying under.

[Roy Belson]: This is the core program.

[Roy Belson]: for renovation and rebuilding and possible new construction.

[Roy Belson]: There are priorities.

[Roy Belson]: There are different seven priorities that the state lists that they would consider.

[Roy Belson]: We have selected four of them that we've brought in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: Now, all the items listed may not be items we're interested in, but we put them down because if the state comes out, we'll talk about everything that's possible

[Roy Belson]: and see what their interest level is.

[Roy Belson]: So for example, it's highly unlikely that we're interested in boilers because we just replaced the boilers at Medford High School.

[Roy Belson]: But we put it down because boilers lead to a discussion of heating systems.

[Roy Belson]: An important thing to talk about is an upgrade, if you will, of the fire alarm system at Medford High School.

[Roy Belson]: It goes back to 1970.

[Roy Belson]: So it's clear that, you know,

[Roy Belson]: this is a good time to look at the fire alarm system.

[Roy Belson]: We know that the roof was replaced in 2001.

[Roy Belson]: We know that at some point in time the roof is going to need

[Roy Belson]: a replacement, we think it's five, six years out, but if we got funding for it, it would be propitious to move forward with that.

[Roy Belson]: We know that there are, the vocational school is moving into very high tech areas, and anything that would allow us to improve our shops in ways that would enable us to offer state of the art programs above and beyond what we're currently doing is an advantage.

[Roy Belson]: So anything that moves the show forward

[Roy Belson]: enables us to look at the things that would be useful going forward as something that we would like to explore.

[Roy Belson]: Another example would be the floor tiles.

[Roy Belson]: The floor tiles contain a certain amount of asbestos in them.

[Roy Belson]: Now, they're not dangerous because they're not friable.

[Roy Belson]: But you can't pick them up without an abatement.

[Roy Belson]: And an abatement costs a lot of money.

[Roy Belson]: So if we're going to have to change the flooring, if we're going to improve the flooring and things of that type, then we should have somebody else join with us and partner with us in the funding of it.

[Roy Belson]: So those are the kinds of discussions we would like to have.

[Roy Belson]: We certainly know that some things they'll tell us we're not high enough priority for because there are other places that are in greater need.

[Roy Belson]: But there are some things that might actually fly through, and we'd like to find out what they are.

[Roy Belson]: And that will inform not only a funding proposal potentially going forward, which would then come before you again, but it also informs what we would then push for in local capital funding

[Roy Belson]: which would be necessary to do.

[Roy Belson]: Technology is another major area.

[Roy Belson]: With testing now being done on computers, with reporting all being done on computers and data management and the like, it's critical that, you know, our technology be totally up to date and 100% that we continue to move forward with that area.

[Roy Belson]: That's an area that might be of interest to the state.

[Roy Belson]: We certainly would move forward with that.

[Roy Belson]: We've also applied or will apply under the E-Rate Program, the Universal Libraries Program,

[Roy Belson]: And we think we're eligible for about $600,000 there on top of this.

[Roy Belson]: So these are things that, you know, we're looking at.

[Roy Belson]: We want to advance our possibilities.

[Roy Belson]: We want to put before you all the possibilities for outside funding that will complement local funding.

[Roy Belson]: And the only way we can find out is if we sit with the state in a formal process and review and explore what they would consider a priority for Medford.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: Well, the SOI includes everything.

[Roy Belson]: The SOI just simply talks about everything possible.

[Roy Belson]: We would look at the entire building with MSBA and not leave anything out that they might consider eligible for funding.

[Roy Belson]: The school committee obviously wants to anticipate possible needs going forward, as I indicated, flooring, staircases.

[Roy Belson]: The fire alarm system.

[Roy Belson]: These are things, the roof.

[Roy Belson]: These are things that should be looked at because the building is going to be 50 years old in another couple of years.

[Roy Belson]: And we have a very solid building.

[Roy Belson]: It's not a building that needs to be replaced.

[Roy Belson]: You can't buy a CMU building anymore.

[Roy Belson]: with the kind of money out there.

[Roy Belson]: Somerville is, what, $250 million to replace a building?

[Roy Belson]: Minuteman is $155 million.

[Roy Belson]: Waltham's looking at a couple hundred million.

[Roy Belson]: We're not going to spend that kind of money.

[Roy Belson]: We have the solid structure, but we have to make sure the internal systems are going to be up to date so they can go for another 40, 50 years before someone has to consider whether this building has any further life.

[Roy Belson]: So that's sort of what we're looking at.

[Roy Belson]: I think the school committee wants to understand and hear what the state is willing to fund.

[Roy Belson]: And I think we have a very extensive list of just almost a laundry list of everything we would look at.

[Roy Belson]: It's on here.

[Roy Belson]: If you read through, you'll see the things that the school committee approved as things they would like the MSBA to look at.

[Roy Belson]: That it references.

[Roy Belson]: So each under each of the four priorities to address, we list a whole series of things we'd like MSBA to look at with us.

[Roy Belson]: I just, those are one, uh, the last two pages.

[Roy Belson]: March 16th, yeah.

[Roy Belson]: My address is March 17th, mine is March 16th.

[Roy Belson]: Exactly.

[Roy Belson]: They would tell us, these are the things that we would consider funding with you.

[Roy Belson]: These are the things you're going to do yourself.

[Roy Belson]: Point of information if I can.

[Roy Belson]: So that's a discussion, Councilor, that we would have.

[Roy Belson]: First we wanna know who's gonna join with us on what projects.

[Roy Belson]: And then the school committee, and then obviously you, because you have to bond with us, to determine which items will take precedence and priority.

[Roy Belson]: Because otherwise, you know, we have a plan that

[Roy Belson]: might avoid doing something that we consider more important and MSBA might not consider as a priority for them.

[Roy Belson]: But we have to begin to understand what they will fund so we can understand how many dollars we might have left to tackle other issues and go back and forth.

[Roy Belson]: Now, it may be something they're willing to fund that we don't care to fund in the short term.

[Roy Belson]: But we can keep it on the boards.

[Roy Belson]: But once they determine it's eligible, we can go back in and apply for it.

[Roy Belson]: So the goal is to know what we can apply for so that we know which items have to be funded by ourselves and which items can be funded in partnership, and then to determine the prioritization and the timing of each of these projects.

[Roy Belson]: It really depends on what they determine eligibility.

[Roy Belson]: Somerville, when they're rebuilding the high school, I guess, is eligible for about $130 million.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I don't think we're in that category.

[Roy Belson]: We're looking at something much smaller than that.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly, whatever they determine we're eligible for, we'll put a price tag on it after we do some feasibility work.

[Roy Belson]: And then we can decide how much this community wants to invest at this particular point in time or going forward.

[Roy Belson]: But at least we know.

[Roy Belson]: what our partners are willing to put up on the table, so that we can give you an informed proposal for both local capital planning and partnered capital planning.

[Roy Belson]: So the school committee had several meetings on this topic.

[Roy Belson]: And it's our impression that while there are things to be done at every school, obviously you have to keep it up.

[Roy Belson]: The major issues will be going forward at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: High school is now the oldest major building in our possession.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things I told the school committee so I feel comfortable sharing it here is that in next year's budget, I will look to increase the amount of money put in for maintenance across the board so that we can do some of the things that people have raised independent of any capital planning and independent of any state funded planning.

[Roy Belson]: We also have grants, as we've indicated before, that are also giving us money.

[Roy Belson]: For example, we got $100,000 or just under $100,000 in biosciences recently.

[Roy Belson]: We got a $500,000 grant in capital skills development from the state just the other day, a week ago Friday.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got some other grants out there they're looking for.

[Roy Belson]: There's about $600,000, $700,000 in technology funding that we are eligible for that we're putting together the proposal for.

[Roy Belson]: It's an entitlement as long as we meet certain requirements.

[Roy Belson]: So we're putting all of this together to come so that we can actually deal with issues with other people's money as much as possible, but certainly recognizing that not everything that we want to do will be eligible for funding by an outside agency.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: So let me give you a couple of examples.

[Roy Belson]: Anyone who's been up to high school, by the way, with a lot of, and with your help, by the way, and I appreciate that, a lot of capital projects have been done, and I could enumerate them at some point if you're interested, but the council has approved money for them, so I appreciate that.

[Roy Belson]: But let's take the locker rooms at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: You've been up to the locker rooms at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: You know they're old, and you know that they're not particularly what we want them to be.

[Roy Belson]: The girls' locker room, it is what it is.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of old things in there.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of old marble, old shower stalls.

[Roy Belson]: It's a lot of empty space, unutilized space.

[Roy Belson]: That needs to be redone, because if it's redone, we'll recapture some space for other programming, and we can provide a state-of-the-art locker room for the young women

[Roy Belson]: to use it.

[Roy Belson]: The same thing is true with the men's locker room.

[Roy Belson]: We need to do that.

[Roy Belson]: It's just these are the things that are there.

[Roy Belson]: When you talk about a performing arts center, that may be a little aspirational, you know, in regard because, you know, we're talking about having a program that promotes the theater arts and promotes media and the like, but I don't know that we need to go to 1,000 seats right now.

[Roy Belson]: So that may be a little bit aspirational, but the people doing the thinking raised it and said, you know,

[Roy Belson]: Let's put it down and let's see if there's some interest in doing more with that.

[Roy Belson]: I think those are the kinds of cafeteria.

[Roy Belson]: Right now there's three cafeterias.

[Roy Belson]: It may be that we can reconfigure them, especially since right now, as you undoubtedly have heard, or maybe read in the transcript recently, we're redoing the Cafe Electra into a brand new hospitality and restaurant suite with state money.

[Roy Belson]: And that's critical, because that's going to be up on the first floor.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to be a restaurant for the public.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to tie into our partnerships with Wynn.

[Roy Belson]: which is creating the casino up the street and developing job opportunities.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to tie into a whole pile of activities and revenue-generating activities that will support other programs.

[Roy Belson]: And that will free up space where Cafe Elektor is now, and we can do some other things with that.

[Roy Belson]: So this is a whole process of looking at how we can reconfigure space to our greatest advantage.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the print shop, because they don't use the big presses anymore, can now go down to a smaller place.

[Roy Belson]: We don't have to give them the big cavern that they have, because they don't use that anymore.

[Roy Belson]: That's not what printing is about anymore.

[Roy Belson]: So Dr. Ritchiell, for example, has created what we'll call clusters or academies, putting programs together, human service programs together, construction programs together, programs that deal with media and development together, so that they can interact with each other.

[Roy Belson]: So that a youngster, when they're trained, is cross-trained for more than one area.

[Roy Belson]: That creates great opportunities for our young people.

[Roy Belson]: Instead of being trained only in one area, you're trained in multiple areas.

[Roy Belson]: You may have noticed that we've virtually recaptured all the students from Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: By next year, we'll have only eight students at Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have saved a million dollars a year on that alone by putting these programs together.

[Roy Belson]: By bringing some students in from the outside, we're recapturing revenue.

[Roy Belson]: possibly projecting over two or three years, a million dollars a year in new revenue coming into it.

[Roy Belson]: This is going to help us weather the storm, whether it's federal cutbacks, state failure to pay, or some of the local issues, the priorities that we have.

[Roy Belson]: So these are ways that I think we're moving forward.

[Roy Belson]: And I believe that looking at our school at 50 years of age and looking for another 50 years from that building is a really good time to start and be proactive now.

[Roy Belson]: Plan, recognizing we've got to come back to you.

[Roy Belson]: You're not voting for money tonight.

[Roy Belson]: You're voting for planning tonight.

[Roy Belson]: You're voting to be proactive, to look and see what's possible.

[Roy Belson]: And that's what we were asking you to do.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it's a great opportunity.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: If we become eligible,

[Roy Belson]: We would then petition MSBA for a feasibility study for the specific projects that we determined were the priority that we wanted to go with them for or with.

[Roy Belson]: And they would reimburse us at the same rate they would reimburse the construction.

[Roy Belson]: So if the feasibility study was $500,000 and we're eligible for 50%, we'd get $250,000 back.

[Roy Belson]: We lay it out, but they reimburse us.

[Roy Belson]: It gets us in the game, and it allows us to consider our options, which I think is really important.

[Roy Belson]: Earlier this evening, I heard you talking.

[Roy Belson]: You want to consider options?

[Roy Belson]: Well, you want to know who's going to pay for what.

[Roy Belson]: And if you've got somebody else who wants to pay for it, or will help you pay for it, you want to know that before you put your own money on the table.

[Roy Belson]: I have the copies of the votes if you need it.

[Roy Belson]: 7-0.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: So I can't tell you that, because basically we listed almost everything that we possibly could think of in the SOI.

[Roy Belson]: So it really depends on what the state determines would be eligible.

[Roy Belson]: I would say most of the things that we listed on that would be something we would discuss with them.

[Roy Belson]: There may be some things that they would say, that's your problem.

[Roy Belson]: They're all good questions, thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Personally, I allowed the planning team at the high school to put down some of their aspirational things.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I don't personally think I need a 500-student cafeteria.

[Roy Belson]: Personally, I don't think that.

[Roy Belson]: But I wouldn't tell my people they can't ask for it and let somebody else tell them, we don't think we'd fund that, OK?

[Roy Belson]: So I don't think that's going to be something MSBA is going to be interested in, because I think they already know we have cafeterias.

[Roy Belson]: And they'd say, probably, why don't you just put a coat of paint on and do some other things?

[Roy Belson]: So I don't think that's an issue.

[Roy Belson]: Point of information.

[Roy Belson]: Why are we throwing everything at the wall right now?

[Roy Belson]: Again, as I said to you, the SOI is a planning document.

[Roy Belson]: It's to get you into an exploration process.

[Roy Belson]: and to find out what the state is willing to pay for.

[Roy Belson]: So you put down everything to talk about, and you find out that they're going to discard a few things here and a few things there, and maybe several things, and say that's really not important enough to us.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll find out.

[Roy Belson]: The document that you had in front of you is really a document that was produced in September, or early on, based on what people thought at that particular time.

[Roy Belson]: Different things emerge.

[Roy Belson]: People want to talk about them.

[Roy Belson]: There are some ideas that the headmaster has, that the vocational director has, that we put it down so that we could explore them with the state.

[Roy Belson]: Not because we necessarily think that they're going to fund all these things.

[Roy Belson]: We want to get into an exploratory process to examine what is possible for partnership with state funding.

[Roy Belson]: And then we'll merge the documents.

[Roy Belson]: The key thing you have to remember is we have to come back to you for the money.

[Roy Belson]: And any amount that we're going to spend, you're gonna prioritize along with the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: It's not gonna be the superintendent who makes the final call.

[Roy Belson]: The superintendent might make a recommendation.

[Roy Belson]: But you're gonna decide, and the mayor's gonna decide, and the school committee's gonna decide how much money you're willing to put on the table at any given point in time.

[Roy Belson]: But knowing what's eligible gives you a leg up on what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: And as far as the percentage goes, I know what other people are getting at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: I know what the relative things are.

[Roy Belson]: The state's not going to commit to something before they see it.

[Roy Belson]: I know we fall in that basic line of where we would be eligible because I know what the economics are between the different communities.

[Roy Belson]: It doesn't mean that it won't, it won't go down a little bit because obviously the wealth of the community is increasing.

[Roy Belson]: I hear what you're saying, but my experience tells me in meeting, because I've had these meetings before, as you know, we've had science labs,

[Roy Belson]: We've built new buildings and so on.

[Roy Belson]: My experience tells me that when we sit down with them, we'll focus in on the things that are high priority first, and then we'll look at whether these things, any of these other things are possible.

[Roy Belson]: But they know the difference between a fire alarm system and a roof and a cafeteria.

[Roy Belson]: They know the difference, and they know where we would like to go first.

[Roy Belson]: This is an attempt to give everybody, every stakeholder who is involved in the planning process of putting an SOI together a chance to be heard,

[Roy Belson]: rather than say your idea is not worth being explored with the state.

[Roy Belson]: We're giving them a chance to be heard.

[Roy Belson]: But you know and I know that the state will zero in on firearms and roofs.

[Roy Belson]: and heating systems long before they worry about the cafeteria.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: You sit down and you go over and they'll tell you what they would consider to be priorities, what they would consider to be something that they would consider to be of concern to them, what they would like to fund.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, after all, they're accountable to their funding agency and their board as well.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that they'd be more interested in a fire alarm system, a roof, heating systems, more so than some of the other things.

[Roy Belson]: But we're giving them all these things and they might say,

[Roy Belson]: We're doing something with this.

[Roy Belson]: Who knew a few years ago that they were going to be funding science labs?

[Roy Belson]: But we put it in front of them, and we got it.

[Roy Belson]: You know, you have to try all these things.

[Roy Belson]: You put it in front of them and say, are you interested in this?

[Roy Belson]: Could you consider this to be a reasonable investment?

[Roy Belson]: Maybe someone's going to say, yes, you know, we've got an interest in this at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: So we're moving forward with a planning process.

[Roy Belson]: That's all we're doing tonight, asking you to allow us to go forward proactively and find out what the state wants to prioritize in our community.

[Roy Belson]: And this is going to take,

[Roy Belson]: probably two to three years to actually actualize.

[Roy Belson]: And in the meantime, that will inform our other capital planning that may have to be locally funded.

[Roy Belson]: And we will form also our maintenance issues, which will be locally funded.

[Roy Belson]: And then grant applications we make.

[Roy Belson]: If someone were to say we can't get grants for this, for example, we're building the Culinary Arts and Hospitality Center, that wasn't gonna be funded by MSBA.

[Roy Belson]: But we got a grant to do it.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to know where we have to go.

[Roy Belson]: We have to know what's possible under what set of funding and what's possible under other sets of funding.

[Roy Belson]: And then we can then lay it out.

[Roy Belson]: And of course, we're going to have to work with you and the school committee for any kind of local money.

[Roy Belson]: that's going to be needed to move the project forward.

[Roy Belson]: This isn't you say yes tonight, and I go off and do whatever I want.

[Roy Belson]: This is you say yes tonight, we get the process going, and then we come back to you and sit down.

[Roy Belson]: And it should be a robust process, because the city wants to move forward on some good projects, not only in the schools, but in the city.

[Roy Belson]: And we look forward to that.

[Roy Belson]: No, because I don't know, you know,

[Roy Belson]: the extent to which any of these things would be funded.

[Roy Belson]: But I do know.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I'm not talking about funding.

[Roy Belson]: What is the actual cost of your SOI request?

[Roy Belson]: You know, I wouldn't want to give you a guess right now, because quite frankly, it depends on the extent to which you do them.

[Roy Belson]: And any one of these things might be a partial thing, maybe some windows, maybe some doors, and maybe all doors.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think we can do that right now.

[Roy Belson]: When we get back from a planning process,

[Roy Belson]: and we get to a financial phase, then we can do that.

[Roy Belson]: That's the most prudent way to do it, not to throw speculative numbers out there right now.

[Roy Belson]: And if people come and say, look, that's too much at any one time, then that'll be too much at any one time.

[Roy Belson]: I'd be prepared to come back to you to tell you what your options are and to allow you to decide what the finances of this city is willing to support in support of your public schools.

[Roy Belson]: That's all just like anything else.

[Roy Belson]: We come to you with a budget.

[Roy Belson]: We come to you with other kinds of financial things.

[Roy Belson]: You can tell us how much more you want to put into it.

[Roy Belson]: But you know, for example, in five or six years, you're going to replace a roof at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: You are going to do it.

[Roy Belson]: The question is, who's going to pay for it?

[Roy Belson]: But if we are eligible to get somebody to share that with us, why not find out now?

[Roy Belson]: You know that there are some heating things that we wanna do at the high school that we should do.

[Roy Belson]: If you don't do them in the next few years, you'll end up paying for it.

[Roy Belson]: So we should find out if we have a partner.

[Roy Belson]: And so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: We know that technology is moving at a rapid rate.

[Roy Belson]: And if we know that it's gonna be expensive to increase all the technology that's gonna be required of public schools,

[Roy Belson]: So if someone's willing to partner with us, great.

[Roy Belson]: You'll know that.

[Roy Belson]: That gives you those things.

[Roy Belson]: But you can decide that I'm not interested in a performing arts center, and I'm not interested in an expanded cafeteria, and I don't really care about some other things you're interested in.

[Roy Belson]: So even though someone's willing to partner with us, it's off the table for Medford because we have other things we want to do.

[Roy Belson]: My job is to give you options.

[Roy Belson]: My job is to give you an opportunity to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: Well, what I'm telling you is I'm telling you it'll take two to three years to get through the process to actually get construction going on something, any project that gets approved.

[Roy Belson]: and the like, but we won't even get to design feasibility and design until we come back here and talk about what the state is interested in.

[Roy Belson]: And in the feasibility period, that's when you will make some decisions before we actually go forward with a final number.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, the reality is that some things will be done over five years, some things may be done over 10 years.

[Roy Belson]: The reality is, is to find out what we can get some funding for and what we can get support for.

[Roy Belson]: And we're at such an early stage.

[Roy Belson]: I know that.

[Roy Belson]: And quite frankly, look, you get hit with a lot of decisions that require you to make tough decisions on money, on

[Roy Belson]: policies, on zoning, on any number of issues.

[Roy Belson]: You can't hide from, not that you want to, from making tough decisions that make some people happy and some people less happy.

[Roy Belson]: I said I respected the right of the planning team to forward things

[Roy Belson]: that they consider to be important to them because I want to respect my administrative team and the teachers and others who participate.

[Roy Belson]: You're the educational leader of this community, Mr. Superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: And I like the participation of people.

[Roy Belson]: I don't have to make all the decisions myself.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is that nothing is going to go forward financially unless you decide you can afford it.

[Roy Belson]: Nothing's going to go forward.

[Roy Belson]: We're trying to explore who wants to partner with us.

[Roy Belson]: And you know that the most important things will be systems that are important to the school.

[Roy Belson]: The operation of the building will get higher priority than some of the things that maybe are aspirational.

[Roy Belson]: You know that.

[Roy Belson]: So if you decide that certain things aren't something you want to fund, then you say, well, put that off for a couple of years.

[Roy Belson]: But certainly, you're going to face a roof.

[Roy Belson]: Certainly, you're going to face technology.

[Roy Belson]: Certainly, you're going to deal with other systems, heating systems, and other things like that.

[Roy Belson]: And if we don't get in the game now, it'll be longer.

[Roy Belson]: before we get funding.

[Roy Belson]: And if we don't, and if the funding dries up because of the Commonwealth not being able to keep things moving, you see the green line, other things like that.

[Roy Belson]: We talk about these things and it keeps getting pushed off, keeps getting pushed off.

[Roy Belson]: Let's get in the game and then you can decide whether or not it's something you desire as a priority.

[Roy Belson]: That's what we need to look at.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's my job to put it in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: I hope it's your job to, or I hope it's your willingness to let me find out what's possible going forward.

[Roy Belson]: I would agree that restrooms are something that should be addressed, yes.

[Roy Belson]: How come they're not part of the SOI?

[Roy Belson]: That's something that we can talk about.

[Roy Belson]: would meet to talk about that.
