[Roy Belson]: But I think you should allow us to go forward.

[Roy Belson]: And to get this going, I mean, it doesn't hurt.

[Roy Belson]: You're not committing anything in terms of money.

[Roy Belson]: You're just allowing us to submit an application to the state so that we can be heard with their team that evaluates issues.

[Roy Belson]: And they won't even get to us for a couple of months, I'm sure.

[Roy Belson]: They won't even get to us for a short period of time.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, we have to be in.

[Roy Belson]: Because there are other communities going to submit as well.

[Roy Belson]: And if we're not in, we don't get any consideration.

[Roy Belson]: So I think I'll be happy to bring that up with the school committee to give you some sort of what they consider priorities within this list.

[Roy Belson]: But I don't think you should stop it tonight.

[Roy Belson]: I certainly have no problem with any of that.

[Roy Belson]: I think, you know, look, let's not kid ourselves.

[Roy Belson]: Any project to go forward needs a school committee, needs the mayor, needs the city council, and needs the state.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of deliberation that's going to have to take place and a lot of prioritization that's going to take place.

[Roy Belson]: But if you're only asking me to go back to the school committee and sit down and ask them to tell you what's most important to them, happy to do that.

[Roy Belson]: I think that that's a good thing, but I don't think we should stop getting in on the

[Roy Belson]: uh, into the state with this.

[Roy Belson]: So we can continue to move and get them to come out to a sooner rather than later, because everybody's going to be submitting.

[Roy Belson]: And if we're the last one in the door, maybe our review date doesn't happen till August, September, October, whatever the case may be.

[Roy Belson]: I respect your right to make those decisions, and, you know, I understand them.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, I'm not a rookie.

[Roy Belson]: I've been here a long time, and I've been in and out of these meetings many times, asking for funding and other forms of support.

[Roy Belson]: So I respect that.

[Roy Belson]: But it's important that you know your options, and that's all I'm asking you to know.

[Roy Belson]: Know your options.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, just one quick thing to Councilor, if I may.

[Roy Belson]: Just that we did an infrared study of the high school roof.

[Roy Belson]: We will repair those things that need to be repaired for about $25,000 this summer.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: That's about all we need to do.

[Roy Belson]: The long-term renovation or repair or reconstruction of the roof is five to six years out, and, you know, if we were to take it to the end.

[Roy Belson]: So that's really where we're at.

[Roy Belson]: We had a couple of very difficult snow periods a few years ago where shoveling was required on the roof to avoid collapse and the like that may have done some damage in certain areas, and we need to repair those.

[Roy Belson]: But other than that, the roof's got another five, six years.

[Roy Belson]: Councilor Lungo-Koehn.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: So, Mr. President, if I could just respond.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, I feel I have to.

[Roy Belson]: The document you're referring to in September was a different document.

[Roy Belson]: That's the capital plan that came from the mayor, which through the school committee, the document you have in front of you was approved by the school committee on February 6th after a committee, the whole meeting that they had the week before on that.

[Roy Belson]: And you received it, what do you call it tonight?

[Roy Belson]: Uh, because what do you call it?

[Roy Belson]: You were busy dealing with other capital

[Roy Belson]: considerations, in particular the police station and other things like that, so that we didn't confuse those two items.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is that that's the two things.

[Roy Belson]: And the other point I guess I would make is that the state has a form.

[Roy Belson]: We filled out the form.

[Roy Belson]: You don't add to the form.

[Roy Belson]: We'll be happy to provide that priority list to them.

[Roy Belson]: But the form is the form.

[Roy Belson]: That's what you submit.

[Roy Belson]: You don't add things to an application that is not required.

[Roy Belson]: I think that would be not consistent with the way you make a submittal.

[Roy Belson]: Um, so, but certainly we respect the right, you know, that the council has asked and we've certainly will honor that to come up with a priority list, provide it to you and provide it to MSBA as part of the discussions that take place.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: The MSBA opens up a window for statements of interest in January.

[Roy Belson]: and then expects it to follow through by the April date.

[Roy Belson]: They actually pushed it out a little bit this year.

[Roy Belson]: Normally it's in March.

[Roy Belson]: But they open up the window for the SOIs in January.

[Roy Belson]: As amended, Mr. Belson, do you want to finish up with anything?

[Roy Belson]: I just want to finish a couple of quick statements, if I may, with your permission.

[Roy Belson]: First of all, some of the things that were quoted were quoted as the priorities of the state.

[Roy Belson]: When they say the building structurally unsound, that's not what we're saying.

[Roy Belson]: That's what the state is using as a category for things that you can put things under.

[Roy Belson]: When the building says that the renovation of schools such as roofs, that's what they're saying you can ask for.

[Roy Belson]: That's not what we're saying is our need.

[Roy Belson]: That's the first thing.

[Roy Belson]: As far as handicapped accessibility, we put in three elevators, ramps.

[Roy Belson]: We've made the Little Theater or the Caron Theater now handicapped accessible.

[Roy Belson]: The building is handicapped accessible.

[Roy Belson]: There are a lot of things.

[Roy Belson]: And with all due respect to, I understand there's a give and take here.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is that a lot of improvements have been made to that high school and that technical school.

[Roy Belson]: And you have helped to pay for it over the years as a city council and as a school committee.

[Roy Belson]: The school committee had a right when this thing came out to deliberate and determine what it considered to be important and to talk about it.

[Roy Belson]: And they had a committee of the whole.

[Roy Belson]: And they then had a follow-up meeting where they voted it.

[Roy Belson]: You're getting it.

[Roy Belson]: And all we're asking is for you to allow us to submit it so we can then begin a process of finding out what's possible.

[Roy Belson]: And then we can have a more robust

[Roy Belson]: interactive process between council, school committee, mayor, administration, to determine what this city considers important, what this city wants to fund on its own, what this city wants to partner with, and what we're gonna do in what time frame.

[Roy Belson]: And that's all we're looking for tonight.

[Roy Belson]: Roy Bellison, Superintendent of Schools, 2500 Mystic Valley Parkway, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, members of the Council, thank you for hearing us this evening.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford School Committee recently approved a statement of interest to the Massachusetts School Building Authority, the purpose of which is to be very proactive and to find out, under the core program,

[Roy Belson]: that is funded by MSBA, what projects would be fundable for Medford High School, Medford Vocational Technical High School going forward?

[Roy Belson]: This particular SOI does not bind the city financially in any way.

[Roy Belson]: What it does is it enables the process to begin and to bring out a team from MSBA to sit with us to go over the various projects that may be possible

[Roy Belson]: and to determine what they would be considered eligible for possible funding going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if in fact they identify projects that are eligible for going forward, we would then have to come back to you and talk to you about the possibility of doing a feasibility study, which would then possibly lead to design, and then later construction documents, which would then lead to an actual implementation.

[Roy Belson]: But at this point, all we're asking

[Roy Belson]: you for is approval to submit to the state an opportunity to meet with their team to review what we have at our schools and determine what is eligible for funding under their current funding structure.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's a very proactive thing.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's consistent with what I just heard about being part of a plan rather than simply asking for an item at a time.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that it's the kind of thing that we want to do to know what we can go forward with on our own or what we should go forward with on our own and what we clearly need support from the state for or could be eligible for support from the state.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's particularly significant since as we look at the future, inflation of construction costs certainly goes up.

[Roy Belson]: and the possibility of the reduction of reimbursement goes down as the city's wealth increases and our eligibility for a higher reimbursement rate might decrease.

[Roy Belson]: This is clearly something that would, if it goes forward, would be a two to three year activity.

[Roy Belson]: It wouldn't be something that would happen overnight, but it would be something that enables us to get into the discussion range with the MSBA.

[Roy Belson]: So with that, I just ask that the City Council

[Roy Belson]: approve what the school committee has already approved, allow us to submit a statement of interest to MSBA so that we can begin the process of exploring what might be helpful to us in Medford and what we can have the state share the cost of.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: So there are two programs at MSBA that take place.

[Roy Belson]: One is called Accelerated Repair.

[Roy Belson]: That's not the program we're applying under.

[Roy Belson]: This is the core program for renovation and rebuilding and possible new construction.

[Roy Belson]: There are priorities.

[Roy Belson]: There are different seven priorities that the state lists that they would consider.

[Roy Belson]: We have selected four of them that we've brought in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: All the items listed may not be items we're interested in, but we put them down because if the state comes out, we'll talk about everything that's possible and see what their interest level is.

[Roy Belson]: So, for example, it's highly unlikely that we're interested in boilers because we just replaced the boilers, okay, at Medford High School.

[Roy Belson]: But we put it down because boilers lead to a discussion of heating systems.

[Roy Belson]: An important thing to talk about is an upgrade, if you will, of the fire alarm system.

[Roy Belson]: at Medford High School, it goes back to 1970.

[Roy Belson]: So it's clear that this is a good time to look at the fire alarm system.

[Roy Belson]: We know that the roof was replaced in 2001.

[Roy Belson]: We know that at some point in time, the roof is going to need

[Roy Belson]: a replacement.

[Roy Belson]: We think it's five, six years out.

[Roy Belson]: But if we got funding for it, it would be propitious to move forward with that.

[Roy Belson]: We know that the vocational school is moving into very high-tech areas.

[Roy Belson]: And anything that would allow us to improve our shops in ways that would enable us to offer state-of-the-art programs above and beyond what we're currently doing is an advantage.

[Roy Belson]: So anything that moves the show forward

[Roy Belson]: enables us to look at the things that would be useful going forward as something that we would like to explore.

[Roy Belson]: Another example would be the floor tiles.

[Roy Belson]: The floor tiles contain a certain amount of asbestos in them.

[Roy Belson]: Now, they're not dangerous because they're not friable, but you can't pick them up without an abatement, and an abatement costs a lot of money.

[Roy Belson]: So if we're going to have to change the flooring, if we're going to improve the flooring and things of that type, then we should have somebody else join with us and partner with us in the funding of it.

[Roy Belson]: So those are the kinds of discussions we would like to have.

[Roy Belson]: We certainly know that some things they'll tell us we're not high enough priority for because there are other places that are in greater need.

[Roy Belson]: But there are some things that might actually fly through and we'd like to find out what they are.

[Roy Belson]: And that will inform not only a funding proposal potentially going forward, which would then come before you again.

[Roy Belson]: But it also informs what we would then push for in local capital funding, which would be necessary to do.

[Roy Belson]: Technology is another major area, with testing now being done on computers, with

[Roy Belson]: reporting all being done on computers and data management and the like, it's critical that, you know, our technology be totally up to date and 100% that we continue to move forward with that area.

[Roy Belson]: That's an area that might be of interest to the state.

[Roy Belson]: We certainly would move forward with that.

[Roy Belson]: We've also applied or will apply under the e-rate program, the universal libraries program, and we think we're eligible for about $600,000 there on top of this.

[Roy Belson]: So these are things that we're looking at.

[Roy Belson]: We want to advance our possibilities.

[Roy Belson]: We want to put before you all the possibilities for outside funding that will complement local funding.

[Roy Belson]: And the only way we can find out is if we sit with the state in a formal process and review and explore what they would consider a priority for Medford.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: Well, the SOI includes everything.

[Roy Belson]: The SOI just simply talks about everything possible.

[Roy Belson]: We would look at the entire building with MSBA and not leave anything out that they might consider eligible for funding.

[Roy Belson]: The school committee obviously wants to anticipate possible needs going forward, as I indicated, flooring, staircases,

[Roy Belson]: The fire alarm system, these are things, the roof, these are things that should be looked at because the building is going to be 50 years old in another couple of years.

[Roy Belson]: And we have a very solid building.

[Roy Belson]: It's not a building that needs to be replaced.

[Roy Belson]: You can't buy a CMU building anymore.

[Roy Belson]: with the kind of money out there.

[Roy Belson]: Somerville is, what, $250 million to replace a building?

[Roy Belson]: Minuteman is $155 million.

[Roy Belson]: Waltham's looking at a couple hundred million.

[Roy Belson]: We're not going to spend that kind of money.

[Roy Belson]: We have the solid structure, but we have to make sure the internal systems are going to be up to date so they can go for another 40, 50 years before someone has to consider whether this building has any further life.

[Roy Belson]: So that's sort of what we're looking at.

[Roy Belson]: I think the school committee wants to understand and hear what the state is willing to fund.

[Roy Belson]: And I think we have a very extensive list of just almost a laundry list of everything we would look at.

[Roy Belson]: It's on here.

[Roy Belson]: If you read through, you'll see the things that the school committee approved as things they would like the MSBA to look at.

[Roy Belson]: That it references.

[Roy Belson]: So under each of the four priorities to address, we list a whole series of things we'd like MSBA to look at with us.

[Roy Belson]: Those are one, the last two pages.

[Roy Belson]: March 16th.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, well, my address is March 17th, mine's March 16th.

[Roy Belson]: Exactly.

[Roy Belson]: They would tell us, these are the things that we would consider funding with you.

[Roy Belson]: These are the things you're going to do yourself.

[Roy Belson]: Point of information, if I can.

[Roy Belson]: First we want to know who's going to join with us on what projects.

[Roy Belson]: And then the school committee, and then obviously you, because you have to bond with us, to determine which items will take precedence and priority.

[Roy Belson]: Because otherwise, you know, we have a plan that

[Roy Belson]: might avoid doing something that we consider more important and MSBA might not consider as a priority for them.

[Roy Belson]: But we have to begin to understand what they will fund so we can understand how many dollars we might have left to tackle other issues and go back and forth.

[Roy Belson]: Now it may be something they're willing to fund that we don't care to fund in the short term.

[Roy Belson]: We can keep it on the boards, but once they determine it's eligible, we can go back and apply for it.

[Roy Belson]: So the goal is to know what we can apply for so that we know which items have to be funded by ourselves and which items can be funded in partnership, and then to determine the prioritization and the timing of each of these projects.

[Roy Belson]: It really depends on what they determine eligibility.

[Roy Belson]: Somerville, when they're rebuilding the high school, I guess, is eligible for about $130 million.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: Now, we're not, I don't think we're in that category.

[Roy Belson]: We're looking at something much smaller than that.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly, whatever they determine we're eligible for, we'll put a price tag on it after we do some feasibility work.

[Roy Belson]: And then we can decide how much this community wants to invest at this particular point in time or going forward.

[Roy Belson]: But at least we know

[Roy Belson]: what our partners are willing to put up on the table so that we can give you an informed proposal for both local capital planning and partnered capital planning.

[Roy Belson]: So the school committee had several meetings on this topic.

[Roy Belson]: And it's our impression that while there are things to be done at every school, obviously you have to keep it up.

[Roy Belson]: The major issues will be going forward at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: High school is now the oldest major building in our possession.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things I told the school committee, so I feel comfortable sharing it here, is that in next year's budget, I will look to increase the amount of money put in for maintenance across the board so that we can do some of the things that people have raised independent of any capital planning and independent of any state-funded planning.

[Roy Belson]: We also have grants, as we've indicated before, that are also giving us money.

[Roy Belson]: For example, we got $100,000 or just under $100,000 in biosciences recently.

[Roy Belson]: We got a $500,000 grant in capital skills development from the state just the other day, a week ago Friday.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got some other grants out there they're looking for.

[Roy Belson]: There's about $600,000, $700,000 in technology funding that we are eligible for that we're putting together the proposed for.

[Roy Belson]: It's an entitlement as long as we meet certain requirements.

[Roy Belson]: So we're putting all of this together to come so that we can actually deal with issues with other people's money as much as possible, but certainly recognizing that not everything that we want to do will be eligible for funding by an outside agency.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: So let me give you a couple of examples.

[Roy Belson]: Anyone who's been up to high school, by the way, with a lot of, and with your help, by the way, and I appreciate that, a lot of capital projects have been done, and I could enumerate them

[Roy Belson]: You know, at some point, if you're interested, the council has approved money for them, so I appreciate that.

[Roy Belson]: But let's take the locker rooms at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: You've been up to the locker rooms at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: You know they're old, and you know that they're not particularly what we want them to be.

[Roy Belson]: The girls' locker room, it is what it is.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of old things in there.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of old marble, old shower stalls.

[Roy Belson]: It's a lot of empty space, unutilized space.

[Roy Belson]: That needs to be redone.

[Roy Belson]: Because if it's redone, we'll recapture some space for other programming, and we can provide a state-of-the-art locker room for the young women to use it.

[Roy Belson]: The same thing is true with the men's locker room.

[Roy Belson]: We need to do that.

[Roy Belson]: It's just these are the things that are there.

[Roy Belson]: When you talk about a performing arts center, that may be a little aspirational, you know, in regard because, you know, we're talking about having a program that promotes the theater arts and promotes media and the like, but I don't know that we need to go to 1,000 seats right now.

[Roy Belson]: So that may be a little bit aspirational, but the people doing the thinking raised it and said, you know, let's put it down and let's see if there's some interest in doing more with that.

[Roy Belson]: I think those are the kinds of cafeteria right now.

[Roy Belson]: There's three cafeterias.

[Roy Belson]: It may be that we can reconfigure them, especially since right now, as you undoubtedly have heard, maybe read in the transcript recently, we're redoing the Cafe Electra into a brand new hospitality and restaurant suite with state money.

[Roy Belson]: And that's critical because that's going to be up on the first floor.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to be a restaurant for the public.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to tie into our partnerships with WIN, which is creating the casino up the street and developing job opportunities.

[Roy Belson]: That's going to tie into a whole pile of activities and revenue generating activities that will support other programs.

[Roy Belson]: And that will free up space where Cafe Elector is now.

[Roy Belson]: And we can do some other things with that.

[Roy Belson]: So this is a whole process of looking at how we can reconfigure space to our greatest advantage.

[Roy Belson]: Now the print shop, because they don't use the big presses anymore, can now go down to a smaller place.

[Roy Belson]: We don't have to give them the big cavern that they had because they don't use that anymore.

[Roy Belson]: That's not what printing is about anymore.

[Roy Belson]: So Dr. Riccio, for example, has created what we'll call clusters or academies.

[Roy Belson]: putting programs together, human service programs together, construction programs together, programs that deal with media and development together, so that they can interact with each other.

[Roy Belson]: So that a youngster, when they're trained, is cross-trained for more than one area.

[Roy Belson]: That creates great opportunities for our young people.

[Roy Belson]: Instead of being trained only in one area, you're trained in multiple areas.

[Roy Belson]: You may have noticed that we've virtually recaptured all the students from Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: By next year, we'll have only eight students at Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have saved a million dollars a year on that alone by putting these programs together.

[Roy Belson]: By bringing some students in from the outside, we're recapturing revenue, possibly projecting over two or three years a million dollars a year in new revenue coming into it.

[Roy Belson]: This is going to help us weather the storm, whether it's federal cutbacks, state failure to pay, or some of the local issues, the priorities that we have.

[Roy Belson]: So these are ways that I think we're moving forward, and I believe that

[Roy Belson]: Looking at our school at 50 years of age and looking for another 50 years from that building is a really good time to start and be proactive now.

[Roy Belson]: Plan, recognizing we've got to come back to you.

[Roy Belson]: You're not voting for money tonight.

[Roy Belson]: You're voting for planning tonight.

[Roy Belson]: You're voting to be proactive, to look and see what's possible.

[Roy Belson]: And that's what we were asking you to do.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it's a great opportunity.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: If we become eligible, we would then petition MSBA for the feasibility, a feasibility study for the specific projects that we determined were the priority that we wanted to go with them for, or with, and they would reimburse us

[Roy Belson]: At the same rate, they would reimburse the construction.

[Roy Belson]: So if the feasibility study was $500,000 and we're eligible for 50%, we'd get $250,000 back.

[Roy Belson]: We lay it out, but they reimburse us.

[Roy Belson]: I'm all set.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: It gets us in the game, and it allows us to consider our options, which I think is really important.

[Roy Belson]: Earlier this evening I heard you talking, you want to consider options, well you want to know who's going to pay for what.

[Roy Belson]: And if you've got somebody else who wants to pay for it, or will help you pay for it, you want to know that before you put your own money on the table.

[Roy Belson]: 7-0.

[Roy Belson]: 7-0.

[Roy Belson]: That's correct.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: So I can't tell you that because basically we listed almost everything that we possibly could think of in the SOI.

[Roy Belson]: So it really depends on what the state determines would be eligible.

[Roy Belson]: I would say most of the things that we listed on that would be something we would discuss with them.

[Roy Belson]: There may be some things that they would say, that's your problem.

[Roy Belson]: You know, okay.

[Roy Belson]: They're all good questions.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Personally, I allowed the planning team at the high school to put down some of their aspirational things.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I don't personally think I need a 500-student cafeteria.

[Roy Belson]: Personally, I don't think that.

[Roy Belson]: But I wouldn't tell my people they can't ask for it and let somebody else tell them, we don't think we'd fund that, OK?

[Roy Belson]: So I don't think that's going to be something MSBA is going to be interested in, because I think they already know we have cafeterias.

[Roy Belson]: And they'd say, probably, why don't you just put a coat of paint on and do some other things?

[Roy Belson]: So I don't think that's an issue.

[Roy Belson]: Point of information.

[Roy Belson]: Again, as I said to you, the SOI is a planning document.

[Roy Belson]: It's to get you into an exploration process and to find out what the state is willing to pay for.

[Roy Belson]: So you put down everything to talk about,

[Roy Belson]: And you find out that they're going to discard a few things here and a few things there, and maybe several things, and say that's really not important enough to us.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll find out.

[Roy Belson]: The document that you had in front of you is really a document that was produced in September, or early on, based on what people thought at that particular time.

[Roy Belson]: Different things emerge.

[Roy Belson]: People want to talk about them.

[Roy Belson]: There are some ideas that the headmaster has, that the vocational director has, that, you know, we put it down so that we could explore them with the state.

[Roy Belson]: Not because we necessarily think that they're going to fund all these things.

[Roy Belson]: We want to get into an exploratory process to examine what is possible for partnership with state funding.

[Roy Belson]: And then we'll merge the documents.

[Roy Belson]: The key thing you have to remember is we have to come back to you for the money.

[Roy Belson]: And any amount that we're going to spend, you're going to prioritize along with the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: It's not going to be the superintendent who makes the final call.

[Roy Belson]: The superintendent might make a recommendation.

[Roy Belson]: But you're going to decide, and the mayor's going to decide, and the school committee's going to decide how much money you're willing to put on the table at any given point in time.

[Roy Belson]: But knowing what's eligible gives you a leg up on what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: And as far as the percentage goes, I know what other people are getting at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: I know what the relative things are.

[Roy Belson]: The state's not going to commit to something before they see it.

[Roy Belson]: I know we fall in that basic line of where we would be eligible, because I know what the economics are between the different communities.

[Roy Belson]: It doesn't mean that it won't go down a little bit, because obviously the wealth of the community is increasing.

[Roy Belson]: I hear what you're saying, but I'm

[Roy Belson]: My experience tells me in meeting, because I've had these meetings before.

[Roy Belson]: As you know, we've had science labs.

[Roy Belson]: We've built new buildings and so on.

[Roy Belson]: My experience tells me that when we sit down with them, we'll focus in on the things that are high priority first.

[Roy Belson]: And then we'll look at whether any of these other things are possible.

[Roy Belson]: But they know the difference between a firearm system and a roof and a cafeteria.

[Roy Belson]: They know the difference.

[Roy Belson]: And they know where we would like to go first.

[Roy Belson]: This is an attempt to give everybody, every stakeholder,

[Roy Belson]: who was involved in the planning process of putting an SOI together, a chance to be heard, rather than say your idea is not worth being explored with the state.

[Roy Belson]: We're giving them a chance to be heard.

[Roy Belson]: But you know and I know that the state will zero in on firearms and roofs and heating systems long before they worry about the cafeteria.

[Roy Belson]: No, you sit down and you go over and they'll tell you what they would consider to be priorities, what they would consider to be something that they would consider to be of concern to them, what they would like to fund.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, after all, they're accountable to their funding agency and their board as well.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that they'd be more interested in a fire alarm system, a roof, heating systems, more so than some of the other things.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, we're giving them all these things, and they might say, you know, we're doing something with this.

[Roy Belson]: Who knew a few years ago that they were going to be funding science labs?

[Roy Belson]: But we put it in front of them, and we got it.

[Roy Belson]: You know, you have to try all these things.

[Roy Belson]: You put it in front of them.

[Roy Belson]: You say, are you interested in this?

[Roy Belson]: Could you consider this to be a reasonable investment?

[Roy Belson]: Maybe someone's going to say, yes, you know, we've got an interest in this at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: So we're moving forward with a planning process.

[Roy Belson]: That's all we're doing tonight, asking you to allow us to go forward proactively and find out what the state wants to prioritize in our community.

[Roy Belson]: And this is going to take probably two to three years to actually actualize.

[Roy Belson]: In the meantime, that will inform, you know, our other capital planning that may have to be locally funded.

[Roy Belson]: And we will form also our maintenance issues, which will be locally funded.

[Roy Belson]: So, and then grant applications we make.

[Roy Belson]: If someone were to say we can't get grants for this, you know, for example, we built the, we're building the Culinary Arts and Hospitality Center.

[Roy Belson]: That wasn't gonna be funded by MSBA.

[Roy Belson]: But we got a grant to do it.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to know where we have to go.

[Roy Belson]: We have to know what's possible under what set of funding and what's possible under other sets of funding.

[Roy Belson]: And then we can then lay it out.

[Roy Belson]: And of course, we're going to have to work with you and the school committee for any kind of local money that's going to be needed to move the project forward.

[Roy Belson]: This isn't you say yes tonight, and I go off and do whatever I want.

[Roy Belson]: This is you say yes tonight, we get the process going, and then we come back to you and sit down.

[Roy Belson]: And it should be a robust process, because the city wants to move forward on some good projects, not only in the schools, but in the city.

[Roy Belson]: And we look forward to that.

[Roy Belson]: No, because I don't know, you know,

[Roy Belson]: the extent to which any of these things would be funded.

[Roy Belson]: What is the actual cost of your SOI request?

[Roy Belson]: You know, I wouldn't want to, you know, give you a guess right now, because quite frankly, it depends on the extent to which you do them.

[Roy Belson]: You know, and any one of these things might be a partial thing, maybe some windows, maybe some doors, and maybe not all, maybe all doors.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think we, you know, we can do that right now.

[Roy Belson]: When we get back from a planning process,

[Roy Belson]: and we get to a financial phase, then we can do that.

[Roy Belson]: That's the most prudent way to do it, not to throw speculative numbers out there right now.

[Roy Belson]: And if people come and say, look, that's too much at any one time, then that'll be too much at any one time.

[Roy Belson]: I'd be prepared to come back to you to tell you what your options are and to allow you to decide what the finances of this city is willing to support in support of your public schools.

[Roy Belson]: That's all, just like anything else.

[Roy Belson]: We come to you with a budget.

[Roy Belson]: We come to you with other kinds of financial things.

[Roy Belson]: You can tell us how much more you want to put into it.

[Roy Belson]: But you know, for example, in five or six years, you're going to replace a roof at the high school.

[Roy Belson]: You are going to do it.

[Roy Belson]: The question is, who's going to pay for it?

[Roy Belson]: But if we are eligible to get somebody to share that with us, why not find out now?

[Roy Belson]: You know that there are some heating things that we want to do at the high school that we should do.

[Roy Belson]: If you don't do them in the next few years, you'll end up paying for it.

[Roy Belson]: So we should find out if we have a partner.

[Roy Belson]: And so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: We know that technology is moving at a rapid rate.

[Roy Belson]: And if we know that it's going to be expensive to increase all the technology that's going to be required of public schools,

[Roy Belson]: So if someone's willing to partner with us, great.

[Roy Belson]: You'll know that.

[Roy Belson]: That gives you those things.

[Roy Belson]: But you can decide that, you know, I'm not interested in a performing arts center, and I'm not interested in an expanded cafeteria, and I don't really care about some other things you're interested in.

[Roy Belson]: So even though someone's willing to partner with us, it's off the table for Medford because we have other things we want to do.

[Roy Belson]: My job is to give you options.

[Roy Belson]: My job is to give you an opportunity to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: Well, what I'm telling you is I'm telling you it'll take two to three years to get through the process to actually get

[Roy Belson]: construction going on something, any project that gets approved and the like.

[Roy Belson]: But we won't even get to design feasibility and design until we come back here and talk about what the state is interested in.

[Roy Belson]: And in the feasibility period, that's when you will make some decisions before we actually go forward with a final number.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, the reality is that some things will be done over five years, some things may be done over 10 years.

[Roy Belson]: The reality is to find out what we can get some funding for and what we can get support for.

[Roy Belson]: And we're at such an early stage.

[Roy Belson]: I know that.

[Roy Belson]: And quite frankly, look, you get hit with a lot of decisions that require you to make tough decisions on money.

[Roy Belson]: on policies, on zoning, on any number of issues.

[Roy Belson]: You can't hide from, not that you want to, from making tough decisions that make some people happy and some people less happy.

[Roy Belson]: I said I respected the right of the planning team to forward things

[Roy Belson]: that I consider to be, that they consider to be important to them, because I want to respect my administrative team and the teachers and others who participate.

[Roy Belson]: You're the educational leader of this community, Mr. Superintendent, and sometimes you have to make the tough decisions.

[Roy Belson]: And I like the participation of people.

[Roy Belson]: I don't have to make all the decisions myself.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is that nothing is going to go forward financially unless you decide you can afford it.

[Roy Belson]: Nothing's going to go forward.

[Roy Belson]: We're trying to explore who wants to partner with us.

[Roy Belson]: And you know that the most important things will be systems that are important to the school.

[Roy Belson]: The operation of the building will get higher priority than some of the things that maybe are aspirational.

[Roy Belson]: You know that.

[Roy Belson]: So if you decide that certain things aren't something you want to fund, then you say, well, put that off for a couple of years.

[Roy Belson]: But certainly, you're going to face a roof.

[Roy Belson]: Certainly, you're going to face technology.

[Roy Belson]: Certainly, you're going to deal with other systems, heating systems and other things like that.

[Roy Belson]: And if we don't get in the game now, it'll be longer.

[Roy Belson]: before we get funding, and if we don't, and if the funding dries up because of the Commonwealth not being able to keep things moving, you see the green line, other things like that, we talk about these things, and it keeps getting pushed off, keeps getting pushed off.

[Roy Belson]: Let's get in the game, and then you can decide whether or not it's something you desire as a priority.

[Roy Belson]: That's what we need to look at.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's my job to put it in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: I hope it's your job to, or I hope it's your willingness to let me find out what's possible going forward.

[Roy Belson]: I would agree that restrooms are something that should be addressed, yes.

[Roy Belson]: How come they're not part of the SOI?

[Roy Belson]: Because they're part of the general building envelope.

[Roy Belson]: That's something that we can talk about.

[Roy Belson]: They're part of the plumbing.

[Roy Belson]: They're part of the heating system, believe it or not.

[Roy Belson]: It's all part of the same consideration.

[Roy Belson]: And just because something isn't written here doesn't mean we can't talk about it with the team that comes out from MSBA.

[Roy Belson]: We can talk stuff, yes.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe they'll let us add, maybe they won't.

[Roy Belson]: I guess I'm a stakeholder.

[Roy Belson]: That would be my addition.

[Roy Belson]: I certainly would bring that up in any kind of discussion, but I can tell you that I don't share your full assessment of our bathroom facilities.

[Roy Belson]: There may be a few that need some additional work, but there's a lot of them that work very well.

[Roy Belson]: They're in good shape and are being cleaned on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: So we can go back and forth on that.

[Roy Belson]: would meet to talk about that.

[Roy Belson]: I certainly have no problem with any of that.

[Roy Belson]: I think, you know, look, let's not kid ourselves.

[Roy Belson]: into the state with this so we can continue to move and get them to come out to us sooner rather than later.

[Roy Belson]: By rule, with the Department of Ed, we have to make allowance for five days, but we actually have another seven days if we needed it.

[Roy Belson]: So we really have 12 days available to us, not counting if we were to reclaim a professional day.

[Roy Belson]: So remember, if the last day with five days is the 20th of June, you still got to the 30th of June if we actually needed it.

[Roy Belson]: So we've really built in quite a bit of protection.

[Roy Belson]: We can put a one-liner in the notice out there.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, we should do five.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor, members of the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: You know, on February 22nd, 2017, the federal government, using an executive order from the president, rescinded guidance and determined that Title IX's prohibition on gender identity discrimination was null and void.

[Roy Belson]: The president took the position that the protection of transgender rights should be left to each state.

[Roy Belson]: Massachusetts law already protects the rights of transgender students in schools.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 199 of the Acts of 2011 went into effect in July 2012.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford School Committee approved a local policy affirming the Massachusetts law on April 11, 2016.

[Roy Belson]: We had taken a previous position on the 13th in 2013, but we updated in 2016.

[Roy Belson]: In your packet, you have information from

[Roy Belson]: Mike Long, who is the legal counsel to the Massachusetts Association of School Committees.

[Roy Belson]: You have guidance from the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.

[Roy Belson]: You have your own policy, the Medford Public Schools Policy, that was adopted in 2016.

[Roy Belson]: You have some guidance from the MTA, the Largest Teachers Union, and you have a copy of the bills that were enacted.

[Roy Belson]: Clearly, in Medford,

[Roy Belson]: And clearly, throughout Massachusetts, transgender rights are protected.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes federal laws supersede, but not in this instance.

[Roy Belson]: Because in this instance, the executive order said, let the states decide.

[Roy Belson]: In this instance, the state has decided, and we have an active plan in place

[Roy Belson]: And at this point, we have really no problems with what we've done and what we're doing in our schools.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to bring you up to date on that.

[Roy Belson]: I would like to, if I can, Mayor, also comment on the immigration rules, because I believe that's also tied to equal access to education, which is part of the same vein of thinking as the transgender rule.

[Roy Belson]: I've given you an advisory from Mara Healy, the Massachusetts Attorney General, on equal access to public education for all students, irrespective of immigration status.

[Roy Belson]: In Massachusetts, the Supreme Court of the United States recognized Brown versus Board of Education, and it is true today as it was back in 1953.

[Roy Belson]: The advisory that the Attorney General has provided you is very, very clear.

[Roy Belson]: There has been a case in Massachusetts, Filer v. Doe, in 1982, where the Supreme Court held that public elementary and secondary schools may not deny any child residing in the applicable jurisdiction access to public education, whether the child is present in the country legally or not.

[Roy Belson]: Filer made it clear that a child's immigration or citizenship status, or that his or her parents are guarding, is not relevant to the child's right to a public education.

[Roy Belson]: So, irrespective of any rulings that come down, Massachusetts law, states rights,

[Roy Belson]: made the decision that we will accept anyone who resides in our community.

[Roy Belson]: We will not ask them what their status is, visa or otherwise.

[Roy Belson]: We will not pursue anything other than the fact they are not living in the community.

[Roy Belson]: If they're not living in the community, it's a residence issue.

[Roy Belson]: But if they're living in the community, whether they're living with their parents or they're residing with some other responsible adult,

[Roy Belson]: we will provide them free and public access to our educational system.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to clarify that I am not allowed to ask what a person's visa status is.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not allowed to ask what their immigrant status is.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not allowed to ask for some of these things.

[Roy Belson]: And in fact, in some instances, there are people that are homeless, and I might have to accept that just simply based on homelessness.

[Roy Belson]: We just had a webinar today on homelessness that dealt with foster children.

[Roy Belson]: More guidance is coming out on that.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to make it clear that we're an equal opportunity school system, whether it's transgender or immigrant status.

[Roy Belson]: If a youngster resides in our community, they're entitled to free access to our public education system, and that's the way we will treat them.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: An automated defibrillator, or an AED, is a medical device that will analyze heart rhythms and can deliver electric shocks to help a heart reestablish an effective rhythm during a sudden cardiac arrest.

[Roy Belson]: The American Red Cross recommends that AEDs be readily available and applied within four minutes of cardiac arrest.

[Roy Belson]: Now, under this law,

[Roy Belson]: We have to have trained people on staff.

[Roy Belson]: We do.

[Roy Belson]: We have nurses, we've trained our coaches, and we'll train even more people to use these items.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight, we will have a moment of silence from somebody who could have used one.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, this is important.

[Roy Belson]: It's good to know that we're ahead of the curve.

[Roy Belson]: We have them in every school.

[Roy Belson]: We'll review them to see whether or not we should be adding.

[Roy Belson]: We have had good fortune working with our ambulance providers and others who have donated equipment to us.

[Roy Belson]: They get checked every day for battery effectiveness, and we have to keep that up because you never know when the equipment's there, but the battery doesn't operate, so you have to check this on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: And we have to continuously train people.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to make sure you're aware that we're in compliance with this law well in advance of its implementation.

[Roy Belson]: But there's obviously more work that we will do to make this a more efficient and effective system for utilization should it be necessary.

[Roy Belson]: It will be brought by coaches and trainers.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have them available on the fields.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's important to recognize that I don't want people who are afraid to use this thing to use it.

[Roy Belson]: I want people only who are comfortable using it to use it.

[Roy Belson]: There are some people who... Who are certified.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, and certified.

[Roy Belson]: You know, there are some people who would be very uncomfortable taking this device off the wall and using it.

[Roy Belson]: Every building will have people, and we can provide you with a list of who's trying to use it.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to be careful that we have sufficient numbers, but that we don't put people in situations of doing things that we're uncomfortable doing.

[Roy Belson]: It's very different than an EpiPen.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of people can use an EpiPen very effectively.

[Roy Belson]: I understand what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to make it clear that this isn't one of those things like CPR that everyone is going to be trained in.

[Roy Belson]: It's something that you really want to make sure that the four or five people in the building who are the go-to people are the people that are really comfortable using a device like this.

[Roy Belson]: This is a very sophisticated device.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know that, but I will check that.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know that, but I'm told by Tony Vento that they check them every day and that's their, one of their responsibilities.

[Roy Belson]: Now,

[Roy Belson]: Could it be that one day went by when they didn't entirely possible, but we will certainly reinforce that.

[Roy Belson]: But I want to make sure that, you know, the people that use this know what they're doing, but we'll provide that.

[Roy Belson]: Four minutes is the guideline from the point of which the heart stops.

[Roy Belson]: It's not for the person starting to feel chest pain or starting to feel dizzy or things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: So it's tricky.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, obviously, you know, we have a 500,000 square foot high school.

[Roy Belson]: You know what I mean?

[Roy Belson]: And things can happen anywhere.

[Roy Belson]: But obviously, you know, our goal is to get people to the scene as quickly as possible.

[Roy Belson]: Same thing with CPR.

[Roy Belson]: Same thing with any other.

[Roy Belson]: with EpiPens, anything that requires a medical intervention to get them there as quickly as possible.

[Roy Belson]: I'll go over it with Tony and with other people and see exactly if we can give you more specifics as to how they would respond.

[Roy Belson]: I'll sit with Tony, and let's go over a list of people who are more likely to be available and capable.

[Roy Belson]: And then we'll approach them and try to add to the list.

[Roy Belson]: But it's unlikely that we're going to be able to get every person in every corner, nor should we try, because I think inappropriate application is more dangerous than none at all.

[Roy Belson]: You asked for a report that broke it out by actual classes.

[Roy Belson]: You have that report in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: It was appended to the previous report.

[Roy Belson]: It shows you what each teacher has as of the same date that the previous report was provided.

[Roy Belson]: I'm happy to take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: If a youngster comes from a substantially separated class, they come with the teachers or the staff that's with them.

[Roy Belson]: So these numbers could, during the day... A number could increase mostly for gym or for some of the larger

[Roy Belson]: activities, but certainly not for classes that are substantially contained.

[Roy Belson]: Although occasionally a youngster may try, they may try to put a youngster in a class.

[Roy Belson]: The other thing you got to keep in mind is on any given day, you know, with not to say that we encourage this, but any given day, a hundred percent of the pupils aren't always in attendance.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have 20 youngsters in the class, you might have 18 on a given day, you know, on that day and then another day you might have all 20.

[Roy Belson]: So it just depends on who's there on any given day as well.

[Roy Belson]: So just so we have one understanding that we have to have all the time, I never send anything to the civil city council like this until you get it first.

[Roy Belson]: Right?

[Roy Belson]: So,

[Roy Belson]: It may be a little bit of a wait sometimes when they ask for something like this, but you always get it first before they get it.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: And then we send it through the council just so you understand the process.

[Roy Belson]: So this policy was in front of you earlier and we took it back to review it to make sure there were no situations that we were missing using current, you know, let's say legal opinions that were out there.

[Roy Belson]: We vetted it at this time.

[Roy Belson]: We believe that this is ready to go.

[Roy Belson]: So I recommend that you approve it.

[Roy Belson]: There will be.

[Roy Belson]: When a person gets in the States, they sign off on the

[Roy Belson]: If you look on the cover page, all users must sign off on the reasonable use policy each year.

[Roy Belson]: then we'll work on distribution.

[Roy Belson]: The unions to come in and work with us until they're ready.

[Roy Belson]: We can't, I can't, we should expect something very soon.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm just going to answer what I answered before until the hall straightens out the accounts.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not going to give you a report where commingled money is, it can't be,

[Roy Belson]: can't be separated out so I can actually give you an accurate report.

[Roy Belson]: They're working on it.

[Roy Belson]: We have major changes in the financial administration of the city and major change in the financial administration of the schools, and they're working on that right now.

[Roy Belson]: I would hope to have it soon, but as late as last week, I'm down there talking to the people in the city hall trying to get that broken out so we can give you an accurate report.

[Roy Belson]: The good news is that we're not in jeopardy of anything financial.

[Roy Belson]: The bad news is, what do you call it, I'm still trying to get this separated out so that you can see each account very cleanly as opposed to having four or five accounts somehow consolidated together which doesn't give you a real picture.

[Roy Belson]: Soon as it, as soon as I get the numbers, the way they should be given to me, I will be happy to give you the report and I hope it's soon.

[Roy Belson]: So as we get into this time of year, people ask the question frequently,

[Roy Belson]: When will school start?

[Roy Belson]: When will be the vacation periods and the like?

[Roy Belson]: This is a draft that requires your approval.

[Roy Belson]: I'm gonna call on our deputy superintendent to go over the particulars and to tell you why we picked certain dates the way we did.

[Roy Belson]: So let me just answer that.

[Roy Belson]: By rule, with the Department of Ed, we have to make

[Roy Belson]: allowance for five days, but we actually have another seven days if we needed it.

[Roy Belson]: So we really have 12 days available to us, not counting if we were to reclaim a professional day.

[Roy Belson]: So remember, if the last day with five days is the 20th of June, you still got to the 30th of June if we actually needed it.

[Roy Belson]: So we've really built in quite a bit of protection.

[Roy Belson]: We can put a one-liner in the notice out there.

[Roy Belson]: We should do five.

[Roy Belson]: We built in probably 11 days.

[Roy Belson]: We can put a statement and should, you know, we require more days because of snow or other inclement weather or other reasons.

[Roy Belson]: So our deputy superintendent, our assistant superintendent have led the charge in putting this program together.

[Roy Belson]: It's done with a great deal of input from the teachers and others, and it's a lot of work involved.

[Roy Belson]: So congratulations to both of them putting together a very interesting day and let them tell you about it.

[Roy Belson]: very, very good progress in most instances using school brains to report out.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I think any program can be moved.

[Roy Belson]: So the Andrews uses things like Study Island and other things like that.

[Roy Belson]: So we want to give principals some degree of autonomy to make decisions that they believe are in the best interest.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll check into it.

[Roy Belson]: We'll get back.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor, members of the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: You know, on February 22nd, 2017, the federal government, using an executive order from the president, rescinded guidance and determined that Title IX's prohibition on gender identity discrimination was null and void.

[Roy Belson]: The president took the position that the protection of transgender rights should be left to each state.

[Roy Belson]: Massachusetts law already protects the rights of transgender students in schools.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 199 of the Acts of 2011 went into effect in July 2012.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford School Committee approved a local policy affirming the Massachusetts law on April 11, 2016.

[Roy Belson]: We had taken a previous position on the 13th in 2013, but we updated in 2016.

[Roy Belson]: In your packet, you have information from

[Roy Belson]: Mike Long, who is the legal counsel to the Massachusetts Association of School Committees.

[Roy Belson]: You have guidance from the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.

[Roy Belson]: You have your own policy, the Medford Public Schools policy that was adopted in 2016.

[Roy Belson]: You have some guidance from the MTA, the Largest Teachers Union, and you have a copy of the bills that were enacted.

[Roy Belson]: Clearly, in Medford,

[Roy Belson]: And clearly, throughout Massachusetts, transgender rights are protected.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes federal laws supersede, but not in this instance.

[Roy Belson]: Because in this instance, the executive order said, let the states decide.

[Roy Belson]: In this instance, the state has decided.

[Roy Belson]: And we have an active plan in place.

[Roy Belson]: And at this point, we have really no problems with what we've done.

[Roy Belson]: and what we're doing in our schools.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to bring you up to date on that.

[Roy Belson]: I would like to, if I can, Mayor, also comment on the immigration rules, because I believe that's also tied to equal access to education, which is part of the same vein of thinking as the transgender rule.

[Roy Belson]: I've given you an advisory from Mara Healy, the Massachusetts Attorney General,

[Roy Belson]: on equal access to public education for all students, irrespective of immigration status.

[Roy Belson]: In Massachusetts, the Supreme Court of the United States recognized Brown versus Board of Education, and it is true today as it was back in 1953.

[Roy Belson]: The advisory that the Attorney General has provided you is very, very clear.

[Roy Belson]: There has been a case in Massachusetts, Filer v. Doe, in 1982, where the Supreme Court held that public elementary and secondary schools may not deny any child residing in the applicable jurisdiction access to public education, whether the child is present in the country legally or not.

[Roy Belson]: Filer made it clear that a child's immigration or citizenship status, or that his or her parents

[Roy Belson]: Our guardian is not relevant to the child's right to a public education.

[Roy Belson]: So irrespective of any rulings that come down, Massachusetts law, states rights, made the decision that we will accept anyone who resides in our community.

[Roy Belson]: We will not ask them what their status is, visa or otherwise.

[Roy Belson]: We will not pursue anything other than the fact they are not living in the community.

[Roy Belson]: If they're not living in the community, it's a residence issue.

[Roy Belson]: But if they're living in the community, whether they're living with their parents or they're residing with some other responsible adult, we will provide them free and public access to our educational system.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to clarify that I am not allowed to ask what a person's visa status is.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not allowed to ask what their immigrant status is.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not allowed to ask for some of these things.

[Roy Belson]: And in fact,

[Roy Belson]: In some instances, there are people that are homeless, and I might have to accept that just simply based on homelessness.

[Roy Belson]: We just had a webinar today on homelessness that dealt with foster children.

[Roy Belson]: More guidance is coming out on that.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to make it clear that we're an equal opportunity school system, whether it's transgender or immigrant status.

[Roy Belson]: If a youngster resides in our community, they are entitled to free access to our public education system, and that's the way we will treat them.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: So effective July 1, 2018, all schools must have automated external defibrillators on site.

[Roy Belson]: The good news is we have them in every one of our schools.

[Roy Belson]: An automated defibrillator, or an AED, is a medical device that will analyze heart rhythms and can deliver electric shocks to help a heart reestablish an effective rhythm during a sudden cardiac arrest.

[Roy Belson]: The American Red Cross recommends that AEDs be readily available and applied within four minutes of cardiac arrest.

[Roy Belson]: Now, under this law,

[Roy Belson]: We have to have trained people on staff.

[Roy Belson]: We do.

[Roy Belson]: We have nurses, we've trained our coaches, and we'll train even more people to use these items.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight, we will have a moment of silence from somebody who could have used one.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, this is important.

[Roy Belson]: It's good to know that we're ahead of the curve.

[Roy Belson]: We have them in every school.

[Roy Belson]: We'll review them to see whether or not we should be adding.

[Roy Belson]: We have had good fortune working with our ambulance providers and others who have donated equipment to us.

[Roy Belson]: They get checked every day for battery effectiveness.

[Roy Belson]: And we have to keep that up because you never know when the equipment's there, but the battery doesn't operate.

[Roy Belson]: So you have to check this on a regular basis and we have to continuously train people.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to make sure you're aware that we're in compliance with this law well in advance of its implementation, but there's obviously more work that we will do.

[Roy Belson]: to make this a more efficient and effective, uh, system for utilization.

[Roy Belson]: Should it be necessary?

[Roy Belson]: It will be brought by coaches and trainers.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have them available on the fields.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's important to recognize that I don't want people who are afraid to use this thing to use it.

[Roy Belson]: I want people only who are comfortable using it to use it.

[Roy Belson]: There are some people who- Who are certified.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, and certified.

[Roy Belson]: There are some people who would be very uncomfortable taking this device off the wall and using it.

[Roy Belson]: Every building will have people, and we can provide you with a list of who's trying to use it.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to be careful that we have sufficient numbers, but that we don't put people in situations of doing things they're uncomfortable doing.

[Roy Belson]: It's very different than an EpiPen.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of people can use an EpiPen very effectively.

[Roy Belson]: I understand what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to make it clear that this isn't one of those things like CPR that everyone is going to be trained in.

[Roy Belson]: It's something that you really want to make sure that the four or five people in the building who are the go-to people are the people that are really comfortable using a device like this.

[Roy Belson]: This is a very sophisticated device.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know that, but I will check that.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know that, but I'm told by Tony Vento that they check them every day and that's their, one of their responsibilities.

[Roy Belson]: Now,

[Roy Belson]: Could it be that one day went by when they didn't entirely possible, but we will certainly reinforce that.

[Roy Belson]: But I want to make sure that, you know, the people that use this know what they're doing, but we'll provide that.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, again, four minutes is the

[Roy Belson]: guideline from the point of which the heart stops.

[Roy Belson]: It's not when a person's starting to feel chest pain, or starting to feel dizzy, or things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: So it's tricky.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, obviously, we have a 500,000 square foot high school.

[Roy Belson]: And things can happen anywhere.

[Roy Belson]: But obviously, our goal is to get people to the scene as quickly as possible.

[Roy Belson]: Same thing with CPR, same thing with any other, with EpiPens, anything that requires a medical intervention

[Roy Belson]: to get them there as quickly as possible.

[Roy Belson]: I'll go over it with Tony and with other people and see exactly if we can give you more specifics as to how they would respond.

[Roy Belson]: I'll sit with Tony, and let's go over a list of people who are more likely to be available and capable, and then we'll approach them and try to add to the list.

[Roy Belson]: It's unlikely that we're going to be able to get every person in every corner, nor should we try, because I think inappropriate application is more dangerous than none at all.

[Roy Belson]: You asked for a report that broke it out by actual classes.

[Roy Belson]: You have that report in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: It was appended to the previous report.

[Roy Belson]: It shows you what each teacher has as of the same date that the previous report was provided.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: If a youngster comes from a substantially separated class, they come with the teachers or the staff that's with them.

[Roy Belson]: So these numbers could, during the day... The number could increase mostly for gym or for some of the larger

[Roy Belson]: activities, but certainly not for classes that are substantially contained.

[Roy Belson]: Occasionally a youngster may try.

[Roy Belson]: They may try to put a youngster in the class.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: The other thing you got to keep in mind is on a given day, you know, with not to say that we encourage this, but any given day, a hundred percent of the pupils aren't always in attendance.

[Roy Belson]: So if you have 20 youngsters in a class, you might have 18 on a given day, you know, on that day and then another day you might have all 20.

[Roy Belson]: You know, I think that, you know, different field trips are going to cost different things anyway.

[Roy Belson]: The cost of Disney for the band is going to be one cost and the cost of Disney for the science trip is going to be another cost regardless.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, again, it's your call and, you know, whatever wisdom you want to have us follow, we will.

[Roy Belson]: Another factor is that

[Roy Belson]: We generally don't know the enrollment of the trip until we get pretty close to the event, because youngsters may change their mind, may not make the commitment.

[Roy Belson]: And depending on when the trip is coming and when the cutoff date is, it may be a month before, a couple of months before, whatever it is, or it may be six months before.

[Roy Belson]: So we may not know who's on the trip until we actually put the final enrollment on it.

[Roy Belson]: It's a choice you make when you budget as to which things you'll fund.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: That's a priority.

[Roy Belson]: When you fund certain student activities and not others, you've made a choice.

[Roy Belson]: So this is a choice you can make.

[Roy Belson]: You know, we had this discussion last year.

[Roy Belson]: You know, some people will take the insurance, and some people will not take the insurance.

[Roy Belson]: Individually, all of us have flown on an airplane, and sometimes we've taken insurance, and sometimes we've not taken insurance to cover the cost of a trip that might have to change because of circumstances.

[Roy Belson]: So as another example, there are variables built into all of these things.

[Roy Belson]: Some trips, you know, individuals will ask for other things that others don't need.

[Roy Belson]: We can do that.

[Roy Belson]: The A building area has had ongoing issues for a long period of time.

[Roy Belson]: And we went in there to diagnostically try to fix a few things, and we found that every time we fixed something, it got a little worse and a little bit worse.

[Roy Belson]: So we decided to go in there and really just do a good job and try to clean it up.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, it isn't a big urgency thing, but it's an expense.

[Roy Belson]: It's the kind of thing we can fix.

[Roy Belson]: It requires things, I think, going forward.

[Roy Belson]: It should be part of the capital plan thinking as we go, but it's definitely an item that

[Roy Belson]: you know, taking a few dollars out of our repair budget this year.

[Roy Belson]: Well, it's repaired at this point in time, but you know, I think we may spring another leap.

[Roy Belson]: Who knows, as the winter season's coming, it's very hard to know, you know, whether that's going to happen, but we've repaired it to the point that we need to right now.

[Roy Belson]: No.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I'm not sure, you know, everything has an exact dollar amount yet because there's still some work going on, but I think we're in excess of $25,000 at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: And that how much more we have to spend will depend on what actually takes place.

[Roy Belson]: What I said a few moments ago, I think is accurate, is that we're now doing an assessment to determine, you know, how much of this needs to go into a full capital plan.

[Roy Belson]: We think that a building is an area that probably is going to need a lot of attention because, I don't know if you know the piping structure, but you know the flooring is terrazzo tile?

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: You've got to go into the terrazzo tile and go down under into the tunnel.

[Roy Belson]: That alone is an expense, and that alone is a major activity, and then go down and in.

[Roy Belson]: To replace that piping is almost like ripping up a straight Winthrop street, taking out the thing, and then putting a pipe in.

[Roy Belson]: So I think in the long run, going into the capital plan, we're going to want to replace those pipes, because I think they're going to keep happening from now on.

[Roy Belson]: I think that's the way we're going to look at it.

[Roy Belson]: I think we're making this as more of a capital look.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I think the capital plan will start to roll out in the next couple of months.

[Roy Belson]: There could be.

[Roy Belson]: We're in January.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: And on a given day, you could walk in and, you know, we could have another pipeline.

[Roy Belson]: We did last year, for example, you remember up in B building, in the second floor, there were several pipes that broke.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: part of the structure of that building where some of the stuff is a little bit older.

[Roy Belson]: Which room is it, do you know?

[Roy Belson]: Well, so let me just answer it.

[Roy Belson]: But until, what do you call it, the money is moved properly, you know, I can't give you a reconciliation against the city's chart of accounts.

[Roy Belson]: So, we'll do that, and if necessary, we'll provide you our report, you know, with a disclaimer at the end of it.

[Roy Belson]: Right now, you know, there's stuff that's still moving.
