[Roy Belson]: So there are still some people who do not go online and give us checks.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, they walk in the door and they want to go swimming, and they give us a check or something like that.

[Roy Belson]: But for the most part, most people are using the online system.

[Roy Belson]: But there are some, as far as vendors go, they're using an online system with us.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is that some people still walk in the door and hand us a check.

[Roy Belson]: Primarily, that's the middle school bus in the afternoon.

[Roy Belson]: No, the two or three days that you've asked for.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: you anticipate a cost, you put that amount in there to say that that money is pretty much committed.

[Roy Belson]: And as you pay it down, you liquidate the amount that's been paid out so that the encumbrance decreases.

[Roy Belson]: But sometimes the liquidation is slower than the actual expenditure.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sorry.

[Roy Belson]: item out of order.

[Roy Belson]: So there are a couple of things we've just got to keep in mind.

[Roy Belson]: First of all, we have to stay compliant with the fact the federal government will give us a certain amount of money per student on free and reduced.

[Roy Belson]: If we ask our paid students to pay less,

[Roy Belson]: federal government's comeback is that we are subsidizing students who are not eligible for a free or reduced meal.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to at least meet that in order to stay in compliance, because otherwise the government's saying, well, we're paying you for students who can afford to pay for it.

[Roy Belson]: That's one piece.

[Roy Belson]: The second piece that we've got to keep in mind is that the U.S.

[Roy Belson]: Department of Agriculture has got a new administration in Washington.

[Roy Belson]: Recent signals are they're looking to make cuts in agencies like USDA.

[Roy Belson]: If they're making cuts in USDA, that could reduce the subsidies coming back to states, could reduce the commodities and the like, and we could get through the back door for less availabilities to us.

[Roy Belson]: So we've got to keep that in mind too.

[Roy Belson]: And three, we are in the process, we've had some discussions about negotiating with our cafeteria workers and what we've planned for them.

[Roy Belson]: modest as it is, will impact this as well.

[Roy Belson]: And if we don't plan for that, we will drive our program off the, you know, off the balance sheet.

[Roy Belson]: So there's several things going on and you know, no one likes to see price increases, but on the other hand, we're trying to be realistic.

[Roy Belson]: 30, 36, 36 times five is 180 days.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, we're not against you taking action tonight.

[Roy Belson]: We think it's real.

[Roy Belson]: But if you need more time to think about it.

[Roy Belson]: We can certainly do it.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, you know, I think it's, it's always informative to learn about all the things going on, but from a financial standpoint, this report was developed in conjunction with them.

[Roy Belson]: I'm just learning about nutrition and learning about what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: Sure.

[Roy Belson]: We can always send it.

[Roy Belson]: It's been a long time.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Superintendent calling upon our assistant superintendent to deliver this report.

[Roy Belson]: Cost analysis.

[Roy Belson]: We'll put that as part of the budget.

[Roy Belson]: It could be some efficiencies.

[Roy Belson]: Just to give you a little quick update on this because the governor will be speaking tomorrow night And there will be releases of the state budget His proposed budget and then the process will begin and so just to keep you informed as to what goes on because this is a

[Roy Belson]: What happens at the state level obviously impacts us.

[Roy Belson]: So the governor is going to be speaking tomorrow night.

[Roy Belson]: Somewhere in the next little while, you will get some more details on that presentation.

[Roy Belson]: But on January 13th, the Senate, the House, and the governor agreed on a revenue distribution, which is 3.9%, or approximately $1.02 billion more into next year from

[Roy Belson]: taxation and other revenues from the state.

[Roy Belson]: This is what we call a consensus budget guideline to help them produce budgets in each chamber.

[Roy Belson]: The thing you have to understand is that you can project 3.9% increase.

[Roy Belson]: Last year they projected 4.3.

[Roy Belson]: But to get to that number, they probably have to increase the revenue by even more.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll guess that to about 5.5%.

[Roy Belson]: something along that kind of line, because there are tax cuts.

[Roy Belson]: There are other things that are one-time revenues that we used that won't be used again.

[Roy Belson]: So even though they project that, they're now going to have to resolve what they've lost from revenue from the previous year or what they will lose with programs that maybe need more money.

[Roy Belson]: So in our budget, for example, as salaries go up, you know, that factors into the increase in what we need to come up with.

[Roy Belson]: It's not just revenue.

[Roy Belson]: So there are at least six major factors you need to pay attention to going through.

[Roy Belson]: One is how much money the FY 2017 budget was dependent upon as temporary and one-time revenues that won't be available in fiscal 2018.

[Roy Belson]: How much temporary money did they use?

[Roy Belson]: Two, what accounts were underfunded in 2017?

[Roy Belson]: Things that they short-funded and they have to provide a supplemental to.

[Roy Belson]: And they may need more money in 2018.

[Roy Belson]: What is the actual cost of providing current service levels in fiscal 18?

[Roy Belson]: Not more, current service levels.

[Roy Belson]: What will be the actual growth in revenues for fiscal 2018?

[Roy Belson]: Will there be new sources of sustainable revenue, not just one-time revenue?

[Roy Belson]: You know, for example,

[Roy Belson]: And if marijuana or other things like that were out there, there's money coming in, there's gambling issues, there's things like that that may generate hotel revenues, meal tax.

[Roy Belson]: As things come in, we have to watch all of that stuff to see exactly what goes into the state coffers.

[Roy Belson]: What new initiatives, projects will be approved?

[Roy Belson]: They want to do something they've never done before.

[Roy Belson]: All of a sudden, that's a new program that has to be funded.

[Roy Belson]: Or maybe it won't be funded, and it'll be sent down to us to fund, placing new demands on the budget.

[Roy Belson]: What previously funded items will be dropped or diminished?

[Roy Belson]: What will be the impact of a new administration in Washington?

[Roy Belson]: What states will gain or lose resource or policy changes?

[Roy Belson]: Medicaid, Medicare.

[Roy Belson]: the way it's funded, the way it's done, health care.

[Roy Belson]: All these things are going to have to be phased in.

[Roy Belson]: The governor's already talking about making some serious changes in health care, you were probably there, which could alter it.

[Roy Belson]: The GIC numbers are coming to us now, and they're looking for more deductibles and other factors, premium increases that will affect teachers and possibly affect, and other employees, and possibly affect what we have to budget for our percentage.

[Roy Belson]: So all those things have to come into from a state budget, so we're looking at this stuff now.

[Roy Belson]: It'll be at the center of our concerns, but any adverse state effect on the municipal budget as well, things that affect the municipal side of the budget, has an impact on us.

[Roy Belson]: The mayor's got one whole budget to look at.

[Roy Belson]: We want what we want, he's gonna look at the whole city.

[Roy Belson]: And that could be something that impacts us as well.

[Roy Belson]: Chapter 70 allocations.

[Roy Belson]: The governor was talking about $95 million.

[Roy Belson]: He thinks that's new money.

[Roy Belson]: That, to us, is no new money.

[Roy Belson]: That's like $20.

[Roy Belson]: Last year, we got $55.

[Roy Belson]: And it's well below what the foundation-level budget review committees were proposing.

[Roy Belson]: So that's not doing us much good unless it gets better on the foundation level.

[Roy Belson]: We are a hold-harmless district.

[Roy Belson]: Because of where we are, we're going to get a certain amount of money that we got last year, plus minimum aid, which could be anywhere from $20 to $55.

[Roy Belson]: That's the way it works.

[Roy Belson]: There may be some other pockets, but, for example, last year, you know, you were concerned about the kindergarten money not coming in.

[Roy Belson]: Other things that may not come in, other budgets that could get sliced, we have to pay attention to.

[Roy Belson]: The sped circuit breaker is now being discussed.

[Roy Belson]: There's a legislative briefing on February 2nd or 3rd.

[Roy Belson]: I forget which date it is exactly right now that I'll attend.

[Roy Belson]: I'm part of that coalition.

[Roy Belson]: We typically get 75% above the threshold of four times foundation.

[Roy Belson]: But four times foundation goes up every year, so that means our eligibility gets shortchanged a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: If they don't give us 75%,

[Roy Belson]: That affects what we can put into the pie for special needs, extraordinary tuitions.

[Roy Belson]: So all those things are, you know, part of our calculus.

[Roy Belson]: Charter school reimbursements have been underfunded for a number of years now.

[Roy Belson]: They didn't increase last year.

[Roy Belson]: There won't be any major increase in the number of charter schools, but there will be some more charter schools because the state board is going to be discussing them in the next couple of weeks at their board meeting.

[Roy Belson]: And the more you have,

[Roy Belson]: The more pupils that you have statewide, the more the distribution takes place.

[Roy Belson]: And if you only have the same pot of money, it gets spread out.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll have to see where that takes that.

[Roy Belson]: We brought youngsters back to Medford last year, and we paid more.

[Roy Belson]: So it's a tricky formula.

[Roy Belson]: It's got to be what?

[Roy Belson]: Out-of-district transportation costs for non-resident students to Minutemen.

[Roy Belson]: The reimbursement level came down again this year.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully it'll be sustained, but if that gets knocked out of the budget, it could be $20,000, $30,000 out of our pocket.

[Roy Belson]: Homeless funding has always been underfunded.

[Roy Belson]: The various grant programs, including early childhood, kindergarten, academic support, vocational education, and substance abuse prevention, the new opiate bill, it's not funded as far as I can see.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know who's funding that, but we all have responsibilities on it.

[Roy Belson]: And will there be any new mandated programs that emerge from legislative deliberations?

[Roy Belson]: So this is a snapshot of some of the challenges ahead.

[Roy Belson]: I want you to be aware of it.

[Roy Belson]: We don't know, you know, all the facts right now, but this is the stuff that we'll process every week, every day.

[Roy Belson]: I get newsletters and materials, speak to people.

[Roy Belson]: It's the kind of stuff I have to do on a regular basis to see what's likely to happen or not likely to happen.

[Roy Belson]: superintendents, teachers, unions, all kinds of people will be in there lobbying to keep money at a certain level or to get more money.

[Roy Belson]: But they'll all be clashing with each other.

[Roy Belson]: And the hard question is, is that what can happen that's new if the revenue growth is only at a certain level and one time revenues are either not available.

[Roy Belson]: We always hear about the rainy day fund.

[Roy Belson]: No one likes to dip into that unless they absolutely have to.

[Roy Belson]: Um, we don't know what capital gains will do for,

[Roy Belson]: you know, revenue into the city, I mean into state rather, all that's there.

[Roy Belson]: So Mayor and members of the committee, earlier in the minutes you heard that we approved retaining Massachusetts Association of School Committees to be our agent to advance the search.

[Roy Belson]: This afternoon, the Mayor and I met with Glenn Kuchar, the Executive Director of MASC, and went over all the different functions and activities that they can assist us with.

[Roy Belson]: And it's quite substantial.

[Roy Belson]: And as you know, because we pay dues,

[Roy Belson]: You know, we're not incurring an additional charge, which we might if we contracted with someone else.

[Roy Belson]: In the interim, we've put a pretty aggressive schedule together.

[Roy Belson]: As the mayor indicated, we'll clean it up tonight and get something out to you over the next day or so.

[Roy Belson]: But the first schedule was obviously the search committee, and the mayor's put something like that out.

[Roy Belson]: But in the interim, just to give you some information with regard to this particular activity,

[Roy Belson]: Glenn Kuchar indicated to us that he could distribute our brochure, he could distribute our applications, he could take in the applications as they came in, turn them around very quickly, give us a tiering as to who's eligible or not just simply by licensure and a few things like that, get it over to the search committee generally within a day, believe it or not, and create the circumstances in which this would go forward.

[Roy Belson]: He would also work on creating focus groups

[Roy Belson]: and other aspects of this search, site visits, and other things that you may or may not want to do.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly, this will take us into high gear with the idea being that a decision would be made sometime at the beginning of April.

[Roy Belson]: And this is the path we're on.

[Roy Belson]: The report I'm giving you right now gives you an idea that he'll get it out to a wide audience to help us screen the applicants to make sure the people are eligible.

[Roy Belson]: The search committee will get every applicant, whether they consider them eligible or not, in hard copy as well as electronically.

[Roy Belson]: The survey developed by the school committee, I want to talk to Mr. Rousseau about that.

[Roy Belson]: He will assist in getting that out and pulling those results together along with the focus groups.

[Roy Belson]: Again, pulling it together so that it takes the burden off any one member to do that or the administrations to keep it clean.

[Roy Belson]: He'll assist in the preparation of interviews, you know, questions for you to help you develop questions and appropriate information so you can group them properly.

[Roy Belson]: I went through a process of how they do that.

[Roy Belson]: And then, of course, following up with contract negotiations with the successful candidate or the candidate that you select.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot here.

[Roy Belson]: Clearly having an agent on board moves it forward, takes the burden off us to do it, and it keeps us on track to have a decision by April, hopefully.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the one thing we've got to understand is that when materials come in, it's confidential at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Just because you get something doesn't mean you go talking about who applied, because people are entitled to a certain amount of privacy.

[Roy Belson]: Once it reaches the final stage, privacy's off.

[Roy Belson]: And then people can see it.

[Roy Belson]: There'll be public interviews.

[Roy Belson]: There'll be all the kinds of things that will give the community total transparency as to the process.

[Roy Belson]: So the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education has launched an initiative which will celebrate Massachusetts and Massachusetts' achievements as leading the nation.

[Roy Belson]: Massachusetts, you know, leads the nation in typical test scores and other kinds of indicators.

[Roy Belson]: Also, if you look at the PISA results, the international results, if Massachusetts counts itself as a nation, which we do in the rankings, we're always very close to the top, if not on top.

[Roy Belson]: So, Massachusetts has decided through the department to celebrate that, and they've begun a project to provide a statewide platform for public schools in Massachusetts to celebrate their great achievements.

[Roy Belson]: We've already begun to pull together highlights and other things that are particular to us that go beyond testing, that highlight the kinds of educational programs that we're running, that we believe make Massachusetts not only tops in those categories of testing, but actually makes Massachusetts, in places like Medford, you know, renowned for doing some

[Roy Belson]: programs, whether it's Global Scholars, CCSR, or other things that you have heard about over the years.

[Roy Belson]: I want to make you aware of it because we're going to start to ramp up very soon, and we hope that you'll all participate.

[Roy Belson]: And you can see some of the things that are going to go on statewide at the Statehouse and other activities, which will give us an opportunity to highlight our school systems.

[Roy Belson]: We'll also use our various media.

[Roy Belson]: To talk about the things that are going well in our community and neighboring communities are the things we collaborate with so that's just an Informational piece for you right now to let you know and welcome any ideas that you may have Thank you

[Roy Belson]: They've actually got some interviews going on, I believe, at the end of this week.

[Roy Belson]: They'll be interviewing, they've narrowed it down to three finalists, a person who's a deputy commissioner in the state of New York, a person who's a deputy commissioner in the state of Texas, and the current superintendent of the Lawrence Public Schools have been designated as the three finalists.

[Roy Belson]: The board will interview them and potentially even next week will make a decision and make their recommendation to the Secretary of Education, Mr. Pizer.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have an affirmation or a veto at his discretion.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully we'll have someone in place very soon in that role when that person will actually take office I don't know probably depends on their current contracts and their current obligations But I assume that in the interim Jeff Wilson will continue to be the acting commissioner until that person can actually assume the role so we expect that to happen fairly soon and I'll get you posted as soon as I know

[Roy Belson]: They've named three finalists.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, you know, so if I want to speculate, you know, I might have thoughts, but I mean, it'd be inappropriate.

[Roy Belson]: So as our community becomes culturally and religiously diverse, more so than it has been, although, you know, it's quite a change.

[Roy Belson]: In 1982, 4% of our school population were persons of color.

[Roy Belson]: Today, it's close to 38% in an idea of what's taken place over time.

[Roy Belson]: But as we become more culturally diverse and religiously diverse, it's incumbent upon us to actively ensure that our students, employees, citizens are treated with respect and dignity and that they celebrate their personal cultures and religious observances.

[Roy Belson]: So adopting appropriate, inclusive holidays, observances, protocols does not violate the establishment clause of the Constitution.

[Roy Belson]: There's a difference between establishing religion and just allowing people to celebrate.

[Roy Belson]: It's a distinct difference.

[Roy Belson]: Rather, it protects it by recognizing the rich diversity of people's experiences.

[Roy Belson]: Massachusetts laws prohibit discrimination in all its forms.

[Roy Belson]: The best way to ensure that discrimination does not occur is to educate our students and community through positive learning and experience.

[Roy Belson]: We must always seek to move forward, to go beyond toleration to understanding.

[Roy Belson]: and enlightened understanding for both our diverse and common human heritage.

[Roy Belson]: The topic is far too involved to have a broad discussion this evening, but we need to invest more time through focus groups and additional sessions.

[Roy Belson]: In the interim, I've provided you with some materials in preparation for a more robust discussion.

[Roy Belson]: And we certainly will include people, and I've listed holidays and other things that deal with inclusive practices that have been put out by various agencies that are known for their expertise in this area.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, you know, this is not only a local thing, it's a national thing, it's a statewide thing.

[Roy Belson]: And for us to be in the forefront of it is very important.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of good things happening in our community already.

[Roy Belson]: But the price of doing the right thing is eternal vigilance.

[Roy Belson]: You have to be diligent with it.

[Roy Belson]: You can't let it slip.

[Roy Belson]: And we have a lot of things going on.

[Roy Belson]: And different things will occur, and there'll be some people that perhaps don't understand it.

[Roy Belson]: But it's our job to make sure that everyone feels protected, feels safe, and that we don't have any situation where a person feels isolated because of the policies and practices of our school system.

[Roy Belson]: Well, what we do is, I'll probably recognize the fact that if a person's out for those holidays and documents it, there's an excuse.

[Roy Belson]: So every year we go through various stages of why we close school and why we keep open.

[Roy Belson]: And some people understand it and some people agree and some people don't agree.

[Roy Belson]: I found the last little while the people who are more aggressively emailing me are generally students.

[Roy Belson]: High school students in particular.

[Roy Belson]: High school students, generally around.

[Roy Belson]: 8 o'clock in the morning before a storm, I'm getting things being told that their life is being put in peril and we're endangering them and their families.

[Roy Belson]: And I write back to them as courteously as I possibly can.

[Roy Belson]: For the most part, people do understand it.

[Roy Belson]: But I want to take a little bit of opportunity in between storms, if you will, to go over a couple things.

[Roy Belson]: So if people are listening, and we'll put it on our website again, they'll get an idea as to how we make these decisions.

[Roy Belson]: We want to keep open if we can.

[Roy Belson]: There are many youngsters out there who have no one supervising them if we close the schools.

[Roy Belson]: There are many youngsters out there who have no one feeding them if we close the schools.

[Roy Belson]: On the other hand, if conditions warranted, having youngsters out in the cold and driving snow, possibly with vehicles sliding on the road,

[Roy Belson]: Has to be balanced with our decision to open the schools Parents always have the opportunity to make a decision and if they document that they kept the youngster home Because of you know the weather and we have a reason to believe that the weather was that way we will provide an excused absence

[Roy Belson]: If, in fact, a youngster comes to us late on a day when conditions are such, rather than delay the whole day, which could mess up a number of things for a number of people, we won't mark them tardy to the extent that there's a reasonable arrival.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if they come in two minutes before the closing, we might think that that's not reasonable.

[Roy Belson]: But if they're an hour or so late, that's not a bad problem for us to recognize that as part of travel conditions.

[Roy Belson]: So we're entering the winter season, we're in the winter season, and from year to year, we may have more or less closings because of weather, or cold, or any other number of reasons, or for some reason that there's a building problem, or a safety problem that's different.

[Roy Belson]: We will use our media to inform people.

[Roy Belson]: We use all the television media.

[Roy Belson]: We use our own media to put things out.

[Roy Belson]: We use robocalls.

[Roy Belson]: We do everything we possibly can to let people know as soon as possible.

[Roy Belson]: Now, this last storm had to wait till almost 6 o'clock in the morning to take a good hard look to see what would come in.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I knew in this area we weren't going to get much snow.

[Roy Belson]: But a little to the west and a little to the north and the southeast, they got snow and they got bad conditions.

[Roy Belson]: So that was a tough one because we weren't sure what actually would happen, how it would track.

[Roy Belson]: The one before, people ask me, why didn't you call off school on that Tuesday when it was cold?

[Roy Belson]: If I had called off school on that Tuesday when it was cold, we would have been out Thursday and Friday anyway.

[Roy Belson]: We would have had one day of school that week because Monday was a holiday.

[Roy Belson]: So sometimes you just have to balance it a little bit and think about what's going to happen.

[Roy Belson]: You also have to think about the fact that teachers and others come from distance, and if they have

[Roy Belson]: young people of their own that have to stay home with, they may not come in.

[Roy Belson]: Or if they have the travel arrangements coming from the north or the south, it may not work for them to be in and on time.

[Roy Belson]: It may not be a productive day.

[Roy Belson]: So these are all kinds of considerations if you have to pay attention to where the DPW and the contractors can clear out lots.

[Roy Belson]: whether we think that the buses can actually make it up and go the various routes, whether the bus stops and the sidewalks have had an opportunity to be cleared to the greatest extent possible, although it's never perfect.

[Roy Belson]: It's very rarely perfect.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of considerations that we have to look at.

[Roy Belson]: I do talk to area colleagues as we come into this kind of season, and we take a look and see what's happening, and we try to make decisions that way.

[Roy Belson]: It's very important for people to understand that schools provide safety, it provides warmth, it provides nutrition to many youngsters.

[Roy Belson]: And we don't take school closings lightly.

[Roy Belson]: But if you think that safety is an issue, if you think that we can't clear the lots, we don't think we're going to have a productive day, we will call it.

[Roy Belson]: And I will try to call it as early as possible, often the night before.

[Roy Belson]: But some days it's not, we don't know until 5 o'clock in the morning, just the way it is.

[Roy Belson]: I would just tell you that there are people who, not what you're telling me, we should talk about long term, but there are people who rush to do what they call blizzard packs.

[Roy Belson]: I find that unproductive.

[Roy Belson]: We pay our teachers to teach 180 days of school.

[Roy Belson]: It's not a trade-off to give kids some homework.

[Roy Belson]: They're supposed to do homework anyway.

[Roy Belson]: And you know, the reality is that we want our teachers in front of students and they don't want to trade days.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if we get hit like the storm of 1978, we're out a whole week or ten days or something like that.

[Roy Belson]: We could probably have a plan in place to send materials out, especially with today's electronics.

[Roy Belson]: But I think we should be very careful that we start trading days for short-term days off.

[Roy Belson]: But I hear what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: If it's long-term, maybe we should consider it through a meeting.

[Roy Belson]: We sent you out on that particular day.

[Roy Belson]: The high school was not badly attended that day.

[Roy Belson]: It was over 80% of the people that were there.

[Roy Belson]: That's pretty good since normal attendance is in the low 90s.

[Roy Belson]: Plus teachers, there weren't that many people.

[Roy Belson]: There were people out, but there weren't that many people out comparatively to what could have been out.

[Roy Belson]: As far as the cold goes, part of the issue was the fact that it came on so suddenly.

[Roy Belson]: Certain areas of the building were still trying to adjust.

[Roy Belson]: But we can work on the heating system.

[Roy Belson]: We can work on different aspects of it.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of people were in school, and for the 80% plus of the people that were in school, I think it was good to have them there, as opposed to shut it down and then everyone's out.

[Roy Belson]: We'd end up making it up, and I think it was a day to have, especially that week.

[Roy Belson]: Because remember, again, if we called off school that day, we were in school potentially Wednesday.

[Roy Belson]: That was a whole week would have been gone.

[Roy Belson]: So at least we got a couple days in.

[Roy Belson]: I hear what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: We'll certainly work on that, and John and I will check.

[Roy Belson]: We'll certainly have the principals review that as a practice so that they understand that check the room out.

[Roy Belson]: Put them in the warmest place as possible.

[Roy Belson]: Mayor and members of the school committee, we had an extensive discussion in the committee of the whole.

[Roy Belson]: And again, just to briefly summarize it,

[Roy Belson]: The organizations that exist to support our schools are all good people.

[Roy Belson]: They're working hard.

[Roy Belson]: They give up a lot of their time.

[Roy Belson]: They generate a lot of support for our schools.

[Roy Belson]: We're very grateful and thankful.

[Roy Belson]: However, in order to optimize it, in order to make it more efficient and more effective overall across the city, and in order to tie it together with our own work, it's important for us to adopt some guidelines, adopt some training protocols, so that we can help these organizations do that much better.

[Roy Belson]: and to dovetail much better with us.

[Roy Belson]: So I've put together for you some recommendations to adopt oversight guidelines for PTOs, PTGs, and other 501c3 internal organizations.

[Roy Belson]: And I say internal organizations because I'm not talking about if a major corporation's 501c3 gives us money, I'm not going to ask them to audit their books.

[Roy Belson]: But I'm talking about groups that technically work with us or use our name.

[Roy Belson]: Michael Bloomberg gives us some money, I'm not going to ask him for his financials this week.

[Roy Belson]: I guess you probably wouldn't send it to me anyway.

[Roy Belson]: But I mean, but having said that, you know, our Cummings Foundation, things like that, they give us money and, you know, I'm appreciative that they do.

[Roy Belson]: But I'm talking about the internal groups that are clearly ours.

[Roy Belson]: And so I've listed eight items and I would ask that you approve them.

[Roy Belson]: I can read them off or you can accept them as they're written.

[Roy Belson]: Let me know what you're.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: Up to you.

[Roy Belson]: I can read them.

[Roy Belson]: One, all PTG, PTOs, and other internal 501c3 organizations affiliated with the Medford Public Schools must be registered with the superintendent's office annually.

[Roy Belson]: All registrations must be renewed by September 1st of each year.

[Roy Belson]: A registration is simply a process of recognizing that an organization exists.

[Roy Belson]: If they're out in the street, that there's a number they can have, and if a person who's a member of the community wants to donate, they know this is a valid organization.

[Roy Belson]: And they, we also know that they exist, and they're using our name, and raising money using our name.

[Roy Belson]: To all registered organizations.

[Roy Belson]: Ms.

[Roy Belson]: MPS one, two, three, four, whatever it is.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: Which is a very simple thing, but I want to know they exist.

[Roy Belson]: Who they are.

[Roy Belson]: You'll see it as it comes down.

[Roy Belson]: Well, it'll come down, you'll see it, okay, you'll see the things that you'll be on the form.

[Roy Belson]: Who the officers are, you know, you know, and so and so forth, where they're banking, and the likes of this.

[Roy Belson]: All registered organizations must submit bylaws, names of officers and board members, annual fundraising and expenditure plans, and a year-end financial statement.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, we want to know that every organization has some rules.

[Roy Belson]: We want to know that they have a plan, that it's not just something.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if they want to modify it, they can let us know they want to modify it.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not running around trying to second guess every move, but they should have a plan.

[Roy Belson]: And another reason for that is the fact that, you know, if everyone hits the same bank and everyone hits the same business over and over again,

[Roy Belson]: We're working on our community pretty hard.

[Roy Belson]: And also, when the school department goes to them for various things, they might say, well, you already gave.

[Roy Belson]: So it's important for us to know who is being asked for money, who is being repeatedly asked for money, who is being repeatedly asked for services, and whether or not it interferes with something that might be a larger project that the school department might be able to do for the greater benefit of all.

[Roy Belson]: You can modify it.

[Roy Belson]: You can make changes.

[Roy Belson]: It's a projection.

[Roy Belson]: It's like our budget.

[Roy Belson]: We project certain things and changes happen during the year.

[Roy Belson]: It's just that nature.

[Roy Belson]: You can just send in a note and say we did something different or we added something.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe it doesn't have to be that tight.

[Roy Belson]: Let me keep going and then we can hit it all, okay?

[Roy Belson]: There's some of these things that sort of intersect with each other.

[Roy Belson]: Three, bylaws must clearly identify how a person becomes eligible for membership.

[Roy Belson]: and how a person becomes a voting member.

[Roy Belson]: Distinct difference.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, a person comes to a meeting, you know, they may be a member, but if they've been to one meeting in three years, do they have the right to make decisions for a group of people that have been, you know, working on it for an extended period of time?

[Roy Belson]: That's a decision people can make.

[Roy Belson]: Bylaws must identify what is a voting quorum.

[Roy Belson]: Some of them, three people in the room could be a voting quorum.

[Roy Belson]: Is that a voting quorum?

[Roy Belson]: Do you have to have so many members of the executive board to be a voting quorum?

[Roy Belson]: Do you have to have so many members of the established membership to make a major decision?

[Roy Belson]: Bylaws must provide detailed information how, when elections for officers and board members will be implemented.

[Roy Belson]: When is it going to happen?

[Roy Belson]: What is the process?

[Roy Belson]: What is the distribution of information so that people know that an election is coming?

[Roy Belson]: Expenditures or funds must be done in coordination with the principal to ensure that supported programs, activities, and materials are consistent with the school's program and do not distract from the main mission of the school.

[Roy Belson]: Can't have an organization decide to buy a new curriculum that is counter indicative to the ones the school system has adopted.

[Roy Belson]: We can't have people planning trips that get in the way of testing or planning trips that come just as the testing season's about to begin or planning trips that

[Roy Belson]: are not tied to the curriculum in an important way.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe once in a while, but not all the time.

[Roy Belson]: Remember, we only have 180 days of school.

[Roy Belson]: We want to make sure all of them are used properly.

[Roy Belson]: The public schools, through the superintendents, will offer training to each entity.

[Roy Belson]: We want to make sure they all know what forms they have to fill out, if they're raising funds, if they're a non-profit.

[Roy Belson]: We want them to understand regulations and ordinances, what they can do.

[Roy Belson]: If you pay somebody money, and you pay them a certain amount of money, guess what?

[Roy Belson]: You've got to give them a form, or technically you're paying them under the table.

[Roy Belson]: That's not acceptable.

[Roy Belson]: If you're giving people money as reimbursement, reimbursement for what?

[Roy Belson]: What's your, what are you requiring?

[Roy Belson]: I mean, tonight you asked, you know, about slips and things like that.

[Roy Belson]: It's all heavily documented when it comes through the school system.

[Roy Belson]: Are we documenting these things?

[Roy Belson]: Give us an idea of those things.

[Roy Belson]: And if a person doesn't participate and doesn't become these things, then we maybe decertify them and say, look, we're not going to register you.

[Roy Belson]: You're not going to be an allowable organization because we can't track what you're doing.

[Roy Belson]: And then an annual report should be made to the school committee about all the organizations that exist.

[Roy Belson]: And the general thing, it may not be every expenditure they have, but it certainly should give you an idea of what started the year, what ended the year, and the main activities and the like that they had, and if they had an election, did they change officers, if there were special circumstances, was it reported.

[Roy Belson]: And I think if we do something like that, we'll have helped these organizations be that much better.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll help ourselves as we try to coordinate their activities with our initiatives as well.

[Roy Belson]: So I guess the floor is open for discussion.

[Roy Belson]: I think we're looking at people who don't have experience.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, if a person's been doing it and doing it successfully, you don't have to go to things.

[Roy Belson]: We don't have our teachers take courses that they've already passed and know.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes there's a refresher.

[Roy Belson]: It's required by the statute.

[Roy Belson]: the right to go, and they may have needs.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result, it's important to have the possibility that we would have a nurse on there.

[Roy Belson]: But for the school system to assume that cost altogether undercuts our ability to fund or let's say sponsor these trips.

[Roy Belson]: So by spreading it out, everybody shares a little bit of that responsibility.

[Roy Belson]: The way the civil rights office would look at it is, is that if in fact an individual student, because they had a handicap or some other kind of need, we had to pay more, that would be reducing access.

[Roy Belson]: That would be a, you know, making it more difficult for them to participate.

[Roy Belson]: So that's one of the reasons why, you know, it has to be spread out.

[Roy Belson]: So the choice is whether the school system picks it up or we spread it out across the cost of the trip.

[Roy Belson]: That's really the only two choices you have.

[Roy Belson]: You have to have it as a, as a reality.

[Roy Belson]: The question is, is that who pays?

[Roy Belson]: Is it spread out among all the people as a legitimate cost or is it the school system that picks it up every time there's a trip?

[Roy Belson]: No.

[Roy Belson]: We've got some estimates on them that have changed since the last time.

[Roy Belson]: So I'll pursue that with people as to find out what, what the status is.

[Roy Belson]: I know that we ran into a problem.

[Roy Belson]: It's pretty self-explanatory.

[Roy Belson]: Tufts Neighborhood Service Fund provides these, uh, funds to the schools will be used by our early childhood.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee, you have a report in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: The headmaster is here.

[Roy Belson]: The director and principal of the vocational school is here.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight we'll give you a brief introduction and then we should schedule a more formal meeting to discuss it in greater depth.

[Roy Belson]: But just to go over it so that you have a brief introduction and that you can ask any quick questions you may have of the two individuals, why don't you come on up and we can go over it.

[Roy Belson]: You know, as you know, we're currently in the fourth year of the process of having the two schools collaborate more completely together.

[Roy Belson]: And it's been a pretty high priority for the school committee because you've made that very clear that you want to see the two schools work closely together.

[Roy Belson]: And this goal would continue to

[Roy Belson]: expand the program to the comprehensive nature and give opportunities to both students at the Volk and at the high school that were previously not available.

[Roy Belson]: We've advanced the program so that there's a lot of participation across the schools.

[Roy Belson]: This time the ninth and tenth grade students are fully integrated academically.

[Roy Belson]: Some eleventh grade students are also integrated.

[Roy Belson]: High school students can now explore occupational programs

[Roy Belson]: and so on and so forth, the number of electives.

[Roy Belson]: So there are a number of benefits.

[Roy Belson]: I won't read the whole report.

[Roy Belson]: You get the idea.

[Roy Belson]: And then we can schedule a committee of the whole to move forward.

[Roy Belson]: It is important, if we're going to do this, that we move forward, because obviously we need a plan going into next year.

[Roy Belson]: we believe that the nature of what we're proposing does not require any contractual, uh, uh, negotiations.

[Roy Belson]: However, you know, from time to time, the union may raise something, but, uh, we have, uh, vetted a lot with them.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that, uh, at this point in time, uh, the issues that we have in front of you, changing the LAA code would not fall into that category.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, we have the director and the director both here to tell you about some of the fabulous grants we're getting.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, before we move away from these two, I think it's kind of important to see.

[Roy Belson]: Here's two examples of the high school and the vocational school working together.

[Roy Belson]: Biotech was never envisioned at the vocational school.

[Roy Belson]: Environmental science was never envisioned as a vocational program because it was really a trade school.

[Roy Belson]: This is one of the evolutions that has taken place, and this is one of the results.

[Roy Belson]: And this is where both sides of the school need to be able to participate.

[Roy Belson]: because it's equally valuable to whether you're pursuing a high school diploma as a high school or a vocational technical area.

[Roy Belson]: And this is kind of the kind of thing we're looking at right now.

[Roy Belson]: In many of the jobs that come out, a high school graduate who knows this stuff will actually be able to go on and get a two-year degree before they pursue either a four-year degree.

[Roy Belson]: So there's all kinds of options that are coming out that didn't exist before when we had a more traditional alignment.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, look at the relationships.

[Roy Belson]: The earlier you saw a gift to the robotics club, they go together.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, these things have synergy.

[Roy Belson]: They actually fit together.

[Roy Belson]: That's part of the reason why you see them all on the same agenda, so that you can see the relationships of different activities, how they interact with each other.

[Roy Belson]: They're not just standalone activities.

[Roy Belson]: So we have our assistant superintendent, buttressed by our director of science.

[Roy Belson]: So madam mayor, if I can, um, as you know, the envision series will be paid for.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result, our next budget will allow some funding that was previously assigned to envision, and then previously before that to journeys will now become available for science.

[Roy Belson]: That's our next priority.

[Roy Belson]: And that was what we discussed at budget last time.

[Roy Belson]: So Rocco has brought in kids in the past.

[Roy Belson]: And like I said a few moments ago, the availability of funding now that Envision has paid for, and Journeys has paid for, now moves to science.

[Roy Belson]: So Rocco will get first crack at those dollars that have been previously assigned to mathematics.

[Roy Belson]: For going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Well, at the elementary level, I mean, the science program has not been everything we want it to be.

[Roy Belson]: But you can see at the upper grades, based on some of the discussions that you've seen, science has taken off in a very, very robust way.

[Roy Belson]: But this one of the discussions we had was to make the elementary science program a priority going forward with funding available.

[Roy Belson]: that can be used in the next fiscal year.

[Roy Belson]: And with a game plan to review it against the standards, I think you're going to see quite a bit of material going in there.

[Roy Belson]: But the material that's selected will have to be things that we know will match up with the standards and with either one of the two or three curriculum programs that we would adapt.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, for example, if you're looking at thermodynamics, you're looking at heat and cold and the impact on matter, you can have kits that demonstrate that.

[Roy Belson]: that aren't going to be contradictory to any program.

[Roy Belson]: And you can do those things.

[Roy Belson]: You can have botany programs that aren't going to contradict any program.

[Roy Belson]: But you won't get the exact program until people actually review it.

[Roy Belson]: But you will get the opportunity to have additional materials at the elementary level based on our budget allocations next year.

[Roy Belson]: Well, this is where, you know, if Rocco knows that we are going to allocate, which he will know, we're going to allocate those funds, he will start identifying those items with teachers and letting us know so that we begin the purchasing process going into the summer and possibly running some workshops.

[Roy Belson]: The final program selection won't be until 2018-19, but the curriculum based on standards and based on new materials will be available next year.

[Roy Belson]: Well, every teacher has their own evaluation and they set up SMART goals and they set up individual goals.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, obviously you try to encourage them to take on goals that are going to advance their capacity to help their students in their classroom.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, there are so many different areas for an elementary school teacher to be involved in.

[Roy Belson]: Many of which is, many of which these things are tied to differentiated instruction, working with youngsters who have other needs and the like.

[Roy Belson]: The content areas, you know, really vary based on the expertise of the teachers as to which ones they would spend more time with.

[Roy Belson]: But certainly something as important as this, you know, will get greater emphasis in our discussions with the teachers.

[Roy Belson]: There are many things that teachers need to be competent in.

[Roy Belson]: As you know, there are at least, in most instances, four sections in each elementary school by grade level.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes it's five.

[Roy Belson]: And generally within each of those groups, there are people who have expertise in different areas.

[Roy Belson]: So it's important that we emphasize that they share with each other and that they work together.

[Roy Belson]: And we've done that right along, but we need to perhaps emphasize that a little bit to people that are more akin to a particular subject matter like science, that they step up and serve maybe as a little bit of a leadership role for the other members of that group.

[Roy Belson]: So as you know, we have to test our non-native language speakers, our ELL students, every year under a system called the WIDA testing.

[Roy Belson]: And our director of ELL is here to go over that with you.

[Roy Belson]: It's now underway.

[Roy Belson]: It's going well.

[Roy Belson]: But we want to bring you up to date in case you hear these terms and you want to know what's going on with regard to access testing

[Roy Belson]: and how it works in terms of the schools.

[Roy Belson]: So Leslie Trotter is here.

[Roy Belson]: So as you heard about ELL or EL, you know, in the use of technology and the use of technology and with regard to our other programs, science programs and the like, one of the most important initiatives that we have to launch in this district is to upgrade our technology network infrastructure.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, in order to be eligible for substantial,

[Roy Belson]: tier two E-rate funding and related grants, we have to complete a study of our current network infrastructure, which will then guide our applications for funding and ensure that we efficiently and effectively identify and target the critical elements of our infrastructure.

[Roy Belson]: We're eligible approximately for $400,000 federal entitlement funds, which we then have to match with an additional 40% at this time.

[Roy Belson]: This funding would then supplement local capital funds and other available grants.

[Roy Belson]: The funding is available this year.

[Roy Belson]: We cannot guarantee that going forward, given changes in Washington and other places, that the money will be available in subsequent years.

[Roy Belson]: So it behooves us to go get it now.

[Roy Belson]: It's imperative that we act now for multiple reasons, the availability of funding,

[Roy Belson]: the overall demand for technology for both instructional and administrative matters, the increased requirement to implement computer-based estate testing, and planned initiatives for online coursework and remedial credit recovery programs.

[Roy Belson]: Further, the purchase of state-of-the-art hardware and software must be supported by a network infrastructure that is sufficiently constructed to enable simultaneous high utilization and to filter out cyber malware

[Roy Belson]: consistent with SIPA standards.

[Roy Belson]: SIPA is the Computer Protection Act.

[Roy Belson]: The study must provide us with detailed information, an independent assessment that is free from internal bias, which we tend to have.

[Roy Belson]: Everybody has a different idea of what ought to be done.

[Roy Belson]: Programs and services are becoming increasingly dependent upon a robust and reliable internet and intranet capacity.

[Roy Belson]: So we selected,

[Roy Belson]: TechEdge of Cambridge to conduct the study and provide us with ongoing support.

[Roy Belson]: TechEdge is our current E-rate consultant and have done this for a period of years.

[Roy Belson]: They are also the E-rate consultants in the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education, Massachusetts Instructional Technology, Informational Technology rather, Massachusetts Department of Youth Services, and over 20 Massachusetts school districts.

[Roy Belson]: And they serve as the technical consultants to the DESE Office of Digital Learning

[Roy Belson]: the digital connections partnership grant, which is another grant we'll go after, which is an important grant.

[Roy Belson]: And they're the consultants.

[Roy Belson]: So anyway, you know, what's in here.

[Roy Belson]: If you agree with me, we need to go forward.

[Roy Belson]: We want to get this done so we can apply and move it, move it forward.

[Roy Belson]: We'll be approving check-edge, approximately that kind of money.

[Roy Belson]: She's extremely diligent and capable of doing this kind of work.

[Roy Belson]: And that's where we're going to go with this appointment.

[Roy Belson]: And we believe that there's a lot involved here.

[Roy Belson]: We've already started to get some requests across our table, and they need to be responded to very quickly.

[Roy Belson]: And we need to have the capacity to do that.

[Roy Belson]: Naturally, no one person does things.

[Roy Belson]: The individual coordinates other people.

[Roy Belson]: So if something's requested from a department, that individual needs to get on that department to get the information, pull it up, coordinate it, pull it together, and ship it out in a timely way.

[Roy Belson]: It won't affect our budget that much.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, we're talking about approximately $5,000 of annual outlay, uh, to do this plus any costs associated with the production of materials.

[Roy Belson]: But we can charge individuals making the request and we will recoup a substantial portion of that cost, um, over time because as individuals request items, we will appropriately charge them.

[Roy Belson]: If individual requests, a simple couple of documents, that's one thing.

[Roy Belson]: But if an individual requests any kind of work, we're going to be charging them at the rate that's allowed by law, and also for the paperwork and production that's required by law.

[Roy Belson]: It's appointable because the individual is not part of a unit, and they don't have to be bid within a unit.

[Roy Belson]: And that's why we're keeping it close to our office so that Kirsten and I can monitor it very closely.

[Roy Belson]: Because obviously, an individual getting a request would have to know what can be asked, what can't be asked.

[Roy Belson]: And we will also provide training.

[Roy Belson]: We're also going to run some training programs so that everybody is really on top of this.

[Roy Belson]: This is one of those things where there are fines if we don't do it.

[Roy Belson]: So we need to, we need to have everything properly set up and we need to have an inventory and an archive for everything we responded to.

[Roy Belson]: So Madam Mayor and members of the committee, we did get some inquiries from people about why we didn't always let students out, you know, on recess and cold days.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, I've tried to provide something that would give us some guidance and I just try to go through it a little bit because I think some people,

[Roy Belson]: think that there's one universal thing you can do.

[Roy Belson]: You can't paint this with a broad brush.

[Roy Belson]: Days are different.

[Roy Belson]: It's not only temperature, it's wind chill, it's ground conditions, it's disabilities on the part of certain youngsters in certain situations that take place, it's timing.

[Roy Belson]: And there's so many different factors that come into play.

[Roy Belson]: But recently, some elementary parents have raised the concern that students were not allowed to have outdoor recess on certain cold weather days.

[Roy Belson]: And we all recognize that recess, and we've talked about this many times, is an important element of the school day.

[Roy Belson]: It provides an opportunity for students to get a break from academics, to burn off excess energy, and get some exercise.

[Roy Belson]: Current time and learning regulations, as well as curriculum demands of the school, limit the amount of time we can currently allow for recess at this point.

[Roy Belson]: Outdoor recess is certainly desirable in most instances because it changes the environment.

[Roy Belson]: It provides fresh air opportunities to students.

[Roy Belson]: However, there are significant reasons to keep students indoors when weather conditions are adverse.

[Roy Belson]: There is no national standard for keeping students indoors or allowing them to go outdoors for school recess.

[Roy Belson]: As a result, site principals must make the decision based upon local conditions.

[Roy Belson]: We trust our principals to make decisions about the safety of our youngsters in many ways.

[Roy Belson]: We need to trust them to make this decision.

[Roy Belson]: We give them some guidance, but they need to be able to have that discretion.

[Roy Belson]: You don't want to be making it from distance.

[Roy Belson]: Temperatures alone is not sufficient to control decision making.

[Roy Belson]: Wind chill, rain, ice, snow, other factors have to be considered.

[Roy Belson]: Not all students, and that's true of a lot of students who come to our schools, have sufficient layered clothing to withstand extreme cold and other weather factors, even if we try.

[Roy Belson]: Student safety is most important consideration.

[Roy Belson]: Decisions aren't made with a broad brush.

[Roy Belson]: We can encourage outdoor recess,

[Roy Belson]: but ultimate decisions must rest with the building principal at the local school site.

[Roy Belson]: Now there are a number of things we can do.

[Roy Belson]: We can advise parents to provide layered clothing, including hats and gloves.

[Roy Belson]: We can also carry a supply of our own for some youngsters who don't have it, who don't come prepared.

[Roy Belson]: and that sometimes is reality.

[Roy Belson]: We can reschedule recess to some degree for a warmer part of the day if possible, maybe a little bit later in the morning rather than earlier.

[Roy Belson]: Difficult because there's a lot of other factors going on.

[Roy Belson]: We can shorten the time spent outside.

[Roy Belson]: Mix indoor with outdoor time.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe it's 10 minutes outside, read in the full time.

[Roy Belson]: And we can differentiate which students participate either by age or by condition when circumstances allow.

[Roy Belson]: And obviously we have to closely monitor certain students who may be more susceptible to cold conditions.

[Roy Belson]: I will direct principals to keep a log of the days when outdoor recess is not implemented.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll collect the data and review it this spring to see what patterns emerge.

[Roy Belson]: In the interim, it's my strong recommendation that principal discretion be maintained.

[Roy Belson]: We trust our principals to make safety decisions regarding students.

[Roy Belson]: This is just one of the many safety decisions that they must make on a daily basis.

[Roy Belson]: And I provided a chart for you to look at, which we'll provide to them, and they've been provided with some of this material in the past, to look at this stuff to see exactly how to make these decisions maybe a little bit more scientifically.

[Roy Belson]: We will once, you know, we're through tonight.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I think, you know, I wanted to present it to you and get feedback that you have, but we'll send this out.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, every building has its own culture, but I will now make it imperative upon the teacher to consult with the principal.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, sometimes an older child can go out, a younger child may not be able to go on.

[Roy Belson]: Um, there may be some mitigating circumstances, but the emphasis will be on having the school work as a unit as much as possible.

[Roy Belson]: and the principal consult with those teachers who might have a particular reason for not wanting to do it.

[Roy Belson]: I want to maintain principal discretion, but I also want to encourage them to not prevent outdoor recess just on a cavalier basis.

[Roy Belson]: But I do want them to have some discretion because there are individual situations.

[Roy Belson]: There may be a class in which some of the youngsters have severe colds or have some colds or just come back from colds.

[Roy Belson]: There may be some youngsters with other considerations on ground cover.

[Roy Belson]: ice on the playground or whatever the case may be.

[Roy Belson]: All these things need to be thought about.

[Roy Belson]: So we trust our principals to make decisions.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to give them discretion, but we'll monitor it, log it, and then review to see what the pattern has been.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, and monitor the whole thing.

[Roy Belson]: And I wouldn't want teachers just simply to say, I'm not going out because I don't want to go out.

[Roy Belson]: It's really got to be a situation where there's a reason

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: They're not doing it generally based on environmental conditions, but there may be a few other human conditions that require a consideration on a given day.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I think, you know, people have different opinions and I understand that some people are hardier than other people.

[Roy Belson]: Some people ski on a regular base and other people have never been on a mountain.

[Roy Belson]: But I mean, but, uh, but the reality is, is that, you know, we need to have some sort of balance in a school and we need to respect the right of the principal, uh, to, uh, make a judgment and then we'll monitor it.

[Roy Belson]: We'll monitor it.

[Roy Belson]: I just think we've got to use our common sense, you know,

[Roy Belson]: And the reality is, is that, you know, our young people need to be able to understand communication.

[Roy Belson]: So I spoke to the music department.

[Roy Belson]: There are currently 76 wind instruments that have been rented at this time.

[Roy Belson]: Most of them at the elementary level, there are about 66, another 10 at the middle school level.

[Roy Belson]: Most of the instruments beyond the middle school are either owned by the individuals or, well, they are owned by the individuals.

[Roy Belson]: By that time, they've paid for them if they've worked them up all the way up.

[Roy Belson]: So we currently have about 76 instruments that are rented in the school system, mostly at the elementary level.

[Roy Belson]: So Madam Mayor, if I can, the third word is issuance.

[Roy Belson]: It's not borrow, loan.

[Roy Belson]: It's issued.

[Roy Belson]: Issued from the school department, whether it's issued on a lease purchase or issued as a pure rental.

[Roy Belson]: But they're contracted by the school department to do that.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result, the school department is issuing it through the private company.

[Roy Belson]: on behalf of the school department.

[Roy Belson]: If I think I'm correct, I spoke to Mr. Casey, who unfortunately can't be here because he's not feeling well at this point, but he told me that for Medford students, they are issuing it at about $100 for a wind instrument.

[Roy Belson]: for the year, which is well below market.

[Roy Belson]: So they issue to another school district.

[Roy Belson]: I think he says he rents to about 127 different school districts.

[Roy Belson]: It's $25 a month.

[Roy Belson]: In Medford, it's $100 for the year.

[Roy Belson]: So it's a very sharp discount for a Medford student, Jack, as a graduate of the high school.

[Roy Belson]: And we obviously feel some obligation.

[Roy Belson]: The last cost I saw for a typical wind instrument, trumpet, a clarinet, something of that type, and please correct me if I'm wrong, was approximately $125 for the process.

[Roy Belson]: I would say that that's the neighborhood, but it is not necessarily the street.

[Roy Belson]: A larger instrument, for example, a typical kid wouldn't buy a tuba.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, you know, that's something we would do and then we would have to be responsible for that.

[Roy Belson]: No, but that's what he told me.

[Roy Belson]: I asked him what the cost would be.

[Roy Belson]: And he said, that's what it would be.

[Roy Belson]: I didn't say he could sterilize.

[Roy Belson]: I asked him what he thought the cost was since he did, you know, I thought he would know.

[Roy Belson]: I'm wrong.

[Roy Belson]: He's way off.

[Roy Belson]: I don't remember that, but if it's, if it's less, it's less.

[Roy Belson]: It's much less.

[Roy Belson]: So, let's clarify a few things.

[Roy Belson]: The statute says that when the school department issues something for a student to use or borrow, to use or borrow, not own, to use or borrow, then we have to notify parents of this option.

[Roy Belson]: Now, it's incumbent upon us to give them

[Roy Belson]: The pros, maybe some cons if there are, as to why they would or wouldn't do this, the pricing, and to tell them how it works and how to access it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, as far as the school department doing it, if we set up a system where people can bring their instruments to us so we can give them to the appropriate company, that's easily done.

[Roy Belson]: It's not difficult to do.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't have a problem doing that.

[Roy Belson]: The issue is really more of setting up a system, providing appropriate flyer, which I'll provide to you.

[Roy Belson]: We do have one issue, and maybe an attorney can enlighten us on this one.

[Roy Belson]: is to whether or not there's more than one company, because obviously we have bid laws.

[Roy Belson]: Is there one more than one company at this time?

[Roy Belson]: So in other words, saying if we put something out, this might be a sole source.

[Roy Belson]: And if it's a sole source, we put that out there.

[Roy Belson]: But if another source were to show up, we would have to, over time, explain that to people that they have that option as well.

[Roy Belson]: But in the interim, it's not a difficult thing to do.

[Roy Belson]: It's just that we want to provide appropriate notification

[Roy Belson]: Nothing wrong with providing appropriate notification.

[Roy Belson]: And people can make up their own mind.

[Roy Belson]: And if they believe that this is in their best interest, then fine.

[Roy Belson]: If they don't believe it's in their best interest, then that's a choice they can make.

[Roy Belson]: So that's what we're involved with.

[Roy Belson]: The statute is not a difficult one to accept.

[Roy Belson]: It's really a question of how we have people access it.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, and Reverend, I think it's really important, given the climate that sometimes pervades our world, that we reemphasize not only to ourselves as adults, but to

[Roy Belson]: the students that this is important to us.

[Roy Belson]: And when the adults make a motion of this type, you're sending a message to the young people who perhaps have not thought it through as much.

[Roy Belson]: And it's important for us to be able to say this is something that the adults have taken an active stand on.

[Roy Belson]: So that's another reason for doing it in a public body and especially in a school system where we have the care and responsibility of educating our young people about how to get along.

[Roy Belson]: And we've talked a lot about social and emotional health.

[Roy Belson]: We've talked a lot about some of the issues.

[Roy Belson]: And I have to tell you, the academic issues will take care of themselves over the years.

[Roy Belson]: The ones that won't are the social and emotional and the personal interactions of young people if we don't step up as role models and if we don't step up as voices to help them find voice as they grow up.

[Roy Belson]: So to help them with their transition to adulthood, it's critical that we take

[Roy Belson]: visible stance on human issues, human rights, and human fairness.

[Roy Belson]: I think we do.
