[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, making a second appearance.

[Roy Belson]: Um, a couple of weeks ago we gave you a draft of a reasonable use policy with regard to technology.

[Roy Belson]: Um, we pulled it off the table because there was some information that came to us from the ACLU and some other people that we wanted to, uh, review to ensure that we didn't miss anything and that we had a properly looked at legally.

[Roy Belson]: Um,

[Roy Belson]: We can control how devices are used in the school.

[Roy Belson]: We can't control what people do on their own privately as long as it doesn't affect or harass other students or result in bullying.

[Roy Belson]: But certainly the curriculum can talk about these things and the communication and the hostility.

[Roy Belson]: And also the community conversations issue really speaks to this, about people saying things, whether it's about sex or it's about hate or other forms of inappropriate conversation.

[Roy Belson]: It will all come to play through the curriculum, but I think at the same token, a reasonable use policy when we reemerge it, possibly as early as next meeting.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to make sure that it's right.

[Roy Belson]: We've vetted it with enough legal, and maybe the first of the year if we want to take a little bit more time.

[Roy Belson]: We'll speak to the issue of use of devices in schools and suggestions as to what young people should not be doing with their devices.

[Roy Belson]: Well, there shouldn't be any use of that device for that purpose during the school day in the school setting.

[Roy Belson]: But it does happen.

[Roy Belson]: But that in of itself would be a violation of the reasonable use policy.

[Roy Belson]: So that should be forbidden for use during the day of anything like that.

[Roy Belson]: So if it happens outside, you know, it's kind of hard to police that unless it results in some form of bullying or inappropriate harassment that might exist.

[Roy Belson]: No, but you have to be real about it.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, we don't control what people do on the street outside of us except if we are told that it affects how one student interacts with another.

[Roy Belson]: As far as the education side, we can bring that up through the curriculum.

[Roy Belson]: If it were happening.

[Roy Belson]: If it were happening.

[Roy Belson]: Correct.

[Roy Belson]: If it were happening.

[Roy Belson]: I think we can, you know, introduce the term sexting, you know, because that would be a common application of communication issues.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think it's a problem of doing that.

[Roy Belson]: I just think the education side is one side and the technical side is the other side.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, it comes together.

[Roy Belson]: It's not like we're ignoring one or the other.

[Roy Belson]: But Rachel, I think the assumption here is that there was nothing going on at the middle school in health.

[Roy Belson]: I think maybe you should talk a little bit what we are doing in the middle school because I think there's somehow that you see an elementary piece and a high school piece, but we haven't talked about the middle school piece.

[Roy Belson]: I think one of the things that we've got to understand is a common thread that runs through everything.

[Roy Belson]: How do young people make good decisions about anything, whether it's alcohol, sex, behavior towards others, race, things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: The whole constant of all these curricula deals with the issue of good decision making.

[Roy Belson]: How you are responsible to yourself and others as you move through, regardless of the content.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that's really the common thread.

[Roy Belson]: And maybe we just simply have to weave in some additional content is really what you're asking.

[Roy Belson]: So that we can give people at least an introduction to that since it seems to be a concern that may be emergent.

[Roy Belson]: Deputy superintendent will comment on that if you need additional information.

[Roy Belson]: Why don't we announce the date because I think it's important that parents know so they can plan.

[Roy Belson]: Let me tell you why.

[Roy Belson]: I picked a Monday because I want the continuity of the week.

[Roy Belson]: I don't want to have it on the Wednesday.

[Roy Belson]: You come to school for two days and then you have day off and then you go another two days.

[Roy Belson]: I think it breaks up the week.

[Roy Belson]: It's incumbent upon the faculty.

[Roy Belson]: It's incumbent upon students not to use this as an excuse to extend the weekend.

[Roy Belson]: And we need to make that clear to them.

[Roy Belson]: But I think it's important that we not lose four days consecutively, and just simply have two days, break it up in the middle of the week, and then it really doesn't help us in terms of keeping momentum going in classes.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, there's a lot going on in the evaluation process at the state level.

[Roy Belson]: And it's going back and forth between the Teachers Association, the MASC, the MASS, the Commissioner's Office and the like.

[Roy Belson]: And we want to keep you informed because it's a hot topic right now and I want you to understand, you know,

[Roy Belson]: where it's going.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, there was a proposed change that the commissioner brought to the attention of the destiny board.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, this past week, uh, commissioner Chester introduced a change that because of the feedback he was getting from the field, no one was really happy with the way there was, it was set up previously that would there be a student impact rating that was independent of the, um,

[Roy Belson]: with a regular rating.

[Roy Belson]: So we came up with an approach that would embed it in standard two.

[Roy Belson]: Um, so it would be part of the standard two rating.

[Roy Belson]: The teacher's association, as you can see from what's been attached, is adamantly opposed to it.

[Roy Belson]: The MASS and the MASC believe it's workable.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, the board has sent it out for public comment.

[Roy Belson]: Over the next couple of months, there'll be public comment, and we'll see what actually takes place.

[Roy Belson]: But it's an important element of public policy, because obviously, there's got to be some form of teacher evaluation going on.

[Roy Belson]: And the question is, is that is student learning a legitimate element of determining how effective a teacher is in the classroom?

[Roy Belson]: Now, it shouldn't be so plastic that

[Roy Belson]: The teacher who works with the most challenged of students is expected to have the same results as the teachers working with the gifted and talented student who self-motivates and teaches themselves in some ways.

[Roy Belson]: Albeit, good teachers inspire anybody at any level.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, the debate is very sharp right now.

[Roy Belson]: And it reflects a great deal of back and forth.

[Roy Belson]: And I'm not sure exactly how it's going to end up.

[Roy Belson]: I will tell you that it is tying us up in terms of dealing with the Teachers Association, in terms of coming up with new ideas as to how to properly evaluate.

[Roy Belson]: It does create a back and forth between the associations in the Commonwealth, and it clearly is a topic that we're going to hear more and more about.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to keep you informed, I want you to know what people are saying, what happened at the board, what happened with the memo you have from the Teachers Association, both from the MTA and the AFT, although it's on the MTA stationery, as to what their objections are.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll continue to talk about this because the way we evaluate teachers, the way we set goals for performance is very important to us, and how we measure that

[Roy Belson]: is also very important and it will affect personnel decisions going forward.

[Roy Belson]: So, happy to take any questions you may have, but I think the rest of it is self-explanatory.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to call upon our Director of Finance and Administration, Christine

[Roy Belson]: Patterson is doing a great job and stepping in so quickly and Good evening madam mayor members of the committee.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Of course, one of the things, I'll just say this as a commentary on what's going on, we don't know what the federal policy is going to be going into next year with regard to USDA reimbursements to the state and to us.

[Roy Belson]: The supply of commodities and things of that type, it could change at this particular point in time.

[Roy Belson]: So there's some uncertainty on that level.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to deal also with the fact that, you know, the price of food in local markets, we have, you know, some issues with regard to that.

[Roy Belson]: We'll go up farm to school and things like that.

[Roy Belson]: We want farm fresh.

[Roy Belson]: We want certain kinds of food.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to be careful about that.

[Roy Belson]: But so far the food service program is doing fine.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, we'll monitor that.

[Roy Belson]: And our goal would be not to raise prices unless we absolutely have to.

[Roy Belson]: And we try to give you as much advance notice as we can.

[Roy Belson]: But I appreciate what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: We will be.

[Roy Belson]: But I will point out to you that more and more of our students are becoming eligible for free and reduced.

[Roy Belson]: There's two schools that received equipment.

[Roy Belson]: They had to have at least 50% of the student body eligible in order to even apply for the grant.

[Roy Belson]: And the others aren't too far behind.

[Roy Belson]: There's only one school that's really kind of, you know, doesn't have that economic.

[Roy Belson]: But most of the others are starting to head towards that 50% threshold.

[Roy Belson]: It's simply the nature of the demographic in the community, so we are conscious of that very much.

[Roy Belson]: To the extent that they want to.

[Roy Belson]: Some kids will never tell you because they don't want to.

[Roy Belson]: Some families won't, but more and more we're paying attention to that because obviously it affects us.

[Roy Belson]: Part of the reason that prices had to be raised, just so we can remind ourselves of this,

[Roy Belson]: was the fact that the USDA insisted that we charge at least as much as they were reimbursing.

[Roy Belson]: They weren't going to reimburse us more money than we were charging ourselves.

[Roy Belson]: So that was an important thing to bring it up, so we had to actually bring it up.

[Roy Belson]: But the point's well taken, and we'll follow up, and we'll try to do the best we can in giving a word out there.

[Roy Belson]: So in our last meeting, you asked me to draft a letter from you to our legislative delegation.

[Roy Belson]: I have done so.

[Roy Belson]: And you, you know, had a chance to hopefully to look it over so that we can send it in.

[Roy Belson]: But I want to bring you up to date on a couple more things that have since emerged.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, but that law I did attach.

[Roy Belson]: an advisory from the Massachusetts Association of School Superintendents, legal counsel, which went into a great deal of depth about some of the legal challenges in implementing this law.

[Roy Belson]: I also had the opportunity today to meet with the state treasurer as part of the Economic Empowerment Task Force, which I serve, about the implementation, because the implementation comes under her jurisdiction, at least at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: As you may know, there's no money

[Roy Belson]: that's been allocated in the current budget for it and the current collections have gone down this month.

[Roy Belson]: So it's hard to know where that new money is coming and there's no consensus to borrow from the rainy day fund from either the governor or the speaker of the house or the state treasurer.

[Roy Belson]: So it's unlikely that this will be off and running very soon.

[Roy Belson]: Um, because they, they need money to set up the apparatus to do the, the kinds of things that are necessary.

[Roy Belson]: Still, we should be on record.

[Roy Belson]: In addition, we should also note that there are some interesting federal laws that are going to intersect with this right now.

[Roy Belson]: There is the Drug-Free Schools Act.

[Roy Belson]: There's the Communities Act.

[Roy Belson]: There's also, you know, a discussion of states' rights versus federal supremacy clause.

[Roy Belson]: Under the federal supremacy clause,

[Roy Belson]: federal laws take precedent over state laws, unless they're covered by the Tenth Amendment to the Constitution, which reserves rights to the state that are not enumerated for the federal government.

[Roy Belson]: But depending on the court, it really depends on what the judges want to rule at any one time, because it's gone both ways.

[Roy Belson]: So it's entirely possible that the incoming Attorney General, who has been very strong in his advocacy against marijuana, recreational or medical, in his home state,

[Roy Belson]: and in the Senate may actually take a more aggressive stance than the current Attorney General of the United States, Loretta Lynch.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot going on as to how this stuff is going to play out in the national and the local scene in the upcoming months.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing, too, that maybe people don't fully realize is that because it's a federal crime, money's collected for this revenue from marijuana

[Roy Belson]: can't be deposited in a federal bank because it's a criminal act.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, all kinds of, but you know, there's going to be, it's going to be very interesting to see how they play with that because with a new, if you will, sheriff in town at the White House, it could very well be a very difficult thing that goes forward.

[Roy Belson]: So in the interim, it doesn't hurt for us to be on record with the letter that I've drafted for you or any amendments you want to make to it.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, but I think that it's going to be a little while before we start to see this, uh, take place and where it goes.

[Roy Belson]: The superintendent would like to mention just a couple of quick, quick things, you know, again, tomorrow at 1230 is groundbreaking at the community access channel.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to be hosted in part by the mayor, by Lisa Hughes from channel four of Courtney Cox from Nesson.

[Roy Belson]: and a number of other people from the media coming to see us in action.

[Roy Belson]: And it'll be a good opportunity to see how this thing is progressing.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of good work is going on.

[Roy Belson]: Christina has been working real hard with city officials to ensure that the construction goes forward and that the necessary modifications are made so that things go forward.

[Roy Belson]: But tomorrow's an opportunity to see things from the actual site and to get some reports at that opportunity.

[Roy Belson]: I've given you two articles.

[Roy Belson]: from Time Magazine, which was referenced by Paulette a short time ago.

[Roy Belson]: They're worth reading because I think what's important is that we stay up on what's being said out there so we can have the dialogues necessary to guide the future directions of our resources and our curriculum.

[Roy Belson]: It should be noted that the President-Elect has named an incoming U.S.

[Roy Belson]: Secretary of Education, Elizabeth Betsy DeVos of Michigan.

[Roy Belson]: She's an active supporter of school choice, charters, and vouchers.

[Roy Belson]: She also has announced that she's against the Common Core.

[Roy Belson]: We'll see where that happens, what that means.

[Roy Belson]: Again, back to the Supremacy Clause versus states' rights.

[Roy Belson]: All those kinds of things have to be worked out.

[Roy Belson]: But it's going to be very interesting to see, especially coming off the most recent initiative petition in the Commonwealth as to what kinds of incentives will be made to the communities, the states, to expand choice.

[Roy Belson]: and the like.

[Roy Belson]: The Massachusetts Constitution forbids certain types of activities.

[Roy Belson]: Again, you know, it's hard to know how it will all intersect, but it bears watching.

[Roy Belson]: So those are just a few items to bring to your attention, and hopefully you can participate.

[Roy Belson]: And again, on the 14th, if you intend to go, let us know so we can arrange for parking and the other things for you at the Science Museum.

[Roy Belson]: So I spoke to the music department.

[Roy Belson]: There are currently 76 wind instruments that have been rented at this time.

[Roy Belson]: Most of them at the elementary level, there are about 66, another 10 at the middle school level.

[Roy Belson]: Most of the instruments beyond the middle school are either owned by the individuals, well, they are owned by the individuals.

[Roy Belson]: By that time, they paid for them if they worked them up all the way up.

[Roy Belson]: So we currently have about 76 instruments that are rented in the school system, mostly at the elementary level.

[Roy Belson]: So Madam Mayor, if I can, the third word is issuance.

[Roy Belson]: It's not borrow or loan, it's issued.

[Roy Belson]: Issued from the school department, whether it's issued on a lease purchase or issued as a pure rental.

[Roy Belson]: But they're contracted by the school department to do that.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result, the school department is issuing it through the private company on behalf of the school department.

[Roy Belson]: If I think I'm correct, I spoke to Mr. Casey, who unfortunately can't be here because he's not feeling well at this point.

[Roy Belson]: But he told me that for Medford students, they are issuing it at about $100 for a wind instrument for the year, which is well below market.

[Roy Belson]: So they issue to another school district.

[Roy Belson]: I think he says he rents to about 127 different school districts.

[Roy Belson]: It's $25 a month.

[Roy Belson]: In Medford, it's $100 for the year.

[Roy Belson]: So it's a very sharp discount for a Medford student.

[Roy Belson]: Jack is a graduate of the high school.

[Roy Belson]: and we obviously feel some obligation.

[Roy Belson]: The last cost I saw for a typical wind instrument, trumpet, a clarinet, something of that type, and please correct me if I'm wrong, was approximately $125 for the process.

[Roy Belson]: I would say that that's the neighborhood, but it is not necessarily the street.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: A larger instrument, for example, a typical kid wouldn't buy a tuba.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, you know, that's something we would do and then we would have to be responsible for that.

[Roy Belson]: until they paid it off, typically.

[Roy Belson]: No, but that's what he told me.

[Roy Belson]: I asked him what the cost would be and he said, that's what it would be.

[Roy Belson]: I didn't say he could sterilize.

[Roy Belson]: I asked him what he thought the cost was since he didn't, you know, I thought he would know.

[Roy Belson]: If I'm wrong, you know, he's way off.

[Roy Belson]: I don't remember that.

[Roy Belson]: You did.

[Roy Belson]: But if it's, if it's less, it's less.

[Roy Belson]: It's fine.

[Roy Belson]: So, let's clarify a few things.

[Roy Belson]: The statute says that when the school department issues something for a student to use or borrow, to use or borrow, not own, to use or borrow, then we have to notify parents of this option.

[Roy Belson]: Now, it's incumbent upon us to give them

[Roy Belson]: the pros, maybe some cons if there are, as to why they would or wouldn't do this, the pricing, and to tell them how it works and how to access it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, as far as the school department doing it, if we set up a system where people can bring their instruments to us so we can give them to the appropriate company, that's easily done.

[Roy Belson]: It's not difficult to do.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't have a problem doing that.

[Roy Belson]: The issue is really more of setting up a system, providing appropriate flyer, which I'll provide to you.

[Roy Belson]: We do have one issue, and maybe an attorney can enlighten us on this one.

[Roy Belson]: is to whether or not there's more than one company because obviously we have bid laws.

[Roy Belson]: Is there one more than one company at this time?

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: So in other words, saying if we put something out, this might be a sole source.

[Roy Belson]: And if it's a sole source, we put that out there.

[Roy Belson]: But if another source were to show up, we would have to, over time, explain that to people that they have that option as well.

[Roy Belson]: But in the interim, it's not a difficult thing to do.

[Roy Belson]: It's just that we want to provide appropriate notification.

[Roy Belson]: Nothing wrong with providing appropriate notification.

[Roy Belson]: And people can make up their own mind.

[Roy Belson]: And if they believe that this is in their best interest, then fine.

[Roy Belson]: If they don't believe it's in their best interest,

[Roy Belson]: then that's a choice they can make.

[Roy Belson]: So, that's what we're involved with.

[Roy Belson]: The statute is not a difficult one to accept.

[Roy Belson]: It's really a question of how we have people access it.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, and Reverend, I think it's really important, given the climate that sometimes pervades our world,

[Roy Belson]: that we reemphasize not only to ourselves as adults, but to the students, that this is important to us.

[Roy Belson]: And when the adults make a motion of this type, you're sending a message to the young people who perhaps have not thought it through as much.

[Roy Belson]: And it's important for us to be able to say this is something that the adults have taken an active stand on.

[Roy Belson]: So that's another reason for doing it in a public body, and especially in a school system, where we have the care and responsibility of educating our young people about how to get along.

[Roy Belson]: And we've talked a lot about social and emotional health.

[Roy Belson]: We've talked a lot about some of the issues.

[Roy Belson]: And I have to tell you, the academic issues will take care of themselves over the years.

[Roy Belson]: The ones that won't are the social and emotional

[Roy Belson]: and the personal interactions of young people if we don't step up as role models, if we don't step up as voices to help them find voice as they grow up.

[Roy Belson]: So to help them with their transition to adulthood, it's critical that we take visible stands on human issues, human rights, and human fairness.

[Roy Belson]: Madam members of the committee, Baco Sierra is unable to be with us this evening.

[Roy Belson]: He's not feeling well, but we have a terrific substitute, our deputy superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: Oh, just one comment.

[Roy Belson]: So just want to remind you that on the 14th, you've all been invited to the science museum.

[Roy Belson]: If you haven't got the thing on the, uh, the global scholars program, and that's going to intersect with the Bloomberg gift to the science museum on science innovation and innovation around the world, how our middle school students are talking to students from around the world on scientific issues like the digital environment, water,

[Roy Belson]: things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: So you're invited to participate and to watch and that's on the 14th and we'll reemphasize that to you.

[Roy Belson]: That's another aspect of how, you know, science gets integrated into a lot of other activities as well.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, making a second appearance on credit recovery.

[Roy Belson]: And now the members of the committee will call upon our assistant superintendent and our supervisor of physical education and health to inform you about this progress.

[Roy Belson]: So let me try and answer it this way.

[Roy Belson]: Um, a couple of weeks ago we gave you a,

[Roy Belson]: draft of a reasonable use policy with regard to technology.

[Roy Belson]: We pulled it off the table because there was some information that came to us from the ACLU and some other people that we wanted to review to ensure that we didn't miss anything and that we had it properly looked at legally.

[Roy Belson]: We can control how devices are used in the school.

[Roy Belson]: We can't control what people do on their own, you know, privately as long as it doesn't affect or harass other students or result in bullying.

[Roy Belson]: But certainly the curriculum can talk about these things in the communication and the hostility.

[Roy Belson]: And also the community conversations issue, you know, really speaks to this about people saying things, whether it's about sex or it's about hate or other forms of

[Roy Belson]: inappropriate conversation.

[Roy Belson]: So I think it will all come to play through the curriculum, but I think at the same token, you know, our reasonable use policy, when we reemerge it, possibly as early as next meeting, I just want to make sure that it's right, we've vetted it with enough legal, and maybe the first of the year if we want to take a little bit more time, we'll speak to the issue of use of devices in schools and, you know, suggestions as to what young people should not be doing with their devices.

[Roy Belson]: Well, there shouldn't be any use of that device for that purpose during the school day in the school setting.

[Roy Belson]: But it does happen.

[Roy Belson]: But that in of itself would be a violation of the reasonable use policy.

[Roy Belson]: So that should be forbidden for use during the day of anything like that.

[Roy Belson]: So if it happens outside, you know, it's kind of hard to police that unless it results in some form of bullying or inappropriate harassment.

[Roy Belson]: No, but you have to be real about it.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, we don't control what people do on the street outside of us, except if we are told that it affects how one student interacts with another.

[Roy Belson]: As far as the education side, we can bring that up through the curriculum.

[Roy Belson]: Correct.

[Roy Belson]: I think we can introduce the term sexting because that would be a common application of communication issues.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think it's a problem doing that.

[Roy Belson]: I just think the education side is one side, and the technical side is the other side.

[Roy Belson]: So it comes together.

[Roy Belson]: It's not like we're ignoring one or the other.

[Roy Belson]: We can set that up.

[Roy Belson]: But Rachel, I think the assumption here is that there is nothing going on at the middle school in health.

[Roy Belson]: I think maybe you should talk a little bit about what we are doing in the middle school.

[Roy Belson]: Sure.

[Roy Belson]: Because I think to somehow

[Roy Belson]: that you see an elementary piece and a high school piece, but we haven't talked about the middle school piece.

[Roy Belson]: I think one of the things that we've got to understand is a common thread that runs through everything.

[Roy Belson]: How do young people make good decisions about anything, whether it's alcohol, sex?

[Roy Belson]: behavior towards others, race, things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: The whole concept of all these curricula deals with the issue of good decision making.

[Roy Belson]: How you are responsible to yourself and others as you move through, regardless of the content.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that's really the common thread.

[Roy Belson]: And maybe we just simply have to weave in some additional content is really what you're asking.

[Roy Belson]: So that we can give people at least an introduction to that

[Roy Belson]: since it seems to be a concern that may be emergent.

[Roy Belson]: Deputy Superintendent will comment on that if you need additional information.

[Roy Belson]: Why don't we announce the date because I think it's important that parents know so they can plan.

[Roy Belson]: I picked the Monday because

[Roy Belson]: I want the continuity of the week.

[Roy Belson]: I don't want to have it on the Wednesday, you come to school for two days and then you have day off and then you go another two days.

[Roy Belson]: I think it breaks up the week.

[Roy Belson]: It's incumbent upon the faculty.

[Roy Belson]: It's incumbent upon students not to use this as an excuse to extend the weekend.

[Roy Belson]: We need to make that clear to them, but I think it's important that we not lose four days consecutively and just simply have two days, break it up in the middle of the week.

[Roy Belson]: And then it really doesn't help us in terms of keeping momentum going in classes.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, there's a lot going on in the evaluation process at the state level.

[Roy Belson]: And it's going back and forth between the Teachers Association, the MASC, the MASS, the commissioner's office, and the like.

[Roy Belson]: And we want to keep you informed because it's a hot topic right now.

[Roy Belson]: And I want you to understand where it's going.

[Roy Belson]: There was a proposed change that the commissioner brought to the attention of the DESE board this past week.

[Roy Belson]: Commissioner Chester introduced a change that

[Roy Belson]: because of the feedback he was getting from the field.

[Roy Belson]: No one was really happy with the way it was set up previously, that there would be a student impact rating that was independent of the regular rating.

[Roy Belson]: So he came up with an approach that would embed it in standard two, so it would be part of the standard two rating.

[Roy Belson]: The Teachers Association, as you can see from what's been attached, is adamantly opposed to it.

[Roy Belson]: The MASS and the MASC believe it's workable.

[Roy Belson]: The board has sent it out for public comment.

[Roy Belson]: Over the next couple of months, there'll be public comment.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll see what actually takes place.

[Roy Belson]: But it's an important element of public policy, because obviously, there's got to be some form of teacher evaluation going on.

[Roy Belson]: And the question is, is that, is student learning a legitimate element of determining how effective a teacher is in the classroom?

[Roy Belson]: Now, it shouldn't be so plastic that the teacher who works with the most challenged of students is expected to have the same results as the teachers working with the gifted and talented student who self-motivates and teaches themselves in some ways.

[Roy Belson]: Albeit, good teachers inspire anybody at any level.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, the debate is very sharp right now.

[Roy Belson]: And it reflects a great deal of back and forth.

[Roy Belson]: And I'm not sure exactly how it's going to end up.

[Roy Belson]: I will tell you that it is tying us up in terms of dealing with the Teachers Association, in terms of coming up with new ideas as to how to properly evaluate.

[Roy Belson]: It does create a back and forth between the associations in the Commonwealth.

[Roy Belson]: And it clearly is a topic that we are going to hear more and more about.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to keep you informed.

[Roy Belson]: I want you to know what people are saying, what happened at the board, what happened with the memo you have from the Teacher's Association, both from the MTA and the AFT, although it's on MTA stationary, as to what their objections are.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll continue to talk about this, because the way we evaluate teachers, the way we set goals for performance is very important to us.

[Roy Belson]: And how we measure that is also very important.

[Roy Belson]: And it will affect personnel decisions going forward.

[Roy Belson]: So happy to take any questions you may have, but I think the rest of it is self-explanatory.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to call upon our Director of Finance and Administration, Christine.

[Roy Belson]: uh, Patterson is doing a great job and, uh, stepping in, uh, so quickly and, uh, we're going to report on this.

[Roy Belson]: Of course, one of the things, I'll just say this as a commentary on what's going on, we don't know what the federal policy is going to be going into next year with regard to USDA reimbursements to the state and to us, the supply of commodities and things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: It could change at this particular point in time.

[Roy Belson]: So there's some uncertainty on that level.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to deal also with the fact that, you know,

[Roy Belson]: The price of food in local markets, we have some issues with regard to that.

[Roy Belson]: We'll go up farm to school and things like that.

[Roy Belson]: We want farm fresh.

[Roy Belson]: We want certain kinds of food.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to be careful about that.

[Roy Belson]: But so far, the food service program is doing fine.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll monitor that.

[Roy Belson]: And our goal would be not to raise prices unless we absolutely have to.

[Roy Belson]: And we try to give you as much advance notice as we can.

[Roy Belson]: But I appreciate what you're saying.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: We will be.

[Roy Belson]: But I will point out to you that more and more of our students are becoming eligible for free and reduced.

[Roy Belson]: We have, there's two schools that received equipment.

[Roy Belson]: They had to have at least 50% of the student body eligible in order to even apply for the grant.

[Roy Belson]: And the others aren't too far behind.

[Roy Belson]: There's only one school that's really kind of, you know, doesn't have that economic, but most of the others are starting to head towards that 50% threshold.

[Roy Belson]: That's simply the nature of the demographic in the community.

[Roy Belson]: So we are conscious of that very much.

[Roy Belson]: Some kids will never tell you because they don't want to.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, some families won't, but more and more we're paying attention to that because obviously it affects us.

[Roy Belson]: Part of the reason that prices had to be raised, just so we can remind ourselves of this, was the fact that the USDA insisted that we charge at least as much as they were reimbursing.

[Roy Belson]: They weren't going to reimburse us more money than we were charging ourselves.

[Roy Belson]: So that was an important thing to bring it up, so we had to actually bring it up.

[Roy Belson]: But the point is well taken, and we'll follow up, and we'll try to do the best we can in giving a word out there.

[Roy Belson]: So in our last meeting you asked me to draft a letter from you to our legislative delegation.

[Roy Belson]: I have done so and you, you know, got a chance hopefully to look it over so that we can send it in.

[Roy Belson]: But I want to bring you up to date on a couple more things that have since emerged with that law.

[Roy Belson]: I did attach

[Roy Belson]: an advisory from the Massachusetts Association of School Superintendents, legal counsel, which went into a great deal of depth about some of the legal challenges in implementing this law.

[Roy Belson]: I also had the opportunity today to meet with the State Treasurer as part of the Economic Empowerment Task Force, which I serve.

[Roy Belson]: about the implementation because the implementation comes under her jurisdiction, at least at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: As you may know, there's no money that's been allocated in the current budget for it and the current collections have gone down this month.

[Roy Belson]: So it's hard to know where that new money is coming and there's no consensus to borrow from the rainy day fund from either the governor or the speaker of the house or the state treasurer.

[Roy Belson]: So it's unlikely that this will be off and running very soon because they, they need money to set up the apparatus to do the,

[Roy Belson]: the kinds of things that are necessary.

[Roy Belson]: Still, we should be on record.

[Roy Belson]: In addition, we should also note that there are some interesting federal laws that are going to intersect with this right now.

[Roy Belson]: There is the Drug-Free Schools Act.

[Roy Belson]: There's the Communities Act.

[Roy Belson]: There's also, you know, a discussion of states' rights versus federal supremacy clause.

[Roy Belson]: Under the federal supremacy clause, federal laws take precedent over state laws, unless they're covered by the 10th Amendment to the Constitution, which reserves rights to the state that are not enumerated for the federal government.

[Roy Belson]: But depending on the court,

[Roy Belson]: It really depends on what the judges want to rule at any one time because it's gone both ways.

[Roy Belson]: So it's entirely possible that the incoming Attorney General, who has been very strong in his advocacy against marijuana, recreational or medical, in his home state,

[Roy Belson]: and in the Senate, may actually take a more aggressive stance than the current Attorney General of the United States, Loretta Lynch.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot going on as to how this stuff is going to play out in the national and the local scene in the upcoming months.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing, too, that maybe people don't fully realize is that because it's a federal crime, money's collected for this revenue from the

[Roy Belson]: from marijuana can't be deposited in a federal bank, because it's a criminal act.

[Roy Belson]: Multiple levels of different.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, all kinds of, but you know, there's going to be, it's going to be very interesting to see how they play with that, because with a new, if you will, sheriff in town, and they get to stay in the White House, it could very well be a very difficult thing that goes forward.

[Roy Belson]: So in the interim,

[Roy Belson]: It doesn't hurt for us to be on record with the letter that I've drafted for you or any amendments you want to make to it.

[Roy Belson]: But I think that it's going to be a little while before we start to see this take place and where it goes.

[Roy Belson]: Just a couple of quick things.

[Roy Belson]: You know, again, tomorrow at 1230 is groundbreaking at the Community Access Channel.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to be hosted in part

[Roy Belson]: by the mayor, by Lisa Hughes from Channel 4, Courtney Cox from Nessun, and a number of other people from the media coming to see us in action.

[Roy Belson]: It will be a good opportunity to see how this thing is progressing.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of good work is going on.

[Roy Belson]: The President-elect has named an incoming U.S.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Members of the committee.

[Roy Belson]: The advance of technology requires that we improve our policy with regard to use of technology.

[Roy Belson]: The current policy is attached to the cover page, it's called the acceptable use policy, but it's much thinner than the one that we have developed since that time.

[Roy Belson]: However, tonight we have Mr. Trotter and Mr. Arena with us who work on our technology.

[Roy Belson]: Alan is the network administrator, Richard is the

[Roy Belson]: Director of Media and Technology.

[Roy Belson]: But we'd like to table it tonight because some additional information has come to our attention from the ACLU and some other groups.

[Roy Belson]: We want to match up the information to make sure that we've covered all the bases and make sure that there's nothing that we've missed.

[Roy Belson]: We want to be careful that different groups have different issues.

[Roy Belson]: There are some other things that are moving forward, but we do want to address this as an issue.

[Roy Belson]: So, what you have in front of you, look it over and give us any feedback you have, and we will continue to research some of the latest stuff that's come out only this past week.

[Roy Belson]: and determine whether or not we've missed anything that we think should be included or something that should be worded differently.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Trotter and Mr. Arena are here if you have any preliminary questions, otherwise we recommend we lay it on the table.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, the conference was great, but our deputy superintendent is going to issue this report to you.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of attachments, and you'll find at the back there's also a financial accounting that was asked for at a previous meeting.

[Roy Belson]: Well, one of the things that, you know, was in here that you should notice is the fact that we've identified through tier 2 of the E-rate about 700,000, it could be as much as 800,000 that we can access.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll start applying for that after the first year when the window opens.

[Roy Belson]: And that's a match.

[Roy Belson]: That's 60 percent of the cost of what we pay.

[Roy Belson]: So we do our capital plan

[Roy Belson]: We can hope to get as much as $800,000 against the capital plan for technology enhancements, which will be well worth the thing.

[Roy Belson]: And then there's a couple of other technology items in here that also are fundable.

[Roy Belson]: So that was probably the biggest financial takeaway.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing was to look at roofing.

[Roy Belson]: I think I mentioned it here a little bit, because obviously we're looking at roofing going down the future.

[Roy Belson]: And some of the roofing applications now are

[Roy Belson]: very, very good and they're less expensive than some of the previous roofing and they can be done much more quickly.

[Roy Belson]: So becoming familiar with that is a real important thing.

[Roy Belson]: There are some legal things that are coming up that are really questionable that we need to get in front of.

[Roy Belson]: You know that we just had an election and that with that election, ESSA is going to be looked at by a new administration, how it's going to be implemented, how it's going to be changed.

[Roy Belson]: Some of those things were talked about in great length.

[Roy Belson]: There were things that are still unknown.

[Roy Belson]: You know, we just can't know, but people are speculating on them.

[Roy Belson]: So I think there's a lot of takeaways from this that you just can't do when you're not talking to people face to face.

[Roy Belson]: When you're talking to somebody over the telephone, the conversations, they're good, but they're not great.

[Roy Belson]: When you're talking to somebody face to face over a cup of coffee, you can get an awful lot of information, especially if they're working on this on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: I think we're making good progress.

[Roy Belson]: I think, you know, a couple of tweaks here and there, but I think we've broken through the initial gridlock of trying to get some of that stuff to happen.

[Roy Belson]: And I think you start to see things take fuller shape in the next little while.

[Roy Belson]: Elementary was going to be a little bit later because they're in a different position right now.

[Roy Belson]: They don't get report cards the same way the.

[Roy Belson]: The others do, but will roll that out fairly soon.

[Roy Belson]: I think Diane can answer that specifically.

[Roy Belson]: My pleasure.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee, as you know, the

[Roy Belson]: Marijuana question passed the ballot in this past November by about 54% of the voters who actually voted.

[Roy Belson]: And one of the big questions, obviously, is there isn't enough regulatory guidance.

[Roy Belson]: When you look at some of these ballot questions, they're very blunt instruments.

[Roy Belson]: They can only ask for one thing up or down.

[Roy Belson]: And they don't really spell out all the things that are inside that need to happen in order to make it work well.

[Roy Belson]: The Speaker of the House,

[Roy Belson]: Senate President and the Governor have all expressed their concerns, the Attorney General, about the lack of regulatory assistance that they have going forward.

[Roy Belson]: But they can't do much between now and January because they're in an informal session, and all you need is one legislator to object, and the matter can't be discussed.

[Roy Belson]: and obviously there are people that don't want to talk about it right now.

[Roy Belson]: So, I expect that in January, the legislature will take this up in earnest, and the governor will follow quickly, and there'll be a lot of support for regulatory help.

[Roy Belson]: Currently, it's under the state treasurer, Deborah Goldberg, for implementation, but it's unfunded.

[Roy Belson]: She has no funds for it, nor does she have any appointees to her commission, and this is scheduled to go into effect December 15th.

[Roy Belson]: So there's obviously some concerns about that.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of different concerns that we have.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, obviously the medical marijuana piece is better regulated and that's already in place.

[Roy Belson]: But the recreational marijuana issues are not regulated at this point.

[Roy Belson]: So what basically I'm saying, it's imperative that school committees, school officials urge the legislature and the governor to take the necessary action

[Roy Belson]: to prevent the misuse of this substance.

[Roy Belson]: You know, we talk about opiates, we talk about all these things.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I look at marijuana as a gateway drug.

[Roy Belson]: Especially when young people can get access to it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the minimum age is 21, but if a 21-year-old has it, I'm not sure that he or she is going to keep it from their friend who is 16 or 17.

[Roy Belson]: And I have a feeling that, you know, there were issues associated with that.

[Roy Belson]: So, here are some of the things that I would want to write to our legislators on behalf of the committee, and there may be others that we can add to it.

[Roy Belson]: The first is to provide a local opt-in provision.

[Roy Belson]: Right now it's opt-out.

[Roy Belson]: And in order to do it, you have to schedule a referendum vote that could be a year later.

[Roy Belson]: But I want to make them put it opt-in, which means you have to, as a community, decide to actually accept the rule for your community.

[Roy Belson]: That's one.

[Roy Belson]: It would mirror the Colorado law, which is currently in place, and we think that's a good piece to have.

[Roy Belson]: Seventy percent of the communities in Marijuana ban their local areas for distributing it, so that's just an idea.

[Roy Belson]: The second thing is substantially increase the tax rate.

[Roy Belson]: Right now it's 3.75.

[Roy Belson]: At that rate, while it might generate some money, it won't generate enough money for enforcement.

[Roy Belson]: It won't generate enough money for control.

[Roy Belson]: It won't generate enough money for data collection, for the kinds of things that have to go forward in order for us to modify and improve the law as we go forward.

[Roy Belson]: So, we think that the legislature should increase that tax, maybe even double it, in order to ensure that there's sufficient funds to regulate recreational marijuana.

[Roy Belson]: We think they should eliminate the home-grown provision.

[Roy Belson]: The provision as it currently stands will not adequately be enforced.

[Roy Belson]: Who's to know who's going to go in whose home to get warrants to go in people's homes to see if they've only got six plants, or how they're using it, or whether they're putting it in brownies, or whether they're putting in these kinds of things and distributing it in ways that cannot be easily detected.

[Roy Belson]: The other piece on this is that the way the marijuana is grown today,

[Roy Belson]: The intensity of it is much stronger than it was years ago.

[Roy Belson]: And we don't know if it's going to be spiced or spliced, if you will, with other substances in certain venues that may be at home.

[Roy Belson]: We can't control it.

[Roy Belson]: So we think the homegrown piece needs to be looked at in order for us to protect underage students and underage people, or anyone in particular.

[Roy Belson]: We think they need to strengthen the control commission to better understand the impact and to effectively regulate the industry.

[Roy Belson]: The commission should have a staff that collects data to inform future modifications that may be necessary to protect public safety.

[Roy Belson]: If you don't have data out there as to what's happening, whether there's connection between recreational marijuana use and other drug use, you don't know what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: You don't know if you're helping or hurting what's happening.

[Roy Belson]: So, the initiative petition process, like I say, can be a valuable part of the democratic system.

[Roy Belson]: However, it's a very blunt instrument and it needs to be refined.

[Roy Belson]: We obviously will respect the will of the people as we do with all initiative petitions, and the legislature very rarely overturns the will of the people.

[Roy Belson]: But there's no reason why they can't modify it and refine it, and I think the interest is there on the part of the leadership.

[Roy Belson]: So, what I'd like to do is draft a letter to our legislators on behalf of the committee and the school department administration with these suggestions, and hope that they will take action as swiftly as possible at the turn of the

[Roy Belson]: of the year when the legislature goes back into formal session.

[Roy Belson]: I can bring that to you.

[Roy Belson]: So, the state just released the disciplinary statistics from 2015-2016.

[Roy Belson]: Medford is well below the numbers for the state on average.

[Roy Belson]: I've given you some of the reports that I was able to download offline.

[Roy Belson]: We need to do a little bit more analysis, but we're well below.

[Roy Belson]: I gave you some categories that would give you some ideas about different areas, whether it be substance abuse, marijuana, physical theft or assault or anything of that type.

[Roy Belson]: for you to look over.

[Roy Belson]: We'll do a bigger report going forward but I wanted you to have something to look at.

[Roy Belson]: I think some of our initiatives in terms of providing additional programs for youngsters rather than sending them home have worked and will continue to work and we need to strengthen them going forward.

[Roy Belson]: But I think those things are positive steps for us and I think it shows in the results and we'll continue to show in the results going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Well, High Needs is a conglomerate group.

[Roy Belson]: It could be economically disadvantaged, it could be special needs, it could be ELL.

[Roy Belson]: It's a grouping that sort of is an omnibus for all the different groups that have been identified as disaggregated groups.

[Roy Belson]: And we try to

[Roy Belson]: I understand that, but sometimes it's hard to know who's in the group because you don't know who they've included in the group.

[Roy Belson]: But I think it's pretty much the youngsters who fall into groups like special needs, EOL, economically disadvantaged, and some other groups that might be lesser known.

[Roy Belson]: Sure, we will do that.

[Roy Belson]: And as you know, we've talked about this as adding programs, these opportunities for change and things like that.

[Roy Belson]: There are alternative insides which keep kids from being, let's say, sent home and given some additional help or counseling.

[Roy Belson]: That's what we're pushing towards.

[Roy Belson]: That's what we're going to try to keep doing.

[Roy Belson]: Budget's permitting, obviously, and I think that that's reflected in our numbers.

[Roy Belson]: That's why the emphasis on social emotional learning.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah.

[Roy Belson]: It was the opportunities for change program.

[Roy Belson]: Probably halfway through the year, let's give it a half a year to really

[Roy Belson]: – Sure.

[Roy Belson]: We will break it down further.

[Roy Belson]: This came out just at the end of the week, and we just sort of wanted to get it out because it was being announced.

[Roy Belson]: But at the same token, we have more time to break it down now.

[Roy Belson]: I received a number of phone calls from a number of you and others with regard to the election results that took place on November 8th.

[Roy Belson]: And school systems around the Commonwealth and around the country received multiple inquiries from parents and citizens regarding classroom discussions about the recent national election results.

[Roy Belson]: and concerns were raised about some teachers or staff who might introduce their personal opinions and feelings into what might be considered a very charged current topic leading to possible conflict.

[Roy Belson]: As we know, elections are a fundamental element of democracy.

[Roy Belson]: The process of elections and the substantive issues are a legitimate part of citizenship education.

[Roy Belson]: We can't eliminate either process or substance from our schools and our classrooms.

[Roy Belson]: Naturally, discussions must be age-appropriate and devoid of any hostility for expressions of opinion.

[Roy Belson]: There can be no discussions that are racist and discriminatory towards any group.

[Roy Belson]: and adult personnel must ensure that inappropriate comments are not introduced or perpetuated.

[Roy Belson]: So on Wednesday morning, November 9th, I sent out an email to principals, which is listed here, and I wanted to read it so the public did not see it, they understand this, because you've asked me sometimes, do people know this?

[Roy Belson]: And we try to put it out, but obviously not everybody reads everything that we have.

[Roy Belson]: So I wrote, colleagues, last evening citizens elected a new president of our country.

[Roy Belson]: I recognize this election was extremely contentious and polarizing.

[Roy Belson]: Undoubtedly, there were many strong feelings among faculty, staff, and students.

[Roy Belson]: It's extremely important that we do not engage in divisive discussions that can inflame feelings and behaviors.

[Roy Belson]: As educators, we must strive to help our students understand that we have a democratic process and that we need to go forward in a constructive way to support our country and our own people.

[Roy Belson]: There's no room for hate messaging.

[Roy Belson]: Our students must learn that in this country we accept the constitutional process that transfers power after a legitimate election.

[Roy Belson]: This does not mean there can be no discussion of the election.

[Roy Belson]: Any discussion must be respectful and constructive.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you for your attention to this guidance, and I signed it.

[Roy Belson]: Our principals were expected to instruct their faculty and staff of the above expectation, and I have not received any

[Roy Belson]: information from principles that inappropriate discussions have taken place in our classrooms at this time.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll continue to emphasize this.

[Roy Belson]: We'll continue to allow people to discuss the electoral process.

[Roy Belson]: They want to discuss the electoral college.

[Roy Belson]: They want to discuss

[Roy Belson]: Popular votes, they want to discuss states, they want to look at reasons why people vote, that's one thing.

[Roy Belson]: But there's no room in the schools, in the classroom for adult personnel to encourage students to be hostile about any result or in the light we have, we have to get on with business.

[Roy Belson]: So that's the message that's out there and we'll continue to monitor what takes place over the next while.

[Roy Belson]: You know, it's going to be June 7th.

[Roy Belson]: By the way, we do this in part this early, and I'll tell you why we do it.

[Roy Belson]: Not only to help people plan, but once we lock into a date, if it snows, we still can get the days in, you know, even if the

[Roy Belson]: They're on 12 days between graduation and the last day for seniors.

[Roy Belson]: So we walk in with the state in case we have extra snow days and the like.

[Roy Belson]: That's why we do it so quickly.

[Roy Belson]: So by our rules, people who have extended use of our facilities can negotiate some of the rates.

[Roy Belson]: That's by our rules.

[Roy Belson]: And so we take about $60,000 a year from them.

[Roy Belson]: for about five sessions of, you know, maybe 20 courses that are run during the year.

[Roy Belson]: So that's pretty consistent with what, you know, our revenue would be.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, we obviously update it over time as they use facilities.

[Roy Belson]: If they use more facilities, we'll charge them more.

[Roy Belson]: If they use less, we'll obviously modify it down.

[Roy Belson]: So we consider that, you know, consistent.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, at this point in time, I don't think there's anyone in our faculty or administration that's actually teaching a course right now.

[Roy Belson]: So I mean, it happens sporadically, but if it happens, it could happen.

[Roy Belson]: No, same thing.

[Roy Belson]: The only contact that we do with them is through our offices to set up the contract for use.

[Roy Belson]: And then after that,

[Roy Belson]: If they want someone, and the person has to be selected by them, by the way.

[Roy Belson]: We don't have any, let's say, ability to influence who they select.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't tell them who can teach.

[Roy Belson]: Who can't teach.

[Roy Belson]: Just a couple of quick things.

[Roy Belson]: I want to pass this out to each of you.

[Roy Belson]: This is a, something that I, let me pass it down, something that I acquired yesterday when I was in Newport.

[Roy Belson]: It's a good timing kind of thing because what it is is a letter from George Washington to the first Jewish synagogue in America in Newport, Rhode Island, but there's also references to Washington speaking to other congregations of other denominations in 1890, 1790 rather.

[Roy Belson]: Washington at the time was asked whether or not there would be any discrimination in America against religion.

[Roy Belson]: And if you read the letter from Washington, which is perhaps one of the most famous letters of all time, and I wanted to share it with you because I've got copies, he basically said that in this country, you're going to get the actual wording,

[Roy Belson]: that there would be no, you know, toleration of bigotry, and there would be no allowance for discrimination.

[Roy Belson]: And it's a very useful kind of thing because it predates the signing of the Bill of Rights by one year.

[Roy Belson]: In 18, not 18, I keep saying 18, 1791, New Jersey, on the same date as yesterday, the 19th of November,

[Roy Belson]: was the first state to sign the Bill of Rights.

[Roy Belson]: And as we go through a period where we sometimes hear people saying things, you know, about hatred and other issues that we talked about tonight, it goes right back to George Washington, who says basically, for happily the government of the United States will give no bigotry, will give bigotry no sanction, and to persecution no assistance.

[Roy Belson]: requires that only they who live under its protection should demean themselves as good citizens in giving all the occasions of their effectual support."

[Roy Belson]: So he's basically saying, no bigotry, no discrimination.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it's absolutely totally appropriate at this time as we see some of the hateful activity that sometimes has found its way into our country in recent times.

[Roy Belson]: So I just thought you might enjoy it.

[Roy Belson]: It's also some listings of other congregations that he spoke to.

[Roy Belson]: It's quite impressive that this place survived as long as it is in its original form, pretty much original form, going through several periods where it was not allowed to exist by different groups, by the British and by others.

[Roy Belson]: So just something that you might have and could use.

[Roy Belson]: in your work.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing that I just want to mention is in your folder.

[Roy Belson]: Susan Altman, who did the mural at the Roberts, also did a mural for the Family Network recently.

[Roy Belson]: Gorgeous, beautiful.

[Roy Belson]: When you get a chance, go take a look at it.

[Roy Belson]: The kids did the mural.

[Roy Belson]: She guided the mural, and it was really terrific.

[Roy Belson]: I saw it the other day, and really, it shows a transformation of, you know,

[Roy Belson]: How things work, how families work and transform themselves, how communities transform themselves.

[Roy Belson]: It's quite something to be seen and it will be displayed in the family network in this hole in the wall that they had.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, some of those things were talked about in great length.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, there are things that are still unknown.

[Roy Belson]: When you're talking to somebody over the telephone, the conversations, they're good, but they're not great.

[Roy Belson]: elementary elementary, you know, it was going to be a little bit later because they're in a different position right now.

[Roy Belson]: They don't get report cards the same way the, uh, the others do, but, uh, we'll roll that out, uh, fairly soon.

[Roy Belson]: I think Diane can answer that specifically.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee.

[Roy Belson]: Um, as you know, the,

[Roy Belson]: Marijuana question passed the ballot in this past November by about 54% of the voters who actually voted.

[Roy Belson]: And one of the big questions, obviously, is there isn't enough regulatory guidance.

[Roy Belson]: When you look at some of these ballot questions, they're very blunt instruments.

[Roy Belson]: They can only ask for one thing up or down.

[Roy Belson]: And they don't really spell out all the things that are inside that need to happen in order to make it work well.

[Roy Belson]: The Speaker of the House, the Senate President, and the Governor have all expressed their concerns, the Attorney General.

[Roy Belson]: about the lack of regulatory assistance that they have going forward.

[Roy Belson]: But they can't do much between now and January because they're in an informal session and all you need is one legislator to object and the matter can't be discussed.

[Roy Belson]: And obviously there are people that don't want to talk about it right now.

[Roy Belson]: So I expect that in January, uh, the legislature will take this up in earnest and the governor will fall quickly and there'll be a lot of support for regulatory, uh,

[Roy Belson]: help.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, currently it's under the state treasurer, Deborah Goldberg for implementation, but it's unfunded.

[Roy Belson]: She has no funds for it in order.

[Roy Belson]: She have any appointees to her commission and this is scheduled to go in effect December 15th.

[Roy Belson]: So

[Roy Belson]: There's obviously some concerns about that.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of different concerns that we have.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, obviously, the medical marijuana piece is better regulated, and that's already in place.

[Roy Belson]: But the recreational marijuana issues are not regulated at this point.

[Roy Belson]: So what basically I'm saying, it's imperative that school committees, school officials urge the legislature and the governor to take the necessary action to prevent the misuse of this substance.

[Roy Belson]: You know, we talk about opiates, we talk about all these things.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I look at marijuana as a gateway drug, especially when young people can get access to it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, the minimum age is 21, but if a 21-year-old has it, I'm not sure that he or she is going to keep it from their friend who is 16 or 17.

[Roy Belson]: And I have a feeling that

[Roy Belson]: You know, there were issues associated with that.

[Roy Belson]: So here are some of the things that I would want to write to our legislators on behalf of the committee.

[Roy Belson]: And there may be others that we can add to it.

[Roy Belson]: And the first is to provide a local opt-in provision.

[Roy Belson]: Right now, it's opt-out.

[Roy Belson]: And in order to do it, you have to schedule a referendum vote that could be a year later.

[Roy Belson]: But I want to make them put it opt-in, which means you have to, as a community, decide to actually accept the rule for your community.

[Roy Belson]: That's one.

[Roy Belson]: It would mirror the Colorado law, which is currently in place, and we think that's a good piece to have.

[Roy Belson]: 70% of the communities in Marijuana ban their local areas for distributing it, so that's just an idea.

[Roy Belson]: The second thing is substantially increase the tax rate.

[Roy Belson]: Right now it's 3.75.

[Roy Belson]: At that rate, while it might generate some money, it won't generate enough money for enforcement.

[Roy Belson]: It won't generate enough money for control.

[Roy Belson]: It won't generate enough money for data collection, for the kinds of things that have to go forward in order for us to modify and improve the law as we go forward.

[Roy Belson]: So we think that the legislature should increase that tax, maybe even double it, in order to ensure that there's sufficient funds to regulate recreational marijuana.

[Roy Belson]: We think they should eliminate the homegrown provision.

[Roy Belson]: The provision as it currently stands will not adequately be enforced.

[Roy Belson]: Who's to know who's going to go in whose home, and to get warrants to go in people's homes to see if they've only got six plants, or how they're using it, or whether they're putting it in brownies, or whether they're putting in these kinds of things and distributing it in ways that cannot be easily detected.

[Roy Belson]: The other piece on this is that the way the marijuana is grown today,

[Roy Belson]: The intensity of it is much stronger than it was years ago.

[Roy Belson]: And we don't know if it's going to be spiced or spliced, if you will, with other substances in certain venues that may be at home.

[Roy Belson]: We can't control it.

[Roy Belson]: So we think the homegrown piece needs to be looked at in order for us to protect underage students and underage people.

[Roy Belson]: or anyone in particular.

[Roy Belson]: We think they need to strengthen the Control Commission to better understand the impact and to effectively regulate the industry.

[Roy Belson]: The Commission should have a staff that collects data to inform future modifications that may be necessary to protect public safety.

[Roy Belson]: If you don't have data out there as to what's happening, whether there's connection between recreational marijuana use and other drug use, you don't know what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: You don't know if you're helping or hurting what's happening.

[Roy Belson]: So the initiative petition process, like I say, can be a valuable part of the democratic system.

[Roy Belson]: However, it's a very blunt instrument, and it needs to be refined.

[Roy Belson]: We obviously

[Roy Belson]: will respect the will of the people, as we do with all initiative petitions.

[Roy Belson]: And the legislature very rarely overturns the will of the people.

[Roy Belson]: But there's no reason why they can't modify it and refine it.

[Roy Belson]: And I think the interest is there on the part of the leadership.

[Roy Belson]: So what I'd like to do is draft a letter to our legislators on behalf of the committee and the school department administration with these suggestions and hope that they will take action as swiftly as possible at the turn of the year when the legislature goes back into formal session.

[Roy Belson]: I can bring that to you.

[Roy Belson]: So the state just released the disciplinary statistics from 2015-2016.

[Roy Belson]: Medford is well below the numbers for the state on average.

[Roy Belson]: I've given you some of the reports that I was able to download offline.

[Roy Belson]: We need to do a little bit more analysis, but we're well below.

[Roy Belson]: I gave you some categories that would give you some ideas about different areas, whether it be substance abuse, marijuana, physical theft or assault or anything of that type for you to look over.

[Roy Belson]: We'll do a bigger report going forward, but I wanted you to have something to look at.

[Roy Belson]: I think some of our initiatives in terms of providing additional programs for youngsters, rather than sending them home, have worked.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll continue to work, and we need to strengthen them going forward.

[Roy Belson]: But I think those things are positive steps for us, and I think it shows in the results, and we'll continue to show in the results going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Well, high needs as a, as a conglomerate group, it could be economically disadvantaged.

[Roy Belson]: It could be special needs could be ELL.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, it's, it's a grouping that sort of as an omnibus for all the different groups that are identified as disaggregated groups.

[Roy Belson]: And, uh, we try to, uh,

[Roy Belson]: you know, understand that.

[Roy Belson]: But sometimes it's hard to know who's in the group because you don't know who they've included in the group.

[Roy Belson]: But I think it's pretty much the youngsters who fall into groups like special needs, EOL, economically disadvantaged and some other groups that might be lesser known.

[Roy Belson]: We will do that.

[Roy Belson]: And as you know, we've talked about this as adding programs, these, you know, opportunities for opportunities for change and things like that.

[Roy Belson]: There are alternative insights which keep kids from being, let's say sent home and given some additional help or counseling.

[Roy Belson]: So that's what we're pushing towards.

[Roy Belson]: That's what we're going to try to keep doing.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, budgets permitting obviously.

[Roy Belson]: And, uh, I think that that,

[Roy Belson]: reflected in our numbers.

[Roy Belson]: You know probably halfway through the year Let's give it a half a year to really

[Roy Belson]: Sure.

[Roy Belson]: We will break it down further.

[Roy Belson]: This came out just at the end of the week, and we just sort of wanted to get it out because it was being announced.

[Roy Belson]: But at the same token, we have more time to break it down now.

[Roy Belson]: So I received a number of phone calls from a number of you and others with regard to the election results that took place on November 8th.

[Roy Belson]: And school systems around the Commonwealth and around the country received multiple inquiries from parents and citizens regarding classroom discussions about the recent national election results.

[Roy Belson]: And concerns were raised about some teachers or staff who might introduce their personal opinions and feelings into what might be considered a very charged current

[Roy Belson]: topic leading to possible conflict.

[Roy Belson]: As we know, elections are a fundamental element of democracy.

[Roy Belson]: The process of elections and the substantive issues are a legitimate part of citizenship education.

[Roy Belson]: We can't eliminate either process or substance from our schools and our classrooms.

[Roy Belson]: And naturally, discussions must be age appropriate and devoid of any hostility for expressions of opinion.

[Roy Belson]: There can be no discussions that are racist and discriminatory towards any group.

[Roy Belson]: And adult personnel must ensure that inappropriate comments are not introduced or perpetuated.

[Roy Belson]: So on Wednesday morning, November 9th, I sent out an email to principals, which is listed here, and I wanted to read it so if the public did not see it, they understand, because you've asked me sometimes.

[Roy Belson]: Do people know this?

[Roy Belson]: I mean, we try to put it out, but obviously not everybody reads everything that we have.

[Roy Belson]: So I wrote, colleagues, last evening, citizens elected a new president of our country.

[Roy Belson]: I recognize this election was extremely contentious and polarizing.

[Roy Belson]: Undoubtedly, there are many strong feelings among faculty, staff, and students.

[Roy Belson]: It's extremely important that we do not engage in divisive discussions that can inflame feelings and behaviors.

[Roy Belson]: As educators, we must strive to help our students understand

[Roy Belson]: that we have a democratic process and that we need to go forward in a constructive way to support our country and our people.

[Roy Belson]: There's no room for hate messaging.

[Roy Belson]: Our students must learn that in this country, we accept the constitutional process that transfers power after a legitimate election.

[Roy Belson]: This does not mean there can be no discussion of the election.

[Roy Belson]: Any discussion must be respectful and constructive.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you for your attention to this guidance, and I signed it.

[Roy Belson]: Our principals were expected to instruct their faculty and staff of the above expectation.

[Roy Belson]: And I've not received any information from principals that inappropriate discussions have taken place in our classrooms at this time.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll continue to emphasize this.

[Roy Belson]: We'll continue to allow people to discuss the electoral process.

[Roy Belson]: They want to discuss the electoral college.

[Roy Belson]: They want to discuss popular votes.

[Roy Belson]: They want to discuss states.

[Roy Belson]: They want to look at reasons why people vote.

[Roy Belson]: That's one thing.

[Roy Belson]: But there's no room in the schools, in the classroom for adult personnel to encourage students to be hostile about any result or in the light we have, we have to get on with business.

[Roy Belson]: So that's the message that's out there and we'll continue to monitor what takes place over the next while.

[Roy Belson]: June 7th at the Gancher.

[Roy Belson]: By the way, we do this in part this early, and I'll tell you why we do it.

[Roy Belson]: Not only to help people plan, but once we walk into a day, if it snows, we still can get the days in, you know, even if the even if the there aren't 12 days between graduation and the last day for seniors.

[Roy Belson]: So we walk in with the state in case we have extra snow days and the like.

[Roy Belson]: That's why we do it so quickly.

[Roy Belson]: So you have a copy of it, you know, that you requested this and it takes a while for us to get answers from ethics, but there was a question about a potential conflict of interest in regards to American International College, AIC.

[Roy Belson]: So by our rules, people who have extended use of our facilities can negotiate some of the rates, that's by our rules.

[Roy Belson]: And so we take about $60,000 a year from them

[Roy Belson]: for about five sessions of maybe 20 courses that are run during the year.

[Roy Belson]: So that's pretty consistent with what our revenue would be.

[Roy Belson]: And we obviously update it over time as they use facilities.

[Roy Belson]: If they use more facilities, we'll charge them more.

[Roy Belson]: If they use less, we'll obviously modify it down.

[Roy Belson]: So we consider that consistent.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, at this point in time, I don't think there's anyone in our faculty or administration that's actually teaching a course right now.

[Roy Belson]: So I mean, it happens sporadically, but if it happens, it could happen.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, same thing.

[Roy Belson]: The only contact that we do with them is through our offices to set up the contract for use.

[Roy Belson]: And then after that,

[Roy Belson]: If they want someone or the person has to be selected by them, by the way, we don't have any, any, let's say ability to influence who they select.

[Roy Belson]: You know, so I don't tell them who to tell you who can teach.

[Roy Belson]: Just a couple of quick things.

[Roy Belson]: Um, I want to pass this out to each of you.

[Roy Belson]: Um, this is a, um, something that I want to pass it down.

[Roy Belson]: Something that I acquired yesterday when I was in Newport.

[Roy Belson]: Um,

[Roy Belson]: It's a good timing kind of thing, because what it is is a letter from George Washington to the first Jewish synagogue in America in Newport, Rhode Island.

[Roy Belson]: But there's also references to Washington speaking to other congregations of other denominations in 1890, 1790, rather.

[Roy Belson]: It's particularly appropriate because Washington at the time was asked whether or not there would be any discrimination in America against religion.

[Roy Belson]: And if you read the letter from Washington, which is perhaps one of the most famous letters of all time, and I wanted to share it with you because I've got copies, he basically said that in this country, he's going to get the actual

[Roy Belson]: wording that there would be no toleration of bigotry and there would be no allowance for discrimination.

[Roy Belson]: And it's a very useful kind of thing because it predates the signing of the Bill of Rights by one year.

[Roy Belson]: In 1791, New Jersey, on the same date as yesterday, the 19th of November, was the first state to sign the Bill of Rights.

[Roy Belson]: And as we go through a period where we sometimes hear people saying things about hatred and other issues that we talked about tonight, it goes right back to George Washington, who says basically,

[Roy Belson]: For happily, the government of the United States will give bigotry no sanction, and to persecution no assistance.

[Roy Belson]: It requires that only they who live under its protection should demean themselves as good citizens in giving all the occasions of their effectual support."

[Roy Belson]: So he's basically saying, no bigotry, no discrimination.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it's absolutely totally appropriate at this time as we see some of the hateful activity that sometimes has found its way

[Roy Belson]: into our country in recent times.

[Roy Belson]: So I just thought you might enjoy it.

[Roy Belson]: It's also some listings of other congregations that he spoke to.

[Roy Belson]: It's quite impressive that this place survived as long as it is in its original form, pretty much original form, going through several periods where it was not allowed to exist by different groups, by the British and by others.

[Roy Belson]: So just something that you might have and could use

[Roy Belson]: in your work.

[Roy Belson]: Another thing that I just want to mention is in your folder.

[Roy Belson]: Gorgeous, beautiful.

[Roy Belson]: When you get a chance, go take a look at it.

[Roy Belson]: The kids did the mural.

[Roy Belson]: She guided the mural.

[Roy Belson]: And it was really terrific.
