[Roy Belson]: There were 88 different colleges and institutions represented.

[Roy Belson]: The place was packed.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of people participated.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of work goes into it.

[Roy Belson]: This has been going on for many, many years, and it's really critical that our young people get a good start to find out what their options are, to talk to the different representatives about financial aid, what they can do.

[Roy Belson]: to move forward.

[Roy Belson]: There was also a presentation by Jan Hollenbeck and Charlotte Hyam with regard to special needs students who would like to go to higher education and accommodation plans and how to access those as well.

[Roy Belson]: Alice Beth Fitzpatrick from the Voc Guidance Department.

[Roy Belson]: I did a piece on transition to college.

[Roy Belson]: And there's a lot of other pieces that go into it besides just simply the booths.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it's one of the most successful nights we run because people really participate, they really learn a lot, and they come away with a better sense of what they have to do to prepare for college.

[Roy Belson]: College is not cheap.

[Roy Belson]: So you've got to make the right decisions, things that are going to work for you, and you've got to plan well ahead.

[Roy Belson]: So I think this is a great night.

[Roy Belson]: It was another good example of people at work, and Amelia and her staff did a great job.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee and ladies and gentlemen, Massachusetts Association of School Superintendents each year

[Roy Belson]: recognizes outstanding students in each community for which there is a superintendent who is a member of mass.

[Roy Belson]: Now,

[Roy Belson]: These awards are not given lightly, they're given to individuals who have not only accomplished academic excellence, but have done other terrific things in their school environments.

[Roy Belson]: So this evening we have two presentations, one to a member of Medford High School, and one to a member of the Medford Vocational Technical High School, both seniors and both outstanding individuals.

[Roy Belson]: So at this time, it's my great pleasure to read you about the first one, and then we'll bring that person up, and then we'll do the second, and do the same.

[Roy Belson]: The first individual is a member of the class of 2017 at Medford High School.

[Roy Belson]: He is a consistent honor roll student with a GPA of 4.07.

[Roy Belson]: Zachary is interested in environmental studies and plans to apply to several small colleges for environmental programs.

[Roy Belson]: At Medford High School, he is the captain of the swim team, a former member of the crew team, as well as a member of the Roots and Shoots Club, which works for environmental change in the school and community.

[Roy Belson]: He is a member of the Mustang of the Fells Club, which promotes outdoor education.

[Roy Belson]: He participated in the Brainstart Entrepreneurship Program last year at MHS, and is a past Triple Crown award winner for outstanding academic and civic achievements at Medford High School.

[Roy Belson]: Zachary is a runner who participated in the Medford Jingle Bells run fundraiser and last year ran the Burlington Marathon.

[Roy Belson]: In addition to his sports and clubs, Zachary works at the Medford High School pool as a lifeguard.

[Roy Belson]: Ladies and gentlemen, it's my distinct pleasure to call up for your recognition, Zachary Mafia.

[Roy Belson]: Zachary Rice.

[Roy Belson]: Congratulations, Zach.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Our next award winner is from the Medford Vocational Technical High School.

[Roy Belson]: This individual is a senior in the Construction Craft Laborers and is ranked number two in the senior class.

[Roy Belson]: A hard worker and always eager to learn, she has spent the last three years learning many skills in the construction and carpentry field.

[Roy Belson]: Last year she was a medal winner in masonry at the Regional Skills USA competition.

[Roy Belson]: She spent the summer working with a general contractor and recently was hired at Cleveland Fence Company in Stoneham, Massachusetts, where she will work in a cooperative education job.

[Roy Belson]: Her teachers report that during his time at MHS, he had been a consistent and committed student and a great asset to the Construction Craft Laborers Program.

[Roy Belson]: Long-term goal is to become a general contractor.

[Roy Belson]: Immediate goals are to join and work for construction or carpentry union while pursuing a degree in construction management.

[Roy Belson]: It's our pleasure to introduce Valerie Sajud.

[Roy Belson]: Valerie?

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll make sure that it's presented and that individual is duly recognized.

[Roy Belson]: This report was basically a follow-up on things that we didn't cover in the first time.

[Roy Belson]: We did give you a report

[Roy Belson]: You report here, you've got this last piece here which does that.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you can see this in this in these charts.

[Roy Belson]: That's where that's right.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: We can do that.

[Roy Belson]: We're working on that now.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: What the state has done is they've created a high-needs category.

[Roy Belson]: And in that category, an individual might fit in more than one activity.

[Roy Belson]: A youngster might be a person who doesn't speak English as a first language, might be special needs, and might also be economically disadvantaged.

[Roy Belson]: So one person might be in three categories, multiple categories.

[Roy Belson]: So you could find that, you know,

[Roy Belson]: Different scores, different activities are skewed by the fact that an individual repeats themselves in multiple categories.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to break those out periodically as we go just to see exactly what's the dominant category that's driving a particular result.

[Roy Belson]: So high needs is sort of an accumulation or cumulative amount of all the students who fall into any one of those categories as opposed to one.

[Roy Belson]: So 50% would be too high.

[Roy Belson]: I want to look at the latest because basically the other thing that took place is Title I, which normally defined economically disadvantaged, the rule was changed.

[Roy Belson]: And because it was changed, the numbers came way down and it affected communities across the state.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't want to speculate at this point in time, but we certainly are going to break it out.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, disproportionality or what they call prima facie denial in some instances.

[Roy Belson]: There is a tendency in school districts across and almost any institution if a youngster is not doing well.

[Roy Belson]: som kan spekulerar om om det är en ungdom som har en lärnings- eller språkbaserad ungdom, om det är en temporär distraktion som ungdom har, eller om det är en familjedysfunktion, eller om det är andra saker som händer i deras liv.

[Roy Belson]: Så det är väldigt svårt att veta om identifikationen är 100%.

[Roy Belson]: Men vi må klart betala mycket att sikta på att ungdom som inte pratar engelsk som den första språken,

[Roy Belson]: som som som som som som som som som som som

[Roy Belson]: Well, the gap is between the youngsters who don't necessarily fall into these subgroup categories and those youngsters who do.

[Roy Belson]: Det är viktigt att nåta, och det kom ut i vårt sista samarbete, att Medfords uppnivån i dessa subgrupper var eller ökade statens mängder i varje av dessa kategorier.

[Roy Belson]: Så vad det verkligen betyder, det är om staten använder ett instrument som propertiskt analyserar den tillräcklige utvecklingen av dessa ungdomar.

[Roy Belson]: Är det rejält att ge ungdomar en test i engelsk?

[Roy Belson]: in their first year in this country not speaking English.

[Roy Belson]: And then trying to determine whether this youngster knows enough.

[Roy Belson]: I think that the assessment system really deserves a work over because it's inappropriate to ask youngsters to do things for which they are not particularly good at it at this point in their life because of their genesis, where they are at that point in time.

[Roy Belson]: So a youngster who might be progressing at a nice level for

[Roy Belson]: his or her situation might take an extra year or two to get to that level.

[Roy Belson]: What's wrong with that?

[Roy Belson]: The goal is to get to the achievement level as much as possible, and if it takes a little longer, fine.

[Roy Belson]: Some people learn faster, some people learn slower.

[Roy Belson]: Some people are more skilled in a mathematical area, some people are more skilled in a language area.

[Roy Belson]: And so we need to have a better assessment system than the vanilla that we're getting right now

[Roy Belson]: and that's going to be a topic of discussion among superintendents, school committee members, and others as we approach our meetings coming forward.

[Roy Belson]: ESSA, and we'll have that discussion tonight as part of it, makes some changes in NCLB, but not enough.

[Roy Belson]: So let me make a suggestion.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of material here.

[Roy Belson]: It can't be discussed in the robust way it needs to be discussed in a forum like this because, you know, there's too much involved.

[Roy Belson]: Schedule a committee of the whole meeting.

[Roy Belson]: Let's get to it.

[Roy Belson]: We'll get in the background and then we can decide which items

[Roy Belson]: can be done in what sequence and where.

[Roy Belson]: But if we do try to do it here, we'll be back and forth for a long period of time and it's not really going to do it.

[Roy Belson]: So, let's schedule a committee of the whole meeting, let's look at some dates and I'll get back to you with some possible dates and we can do that.

[Roy Belson]: Well, it's happening in one school, but remember, we're asking our faculty and people to do an awful lot right now.

[Roy Belson]: They're taking school brains, they're doing a million different workshops,

[Roy Belson]: They've also got to teach their classes.

[Roy Belson]: I want to make sure that we sit down and we actually roll things out in a very very digestible way and we get everybody on board.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise we're just running a program and it won't work, it won't stick.

[Roy Belson]: So let's have a meeting, let's go over it, let's decide how we can roll things out intelligently.

[Roy Belson]: Let's see which things can be integrated with other initiatives that are already going on.

[Roy Belson]: I think we're in a better place if we do that.

[Roy Belson]: Principals have a certain amount of autonomy to do things that respond to what they see in their buildings.

[Roy Belson]: But when someone does something and it works, we're naturally interested in it.

[Roy Belson]: But what works in one building may not work in another.

[Roy Belson]: We just need to talk about it.

[Roy Belson]: That's all.

[Roy Belson]: Again, principals have a certain amount of autonomy.

[Roy Belson]: We don't micromanage everything that happens every day in the buildings.

[Roy Belson]: We let people do some of the things that they think are appropriate.

[Roy Belson]: You know, and when it becomes something that the whole district is interested in, then maybe we bring it here.

[Roy Belson]: We could be talking about every program.

[Roy Belson]: Not every school had a mock election.

[Roy Belson]: Not every school had another thing going on.

[Roy Belson]: Schools have their own identities.

[Roy Belson]: We want them to have their own identities.

[Roy Belson]: I think you've got a lot going on right now.

[Roy Belson]: I'll get back to you with dates.

[Roy Belson]: To just simply get it in just to get it in is not, I don't think, productive.

[Roy Belson]: Certainly, certainly.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, we're going to call on our assistant superintendent, Diane Caldwell, to talk about this report.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you, Madam Mayor and members of the committee.

[Roy Belson]: Tony Vento is with us this evening, and we'll just go through some of it.

[Roy Belson]: If you have any specific questions, Tony is here to answer.

[Roy Belson]: I provide you with documents that have been produced and gone out to parents.

[Roy Belson]: From the outset, we've worked closely with MassDPH, with the Medford Board of Health.

[Roy Belson]: We appreciate all their help.

[Roy Belson]: They've done a great job right on the spot, helping us right away, making sure we did things the way we needed to, as well as our own medical team under Tony's direction here at the schools.

[Roy Belson]: On Wednesday, October 26th, there will be a TB testing of individuals who have been identified as being in close contact with the individual who was diagnosed with TB.

[Roy Belson]: There were 194 MHS students who were identified, 5 middle school students, and 14 adult personnel.

[Roy Belson]: On the 20th, in the Cowan Theater, we will have a public information night available to everyone from 7 o'clock on,

[Roy Belson]: to answer any questions that anyone might have.

[Roy Belson]: Individuals may choose to have the test conducted by their own physician, and then we would ask them to provide us with the information that would indicate that it was done.

[Roy Belson]: If there is a finding, then there would be some follow-up antibiotic activity.

[Roy Belson]: If there is no finding, it would be a second round of testing during the winter period to see if something emerged subsequent to.

[Roy Belson]: Since the original case was diagnosed, there have been no further identifications, and the DPH procedure has been followed precisely to ensure due diligence.

[Roy Belson]: We have letters here, but I'm happy to take any questions or have the questions referred to Tony, so that if you have any

[Roy Belson]: gaps in your understanding of what's taken place, we can answer them this evening.

[Roy Belson]: And then again, on the 20th, we encourage anyone who really has some questions.

[Roy Belson]: I have not received a lot of phone calls.

[Roy Belson]: I did originally receive the handful.

[Roy Belson]: I know Tony received a handful, but once they were done, it was pretty quiet, and most people were satisfied with the information they received.

[Roy Belson]: But Tony is here and you might want to direct questions to him.

[Roy Belson]: No, there's no payment.

[Roy Belson]: If they go to health insurance, which they should have, that would cover it.

[Roy Belson]: That's one of those things that's covered by health insurance.

[Roy Belson]: And if they come through us, there's no charge whatsoever.

[Roy Belson]: So as you know, No Child Left Behind has been replaced by Every Student Succeeds Act.

[Roy Belson]: And that legislation begins in 2016-2017 as a transition year, with full implementation in 2017-2018.

[Roy Belson]: Now, there are several key elements of the Act.

[Roy Belson]: I want to give you enough of it so you understand it, but not so much that you, you know, get overwhelmed by it because there's an awful lot of pieces and we'll have to break it down piece at a time in order for it to really be understood.

[Roy Belson]: ESSA comprises nine title grants which provide funding to districts and states.

[Roy Belson]: Currently, there are about five or six.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not sure how we count them these days because they keep putting them together.

[Roy Belson]: Title IV grant represents a new funding source, which is an allocation grant for districts in the area of student support services, something that would speak to some of the discussion we had a little bit earlier.

[Roy Belson]: Districts and states are required to conform to the requirements of ESSA, so that No Child Left Behind is now giving way to ESSA and districts and states now must adopt ESSA rules.

[Roy Belson]: ESSA encourages state agencies to think differently about how best to support low-performing schools as the school improvement grants are no longer available.

[Roy Belson]: So they're asking the department

[Roy Belson]: Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to talk to us about how we could best benefit from their help.

[Roy Belson]: That should be a very robust discussion, especially in our conference and so on and so forth going forward.

[Roy Belson]: ESSA minimizes Title I prescriptive school and district accountability requirements.

[Roy Belson]: No Child Left Behind had very, very specific things under Title I. ESSA wiped some of it away, but it adds some things that are interesting too.

[Roy Belson]: Equitable access is perhaps one of the biggest areas.

[Roy Belson]: What is equitable access?

[Roy Belson]: Does it mean every school gets the same thing?

[Roy Belson]: Does it mean it's based on proportion of low income?

[Roy Belson]: Is it based on proportion of high needs?

[Roy Belson]: What is it?

[Roy Belson]: Equitable doesn't automatically mean things.

[Roy Belson]: What if you have a teacher in a school who makes $80,000 a year and a teacher makes $60,000 a year?

[Roy Belson]: Is it different or is it the same thing as long as there's a teacher there who's experienced and can do the job?

[Roy Belson]: Those things are yet to be fleshed out.

[Roy Belson]: And it's problematic because naturally we hire teachers at different stages of their career.

[Roy Belson]: And a lot of it's based on, you know, how many years they've been with us and what their degrees are.

[Roy Belson]: That doesn't necessarily mean they're better or worse at what they will do.

[Roy Belson]: There's a shift in focus on the Title II program from highly qualified to reporting on student learning experience.

[Roy Belson]: Instead of determining just the teachers are highly qualified, the question will be, what have the students learned?

[Roy Belson]: They have to give us some rubrics to determine that going forward.

[Roy Belson]: It focuses mostly on quality access to education, access to quality education.

[Roy Belson]: DESE is going to continue to collect certain data, but it doesn't mean it's going to have a particular impact on what we do or don't do.

[Roy Belson]: Inexperienced teachers will be expected to do different things, but we haven't got guidelines yet.

[Roy Belson]: Total funding for this year has been about the same, a little bit different, with a larger shift in Title IV student support money.

[Roy Belson]: The federal government has readjusted funding levels and our state will receive less money.

[Roy Belson]: The state receives less money, our district receives less money.

[Roy Belson]: In most cases, not always.

[Roy Belson]: Desi does not have the FY18 budget, and they're likely not to know for quite a while as to how much money will or won't be there.

[Roy Belson]: Of course, you know, with an election year, Congress, who knows what Congress will appropriate and what they won't appropriate until the election actually takes place and we determine who chairs which committees and who's in the White House.

[Roy Belson]: It maintains a lot of the requirements under the 1965 Act, Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, the original one.

[Roy Belson]: There's some innovative assessment encouragement that will be there.

[Roy Belson]: The definition of supplement versus supplant has changed.

[Roy Belson]: That's another little thing we've got to get a good handle on.

[Roy Belson]: What does it mean to add to something versus to shift the burden from the locality to the feds?

[Roy Belson]: Something that comes up all the time.

[Roy Belson]: We're hopeful that we'll get clarity on this sooner rather than later so we can plan.

[Roy Belson]: The problem with some of these things is we don't find out until well after we've gone through a budget and say, well, guess what, this is the new rule.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully we'll find out more as this early part of the year progresses.

[Roy Belson]: There's some new accountability requirements under ESSA.

[Roy Belson]: I've talked about that when we had the discussion on the test scores.

[Roy Belson]: Some of the key points in the new system might include maintaining the annual testing requirement, retaining 95% assessment participation requirement, making sure people participate, differentiation between schools depending on what they're supposed to be doing, long-term goals from the state to measure interim progress of all students in subgroups,

[Roy Belson]: New Accountability Indicators, and they're dumping the CPI.

[Roy Belson]: Do you know what the CPI is?

[Roy Belson]: The Cumulative Performance Index?

[Roy Belson]: That has been the staple of NCLB.

[Roy Belson]: And then it got changed to the Growth Interest, SGP, then it got changed to a couple of other things that were going on.

[Roy Belson]: So the more they keep changing the rules, the tougher it is for us to follow as to what's going to be the way they're going to make determinations.

[Roy Belson]: I provided a PowerPoint for you.

[Roy Belson]: We should go over it at some point.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll be studying it.

[Roy Belson]: I'll be looking for more information in the upcoming weeks at the conference.

[Roy Belson]: We'll be sharing with our colleagues as to what they think and what's going on, so that we can come back and give you real specifics.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll be talking to our people who are involved in the federal education agencies to find out where they see the trends are going.

[Roy Belson]: But this is the first rush of information.

[Roy Belson]: It is different.

[Roy Belson]: It isn't totally different, but it's different, and we need to pay attention to it so we can take maximum advantage of it, optimum advantage of it, while at the same time not losing out on any possibilities that would be helpful to us.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to take any questions you have.

[Roy Belson]: So we have that, and our graduation rate, by the way, went up this year.

[Roy Belson]: The data you had in front of you from the last presentation was previous year.

[Roy Belson]: Part of that is a function of how people view what is success.

[Roy Belson]: So if a youngster is missing one course in June and makes it up over the summer, they're not part of the four-year graduation rate.

[Roy Belson]: That's exactly what I'm saying.

[Roy Belson]: That's the whole point of it.

[Roy Belson]: So we can provide that information to you.

[Roy Belson]: The trick will be getting the state and the feds to recognize that as legitimate, especially for youngsters who are challenged.

[Roy Belson]: What we do is we get colleagues on school committees, colleagues in my office, principals around the state, to make that point on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: And that's something that should come up in November when we're down with colleagues.

[Roy Belson]: Because that's the kind of thing that really needs to be understood.

[Roy Belson]: There shouldn't be a rush to succeed.

[Roy Belson]: There should be a steady, intelligent path to succeed.

[Roy Belson]: Especially for youngsters who don't speak English as a first language.

[Roy Belson]: Especially for youngsters who are working with cognitive and procedural difficulties.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, it's unfair.

[Roy Belson]: It's just truly unfair and it makes them look like they're not doing what they need to do or school systems aren't doing.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, it would be a shame not to give a youngster more time if they needed it.

[Roy Belson]: This is the kind of stuff that needs to get out there and I agree with you.

[Roy Belson]: This is something that should be front and center in our discussions.

[Roy Belson]: I think the old thinking was always, well, you know, you put off these kids a little bit longer and keep managing the data to avoid youngsters being reported out.

[Roy Belson]: It's not a question of managing data.

[Roy Belson]: It's a question of providing effective education.

[Roy Belson]: It's a question of recognizing the differences between different types of learners and supporting them.

[Roy Belson]: You know, the average college completion rate, I said that the other night, is six years.

[Roy Belson]: Six years.

[Roy Belson]: Most kids take time to complete college.

[Roy Belson]: And it's not

[Roy Belson]: that a percentage of youngsters should take more time in high school to complete.

[Roy Belson]: Not because they can't do it, but because they need to pace themselves differently so they can learn and take advantage of the opportunities that are in front of them.

[Roy Belson]: So I agree with you very much.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's something that the whole state would benefit from.

[Roy Belson]: So, the reason this is on your agenda is every year I get asked around this time, how do we decide when school closes and what can we do about it?

[Roy Belson]: Now, the main message is this.

[Roy Belson]: You should start planning now as a parent about a situation that might occur and who will help to cover your youngsters if you have to go to work, who's going to stay at home, what neighbors can work with you,

[Roy Belson]: What situations can occur?

[Roy Belson]: Can you talk to your employers, maybe coming in a little bit later on certain days to get things under control?

[Roy Belson]: You can't wait till the day it happens.

[Roy Belson]: You've got to start thinking about it.

[Roy Belson]: And oftentimes, we don't get a final call until later because we don't know if the storm is going to hit.

[Roy Belson]: You know, meteorologists do their job, but they can't be sure.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes the storm veers off at the last second, and sometimes it veers in at the last second.

[Roy Belson]: And we need to be careful.

[Roy Belson]: And sometimes the storm doesn't seem like it's coming to us at the beginning of school, but it's going to hit at 10 o'clock in the morning and getting young people home is its own problem.

[Roy Belson]: The other thing that we have to deal with is the fact that some youngsters have no one at home on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: And getting them to school means they might need a hot meal, they have some supervision.

[Roy Belson]: There's some other things going on that we want to provide.

[Roy Belson]: On the other hand, if you really feel uptight, you really feel like maybe your child shouldn't be out, it's your option to keep them home.

[Roy Belson]: Missing a day is not going to change the world as long as you're diligent about following up on the work.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to understand these things.

[Roy Belson]: Now it takes a lot to figure this out.

[Roy Belson]: We talk to the DPW, we talk to the police department, we talk to the fire department, we talk to our own custodial crews, we talk to the contractors who plow our schools, we talk to neighbors.

[Roy Belson]: What are they doing?

[Roy Belson]: How are they doing it?

[Roy Belson]: And some places are more challenging than others.

[Roy Belson]: If you live in the narrow streets of Everett and Malden, it's a lot tougher to plow those streets than it is maybe in Medford.

[Roy Belson]: It's a lot tougher to do certain things and they have to make decisions a little bit earlier because they can't get their crews out as fast as our crews get out.

[Roy Belson]: We want to provide.

[Roy Belson]: intelligent days.

[Roy Belson]: We also have to think about the days if teachers can't get there.

[Roy Belson]: So school is open and the faculty can't make it in because they no longer all live in Medford or one community over.

[Roy Belson]: People live in wider areas.

[Roy Belson]: So to have a day where the faculty is missing doesn't give us a quality education day.

[Roy Belson]: We started earlier this year, so that should help.

[Roy Belson]: In terms of days, but you never know.

[Roy Belson]: We've had years where there's been no school days.

[Roy Belson]: We've had years when a couple of years ago there were seven or eight school days.

[Roy Belson]: And last year there were three.

[Roy Belson]: So it's hard to know.

[Roy Belson]: And one year we shut down schools when the buildings were too cold.

[Roy Belson]: And it wasn't a question of snow, it just was too cold.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of reasons.

[Roy Belson]: And we try to be up front.

[Roy Belson]: There's always somebody who tells me we shouldn't have done it, and there's somebody who always tells me we should have done it.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, I guarantee you.

[Roy Belson]: And of course, the funniest things are the calls from the kids.

[Roy Belson]: Hello, this is a parent.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think kids should be going to school today.

[Roy Belson]: Hello, I had to shovel all day yesterday.

[Roy Belson]: I need at least one day to play in this stuff.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, it's really funny what the kids will call up and say and do.

[Roy Belson]: You know?

[Roy Belson]: You understand?

[Roy Belson]: But that's what it is.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: So a little bit of planning right now would be helpful.

[Roy Belson]: It's one thing we should also mention is our young people, we've tried to encourage them, especially the older children, to help out with neighbors who may be elderly or infirmed, because obviously sidewalks and things of that type need to be shoveled so that youngsters don't have to walk in streets.

[Roy Belson]: We don't have situations where it's unsafe when a little kid is behind a huge snowbank.

[Roy Belson]: So those are things we need to talk a little bit about to the community about how they can help us make sure that if there's an accumulation of snow, it doesn't block the visibility for youngsters near buses or in their cars.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, the one thing I want to stress with this particular motion, while the motion itself is good, the adequacy word is very important.

[Roy Belson]: Because if they only put a certain amount of money, and even if it's more money, and it gets distributed in ways that Medford doesn't get any money, it doesn't help us.

[Roy Belson]: It's important that they increase the foundation budget, but it's also important that they understand that adequacy means that every community has to receive more than it's currently receiving now, not just those communities that fall below foundation.

[Roy Belson]: So that's critical, you know, that we stress when we talk at the conference about adequacy being funding everyone because everyone can use the money.

[Roy Belson]: You know, there's that John Greenleaf Whittier quote that I love so much, but I modify it.

[Roy Belson]: John Greenleaf Whittier said, of all the sad words of tongue and pen, the saddest of these are what might have been.

[Roy Belson]: I changed that.

[Roy Belson]: Of all the sad words of tongue and pen, the saddest of these are subject to appropriation.

[Roy Belson]: Because when they don't appropriate enough money, the language doesn't mean anything.

[Roy Belson]: They've got to understand that communities like Medford may be wealthier than certain other communities,

[Roy Belson]: Not as wealthy as others, but we need money.

[Roy Belson]: You can't have a Foundation Budget Review Committee that wipes out additional funding to 150 communities, which is what the Foundation Budget Review Committee distribution would have done, including Medford.

[Roy Belson]: We should vote yes, but we should vote for adequacy.

[Roy Belson]: We should push adequacy in our discussion.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, basically, we should be saying that all communities should receive an increase

[Roy Belson]: that is consistent with the demands and the mandates that the state has put in place.

[Roy Belson]: The state has increased the number of mandates to communities, as you know.

[Roy Belson]: Unfunded mandates is almost a way of life at the state house.

[Roy Belson]: We cannot continue to allow that to happen because we continue to use our own money for things.

[Roy Belson]: And then as a result,

[Roy Belson]: Eventually, we have to cut other things that we don't want to cut, or you can't go where you want to go.

[Roy Belson]: So remember this year when we talked budget, I told you that we got $55 per pupil minimum aid, new money in the Chapter 70, which is more than a 25 of the year before.

[Roy Belson]: But the net net was we lost $200,000.

[Roy Belson]: That's not a win.

[Roy Belson]: What that is is a partial win.

[Roy Belson]: It's a balancing act.

[Roy Belson]: We need to make sure that if they're going to increase the foundation budget, that it adequately reflects the needs of all communities.

[Roy Belson]: That's the message to the MASC Resolutions Committee and to the state.

[Roy Belson]: And we received all the scheduled receipts and first quarter payments from Commonwealth?

[Roy Belson]: Uh-huh.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I'd be curious to see what October's receipts look like.

[Roy Belson]: September look better?

[Roy Belson]: But not great.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I think we should put that into our language.

[Roy Belson]: That adequacy, that we should stress adequacy

[Roy Belson]: and a full distribution to all communities under Chapter 70, not just some.

[Roy Belson]: No, amending it, adding another, adding an emphasis point.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it's important to note that if you expect the legislature to enact something,

[Roy Belson]: If you have 150 cities and towns that aren't going to benefit, it's unlikely they're going to enact it.

[Roy Belson]: So the likelihood of it being enacted has a greater chance if every community is a winner.

[Roy Belson]: About 330 right now.

[Roy Belson]: 330 spread amongst.

[Roy Belson]: A few years ago, we did a study along with MASS.

[Roy Belson]: We found that we could fund those youngsters by putting them in classrooms at this point in time, back then, at about a third of the cost.

[Roy Belson]: So, when people say that there is no loss of revenue

[Roy Belson]: They don't do the numbers like we do the numbers.

[Roy Belson]: There may be some communities that don't have space.

[Roy Belson]: There may be some situations that don't exist, that don't work 100%.

[Roy Belson]: But in this community, it will work.

[Roy Belson]: All right, so on the School Brains activity, as you know, we've switched from iPass to School Brains.

[Roy Belson]: It's a much more comprehensive and much more, let's say, modernized version of school software that would keep track of students, staff, and other records and the like.

[Roy Belson]: But there was a rollout period.

[Roy Belson]: And the primary activity initially was, one, to transfer information from iPass to School Brains.

[Roy Belson]: There's still some data that has to be cleaned.

[Roy Belson]: It's a very arduous process because some of the material is in different formats from one to the other and has to be individually looked at to be sure of accuracy as people come and go.

[Roy Belson]: And it's not static.

[Roy Belson]: What's true today may not be true tomorrow as people come and leave.

[Roy Belson]: Secondly, there needs to be training on this and there is training going on.

[Roy Belson]: There is a train-the-trainer activity at the schools, where we're empowering certain teachers and administrators to become lead people.

[Roy Belson]: And on the school professional development day, we're having an all-school activity that will deal with that as well.

[Roy Belson]: Our primary activity initially is to roll out the attendance and grade reporting activities, because that's what's essential for us to do what has to be done, and also the materials that are associated with state reporting.

[Roy Belson]: We will then work on the parent portal.

[Roy Belson]: The high school and the vocational school will be ready at the end of the first quarter, around November 17th, to open up the parent portal for students at those schools.

[Roy Belson]: We think the middle schools probably have a good shot to be opened by the first of the year, and the elementary schools are working on their standards report cards, and we'll get a better handle on that once that's been cleaned up, and we know exactly when they can be able to comment on that.

[Roy Belson]: But it's making progress, we want to do it right,

[Roy Belson]: There is something called a System Interoperational Framework, SIF, that is important to coordinate with the state, because if you will, garbage in, garbage out, and once you get that kind of thing happening, it becomes impossible.

[Roy Belson]: And just simply by inverting the first name and the last name in some reports can create all kinds of errors.

[Roy Belson]: Very careful as we convert.

[Roy Belson]: In the long run, it will be distinctly to our advantage that it may take a little bit longer, but our goal remains the same, to increase our interactivity with parents and to provide people with full information and to be able to create reports that will help us all better understand what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: So that's that particular activity.

[Roy Belson]: In some places, it'll be a little bit slower than others, but we're working on it, and we're certainly not stopping what we need to do.

[Roy Belson]: On the school bus, okay?

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, I don't want to be

[Roy Belson]: I'm foolish enough to say something that I can't deliver on.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things that we want to be careful about is we make a promise and we can't keep it, we're worse off.

[Roy Belson]: I told you that the high school will be ready at the end of the first quarter.

[Roy Belson]: We think the middle school will be ready by the first of the year, if not sooner.

[Roy Belson]: We elementary schools will roll out a little bit differently because they have different informational reporting things than the standards report cards and the other two frameworks.

[Roy Belson]: So we need to be a little bit careful.

[Roy Belson]: Let's just put it this way.

[Roy Belson]: We are diligently proceeding of a better idea after the training is done in November.

[Roy Belson]: Again, to see what teachers' minds are, what they feel comfortable with, and we can work our way through.

[Roy Belson]: But I understand that people are anxious.

[Roy Belson]: On the other hand, I certainly don't want to make promises I can't keep because that only creates more problems.

[Roy Belson]: The MBTA bus passes, the MBTA changed the rules.

[Roy Belson]: The MBTA gave what they called an M-pass and an S-pass.

[Roy Belson]: The M-pass is a pass that allows you to bypass for 30 days, for a month.

[Roy Belson]: And it's $30.

[Roy Belson]: And that gives you unlimited riding privileges.

[Roy Belson]: The S-Pass was a pass that you could put $10 on and you could use up to $10 for a time and then get another pass, get it renewed.

[Roy Belson]: The difficulty is that the S-Pass was being abused widely and the MBTA pulled it in.

[Roy Belson]: And they said school systems and communities are now responsible if the wrong people use it.

[Roy Belson]: And what we had people losing it, people letting their cousins and their relatives use it, and there was all kinds of problems associated with that.

[Roy Belson]: So, we recognize that it's something that we want to be available to people, but we want to do it in a measured way.

[Roy Belson]: So, I've given you a report tonight to show that we've checked it out, we're following it, we're going to do it a limited amount of the time, especially for those people who clearly have a need.

[Roy Belson]: to have it, but at the same token, we want to be very careful that we don't have abuse and we don't have lost passes and things like that because then we'll get charged for it.

[Roy Belson]: And that's not going to happen.

[Roy Belson]: It's not just a Medford issue, it's across the state, across the, let's say, the MBTA area.

[Roy Belson]: So this is an MBTA-driven activity and we want to control it.

[Roy Belson]: Plus the fact, too, it's a lot of man hours, person hours, if you will, to control these passes.

[Roy Belson]: People come in, I've lost my pass, can I have another one?

[Roy Belson]: It's a lot of work associated with it.

[Roy Belson]: So we need to create a certain sense that this is something you need to protect and you need to use it wisely.

[Roy Belson]: And if someone doesn't use it appropriately, they won't get it again.

[Roy Belson]: All right, well, what I told you before, basically, we did a lot of training last year.

[Roy Belson]: We had to negotiate a contract.

[Roy Belson]: We did negotiate the contract.

[Roy Belson]: Then we had to work in training.

[Roy Belson]: Teachers were uncomfortable using some of these things and took time to get them going.

[Roy Belson]: We did run training last year.

[Roy Belson]: They didn't consider it to be sufficient enough and they wanted to do more.

[Roy Belson]: In the summer, people were away.

[Roy Belson]: You can only do so much.

[Roy Belson]: You can only do what the people that want to come in and want to work on it.

[Roy Belson]: There are other things that are going on.

[Roy Belson]: So, it's happening.

[Roy Belson]: The goal was to do it right and to have it be a long-term value to us.

[Roy Belson]: I don't want to rush it and create a situation where we promise you things and then we can't do it.

[Roy Belson]: And as far as a little inconvenience in the front end, I understand that, but better to have that little inconvenience in the front end.

[Roy Belson]: You can certainly communicate with your teachers by email, you can certainly call up the school, you certainly can visit to get any information.

[Roy Belson]: We're certainly still sending out progress reports.

[Roy Belson]: That's not something we've stopped doing, but the electronic system is going to take a little bit longer.

[Roy Belson]: The high school will happen very shortly.

[Roy Belson]: Middle school I think will follow pretty quickly.

[Roy Belson]: And then the elementary schools will have to figure out what's the best way to do that going forward.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think anyone is trying to slow it down.

[Roy Belson]: I just think it takes time to do it right.

[Roy Belson]: And if we rush it and we do something, we're gonna probably find we'll have more headaches down the road than we really bargained for.

[Roy Belson]: Garbage in, garbage out.

[Roy Belson]: We don't want that to happen.

[Roy Belson]: So I appreciate it.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully people understand that we're doing everything we can to get it going.

[Roy Belson]: In a short period of time, it'll happen.

[Roy Belson]: Joanne Mortel is the person on the point of this particular bus pass.

[Roy Belson]: She's in the accounts payable office of the schools.

[Roy Belson]: You can look it up from the business offices to the phone number I have in front of me right now.

[Roy Belson]: He's the person issuing them and paying attention to their monitoring.

[Roy Belson]: It's a lot of work and I appreciate all the work that Joanne has done to keep things in place.

[Roy Belson]: That's been moved.

[Roy Belson]: It's been moved up to the Science Lab and with appropriate arrangements so that the youngsters can come and go freely.

[Roy Belson]: We've just elected two females to the top jobs.

[Roy Belson]: We're ahead of the curve.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee and ladies and gentlemen, Massachusetts Association of School Superintendents each year recognizes outstanding students in each community for which there is a superintendent who is a member of Mass.

[Roy Belson]: These awards are not given lightly.

[Roy Belson]: They're given to individuals who have not only accomplished academic excellence, but have done other terrific things in their school environments.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll make sure that it's presented and that, uh,

[Roy Belson]: individuals duly recognized.

[Roy Belson]: This, uh, report, uh,

[Roy Belson]: was basically a follow-up on things that we didn't cover in the first time.

[Roy Belson]: We did give you a report earlier on state assessment results and accountability ratings.

[Roy Belson]: And that included a lot of the high school 10th grade MCAS scores and comparisons with the state, because that's the only place where the state had any comparative data.

[Roy Belson]: They didn't do anything in the other areas.

[Roy Belson]: But it's in the back of your report here.

[Roy Belson]: You've got this last piece here, which does that.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you can see this in this, in these charts.

[Roy Belson]: That's where that's right.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: We can do that.

[Roy Belson]: We're working on that now.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: No.

[Roy Belson]: What the state has done,

[Roy Belson]: is they've created a high needs category.

[Roy Belson]: And in that category, an individual might fit in more than one activity.

[Roy Belson]: A youngster might be a person who doesn't speak English as a first language, might be special needs, and might also be economically disadvantaged.

[Roy Belson]: So one person might be in three categories, multiple categories.

[Roy Belson]: So you could find that different scores, different activities are skewed by the fact that an individual repeats themselves in multiple categories.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to break those out periodically as we go, just to see exactly what's the dominant category that's driving a particular result.

[Roy Belson]: So high needs is sort of an accumulation or cumulative amount of all the students who fall into any one of those categories, as opposed to one.

[Roy Belson]: So 50% would be too high.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I want to look at the latest, because basically, the other thing that took place is Title I,

[Roy Belson]: Uh, which normally defined, um, economically disadvantaged.

[Roy Belson]: The rule was changed and because it was changed, the numbers came way down and it affected communities across the state.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't want to speculate at this point in time, but I, we certainly are going to break it out.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, disproportionality or what they call prima facie denial in some instances.

[Roy Belson]: tendency in school districts or across almost any institution if a youngster is not doing well to speculate as to whether that youngster has a learning disability, whether it's language-based, whether it's a temporary distraction that the youngster is going through, maybe some family dysfunction, some other things going on in their life.

[Roy Belson]: So it's really hard to know whether the identification is really 100%.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly, we have to pay a lot of attention to making sure that a youngster, let's say, who doesn't speak English as a first language

[Roy Belson]: isn't automatically included as a special needs student.

[Roy Belson]: That's right.

[Roy Belson]: Or a youngster as a special needs student isn't automatically assumed to be of a particular category.

[Roy Belson]: It may very well be that it's a standalone.

[Roy Belson]: So it's going to be done very, very carefully.

[Roy Belson]: And it's going to be done case by case, school by school, so that we really know who's where.

[Roy Belson]: Well, the gap is between the youngsters who don't necessarily fall into these subgroup categories and those youngsters who do.

[Roy Belson]: But it's important to note, and this was brought out at our last meeting,

[Roy Belson]: that Medford's achievement levels in these subgroups either met or exceeded the state average in each of these categories.

[Roy Belson]: So what it really means is, is the state using an instrument that properly assesses the appropriate development of these youngsters?

[Roy Belson]: Is it fair to give a youngster a test in English

[Roy Belson]: in their first year in this country not speaking English and then trying to determine whether this youngster knows enough.

[Roy Belson]: I think that the assessment system really deserves a work over because it's inappropriate to ask youngsters to do things for which they are not particularly good at it at this point in their life because of their genesis, where they are at that point in time.

[Roy Belson]: So a youngster who might be progressing at a nice level for

[Roy Belson]: his or her situation might take an extra year or two to get to that level.

[Roy Belson]: What's wrong with that?

[Roy Belson]: The goal is to get to the achievement level as much as possible.

[Roy Belson]: And if it takes a little longer, fine.

[Roy Belson]: Some people learn faster.

[Roy Belson]: Some people learn slower.

[Roy Belson]: Some people are more skilled in a mathematical area.

[Roy Belson]: Some people are more skilled in a language area.

[Roy Belson]: And so we need to have a better assessment system than the vanilla that we're getting right now

[Roy Belson]: And that's going to be a topic of discussion among superintendents, school committee members, and others as we approach our meetings coming forward.

[Roy Belson]: ESSA, and we'll have that discussion tonight as part of it, makes some changes in NCLB, but not enough.

[Roy Belson]: So let me make a suggestion.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of material here.

[Roy Belson]: It can't be discussed in the robust way it needs to be discussed.

[Roy Belson]: Let's look at some dates and I'll get back to you with some possible dates and we can do that.

[Roy Belson]: Well, it's happening in one school, but remember,

[Roy Belson]: We're asking our faculty and people to do an awful lot right now.

[Roy Belson]: They're taking school brains.

[Roy Belson]: They're doing a million different workshops.

[Roy Belson]: They've also got to teach their classes.

[Roy Belson]: Otherwise, we're just running a program, and it won't work.

[Roy Belson]: It won't stick.

[Roy Belson]: So let's have a meeting.

[Roy Belson]: And let's see which things can be

[Roy Belson]: let's say integrated with other initiatives that are already going on.

[Roy Belson]: And I think we're in a better place if we do that.

[Roy Belson]: Principals have a certain amount of autonomy to do things that respond to what they see in their buildings.

[Roy Belson]: But when someone does something and it works, we're naturally interested in it.

[Roy Belson]: But what works in one building may not work in another.

[Roy Belson]: and we just need to talk about it, that's all.

[Roy Belson]: We don't micromanage everything that happens every day in the buildings.

[Roy Belson]: We let people do some of the things that they think are appropriate, you know, and when it becomes something that the whole district is interested in, then maybe we bring it here.

[Roy Belson]: We could be talking about every program,

[Roy Belson]: Not every school had a mock election.

[Roy Belson]: Not every school had another thing going on.

[Roy Belson]: Schools have their own identities.

[Roy Belson]: We want them to have their own identities.

[Roy Belson]: But let's take a look at this as a gestalt and a committee of the whole, and I think you might have a better way to decide which things should move forward.
