[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, we're going to call on our assistant superintendent superintendent Diane Caldwell to talk about this report.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: Members of the committee, Tony Vento is with us this evening, and we'll just go through some of it.

[Roy Belson]: If you have any specific questions, Tony is here to answer them.

[Roy Belson]: I provide you with documents that have been produced and gone out to parents.

[Roy Belson]: From the outset, we've worked closely with MassDBH, with the Medford Board of Health.

[Roy Belson]: We appreciate all their help.

[Roy Belson]: They've done a great job.

[Roy Belson]: right on the spot, helping us right away, making sure we did things the way we needed to, as well as our own medical team under Tony's direction here at the schools.

[Roy Belson]: On Wednesday, October 26th, there will be a TB testing of individuals who have been identified as being in close contact with the individual who was diagnosed with TB.

[Roy Belson]: There were 194 MHS students who were identified, five middle school students, and 14 adult personnel.

[Roy Belson]: On the 20th, in the Cowan Theater, we will have a public information night available to everyone from 7 o'clock on to answer any questions that anyone might have.

[Roy Belson]: Individuals may choose to have the test conducted by their own physician, and then we would ask them to provide us with the information that would indicate that it was done.

[Roy Belson]: If there is a finding, then there would be some follow-up antibiotic activity.

[Roy Belson]: If there is no finding, it would be a second round of testing during the winter period to see if something emerged subsequent to.

[Roy Belson]: Since the original case was diagnosed, there have been no further identifications, and the DPH procedure has been followed precisely to ensure due diligence.

[Roy Belson]: You have letters here.

[Roy Belson]: But I'm happy to take any questions or have the questions referred to Tony so that if you have any gaps in your understanding of what's taken place, we can answer them this evening.

[Roy Belson]: And then again, on the 20th, we encourage anyone who really has some questions.

[Roy Belson]: I have not received a lot of phone calls.

[Roy Belson]: I did originally receive the handful.

[Roy Belson]: I know Tony received a handful, but once they were done, it pretty much was pretty quiet.

[Roy Belson]: And most people were satisfied with the information they received.

[Roy Belson]: But Tony is here, and you might want to direct questions to him.

[Roy Belson]: No, there's no payment.

[Roy Belson]: If they go to health insurance, which they should have, that would cover it.

[Roy Belson]: That's one of those things that's covered by health insurance.

[Roy Belson]: And if they come through us, there's no charge whatsoever.

[Roy Belson]: So as you know, No Child Left Behind has been replaced by Every Student Succeeds Act.

[Roy Belson]: And that legislation begins in 2016-2017 as a transition year with full implementation in 2017-2018.

[Roy Belson]: Now there are several key elements of the act.

[Roy Belson]: I want to give you enough of it so you understand it, but not so much that you get overwhelmed by it because there's an awful lot of pieces and we'll have to break it down a piece at a time in order for it to really be understood.

[Roy Belson]: ESSA comprises nine title grants which provide funding to districts and states.

[Roy Belson]: Currently there are about five or six.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not sure how we count them these days because they keep putting them together.

[Roy Belson]: Title IV grant represents a new funding source, which is an allocation grant for districts in the area of student support services, something that would speak to some of the discussion we had a little bit earlier.

[Roy Belson]: Districts and states are required to conform to the requirements of ESSA, so that No Child Left Behind is now giving way to ESSA, and districts and states now must adopt ESSA rules.

[Roy Belson]: ESSA encourages state agencies to think differently about how best to support low-performing schools as the school improvement grants are no longer available.

[Roy Belson]: So they're asking the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education to talk to us about how we could best benefit from their help.

[Roy Belson]: That should be a very robust discussion, especially in our conference and so on and so forth going forward.

[Roy Belson]: ESSA minimizes Title I prescriptive school and district accountability requirements.

[Roy Belson]: No Child Left Behind had very, very specific things under Title I. The SSA wiped some of it away, but it adds some things that are interesting, too.

[Roy Belson]: Equitable access is perhaps one of the biggest areas.

[Roy Belson]: What is equitable access?

[Roy Belson]: Does it mean every school gets the same thing?

[Roy Belson]: Does it mean it's based on proportion of low income?

[Roy Belson]: Is it based on proportion of high needs?

[Roy Belson]: What is it?

[Roy Belson]: Equitable doesn't automatically mean things.

[Roy Belson]: What if you have a teacher in a school who

[Roy Belson]: $80,000 a year and a teacher makes $60,000 a year.

[Roy Belson]: Is it different or is it the same thing as long as there's a teacher there who's experienced and can do the job?

[Roy Belson]: Those things are yet to be fleshed out.

[Roy Belson]: And it's problematic because, naturally, we hire teachers at different stages of their career.

[Roy Belson]: And a lot of it's based on how many years they've been with us and what their degrees are.

[Roy Belson]: That doesn't necessarily mean they're better or worse at what they will do.

[Roy Belson]: There's a shift in focus on the Title II program from highly qualified to reporting on student

[Roy Belson]: learning experience.

[Roy Belson]: So instead of determining just the teachers are highly qualified, the question will be, what have the students learned?

[Roy Belson]: And they have to give us some rubrics to determine that going forward.

[Roy Belson]: It focuses mostly on quality access to education, access to quality education.

[Roy Belson]: DESE is going to continue to collect certain data, but it doesn't mean it's going to have a particular impact on what we do or don't do.

[Roy Belson]: Inexperienced teachers will be expected to do different things, but we haven't got guidelines yet.

[Roy Belson]: Total funding for this year has been about the same, a little bit different, with a larger shift in Title IV student support money.

[Roy Belson]: The federal government has readjusted funding levels and our state will receive less money.

[Roy Belson]: State receives less money, our district receives less money.

[Roy Belson]: In most cases, not always.

[Roy Belson]: DESE does not have the FY18 budget, and they're likely not to know for quite a while as to how much money will or won't be there.

[Roy Belson]: And of course, you know, with an election year, Congress, who knows what Congress will appropriate and what they won't appropriate until the election actually takes place and we determine who chairs which committees and who's in the White House.

[Roy Belson]: It maintains a lot of the requirements under the 1965 Act.

[Roy Belson]: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, the original one.

[Roy Belson]: There's some innovative assessment encouragement that will be there.

[Roy Belson]: The definition of supplement versus supplant has changed.

[Roy Belson]: That's another little thing we've got to get a good handle on.

[Roy Belson]: What does it mean to add to something versus to shift the burden from the locality to the feds?

[Roy Belson]: That's something that comes up all the time.

[Roy Belson]: We're hopeful that, you know, we'll get clarity on this sooner rather than later so we can plan.

[Roy Belson]: Problem with some of these things is we don't find out until well after we've gone through budget and says, well, guess what?

[Roy Belson]: This is the new rule.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully we'll find out more as this early part of the year progresses.

[Roy Belson]: There's some new accountability requirements on the ESSA.

[Roy Belson]: I've talked about that when we had the discussion on the test scores.

[Roy Belson]: Some of the key points in the new system might include

[Roy Belson]: maintaining the annual testing requirement, retaining 95% assessment participation requirement, making sure people participate, differentiation between schools, depending on what they're supposed to be doing, long-term goals from the state to measure interim progress of all students in subgroups, new accountability indicators, and

[Roy Belson]: They're dumping the CPI.

[Roy Belson]: You know what the CPI is?

[Roy Belson]: The Cumulative Performance Index?

[Roy Belson]: That has been the staple of NCLB.

[Roy Belson]: And then it got changed to the Growth Interest, SGP.

[Roy Belson]: Then it got changed to a couple of other things that were going on.

[Roy Belson]: So the more they keep changing the rules, the tougher it is for us to follow as to what's going to be the way they're going to make determinations.

[Roy Belson]: I provided a PowerPoint for you.

[Roy Belson]: We should go over it at some point.

[Roy Belson]: But we'll be studying it.

[Roy Belson]: I'll be looking for more information in the upcoming weeks at the conference.

[Roy Belson]: We'll be sharing with our colleagues as to what they think and what's going on so that we can come back and give you real specifics.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll be talking to our people who are involved in the federal education agencies to find out where they see the trends are going.

[Roy Belson]: But this is the first rush of information.

[Roy Belson]: It is different.

[Roy Belson]: It isn't totally different, but it's different.

[Roy Belson]: And we need to pay attention to it so we can take maximum advantage of it, optimum advantage of it, while at the same time not losing out on any possibilities that would be helpful to us.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to take any questions you have.

[Roy Belson]: So we have that, and our graduation rate, by the way, went up this year.

[Roy Belson]: The data you had in front of you from the last presentation was previous year.

[Roy Belson]: Part of that, you know, is a function of how people view what is success.

[Roy Belson]: So if a youngster is missing one course in June and makes it up over the summer, they're not part of the four-year graduation rate.

[Roy Belson]: Well, that's exactly what I'm saying.

[Roy Belson]: That's the whole point of it.

[Roy Belson]: So we can provide that information to you.

[Roy Belson]: The trick will be getting the state and the feds to recognize that as legitimate, especially for youngsters who are challenged.

[Roy Belson]: What we do is we get colleagues on school committees, colleagues in my office, principals around the state, to make that point on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: And that's something that should come up in November when we're down with colleagues, because that's the kind of thing that really needs to be understood.

[Roy Belson]: There shouldn't be a rush to succeed.

[Roy Belson]: There should be a steady, intelligent path to succeed, especially for youngsters who don't speak English as a first language, especially for youngsters who are working with cognitive

[Roy Belson]: and procedural difficulties.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, it's unfair.

[Roy Belson]: It's just truly unfair.

[Roy Belson]: And it makes them look like they're not doing what they need to do.

[Roy Belson]: Our school systems aren't doing it.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, it would be a shame not to give a youngster more time if they needed it.

[Roy Belson]: This is the kind of stuff that needs to get out there.

[Roy Belson]: And I agree with you.

[Roy Belson]: This is something that should be front and center in our discussions.

[Roy Belson]: I think the old thinking was always, well, you know, you put off these kids a little bit longer and keep managing the data to avoid youngsters being reported out.

[Roy Belson]: It's not a question of managing data.

[Roy Belson]: It's a question of providing effective education.

[Roy Belson]: It's a question of recognizing the differences between different types of learners and supporting them.

[Roy Belson]: You know, the average college completion rate, I said that the other night, is six years.

[Roy Belson]: Six years.

[Roy Belson]: Most kids take time to complete college, and it's not

[Roy Belson]: unlikely that a percentage of youngsters should take more time in high school to complete.

[Roy Belson]: Not because they can't do it, but because they need to pace themselves differently so they can learn and take advantage of the opportunities that are in front of them.

[Roy Belson]: So I agree with you very much.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's something that the whole state would benefit from.

[Roy Belson]: So the reason this is on your agenda is every year I get asked around this time, how do we decide when school closes and what can we do about it?

[Roy Belson]: Now, the main message is this.

[Roy Belson]: You should start planning now as a parent about a situation that might occur and who will help to cover your youngsters.

[Roy Belson]: If you have to go to work, who's going to stay at home, what neighbors can work with you.

[Roy Belson]: What situations can occur?

[Roy Belson]: Can you talk to your employers who may be coming in a little bit later on certain days to get things under control?

[Roy Belson]: You can't wait until the day it happens.

[Roy Belson]: You've got to start thinking about it.

[Roy Belson]: And oftentimes, we don't get

[Roy Belson]: a final call until later, because we don't know if the storm is going to hit.

[Roy Belson]: You know, meteorologists do their job, but they can't be sure.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes the storm veers off at the last second, and sometimes it veers in at the last second.

[Roy Belson]: And we need to be careful.

[Roy Belson]: And sometimes the storm doesn't seem like it's coming to us at the beginning of school, but it's going to hit at 10 o'clock in the morning, and getting young people home is its own problem.

[Roy Belson]: The other thing that we have to deal with is the fact that some youngsters have no one at home on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: And getting them to school means they might get to eat a hot meal.

[Roy Belson]: They have some supervision.

[Roy Belson]: There's some other things going on that we want to provide.

[Roy Belson]: On the other hand, if you really feel uptight and you really feel like maybe your child shouldn't be out, it's your option to keep them home.

[Roy Belson]: Missing a day is not going to change the world as long as you're diligent about following up on the work.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to understand these things.

[Roy Belson]: Now, it takes a lot to figure this out.

[Roy Belson]: We talk to the DPW.

[Roy Belson]: We talk to the police department.

[Roy Belson]: We talk to the fire department.

[Roy Belson]: We talk to our own custodial crews.

[Roy Belson]: We talk to the contractors who plow our schools.

[Roy Belson]: We talk to neighbors.

[Roy Belson]: What are they doing?

[Roy Belson]: How are they doing it?

[Roy Belson]: And some places are more challenging than others.

[Roy Belson]: If you live in the narrow streets of Everett and Malden, it's a lot tougher to plow those streets than it is maybe in Medford.

[Roy Belson]: It's a lot tougher to do certain things

[Roy Belson]: and they have to make decisions a little bit earlier because they can't get their crews out as fast as our crews get out.

[Roy Belson]: We want to provide intelligent days.

[Roy Belson]: We also have to think about the days if teachers can't get there.

[Roy Belson]: So school is open and the faculty can't make it in because they no longer all live in Medford or one community over.

[Roy Belson]: People live in wider areas.

[Roy Belson]: So to have a day where the faculty is missing doesn't give us a quality education day.

[Roy Belson]: We started earlier this year, so that should help in terms of days, but you never know.

[Roy Belson]: We've had years where there's been no school days.

[Roy Belson]: We've had years when a couple years ago there was seven or eight school days.

[Roy Belson]: And last year there were three.

[Roy Belson]: So it's hard to know.

[Roy Belson]: And one year we shut down schools when the buildings were too cold.

[Roy Belson]: And it wasn't a question of snow, it just was too cold.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot of reasons.

[Roy Belson]: And we try to be upfront.

[Roy Belson]: There's always somebody who tells me we shouldn't have done it, and there's somebody who always tells me we should have done it.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, I guarantee you.

[Roy Belson]: And of course, the funniest things are the calls from the kids.

[Roy Belson]: Hello, this is a parent.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think kids should be going to school today.

[Roy Belson]: Hello, I had to shovel all day yesterday.

[Roy Belson]: I need at least one day to play in this stuff.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, it's really funny what the kids will call up and say and do.

[Roy Belson]: You know, you understand?

[Roy Belson]: But that's what it is, OK?

[Roy Belson]: So a little bit of planning right now would be helpful.

[Roy Belson]: understand.

[Roy Belson]: It's a one thing we should also mention is our young people.

[Roy Belson]: We've tried to encourage them, especially the older children to help out with neighbors who may be elderly or infirmed because obviously sidewalks and things of that type need to be shoveled so that youngsters don't have to walk in streets.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, and we don't have situations where it's unsafe when a little kid is behind a huge snowbank.

[Roy Belson]: So those are things we need to talk a little bit about to the community about how they can help us make sure that if there's an accumulation of snow, it doesn't block the visibility for youngsters near buses or near cars.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, the one thing I want to stress with this particular motion, while the motion itself is good, the adequacy word is very important.

[Roy Belson]: Because if they only put a certain amount of money, and even if it's more money,

[Roy Belson]: and it gets distributed in ways that Medford doesn't get any money, it doesn't help us.

[Roy Belson]: And it's important that they increase the foundation budget, but it's also important that they understand that adequacy means that every community has to receive more than it's currently receiving now, not just those communities that fall below foundation.

[Roy Belson]: So that's critical, you know, that we stress when we talk at the conference about adequacy being

[Roy Belson]: funding everyone, because everyone can use the money.

[Roy Belson]: You know, there's that John Greenleaf Whittier quote that I love so much, but I modify it.

[Roy Belson]: John Greenleaf Whittier said, of all the sad words of tongue and pen, the saddest of these are what might have been.

[Roy Belson]: I changed that.

[Roy Belson]: Of all the sad words of tongue and pen, the saddest of these are subject to appropriation.

[Roy Belson]: Because when they don't appropriate enough money, the language doesn't mean anything.

[Roy Belson]: They've got to understand that communities like Medford

[Roy Belson]: may be wealthier than certain other communities, not as wealthy as others, but we need money.

[Roy Belson]: You can't have a Foundation Budget Review Committee that wipes out additional funding to 150 communities, which is what the Foundation Budget Review Committee distribution would have done, including Medford.

[Roy Belson]: We should vote yes, but we should vote for adequacy.

[Roy Belson]: We should push adequacy in our discussion.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, basically we should be saying that all communities should receive an increase that is consistent with the demands and the mandates that the state has put in place.

[Roy Belson]: The state has increased the number of mandates to communities, as you know.

[Roy Belson]: Unfunded mandates is almost a way of life at the state house.

[Roy Belson]: We cannot continue to allow that to happen because we continue to use our own money for things.

[Roy Belson]: And then as a result, eventually we have to cut other things that we don't want to cut or you can't go where you want to go.

[Roy Belson]: So remember this year when we talked budget, I told you that we got $55 per pupil minimum aid, new money on the chapter 70, which was more than a 25 of the year before.

[Roy Belson]: But the net net was we lost $200,000.

[Roy Belson]: That's not a win.

[Roy Belson]: What that is is a partial win.

[Roy Belson]: It's a balancing act.

[Roy Belson]: We need to make sure that if they're going to increase the foundation budget, that it adequately reflects the needs of all communities.

[Roy Belson]: That's the message to the MASC Resolutions Committee and to the state.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I'd be curious to see what October's receipts look like.

[Roy Belson]: September look better?

[Roy Belson]: but not great.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I think, I think we should put that into our, into our language.

[Roy Belson]: So that adequacy that we should stress adequacy and you know, and,

[Roy Belson]: a full distribution to all communities, you know, under chapter 70, not just some.

[Roy Belson]: So amending, amending this, amending it, amending it, adding another, adding an emphasis point, right?

[Roy Belson]: It's important to note that if you expect the legislature to enact something, if you have 150 cities and towns that aren't going to benefit,

[Roy Belson]: it's unlikely they're going to enact it.

[Roy Belson]: So the likelihood of it being enacted has a greater chance if every community is a winner.

[Roy Belson]: About 330 right now.

[Roy Belson]: 330 spread amongst.

[Roy Belson]: So a few years ago we did a study along with MASS and we found that we could fund those youngsters by putting them in classrooms.

[Roy Belson]: Um, at this point in time back then at about a third of the cost.

[Roy Belson]: So when people say that there is no loss of revenue,

[Roy Belson]: They don't do the numbers like we do the numbers.

[Roy Belson]: There may be some communities that don't have space.

[Roy Belson]: There may be some situations that don't exist, that don't work 100%.

[Roy Belson]: But in this community, it will work.

[Roy Belson]: All right, so on the School Brains activity, as you know, we've switched from iPass to School Brains.

[Roy Belson]: It's a much more comprehensive and much more, let's say, modernized version of school software that would keep track of students, staff, and other records and the like.

[Roy Belson]: But there was a rollout period.

[Roy Belson]: And the primary activity initially was, one, to transfer information from iPass to School Brains.

[Roy Belson]: There's still some data that has to be cleaned.

[Roy Belson]: It's a very arduous process because some of the material is in different formats from one to the other.

[Roy Belson]: It has to be individually looked at to be sure of accuracy as people come and go.

[Roy Belson]: And it's not static.

[Roy Belson]: What's true today may not be true tomorrow as people come and leave.

[Roy Belson]: Secondly, there needs to be training on this.

[Roy Belson]: And there is training going on.

[Roy Belson]: In fact, tomorrow, there is a train-the-trainer activity at the schools where we're

[Roy Belson]: empowering certain teachers and administrators to become lead people.

[Roy Belson]: And on the school, uh, professional development day, we're having an all school activity that will, we'll deal with that as well.

[Roy Belson]: Our primary activity initially is to roll out the attendance and grade reporting activities.

[Roy Belson]: Cause that's, what's essential for us to, to do what has to be done.

[Roy Belson]: And also the materials that are associated with, with state reporting.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, we will then work on the parent portal, the high school and the vocational school,

[Roy Belson]: uh, as we'll be ready at the end of the first quarter around November 17th to open up the parent portal for students at those schools.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, we think the middle schools probably have a good shot to be opened by the first of the year and the elementary schools are working on their standards report cards and we get a better handle on that once that's been cleaned up and we know exactly when they can be able to comment on that.

[Roy Belson]: But it's making progress.

[Roy Belson]: We want to do it right.

[Roy Belson]: Um,

[Roy Belson]: There is something called a System Interoperational Framework, SIF, that is important to coordinate with the state, because if you will, garbage in, garbage out.

[Roy Belson]: And once you get that kind of thing happening, it becomes impossible.

[Roy Belson]: And just simply by inverting the first name and the last name in some reports can create all kinds of errors.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to be very careful as we convert.

[Roy Belson]: In the long run, it'll be distinctly to our advantage that it may take a little bit longer, but our goal remains the same.

[Roy Belson]: to increase our interactivity with parents, and to provide people with full information, and to be able to create reports that will help us all better understand what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: So that's that particular activity.

[Roy Belson]: In some places it'll be a little bit slower than others, but we're working on it.

[Roy Belson]: And we're certainly not stopping what we need to do.

[Roy Belson]: On the school bus, okay.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, I don't want to be,

[Roy Belson]: foolish enough to say something that I can't deliver on.

[Roy Belson]: And one of the things that we want to be careful about is we make a promise and we can't keep it, we're worse off.

[Roy Belson]: I told you that the high school will be ready at the end of the first quarter.

[Roy Belson]: We think the middle school will be ready by the first of the year, if not sooner.

[Roy Belson]: And the elementary schools will roll out a little bit differently because they have different informational reporting things than the standards report cards than the other two frameworks.

[Roy Belson]: So we need to be a little bit careful.

[Roy Belson]: Let's just put it this way.

[Roy Belson]: We are diligently proceeding.

[Roy Belson]: I'll have a better idea after the training is done in November.

[Roy Belson]: Again, to see what teachers' minds are, what they feel comfortable with, and we can work our way through.

[Roy Belson]: But I understand that people are anxious.

[Roy Belson]: On the other hand, I certainly don't want to make promises I can't keep, because that only creates more problems.

[Roy Belson]: Um, the MBTA bus passes, uh, the MBTA changed the rules.

[Roy Belson]: The MBTA gave what they called an M pass and an S pass.

[Roy Belson]: The M pass is a pass that allows you to buy a pass for 30 days for a month and it's $30 and that gives you unlimited writing privileges.

[Roy Belson]: The S-pass was a pass that you could put $10 on and you could use up to $10 for a time and then get another pass, get it renewed.

[Roy Belson]: The difficulty is that the S-pass was being abused widely and the MBTA pulled it in.

[Roy Belson]: And they said, school systems and communities are now responsible if the wrong people use it.

[Roy Belson]: And what we had people losing it,

[Roy Belson]: letting their cousins and their relatives use it.

[Roy Belson]: And there was all kinds of problems associated with that.

[Roy Belson]: So we recognize that it's a, it's something that we want to be available to people, but we want to do it in a measured way.

[Roy Belson]: So I've given you a report tonight to show that we've checked it out.

[Roy Belson]: We're following it.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to do it a limited amount of the time, especially for those people who clearly have a need to have it.

[Roy Belson]: But at the same token,

[Roy Belson]: We want to be very careful that we don't have abuse and we don't have lost passes and things like that because then we'll get charged for it.

[Roy Belson]: And that's not going to happen.

[Roy Belson]: It's not just a Medford issue, it's across the state, across the, let's say the MBTA area.

[Roy Belson]: So this is an MBTA driven activity and we want to control it.

[Roy Belson]: Plus the fact too, it's a lot of man hours, person hours if you will, to control these passes.

[Roy Belson]: People come in, I've lost my pass, can I have another one?

[Roy Belson]: It's a lot of work associated with.

[Roy Belson]: So we need to create a certain sense that this is something you need to protect and you need to use it wisely.

[Roy Belson]: And if someone doesn't use it appropriately, they won't get it again.

[Roy Belson]: All right.

[Roy Belson]: Well, what I told you before, basically we did a lot of training last year.

[Roy Belson]: We had to negotiate a contract.

[Roy Belson]: We did negotiate the contract.

[Roy Belson]: Then we had to work in training.

[Roy Belson]: Teachers were uncomfortable using some of these things, and it took time to get them going.

[Roy Belson]: We did run training last year.

[Roy Belson]: They didn't consider it to be sufficient enough, and they wanted to do more.

[Roy Belson]: In the summer, people are away.

[Roy Belson]: You can only do so much.

[Roy Belson]: You can only do what the people that want to come in and want to work on it.

[Roy Belson]: There are other things that are going on.

[Roy Belson]: So it's happening.

[Roy Belson]: And the goal was to do it right and to have it be a long-term value to us.

[Roy Belson]: I don't want to rush it and create a situation where we promise you things and then we can't do it.

[Roy Belson]: Felly, byddwn ni'n siarad â phobl amdanyn nhw, byddwn ni'n siarad â phobl amdanyn nhw, ond rydyn ni'n gwrthfeydlu gyda Mrs. Rodrigu, wrth iddyn nhw'n dod i'r microcanon, rydyn ni'n gwrthfeydlu gyda nhw heddiw, rydyn ni'n siarad gyda nhw heddiw, byddwn ni'n siarad gyda phobl eraill, ond rydyn ni'n ei wneud'n ymarferol, rydyn ni'n ei wneud'n ymyrryd yn y ffordd hwnnw, yn hytrach na'n ceisio'i ychydigio.

[Roy Belson]: Dydw i eisiau gwneud hynny'n dda iawn.

[Roy Belson]: Mae'r system ysgol yn ddiddorol iawn, ond rydyn ni hefyd, dim ond ychydig... Iodd eich bod chi ddim yn gobeithio'r hyn sy'n bwysig iawn mewn bywyd.

[Roy Belson]: Trwy'r bywydau y byddwch chi'n gwylio'r lywodraethau pwysig hwnnw.

[Roy Belson]: Rydyn ni wedi ceisio'n fawr iawn.

[Roy Belson]: Un arall, os ydych chi ddim yn meddwl, rydw i'n mynd i ddod allan.

[Roy Belson]: Mae nifer o gofynnau wedi'u gwneud.

[Roy Belson]: Dyma ddim gofyn newydd, ac mae arweinydd Donato wedi mynd ymlaen gyda DCR, ond os byddwn ni'n gofyn mwy o gofynwyr, efallai y byddwn ni'n cael ychydig mwy o steam ar hynny, ond mae wedi bod yn anodd, oherwydd dyma ddim gofyn newydd.

[Roy Belson]: Rydyn ni wedi'u gwneud y gofyn hwn.

[Roy Belson]: Pan ddechreuodd St.

[Roy Belson]: Francis, dywedodd DCR nad oedd angen.

[Roy Belson]: When information comes to us, that classroom's been visited multiple times by both Diane and by Kathy, and there's some plans in place.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't believe it's undoable.

[Roy Belson]: I believe the Roberts does have some population issues, but so don't the other schools.

[Roy Belson]: If you're at the Columbus, you have the therapeutic learning program.

[Roy Belson]: At other schools, you have other programs that are there.

[Roy Belson]: Some years, the Brooks has had more people than the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: In some years, the McGlynn has had more people than the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: Population shifts are by geography to some degree.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, let me ask Diane and Kathy to come up and talk a little bit about the specifics that Mrs. Rodriguez has raised.

[Roy Belson]: And I want to make it very clear, we're very concerned when things happen.

[Roy Belson]: We're not unconcerned.

[Roy Belson]: That's not a fair assessment of what goes on.

[Roy Belson]: but let them speak.

[Roy Belson]: So just if I can comment on that for a minute.

[Roy Belson]: A situation happens.

[Roy Belson]: People are responding to it.

[Roy Belson]: Let's not escalate it up and get more people feeling like there's something tragic going on.

[Roy Belson]: There isn't.

[Roy Belson]: Some years, a place like the Columbus had the therapeutic learning program.

[Roy Belson]: Some people used to call it the behavior management program.

[Roy Belson]: And some of those youngsters had

[Roy Belson]: some serious issues, and they were making noise, and some people said, well, gee, you know, we're gonna move those people.

[Roy Belson]: We deal with it, we work with it.

[Roy Belson]: We will contact parents.

[Roy Belson]: We'll meet with people.

[Roy Belson]: We'll do what we have to do to allay the fears of students, but let's not escalate it at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Let's deal with it.

[Roy Belson]: This is a situation that occurred in a single classroom at a point in time at the beginning of the year.

[Roy Belson]: The two students who weren't on the radar, who aren't IEP students,

[Roy Belson]: So let's find out.

[Roy Belson]: Some people may be more anxious than others.

[Roy Belson]: So at this time, we'll call upon our deputy superintendent to present this report.

[Roy Belson]: So let me jump in on that one.

[Roy Belson]: Every school has got a different reality.

[Roy Belson]: You would expect more suspensions at the high school and the middle schools than you would typically at the elementary schools.

[Roy Belson]: So teachers don't suspend youngsters.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Chairperson, members of the committee, just an update on what's going on in Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: There was a district wide vote among the Minuteman communities.

[Roy Belson]: 16 communities voted on September 20th.

[Roy Belson]: 10% of the population in those 16 communities came out to vote.

[Roy Belson]: Some communities only had 2%.

[Roy Belson]: Some of the communities are withdrawing.

[Roy Belson]: There were 16 communities in Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: It's down to 10 now and by the end of this year.

[Roy Belson]: And then Belmont looks like it will withdraw, so it'll bring it down to nine.

[Roy Belson]: This gives you an idea of what's going on, but they will get to build their building, but they'll build it for a number that I don't believe they're going to fulfill.

[Roy Belson]: The one thing I want to bring to your attention is that our population is decreasing at Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: And I think within two years, we'll have no one there.

[Roy Belson]: But should we have someone there, one of the provisions of the new regulations called for a capital fee, which we feel is an unfunded mandate, and we will contest with many of the communities that are on this back sheet.

[Roy Belson]: But the commissioners put it out, and it gives you an idea of how many communities are involved.

[Roy Belson]: There's like 34 outside of the district communities, most of whom will object to that fee.

[Roy Belson]: We think that they've underestimated the actual cost.

[Roy Belson]: We think that Minuteman could cost a place like Arlington, New England, $30,000 to $40,000 per student.

[Roy Belson]: Going forward, I think it's absurd, but it is what it is.

[Roy Belson]: And we think we'll be out of it, but

[Roy Belson]: informed, and I want you to know that we will, with other communities that are out of district, be initiating appropriate legal action through the Division of Local Mandates, and then, if necessary, through the courts, to avoid any kind of possibility that a capital fee could actually come home to roost at some point should an individual come in.

[Roy Belson]: We don't believe that's appropriate.

[Roy Belson]: We don't have equity in the project.

[Roy Belson]: We don't believe the number is appropriate.

[Roy Belson]: This year, we made four administrative appointments that filled vacancies covered by two resignations, one retirement, and one promotion.

[Roy Belson]: And we reduced one administrative position in the special education budget during budget time.

[Roy Belson]: There were 32 new teachers hired to fill gaps caused by resignations, retirements, leaves of absence, and non-rehires.

[Roy Belson]: And there were multiple shifts of teachers to different positions to better address enrollment and program needs based on individual building preferences.

[Roy Belson]: Additionally, we hired a few new positions based on our budget deliberations, including one middle school librarian, one math coach, one middle school adjustment Councilor,

[Roy Belson]: behavior specialist and three full-time kindergarten aides from previously part-time aides at the Robins.

[Roy Belson]: We were also able to cover both clerical reductions with internal transfers.

[Roy Belson]: There were multiple changes among paraprofessionals and we're working on a full listing that's still evolving a little bit and we'll provide that to you as soon as we feel comfortable that it's solid.

[Roy Belson]: School security plans are in place at all schools and principals have been conducting practice drills

[Roy Belson]: In the first couple of days of school, I visited the schools and walked over to some of them, and everyone was evacuating.

[Roy Belson]: So I thought maybe school wasn't going to happen, but they were actually practicing.

[Roy Belson]: And there was no disruption to school operations caused by the September 8, 2016 primary election at five of our school sites.

[Roy Belson]: We will be closed for the November election, since that's a much heavier election, being a presidential election, and the turnout should be close to 80% versus the 15% or so

[Roy Belson]: som kommer till primär.

[Roy Belson]: Pat is working very hard with the company.

[Roy Belson]: And Ludlow is a perennial state.

[Roy Belson]: They've won 17 state soccer championships for boys.

[Roy Belson]: And Medford has been in the state championship game three times.

[Roy Belson]: And each time we lost a lot of them.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I played in the first one and we got beat the worst.

[Roy Belson]: So I'll take I'll take the heat for that.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is is this time for the last two times we played them, we've tied them one to one.

[Roy Belson]: The next time we play them, we're going to win.

[Roy Belson]: So just so you know what's going on.

[Roy Belson]: All right.

[Roy Belson]: We may come out to vote a contract.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, you have a report in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: It's a preliminary report.

[Roy Belson]: As you know, school opens tomorrow for grades

[Roy Belson]: 1 through 12.

[Roy Belson]: Kindergarten will come in next week on September 7th, on Wednesday.

[Roy Belson]: In preparation for the opening of school, administrators have been meeting all last week and all throughout the summer, hiring and reviewing necessary policies, protocols, and programs.

[Roy Belson]: We've also participated in meetings with our new teachers, staff, contractors to ensure they're off to a great start.

[Roy Belson]: Enrollment in the school is increasing.

[Roy Belson]: We'll reserve judgment on the need for maybe additional faculty or staff until we see who actually shows up in the first week or so of school.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll calculate actual attendance at that time, which is typical practice for us.

[Roy Belson]: Transportation routes are posted online.

[Roy Belson]: We used Transfinder this year, our first time using that.

[Roy Belson]: As usual, adjustments are made during the first month to reflect actual ridership.

[Roy Belson]: And we're working to consolidate at least one bus

[Roy Belson]: and possibly downsize one bus to a smaller vehicle heading to Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: Security plans are in place.

[Roy Belson]: All schools have updated their plans and scheduled drills to practice the various response measures.

[Roy Belson]: I've attached a copy of a recent article which I sent you previously, but in case you didn't see it, on the bomb scares in Medford Public Schools and was in the American School Board's journal featuring Medford.

[Roy Belson]: A preliminary report on our summer maintenance and repair work has been included.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. McLaughlin is here.

[Roy Belson]: A lot was done, a lot more will be done.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight we'll discuss capital planning, which is another dimension of our building repairs and long-term improvement of our facilities.

[Roy Belson]: Additional work was completed in our buildings with the help of the vocational school faculty and staff.

[Roy Belson]: And we're awarding a new contract to cleaning service sometime this week.

[Roy Belson]: We've interviewed multiple vendors.

[Roy Belson]: We've narrowed it down to four individuals, four individual groups, and we should have a decision probably by tomorrow or no later than Thursday.

[Roy Belson]: We're working on a new initiative that would have students, especially in the high school and the middle schools, adopt specific sections of their buildings for upkeep and improvement.

[Roy Belson]: Almost like what you see in the islands around the city where you adopt an island and the like.

[Roy Belson]: We'll have you some details on this initiative at a subsequent meeting.

[Roy Belson]: After school and before school programs are ready to go.

[Roy Belson]: Demand for these programs and services continues to grow.

[Roy Belson]: We're working hard to ensure that we have enough staff.

[Roy Belson]: It's a little challenging as people come and go in this after school staff at the outset.

[Roy Belson]: And sometimes people become available if they feel they don't have another type of job for themselves at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Supplies materials are on hand for the opening.

[Roy Belson]: New techs have been ordered and will be in place this month.

[Roy Belson]: Team Medford, Hallmark Health, and they'll be with us on the meeting at the 12th, along with Armstrong Ambulance and Staples, presented over $27,000 worth of additional school supplies to us this past week.

[Roy Belson]: Our athletic teams have been practicing and will be ready for their openings in September.

[Roy Belson]: A fall schedule is included in your materials.

[Roy Belson]: The marching band practices virtually every day.

[Roy Belson]: and they'll be very active in our games and other community events this year.

[Roy Belson]: I've enclosed some additional articles that have been in the transcript and on our blog that highlight Medford school programs and in particular I put my first article into the transcript this week entitled standing up together for our Medford public schools and cover a lot of the things that went on and will go on in the public schools.

[Roy Belson]: We've had several meetings with the transcript in an attempt to try and develop a new relationship

[Roy Belson]: that will be positive for the transcript and for the public schools.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll follow up with a report on the actual opening of our schools at a regularly scheduled meeting on September 12, 2016.

[Roy Belson]: Again, if we go to the next page, you'll see the typed copy of what was actually in the transcript on August 25th, listing many of the programs.

[Roy Belson]: One of the interesting parts of this first part was that, you know, obviously I'm calling for parents to

[Roy Belson]: stay engaged with us and for us to work with them and to encourage their involvement and giving them ways that they can participate in your meetings and in conjunction with the school system.

[Roy Belson]: We spoke to the faculty about a similar thing this week and we think that we're making that a serious priority going forward.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not going to read through this thing.

[Roy Belson]: I know you've had opportunities to go through these things yourself and if you have any questions I'll be happy to comment on any of it.

[Roy Belson]: It's hard to know whether the buses are going to get there on time in the first week because in the first week a lot of people are still figuring it out.

[Roy Belson]: Some people arrive at the stops a little bit late.

[Roy Belson]: We think we schedule them to get there on time.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, Pat may have another view.

[Roy Belson]: on that with the teachers.

[Roy Belson]: So, happy to take any questions you have.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sure it is and we'll correct it.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: Unless you want to come on the 16th and we'll be happy to hold a meeting for you.

[Roy Belson]: Because what you have is you have people coming and you have people going who don't tell us.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, you'll get a class size chart in our first meeting in September.

[Roy Belson]: That'll give us enough time to really see whether people are going to be with us or go or what it really looks like.

[Roy Belson]: But it looks like we've got it under control.

[Roy Belson]: People can come and go.

[Roy Belson]: So we'll see.

[Roy Belson]: Again, when they actually show, we've got pretty good enrollments right now, but let's see what actually shows.

[Roy Belson]: We are a little stressed on after school staff.

[Roy Belson]: It seems like as people get jobs, they leave that program.

[Roy Belson]: So there's some turnover there, but everyone's working hard to make sure that that's done.

[Roy Belson]: Absolutely.

[Roy Belson]: So what we did was we certainly talked to

[Roy Belson]: our principals and also to Ed Finn, the city clerk, about the location of each polling station.

[Roy Belson]: Now at each polling station, there is a Medford police officer who will be assigned.

[Roy Belson]: So they will be there, and the entrance to and from will be reserved strictly for the people polling.

[Roy Belson]: Students will not go through those entrances or exits, and the people will not be allowed into the buildings in any other way, unless they're coming there for a student as well as election, and then they have to sign in.

[Roy Belson]: Each polling area will have its own entrance.

[Roy Belson]: The police officer will be there.

[Roy Belson]: All day.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, they rotate.

[Roy Belson]: They're not there all the time, but they rotate.

[Roy Belson]: And I did speak to a few parents who called, and you know, someone might keep their youngster home for that day.

[Roy Belson]: I understand some people are more concerned than others about that, but

[Roy Belson]: If we start breaking up the beginning of school, we lose all momentum this first couple weeks of school because of Labor Day and other things that come up.

[Roy Belson]: I'm wondering whether or not if we wouldn't do something like a backpack express.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes robo calls kind of get people uptight.

[Roy Belson]: Yep.

[Roy Belson]: And if we send them a letter from the school saying how it's going to be set up, that might be an easier way for them to see it.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: Yes.

[Roy Belson]: Absolutely.

[Roy Belson]: Absolutely.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sure we can set that up.

[Roy Belson]: These are some additional pieces of paper.

[Roy Belson]: So as you know, the mayor has been working hard with her staff to create a capital plan for the city.

[Roy Belson]: And the school system was asked to create our own capital plan based on our best estimates and judgment as to what we needed.

[Roy Belson]: Naturally, the mayor wants each of you to have the opportunity to review what's in this document so that you can either add, subtract, or modify

[Roy Belson]: what's here as she continues with her plan to present something that's a system-wide plan to the city and the city council would obviously have to approve any kind of bonding.

[Roy Belson]: As we do capital plans, there are four basic functions and we prioritize based on that basis.

[Roy Belson]: Health and safety.

[Roy Belson]: If there was a health and safety issue, we'd want to address that as early as possible.

[Roy Belson]: A functional need for the operation of the schools, something that would keep us from operating the school.

[Roy Belson]: The third would be something of educational value, and the last would be a cosmetic improvement.

[Roy Belson]: Albeit, sometimes things are all of the above, or two or more of the above, but we try to at least deal with health and safety and functional needs first to the extent possible.

[Roy Belson]: Each project should be reviewed with an eye towards an alternative source of funding.

[Roy Belson]: I've just passed out

[Roy Belson]: some information about something coming through MSBA on technology and DESE.

[Roy Belson]: I've spoke to MSBA again today and DESE to get some latest information.

[Roy Belson]: We expect that an RFP will come out of DESE and MSBA in the next few weeks, and then we'll be able to respond more formally to any kind of technology investment that's involved.

[Roy Belson]: have to be scheduled in ways that reduce or eliminate disruption.

[Roy Belson]: When we did the science labs, you can see obviously we had to move a lot of people around.

[Roy Belson]: When we do anything that affects classroom space, we try to do it in a way that eliminates disruption or at least reduces it and doesn't impact operations to the greatest extent possible.

[Roy Belson]: have to be scheduled to reflect emergent or anticipated legal and as well as educational requirements.

[Roy Belson]: Some things we have to do legally, for example, this year at the beginning we put in another ramp into the Caron Theater to meet the handicap requirements.

[Roy Belson]: Other things like that would be necessary to consider.

[Roy Belson]: Proposed project solicitance report based upon our best current cost estimates.

[Roy Belson]: They've been rounded out.

[Roy Belson]: I didn't try to get to $210.26.

[Roy Belson]: You know, it's $200,000, it's $200,000, and it could be $5,000, $10,000, $15,000, more or less, one way or another.

[Roy Belson]: There may be a preference for combining certain projects in any given year that could produce a preferred economy.

[Roy Belson]: And the first step is obviously for you to review it.

[Roy Belson]: Now, we broke it out by school, and we broke it out in five years.

[Roy Belson]: So if you look at

[Roy Belson]: The schools, you'll see that there's year one projections, year two projections, year three projections, year four and year five projections.

[Roy Belson]: There is also a piece for technology as the last item, and it's broken up into instructional technology and network technology, as well as district-wide and equipment needs.

[Roy Belson]: So we try to break it out in categories that were easy to understand and to give us a sense of how we would distribute.

[Roy Belson]: Again, as the mayor points out,

[Roy Belson]: This is a preliminary list.

[Roy Belson]: It's intended to get the conversation going to keep you involved.

[Roy Belson]: Well, at the same token, it's still aspirational at this point, and a lot depends on what other needs exist in the city and what other things can be done through alternative source of funding.

[Roy Belson]: I want to begin by thanking Pat for putting the technical side of this all together and working very hard with other school officials with John and others to identify

[Roy Belson]: what we thought we needed, sat down and went over it.

[Roy Belson]: I want to thank the city's Procurement Officer Schaub for her work in trading ideas with us.

[Roy Belson]: We have an individual sheet for each project or each area, so you can look at that as well.

[Roy Belson]: And I think having said all of that, Madam Mayor, I think we're ready to take any feedback, and I would suggest we go school by school, go down the list, and if you see something that you think isn't there,

[Roy Belson]: And let us know, and if you see something that you don't think deserves attention, let us know.

[Roy Belson]: And if you think we're not spending enough of the mayor's money, then let us know.

[Roy Belson]: And we're happy to spend money, we like to spend money.

[Roy Belson]: Again, if I can, you know, the playgrounds are functional.

[Roy Belson]: They may not be beautiful because of the, you know, the rips in it.

[Roy Belson]: We can patch them and make them functional.

[Roy Belson]: There are some things that we need to do because the building air quality or safety factors would be far more significant.

[Roy Belson]: So, but that's why this is a discussion.

[Roy Belson]: This is where you would feed in and say, you know, I think that's more of an issue than you thought it was an issue.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, we try to spread it out so that as the mayor points out,

[Roy Belson]: As she goes over what her needs are citywide, that there's some distribution across a time frame that's believable financially.

[Roy Belson]: But again, it's all interchangeable.

[Roy Belson]: So that's why we're here talking.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, we get site council reports.

[Roy Belson]: We look at those.

[Roy Belson]: John McLaughlin is obviously involved in every school with buildings and repairs and things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: Pat and I have seen any number of requests over a period of time.

[Roy Belson]: We've also been conscious of things we have to do.

[Roy Belson]: So for example, the vocational school, we know when we did a compliance audit that we know we have to change the door handles on doors to stay compliant because of their handicapped accessibility.

[Roy Belson]: So we tried to take all the pieces of information that came from multiple sources

[Roy Belson]: We met with principals at the end of the school year, we've talked to them since.

[Roy Belson]: So we get input from virtually everybody.

[Roy Belson]: But again, I'm sure different people would have different priorities because obviously, if it's theirs, it's a higher priority than if it's someone else's.

[Roy Belson]: All right.

[Roy Belson]: Well, signage is probably more of an operating budget item, you know, unless it were major pieces of signage.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, in general science, we do that through operating budgets.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, we'll sit down with Dr. Perella and find out what he has in mind.

[Roy Belson]: So we were semi-finalists and we didn't become finalists.

[Roy Belson]: I can't believe the poor judgment on the part of the Jobs Foundation, but nevertheless, you know, the idea is still there and the enthusiasm in the school is still there, but the funding that we had hoped for that particular source is not there for us right now.

[Roy Belson]: But there may be some other source of funding that we can look at and

[Roy Belson]: But that funding is not there.

[Roy Belson]: We can certainly add the library as an item.

[Roy Belson]: The question is, you know, what do we want to, what do we project for that?

[Roy Belson]: And that's something we'd have to do a little bit of homework on.

[Roy Belson]: This is a big place.

[Roy Belson]: Depends what we want to do.

[Roy Belson]: Furniture would be involved.

[Roy Belson]: Certainly rugs, ceilings, lighting.

[Roy Belson]: It's a major expense.

[Roy Belson]: So I would estimate just off the top, we're talking at least a million dollars.

[Roy Belson]: So again you know this is the beginning of a capital plan and there's a lot of things on here we probably haven't fully discussed but internally we're aware of things that should be done from our standpoint so the idea with modular units is that space at the high school is becoming premium

[Roy Belson]: and more and more programs are being developed at the vocational school and other activities.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result, the thought was if we can recapture the skateboard park, we may want to build on what is the skateboard park now for a certain number of programs.

[Roy Belson]: And that would be a very interesting way for us to expand our programming while at the same time using space that right now is badly used in my opinion.

[Roy Belson]: So let me try and say it this way, because I think this is probably the best way to, because we're going to go through this question over and over again.

[Roy Belson]: There are probably a lot of things that you haven't, as a committee, envisioned because you don't live it every day.

[Roy Belson]: And there are other things you would know about, or think about, or hear about that we haven't thought too hard about.

[Roy Belson]: Like, you know, you just mentioned the library, we thought maybe, you know.

[Roy Belson]: So there's going to be some back and forth.

[Roy Belson]: This is not a final document, but this is a preliminary planning document to get your input, to see what kinds of concerns either you have for

[Roy Belson]: inclusion or deletion so that we can move forward.

[Roy Belson]: And then as we move forward, then we would clearly detail each of our items.

[Roy Belson]: Going forward also, remember,

[Roy Belson]: once year one goes or year two goes, it may be that year three, four, and five change dramatically after year one and two because of other considerations.

[Roy Belson]: So this is a plan.

[Roy Belson]: A plan is subject to change, is subject to modification all the way through.

[Roy Belson]: It's just an attempt to try and lay out what we see and what might be possible and challenge us to think about what could be to our advantage.

[Roy Belson]: When this high school was built, there were over 25 schools in the school district.

[Roy Belson]: And while they were smaller, they housed any number of things.

[Roy Belson]: Also, there was the Forest Street complex

[Roy Belson]: which has the office of the superintendent and a number of other programs as well.

[Roy Belson]: As we consolidated down those programs, you know, I mean those spaces get pushed into other areas, that's one.

[Roy Belson]: Secondly, special education has grown exponentially.

[Roy Belson]: ELL has grown exponentially.

[Roy Belson]: Other mandated programs that we have put in place that didn't previously exist have grown exponentially.

[Roy Belson]: Our vocational school has expanded

[Roy Belson]: exponentially in terms of programs so we're doing more with the space we have and we have less total space than we had years ago so clearly you know it's not the same ballgame that it was when

[Roy Belson]: this building housed, I don't think we ever got to 4,000, but about 3,600, 3,700.

[Roy Belson]: I think we exaggerated a little because it sounded really good, you know, back then.

[Roy Belson]: But I think the reality was is that, and also back then, there was open campus, if you remember, and not everybody had a room every day.

[Roy Belson]: So if you were, you know, didn't have a class, you might have been in the cafeteria, you weren't in the classroom.

[Roy Belson]: There are a lot of factors that would mitigate against these things, and plus the fact, too, that there's specialized areas now, occupational therapy, vision testing, things of that type that we didn't have back then.

[Roy Belson]: I think one of the things you need to do is assume the early iterations of some, let's say, modular classrooms

[Roy Belson]: maybe look like trailers.

[Roy Belson]: We've had some that looked a little bit like a trailer.

[Roy Belson]: There were more wooden structures at the Davenport, at the Fulton, and places like that at different times in history.

[Roy Belson]: But today's modular classrooms, you wouldn't know the difference just from the outside.

[Roy Belson]: What they can do today is prefab housing, prefab buildings.

[Roy Belson]: It's amazing.

[Roy Belson]: They slap them up, and they put them together very nicely, and they're durable.

[Roy Belson]: and they've got steel and they've got other things in them that are more expensive, to be sure.

[Roy Belson]: But they can easily be put up and they do create legitimate space.

[Roy Belson]: So the day of the trailer-like modular classroom has gone away.

[Roy Belson]: So Madam Mayor, if we could maybe take a few second breaks so we could prepare for the next activity and we get the first candidate in.

[Roy Belson]: There were well over 20 individuals who applied for this position, some of whom did not have appropriate credentials.

[Roy Belson]: They liked the job.

[Roy Belson]: But I think this evening we have three very fine individuals.

[Roy Belson]: And the process for those of you who have not done it before, the veterans who have done it before as we've had interviews of this type, is that we ask our candidate to give us a little bit of information about themselves, to tell us a little bit of why they think they should be our Director of Finance and Administration.

[Roy Belson]: We then go around the room and give each of you a chance to ask one or two questions, and then maybe a second round.
