[Roy Belson]: So we've reached that point of the evening.

[Roy Belson]: Let's sum it all up with another question.

[Roy Belson]: We've reached that point of the evening, Diane, where you get to tell us something we haven't asked you that you want us to know, or to sum it all up and tell us why you're the best person for this job.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Superintendent, welcome tonight.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you, Mr. President, members of the council.

[Roy Belson]: It was before you last week, and I went over the budget in detail with you.

[Roy Belson]: You did ask for some additional information.

[Roy Belson]: I believe it was forwarded to you over the weekend, if not sooner.

[Roy Belson]: And I'm not sure what specifically you want to talk about, but if there's something specific, I'd be happy to talk.

[Roy Belson]: So as Director of Finance and Administration pointed out, the proposed budget was $54,333,000.

[Roy Belson]: It's an increase over FY 2016 of $1.4 the overall projected

[Roy Belson]: appropriated budget represents a 2.6 increase from last year, and the budget is buttressed by 2.1 of generated revenue.

[Roy Belson]: When the generated revenue is included, the actual projected budgetary expense will be 56,443,392, or a 3.2% increase over FY 2016.

[Roy Belson]: Also, as we've indicated, various aid allocations and grants from federal, state, non-profit groups, corporate sources, and the like are factored in.

[Roy Belson]: We are concerned that the state budget is under some duress right now, because there are funds that come to the school directly from the state, and it's hard to know what the conference committee is going to do.

[Roy Belson]: There are some funds that could be vulnerable, especially since the governor has indicated that the projected shortfall going forward is greater than was originally anticipated, by about $200,000 more than was previously anticipated.

[Roy Belson]: We provide sufficient resources to enable us to meet the requirements of state and federal mandates that are in place.

[Roy Belson]: Undoubtedly, there are a number of contingencies that happen every year that we have to make adjustments for.

[Roy Belson]: Fiscal 2016 saw the successful negotiations of virtually every contract in the school department.

[Roy Belson]: There is one contract out there, but we believe that will close sometime over the next two weeks.

[Roy Belson]: That's with the Carpenters.

[Roy Belson]: There are only three members of that particular group.

[Roy Belson]: But all the funding that we need is accounted for in that budget proposal and budget that was approved by the Medford School Committee on June 20th.

[Roy Belson]: We're working with the mayor, as you know, and you've asked for some of these things on capital planning.

[Roy Belson]: You asked for a listing.

[Roy Belson]: I gave you a listing.

[Roy Belson]: I also gave you a short-term listing of things that we thought might happen sooner or would like to happen sooner.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, it has to be factored into the total cities approach.

[Roy Belson]: to capital planning, and we look forward to working with the mayor.

[Roy Belson]: We've talked about a number of things.

[Roy Belson]: Overall enrollments in the schools remain pretty stable.

[Roy Belson]: Class sizes are very, very good.

[Roy Belson]: The actual distributions by school will vary somewhat as people come and go during the summer months.

[Roy Belson]: The vocational enrollment is definitively up, and there are a number of new offerings that we think are

[Roy Belson]: terrific offerings, and our young people are flocking to them.

[Roy Belson]: Minute Man allocation has been sharply reduced over the last several years.

[Roy Belson]: Three years ago it was a million dollars.

[Roy Belson]: It's now down to about 400, and it will be less than that going forward.

[Roy Belson]: We do anticipate some increase in ELL students, students who don't speak English as a first language.

[Roy Belson]: We have some retirements.

[Roy Belson]: I've indicated that some of that will come and go.

[Roy Belson]: And when we gave you the budget, it was 16 known retirements.

[Roy Belson]: There may be a couple more that come in over the summer because people are talking to us, but I can't tell you who they are at this point because they haven't made up their mind.

[Roy Belson]: There were approximately 11 faculty members when we gave you this budget originally who were not going to be rehired.

[Roy Belson]: I think we made some decisions to rehire at least two of those that were previously on the list to not be rehired.

[Roy Belson]: There may be a couple more that we bring back.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes we put people on a list like that as to give us more time.

[Roy Belson]: The state law requires that when we have a non-professional status teacher, we have to notify them by June 15th if we believe that we may not rehire them.

[Roy Belson]: That's not true for other kinds of positions, but it is true for teachers.

[Roy Belson]: So we sometimes put some extra people on that list just to be sure that we've covered the bases.

[Roy Belson]: Elementary supplies have increased.

[Roy Belson]: All supplies across the district have increased.

[Roy Belson]: I think I did tell you that Envision was in its last year of payment.

[Roy Belson]: It's about $82,000.

[Roy Belson]: And after that, we'll be able to take that amount and use it in other areas.

[Roy Belson]: We did tell you a little bit about our desire not to ask parents to provide substantial amounts of supplies and materials that the school department believes we provide quite a bit.

[Roy Belson]: and that we should be able to cover their needs without asking parents to do much more than a handful of things that they would use at home for the youngster coming home, paper, pencils, pens, rulers, things of that type that might be necessary.

[Roy Belson]: The science budget included 10,000 funding for additional elementary science kits.

[Roy Belson]: The Journey's English language program has already been paid for.

[Roy Belson]: The ELL budget has 6,000 more in it.

[Roy Belson]: There's also additional $2,000 for translation services.

[Roy Belson]: And we've added 1.5 positions to that area to accommodate the incoming people.

[Roy Belson]: The special ed department will add an adjustment Councilor to that level.

[Roy Belson]: There will be 16 adjustment psychologists and four behavioral specialists going forward.

[Roy Belson]: But we've added a fifth behaviorist as part of the discussions with the school committee in their last hearing.

[Roy Belson]: And it's also included in what I've sent to you.

[Roy Belson]: We've eliminated one administrative position, the clinical coordinator's position.

[Roy Belson]: We've added a librarian to the middle school, so each school will have access to a full-time librarian.

[Roy Belson]: Not full-time, but they'll share a librarian plus some para help.

[Roy Belson]: We've added a math coach to the elementary schools.

[Roy Belson]: We've added three full-time kindergarten aides to the Roberts Elementary.

[Roy Belson]: And I believe that's the limit on that.

[Roy Belson]: The vocational school will be adding four teachers to support expanded programs, engineering, robotics, business technology, multimedia program, computer, and business.

[Roy Belson]: Hospitality program is envisioned.

[Roy Belson]: It may happen with some additional dollars that come from the outside.

[Roy Belson]: The vocational budget is $10,000 more for instructional supplies, an additional $23,000 to support needed equipment.

[Roy Belson]: And they also get $65,000 of Perkins federal funds

[Roy Belson]: that we think will be good.

[Roy Belson]: They'll also, as I indicate, save some money in the tuition to Minuteman.

[Roy Belson]: The English department has added $2,000 for textbooks and also e-readers.

[Roy Belson]: It will also help to support a program that helps youngsters in transition.

[Roy Belson]: The mathematics department will be adopting a new high school textbook program with an annual payment of $36,000 each for three years.

[Roy Belson]: Additional math upgrades will follow over the next two years as the Envision payment is done this year.

[Roy Belson]: The department will also be doing some work with school computer science programs and share some teaching time.

[Roy Belson]: The science department has $10,000 increase to fund the elementary engineering program.

[Roy Belson]: I indicated that before.

[Roy Belson]: The social studies department maintains a strong textbook account of $20,000.

[Roy Belson]: That will help them with their advanced placement European textbooks and with

[Roy Belson]: other books that are part of their overall program, including a global scholars program.

[Roy Belson]: They did add 14 classroom sets of new eighth grade US history textbooks this past year.

[Roy Belson]: The foreign language department has an increase of $11,200 to support the acquisition of new Spanish textbooks and to support the Latin program that has been reinstituted.

[Roy Belson]: The physical education department, health education, will receive 9,000 more in place of classroom supplies and equipment system wide.

[Roy Belson]: That came from a decrease in the need to fund the Michigan model, which has already been purchased.

[Roy Belson]: That's the health education model that we use in conjunction with our substance abuse prevention program.

[Roy Belson]: The Fine Arts Department will stay consistent when 9,600 was added to support programs.

[Roy Belson]: We did talk about the band program.

[Roy Belson]: We're working on a paper that we will bring to you to sell off some old musical instruments and deposit that in a gift account that will require your approval.

[Roy Belson]: so that we can then reinvest that in the music department going forward.

[Roy Belson]: The library and media instructional technology has been increased by $14,900.

[Roy Belson]: It's on top of last year's $70,000 increase, which we put in the budget for instructional supplies to ensure that our technology is properly able to go forward.

[Roy Belson]: There are several grants that fund these things as well.

[Roy Belson]: We have some money in Block 03 for technology infrastructure.

[Roy Belson]: The Health Services Department provides a nursing service to our schools and contributes greatly to our efforts to support social emotional issues and substance abuse prevention.

[Roy Belson]: The staff also assists with SPED medical issues that are part of IEPs and 504 plans.

[Roy Belson]: The small increase in the budget to cover contractual professional development and summer coverage.

[Roy Belson]: I told you that the Department of Public Health gave us a $15,000 grant to coordinate with outside agencies.

[Roy Belson]: It's an innovative grant.

[Roy Belson]: Not many in the Commonwealth at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully, we can do something really good with it.

[Roy Belson]: The Department of Public Health also pays for at least the majority of at least one other nursing physician.

[Roy Belson]: The guidance department added an additional Councilor to staff last year, but they're getting $800 more to help them with their supplies, materials, and professional development.

[Roy Belson]: We will continue to pay for the PSAT program, which enables youngsters to take that version of the SAT at the early stages, because many kids can't afford that.

[Roy Belson]: The middle school budget will see an increase in student activities lines by 2,000 per school.

[Roy Belson]: We will be filling the assistant principal position at the Andrews, which was vacated by the retirement of Miriam Morata.

[Roy Belson]: We will be filling the assistant principal position at the Brooks, which was initiated by the leaving of Kevin Andrews as a principal and the promotion of Suzanne Galussi to the position of principal.

[Roy Belson]: We've increased funding to sustain a third late bus at the middle schools.

[Roy Belson]: Parents and others like that, they feel that kids need more time to stay after school.

[Roy Belson]: Medford High School will see a $12,500 increase in non-salary lines to accurately reflect actual expenditures.

[Roy Belson]: The high school student activities block will increase by 10,000.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot of activities going in by the high school.

[Roy Belson]: You see it all the time.

[Roy Belson]: The kids are always coming up with new things.

[Roy Belson]: They're really doing a great job.

[Roy Belson]: The athletic department salary account reflects the actual cost of coaches.

[Roy Belson]: and the trainer's full salary.

[Roy Belson]: Each year we weigh information, the cost of contracted services, officials, bosses, things of that that sometimes drive the cost up.

[Roy Belson]: We're also moving, as we've told you, into the Northeast Conference, effective this spring, so that the GBL will merge in.

[Roy Belson]: The details will flow out in the next little while.

[Roy Belson]: We talked about a user's fee, but we kind of decided at the last minute we weren't going to do that.

[Roy Belson]: We would eat that and try to find other ways to raise money.

[Roy Belson]: Security budget reflects the increase in personnel covering our buildings.

[Roy Belson]: The Raptor technology system is picked up in our technology budget.

[Roy Belson]: We've paid for most of it now, which is supplies and materials.

[Roy Belson]: At this point, we also have some money for camera repairs, but the bulk of camera upgrades will be in capital.

[Roy Belson]: Our operation and maintenance budget reflects a salary increase for custodial and maintenance staffs.

[Roy Belson]: We go out to bid for the cleaning service, projecting a 10% increase.

[Roy Belson]: Our heating and utilities are expected to remain

[Roy Belson]: pretty much the same.

[Roy Belson]: We're adding about $50,000 to the supply budget.

[Roy Belson]: You asked for a breakout, we provided that to you in the weekend distribution to you.

[Roy Belson]: And I indicated major capital repairs would be coming through a different source.

[Roy Belson]: Regular large vehicle pupil transportation is $120,000 higher than last year.

[Roy Belson]: We're in the second year of a contract.

[Roy Belson]: We think we can reduce some of that.

[Roy Belson]: We hope to be able to reduce some of that by using a smaller bus to take youngsters to Minuteman 1 and also to possibly use our new Transfinder route development system possibly to even consolidate and maybe even drop off a bus.

[Roy Belson]: We want to be careful before I say that because obviously I don't want the time to increase for youngsters and travel.

[Roy Belson]: Vocational transportation fund of Block 17 may see some reimbursement from the state.

[Roy Belson]: I'm wary about that.

[Roy Belson]: It's 1.7 million statewide for non-resident transportation.

[Roy Belson]: That's probably a very ripe area to be cut in the state budget and conference committee.

[Roy Belson]: We hope it doesn't.

[Roy Belson]: Special education transportation is up 50,000 from last year, reflecting the cost of small vehicles.

[Roy Belson]: And homeless transportation is also up 50,000.

[Roy Belson]: This was identified as an unfunded mandate originally,

[Roy Belson]: But the state has not funded it at the level that it truly needs.

[Roy Belson]: And there are more and more homeless families that we serve every year.

[Roy Belson]: I've talked to you about the public information officer.

[Roy Belson]: I believe it's a valuable add to us.

[Roy Belson]: I think that the position is well worth what we put into it.

[Roy Belson]: And I believe that we've already seen some significant payback.

[Roy Belson]: So we believe we've provided for many of the priorities identified by our professionals in the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: We all realize no budget provides for everything, and no budget does everything that everyone wants.

[Roy Belson]: A lot of things are aspirational.

[Roy Belson]: And I want to thank my staff and the people that work with me for putting this together, because I believe they've done yeoman's work in making sure that the school budget is a good document.

[Roy Belson]: And the school committee, I believe, put a lot of time in.

[Roy Belson]: They've had several pre-budget hearings, as you know what we're talking about.

[Roy Belson]: They met right through the year, talking with department heads, getting their feedback.

[Roy Belson]: And then they met in June.

[Roy Belson]: twice to go over their priorities and to make final decisions.

[Roy Belson]: So, Mr. President, I think that gives you a little bit to start with, and I'll be happy to take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: I appreciate it.

[Roy Belson]: I know nothing about it.

[Roy Belson]: If it's been done through the city's administration, I'll take the money obviously.

[Roy Belson]: But the school committee does not know about it as far as I know.

[Roy Belson]: Can I ask just a point of clarification?

[Roy Belson]: Listen, I wasn't part of the budget discussion.

[Roy Belson]: As far as I know, it's $54,333,000.

[Roy Belson]: That's the budget.

[Roy Belson]: That's the budget the school committee approved.

[Roy Belson]: The budget line that the school committee approved has not changed since the school committee approved it on the 20th.

[Roy Belson]: It's $54,333,000.

[Roy Belson]: So if something has been added to it, I have not seen anything added to that.

[Roy Belson]: And Ann is telling me that at this point in time, that's the number in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: That's the number in front of you.

[Roy Belson]: That's what the school committee approved.

[Roy Belson]: That's what I know we have.

[Roy Belson]: And I know of no addition outside of the three kindergarten aides to the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: And I indicated in the letter that I sent to you in response to your query that that increase within the lines

[Roy Belson]: It would be taken from certain lines, it would be $23,775.

[Roy Belson]: That's the cost of that particular item, but it's not adding or changing the bottom line.

[Roy Belson]: Anything else?

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, members of the council, I understand that Councilor Marks has legitimate concerns about security.

[Roy Belson]: and the like, but I want to offer a few thoughts, and hopefully, you know, maybe it'll help us understand each other, okay?

[Roy Belson]: Well, let's see what happens.

[Roy Belson]: Let's see what happens.

[Roy Belson]: You know, during the day, we have intensive security.

[Roy Belson]: It's not perfect, but it's a lot better than most school systems.

[Roy Belson]: We have, and we, and you know, some of the events that happened this year obviously ramped up some of the things that we did, because people felt a need to do that.

[Roy Belson]: when the majority of youngsters are there in the school, and they're in concentrated areas, and they need that kind of coverage.

[Roy Belson]: So we have a lot going on.

[Roy Belson]: We have cameras.

[Roy Belson]: We have monitors.

[Roy Belson]: We have guards.

[Roy Belson]: We have resource officers.

[Roy Belson]: We have door locks in the systems.

[Roy Belson]: You know, we have ID systems now.

[Roy Belson]: We meet with CBJ every week to determine what's happening in the streets, so when it comes in Monday morning, we know what's going on, what happened over the weekend,

[Roy Belson]: We have constant contact with the police.

[Roy Belson]: We have constant contact with the DA's office, the courts.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot going on that people don't see.

[Roy Belson]: We belong to NMLEC, which is a regional group that brings things in.

[Roy Belson]: But council raises the issue of what happens around 3.30 when things are over for the main part of the day.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe, just maybe, it would be nice to have all kinds of people there, but you've got to ask a couple questions.

[Roy Belson]: How functionally effective would it be?

[Roy Belson]: Not just cosmetic, how functionally effective would it be?

[Roy Belson]: I'm standing here right now, and there are probably a few people in this room who don't like me.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know if that's true, but I have the feeling that there's some people who don't really like me.

[Roy Belson]: My back is to the wall.

[Roy Belson]: There's no police officer guarding this council.

[Roy Belson]: There's no police officer at churches and synagogues.

[Roy Belson]: There's no police officer at the restaurants we go to, in the parks where the Little Leagues play.

[Roy Belson]: Point of information, Mr. President.

[Roy Belson]: Well, I don't know.

[Roy Belson]: I'm trying to give a point of information.

[Roy Belson]: No, I'm trying to give you an answer.

[Roy Belson]: I'm trying to point out to you.

[Roy Belson]: Not in the afternoon, not thousands in the building.

[Roy Belson]: You know, the parks where the kids play their sports.

[Roy Belson]: I don't see all kinds of people there.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, it would be nice to have all kinds of people around who are doing that officially.

[Roy Belson]: But you talk about all the things that we want in these budgets.

[Roy Belson]: You talk about all the things that we would like to do and all the repairs we'd like to make.

[Roy Belson]: And I personally think that putting people in these roles is not giving us functional value.

[Roy Belson]: I think we can get the same return

[Roy Belson]: from people who are crime watchers, if you will, people who can pick up their phone or use their cell and call 911 if necessary.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think you need that kind of coverage.

[Roy Belson]: So we've talked about it.

[Roy Belson]: I'm listening to you.

[Roy Belson]: I hear you.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe there's something we can think about, but I don't think it's the kind of thing that we could do

[Roy Belson]: with fidelity around the schools in the afternoons.

[Roy Belson]: And I don't think that it's different than what we expect from our little leagues, from our youth programs, soccer programs.

[Roy Belson]: They're all over the city.

[Roy Belson]: Random acts of violence happen anywhere.

[Roy Belson]: So to think that the schools are more likely to have them in the afternoon than the parks where the kids play, or the churches where people go to, or the restaurants where people eat.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think that's real.

[Roy Belson]: And so, it's an exchange.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, I'll think about it.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe there's some things we can do.

[Roy Belson]: But I don't think it's a just refusal to consider the issue.

[Roy Belson]: I think it's well thought through at this point in time.

[Roy Belson]: But maybe you don't agree with me.

[Roy Belson]: That's what I think is really the issue.

[Roy Belson]: We just don't agree on the subject.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm standing here.

[Roy Belson]: Is anyone protecting you right now?

[Roy Belson]: Is anyone protecting me?

[Roy Belson]: Is anyone protecting the citizens of this community right now standing here?

[Roy Belson]: Anyone could walk in and say anything.

[Roy Belson]: Anyone could walk in and do something.

[Roy Belson]: You know, we recognize we live in a society which has some violence to it.

[Roy Belson]: We recognize we live in a society where there's a lot of random acts of terror and activity.

[Roy Belson]: But you can't cover everything.

[Roy Belson]: You can't cover everything realistically.

[Roy Belson]: And putting a couple of people in the place is not going to be a functional value to us.

[Roy Belson]: We can get the same return.

[Roy Belson]: Let me finish the point.

[Roy Belson]: We disagree on the functional value of that type of person in the situation.

[Roy Belson]: But if you want to continue the discussion, maybe the school committee can take it up.

[Roy Belson]: We can have a discussion, but it's going to require some money.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to require, what do you call it, an understanding of what they do and how they do it, and whether or not it's really going to give us value or whether or not it's cosmetic.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm just raising that for you.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think that in the best of all worlds, we wouldn't have everything we wanted.

[Roy Belson]: You've raised several things that we want.

[Roy Belson]: I want a lot of things that I couldn't put in this budget.

[Roy Belson]: There are people that ask me for things that I couldn't give them.

[Roy Belson]: okay, in this budget, or any budget.

[Roy Belson]: I've been doing it for a few years, and I recognize that there are times when you just can't do something.

[Roy Belson]: I don't think that we are neglectful in this situation.

[Roy Belson]: I do believe that when we cover the school day, we're doing what we need to do.

[Roy Belson]: But, okay, look, it's a discussion.

[Roy Belson]: And I appreciate the fact you care, but I also hope you appreciate the fact that we've thought about it.

[Roy Belson]: I haven't just dismissed it out of hand.

[Roy Belson]: I've thought about it, but I don't think it gives us functional value.

[Roy Belson]: Okay?

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President, if I could.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. President.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to comment on something that keeps coming up.

[Roy Belson]: You know, I've sat here and listened to everyone talk about the lack of communication, the lack of information, the lack of stuff that's going out to the public.

[Roy Belson]: I want to tell you, that public information officer has put an awful lot of stuff on the street.

[Roy Belson]: There's an awful lot of information in this community about the schools.

[Roy Belson]: More information than you've ever had before, and people are telling me that.

[Roy Belson]: And you know what?

[Roy Belson]: We can disagree on that, too.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is, is that you talk about public information, they're getting it from the schools.

[Roy Belson]: They're getting it from the schools.

[Roy Belson]: You'll see the budget soon as you approve it.

[Roy Belson]: It'll go right up.

[Roy Belson]: just like it has every year.

[Roy Belson]: And if you want to change that, you just simply vote to have people put their proposed budgets up.

[Roy Belson]: That's all.

[Roy Belson]: But you never did that.

[Roy Belson]: All you did was ask, what do you call it, to put the money up.

[Roy Belson]: And our members of the committee will call on our Deputy Superintendent to tell us about the Administrative Work Week, which will take place beginning on Wednesday of this week.

[Roy Belson]: Good evening.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, as you know, for a period of time now, the GBL has diminished in its size as various members opted to go with different leagues in the area.

[Roy Belson]: That meant Medford, Somerville, Malden, and Everett

[Roy Belson]: had become the remaining members of the GBL.

[Roy Belson]: Scheduling and creating athletic opportunities for young people within the GBL becomes progressively difficult.

[Roy Belson]: We have to find teams outside of our area, and every year it's a different situation.

[Roy Belson]: It also deprives our youngsters of competing against other students in other communities that could take on sports that maybe the GBL members choose not to participate in at a particular time.

[Roy Belson]: So our athletic director is here.

[Roy Belson]: We are looking to merge with the NEC, the Northeast Conference.

[Roy Belson]: Many of the schools in the Northeast Conference once belonged to us, like Revere, and Peabody, and places like that.

[Roy Belson]: So we're looking to go to that at this point in time and see if we can't make sure that we have a robust league for our students to play in over the next several years.

[Roy Belson]: It wouldn't start till the spring.

[Roy Belson]: So we have the fall to get used to it.

[Roy Belson]: It doesn't affect the Medford-Malden football game.

[Roy Belson]: Simultaneously, I just want to mention while we're talking about this is that Jack Dempsey, our softball coach, was named the Boston Globe Coach of the Year.

[Roy Belson]: Congratulations, Jack.

[Roy Belson]: And several of our players, senior Ashley Eisner, girls softball, named the Boston Globe's, and Boston knows all scholastic girls softball team, girls softball, girls tennis team, and lacrosse, boys lacrosse are GBL champions.

[Roy Belson]: Those are some highlights from the sports side of things, and if you have any questions, Ms.

[Roy Belson]: Maloney and I can try to answer them for you.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, obviously, anytime we make a move of this type and change our affiliations, we would like your endorsement.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm not sure that it does, because you basically allow us to play any team and, you know, in the area, as long as they're governed by the MIAA and the like.

[Roy Belson]: But it certainly would be a good idea if you did.

[Roy Belson]: This is the option.

[Roy Belson]: This is the option.

[Roy Belson]: We've been trying for an extended period of time to form a league.

[Roy Belson]: Um, but very few, the middle six league would only take us and not Malden and Everett and then Cambridge bolted to.

[Roy Belson]: another week and Waltham bolted to another week.

[Roy Belson]: So before you know it, we were down teams instead of having a robust.

[Roy Belson]: I know that was just, you know, dissipated.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, we have provided to you a fee structure for community schools as you have requested.

[Roy Belson]: You have previously approved the rules and regs for the rentals of facilities.

[Roy Belson]: There are some

[Roy Belson]: additional items here that were made to accommodate youth groups and also some community groups that might not have the resources necessary to access our facilities on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: And we've tried to take into account the things that have been provided to us.

[Roy Belson]: Pat Velie is here to talk about this particular issue.

[Roy Belson]: And Mr. Maloney is also here as the director of community schools.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm going to have Pat take you through the changes that we've made so that you can go over them.

[Roy Belson]: And we can decide if we're going to go forward with this particular schedule.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sorry?

[Roy Belson]: It's the budget that comes next, that comes after this.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee, recently there's been some discussion about a succession plan, whether we would have one.

[Roy Belson]: And so in response to your request, we've put one together for you.

[Roy Belson]: It comes in the two types of scenarios.

[Roy Belson]: The first scenario is that if there was an untimely or unexpected vacancy created by either illness or some other dastardly act,

[Roy Belson]: and the superintendent is unable to perform his duties for whatever reason, then the deputy superintendent would become the interim superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: The school committee would begin a search process for a permanent replacement.

[Roy Belson]: The deputy would serve until either the superintendent returned or a new leader was selected.

[Roy Belson]: The current school system administration is an experienced team that can handle transition and maintain operations for an extended period of time.

[Roy Belson]: I'll just go over.

[Roy Belson]: We have a deputy superintendent, an assistant superintendent, director of finance and administration,

[Roy Belson]: a director of pupil services, director of buildings and grounds, as well as principals, assistant principals, department directors in place.

[Roy Belson]: And each would be able to carry out their essential functions.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that should there be an unexpected situation occur and that things happen to people and things go on, whether it be illness or something else, I think we have a very experienced team in place that could step up and run the school district for a period of time.

[Roy Belson]: And if the committee reached a point where they felt that they had to do something a little bit more permanent, then the next thing would kick in.

[Roy Belson]: If there was an announced vacancy, for example, the superintendent decided to retire, the committee decided not to rehire the superintendent or whatever the case may be, the Medford School Committee could retain the Massachusetts Association of School Committees as one example to conduct a search or a similar organization.

[Roy Belson]: I'll give you a little bit.

[Roy Belson]: A search by an organization costs generally somewhere between $10,000 and $12,000.

[Roy Belson]: That's a typical search for MASC.

[Roy Belson]: If you went to what Lexington did, it cost them $35,000.

[Roy Belson]: They hired a national firm, and they found three people from Massachusetts after they did their national search.

[Roy Belson]: I think, you know, obviously MASC can, you know, can do a very good job.

[Roy Belson]: They do a lot of them around the country, and we can give you examples of it.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that's probably a preferred option.

[Roy Belson]: It's the least expensive for an experienced organization that does it around the state and has many, many contacts.

[Roy Belson]: A comprehensive search process normally takes four to five months.

[Roy Belson]: It isn't a full year process.

[Roy Belson]: Now, naturally, if you're not happy with the candidates, it could take a little bit longer.

[Roy Belson]: But generally, if things go according to normal plan, it's four to five months to complete.

[Roy Belson]: The time frame may vary depending on geographical location of your search.

[Roy Belson]: Now, if you want to bring people in from California or Montana or Hawaii, it may take a little longer to interview them.

[Roy Belson]: If you're interested in bringing people from Massachusetts, New England area, or things like that, New York, Connecticut, you certainly could do this in that time frame.

[Roy Belson]: Of course, a number of community focus groups that you would want to hold.

[Roy Belson]: Some people want to hold focus groups in different sections of the city.

[Roy Belson]: Some people want to do it by school.

[Roy Belson]: Some people want to do it by topic, special ed, ELL.

[Roy Belson]: You can decide whatever approach you'd want to use.

[Roy Belson]: And we can give you guidelines on how to do that if you chose to do that.

[Roy Belson]: The typical search process, five phases, and they're as follows.

[Roy Belson]: Phase one is a leadership profile development.

[Roy Belson]: It takes about a month.

[Roy Belson]: You would sit and talk about, you know, what you expected in a leader.

[Roy Belson]: And you would create, for the organization running the search for you, the kinds of information they would need to put up brochures and do advertisements and be part of the screening process, which would be,

[Roy Belson]: coming on a little bit later.

[Roy Belson]: Phase two would be candidate recruitment.

[Roy Belson]: Once that's decided, brochures would go out, advertisements would go out, and candidates would be recruited.

[Roy Belson]: And then phase three would be candidate screening, also about a month's worth of time.

[Roy Belson]: Then phase four, community evaluation of candidate finalists, because they would be narrowed down to three, four, five people.

[Roy Belson]: And you could do that generally in less than a month.

[Roy Belson]: You may want to take a little longer, but three weeks is generally a normal search.

[Roy Belson]: And then phase five, the appointment and contract negotiation.

[Roy Belson]: Give yourself a little bit of time to meet the person that you might want to hire, and then spend some time talking to that person about terms and conditions of their contract and what your expectations are.

[Roy Belson]: And from time to time, an individual and a candidate decides at the last minute they don't want to be there, or the terms and conditions, so you might have to go back to candidate two, three, four, whatever you choose to do.

[Roy Belson]: I've given you the MASC detailed guidelines for each phase and the kinds of things they would ask.

[Roy Belson]: I can give you more, but I felt tonight this was a good enough start to get going.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, the recent Brookline search took four, it took four months and I attached that for you.

[Roy Belson]: Brookline, uh, much more expansive than some places.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, the selection of an interim superintendent from Malden is scheduled for three months and change.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, they're currently doing it.

[Roy Belson]: They started in May and they hope to have somebody aboard by July one.

[Roy Belson]: The fall river selection took a little better than three months, and that's a bigger community.

[Roy Belson]: But I can give you other examples of, you know, search times, but I wanted to give you a few that you could look at.

[Roy Belson]: I've attached some information, some brochure-like information, and some other things that people have put out.

[Roy Belson]: Again, we can do more if you felt that was necessary.

[Roy Belson]: The process for community involvement can take many forms.

[Roy Belson]: You can have a community survey online.

[Roy Belson]: You can have a hard copy survey.

[Roy Belson]: You can have community forums like we've had in the past, or you can have categorical focus groups where you bring in, you know, different groups from a school or grade level, areas of interest, talk to the faculty, staff members.

[Roy Belson]: You can mix and match these as you see fit.

[Roy Belson]: And as you review this at some point in time, you may want to give me guidance so that we can refine it and develop it into the next stage of readiness for you to go forward.

[Roy Belson]: And then you want to determine who's going to be on the screening teams internally, whether you're going to have the full committee and other people, or you're just going to use the full committee.

[Roy Belson]: So those are some of the things.

[Roy Belson]: Or you can combine any of the above.

[Roy Belson]: A formal application form, I attached an example of that for your review.

[Roy Belson]: You can change it.

[Roy Belson]: You can ask different questions.

[Roy Belson]: That's up to you, but I think that's typical of what you would ask and what you would look for.

[Roy Belson]: And then, of course, the selection of a group such as MASC can greatly facilitate what goes on to enhance the possibilities of finding a good fit for Medford.

[Roy Belson]: And lastly, there'd be a transition process between the outgoing leadership and the incoming superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: And every effort would be made by my administration to assist in that process to ensure that the individual had the benefit of knowing where things were and what our perspectives were based on our own experience.

[Roy Belson]: So the above report and attached information help allay any concerns that a succession plan is in place and a process can happen in a reasonable timeframe.

[Roy Belson]: Happy to take any questions you might have.

[Roy Belson]: Ms.

[Roy Belson]: So if I can make a suggestion.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, just simply this is that you've got some outlines here, so go down it and see whether you, what kind of, what kind of combinations you like, and then we'll call a committee of the whole or some point and you can decide, you know, if this happens, we want this type of focus group.

[Roy Belson]: We'd like a survey online.

[Roy Belson]: We'd like this, we'd like that.

[Roy Belson]: So you put it together.

[Roy Belson]: So you flesh out the document based on what you would like to see and we'll give you guidance on that.

[Roy Belson]: That's not a difficult thing to do, but remember this was the outline so that you can get started and then you can,

[Roy Belson]: flesh it out a little bit and say what I want.

[Roy Belson]: You know, what do you want?

[Roy Belson]: And it will be different in different communities.

[Roy Belson]: Some communities will emphasize one thing, and some communities will want to emphasize something else.

[Roy Belson]: So we can get started.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sure Glenn Kocher or Jim Harney or some of the other people that work for MASC would be happy to come out.

[Roy Belson]: I think they're your best bargain, to be honest with you.

[Roy Belson]: They do enough of them around the Commonwealth, so they've got lots of experience and lots of contacts and get along with MASS pretty well.

[Roy Belson]: And you don't have to pay the fees for some national firm that, you know, we'll find somebody, uh, two communities over, you know.

[Roy Belson]: This is a standard procedure.

[Roy Belson]: So as we do this virtually every year, because we don't meet as frequently if we meet at all during the summer, I send out all kinds of information to you at different points in the summer.

[Roy Belson]: But from June 21st, 2016,

[Roy Belson]: Through our first meeting in September of 2016, I'm requesting the school committee grant authority to the superintendent and the school committee secretary for the following.

[Roy Belson]: One, that the authority shall be granted to the secretary of the school committee to approve bills and payrolls through July and August, and that the school committee be kept informed of the bills and payrolls approved.

[Roy Belson]: Two, that the administration be given permission to open bids in order to proceed on repair and maintenance work and other essential procurements.

[Roy Belson]: Notice to the school committee will be provided.

[Roy Belson]: Three, that the superintendent be authorized to conduct the normal and necessary business of the school district throughout the summer.

[Roy Belson]: And four, that the superintendent keep the school committee apprised of any special situations or circumstances during the summer months or that are projected to occur at the opening of schools in September.

[Roy Belson]: We were going to schedule one earlier because with the opening of school, we had talked about that once before.

[Roy Belson]: So I think we obviously can stay in touch.

[Roy Belson]: And if you see something and you want to call a meeting, you just need three members to call the meeting.

[Roy Belson]: Well, three would three would allow for a meeting.

[Roy Belson]: You know, I wouldn't schedule a date yet.

[Roy Belson]: Everybody's going to make summer plans.

[Roy Belson]: You know, why don't we, if you agree that you want a summer meeting, we can agree to that and we'll get back to you and check everyone's vacation plans.

[Roy Belson]: But from past experience, you set a date and everyone is,

[Roy Belson]: in different places.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: So if you want a summer meeting, that's fine.

[Roy Belson]: But let me caucus everyone around and find out when people are available, and then we can get a date that we know people are going to be here.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, just a couple of comments, if I may.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know if people fully realize this, but a statistic rolled by my desk this past weekend.

[Roy Belson]: And it's kind of interesting.

[Roy Belson]: About 49, 50 people were killed in the Orlando shooting.

[Roy Belson]: Since that time, there have been 207 homicides by gun violence in this country since that time.

[Roy Belson]: But they're isolated situations.

[Roy Belson]: And there's situations in which, you know, they're not getting the same coverage.

[Roy Belson]: Orlando is truly tragic, but so isn't the ongoing gun violence that exists in our country.

[Roy Belson]: And a lot of it is based on mental health issues that people have, or just domestic disturbances, or drug deals, or other things like that that go on in society.

[Roy Belson]: But it often goes unnoticed.

[Roy Belson]: On an average day, based on the number of gun homicides in this country, 27 people die every day, on average, by guns.

[Roy Belson]: 27 people.

[Roy Belson]: It's horrific.

[Roy Belson]: Until we start dealing with mental health, until we start dealing with the availability of guns and things like that to individuals, we are not going to abate the situation.

[Roy Belson]: Terrorism is an issue and certainly to be dealt with.

[Roy Belson]: But there are other domestic and, let's say, personal issues that are every bit as tragic every day in our various communities.

[Roy Belson]: The other comment is most people who've been around for a long time knew Bob Sarabian.

[Roy Belson]: Bob was just a terrific guy.

[Roy Belson]: I grew up on Governor's Ave in Medford.

[Roy Belson]: Bob lived on Hutchins Road, and the Sarabian brothers operated Carpathic Area for many, many years.

[Roy Belson]: George was the oldest.

[Roy Belson]: Bob was the second oldest, and Ron is still alive and still an active businessman.

[Roy Belson]: Bob was a very giving man.

[Roy Belson]: He worked very closely with John Hand.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know if you remember the name John Hand.

[Roy Belson]: John Hand was the executive vice president of the Medford Cooperative Bank.

[Roy Belson]: And they were in arts festivals and all kinds of things that benefited the community.

[Roy Belson]: So Bob was a real contributor and someone that, you know, sometimes when a person hasn't been in the public light for a long time, new people in the community don't remember that individual because they weren't around when they were very active.

[Roy Belson]: So I thought it was important to at least tell you that Bob Sarabian was quite a player in this community and the Sarabian family as well.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee, pursuant to my consultations with the Brooks faculty and staff and the leadership of the Brooks parent groups, as well as my consultation with you last meeting, I'm very pleased and privileged to announce that Suzanne Galussi, who is with us this evening, is the new principal of the Brooks Elementary School.

[Roy Belson]: Suzanne got her bachelor's degree from Framingham State, and then her master's in education from Wesley University.

[Roy Belson]: She has 14 excellent years of teaching experience in the elementary schools in Medford, and four very successful years as assistant principal of the Brooks School, and her appointment will be effective July 1, 2016.

[Roy Belson]: During the upcoming administrative week, we'll meet with Ms.

[Roy Belson]: Galussi and other members of the administration to determine how we will select

[Roy Belson]: her assistant principal so that Brooks has that in place for the opening of school.

[Roy Belson]: Suzanne, the show's yours.

[Roy Belson]: We have a retirement in that field, and we're able to take some of the money from a higher end salary.

[Roy Belson]: The salary would be $40,000.

[Roy Belson]: that goes south, we'd have to find $150,000.

[Roy Belson]: Did you say that?

[Roy Belson]: You know, I don't know.

[Roy Belson]: I'll find out.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Trotta knows, so he would be your supervisor.

[Roy Belson]: So let me try and answer that this way.

[Roy Belson]: Anytime I make a cut from something that I've got, most of the time, not always, there are a couple of things that I probably can reevaluate and say that wasn't a great move.

[Roy Belson]: But most of the time, it means that there's going to be something that's lost.

[Roy Belson]: But in this instance, the challenge to us is to take a look at the full fleet of clerical assistants and to reposition some people.

[Roy Belson]: And it's probably highly likely that within the area of special education, Kathy's smiling out there, that, you know, there'll be some adjustment in that area and move away from something else.

[Roy Belson]: But every area, every area has got to be scrutinized.

[Roy Belson]: And from time to time, we see that maybe certain jobs can be consolidated, certain things can be shared, and we do that.

[Roy Belson]: If we can't do that, we'll never ever be able to balance a budget.

[Roy Belson]: It'll always be add, add, add, and add later.

[Roy Belson]: So we have to look at that.

[Roy Belson]: So the challenge is to us not to ignore the good work that's done by the clerical staff, but to reposition it in such a way so that we can do the work with maybe a few less people from time to time or find that if we have to add a person, when we go back over during the summer, we'll come back and tell you we added a person and we'll find the money for it.

[Roy Belson]: So, but this is the beginning of a budget.

[Roy Belson]: This is a process.

[Roy Belson]: And just as I came back this evening with these adjustments, I may come back with some more and say, we can do some more things.

[Roy Belson]: Or I might have to come back and say, you know, there's something that's happening to us at the state, the federal level, and we may have to pull back on something that we wanted to do.

[Roy Belson]: But that's the nature of budgeting.

[Roy Belson]: That's the nature of process.

[Roy Belson]: And, uh, but I hear you.

[Roy Belson]: It's, it's no animus towards any particular type of position or any person.

[Roy Belson]: It's really just simply a function of trying to find what the balances are.

[Roy Belson]: And that we've got 29 less kids going to charter schools right now.

[Roy Belson]: We've got significantly more youngsters coming back from other areas.

[Roy Belson]: And we've got a larger kindergarten enrollment.

[Roy Belson]: And I think a lot of it has to do with people knowing something about our school system.

[Roy Belson]: The other night, I happened to listen to the city council.

[Roy Belson]: Why I did that, I have no idea.

[Roy Belson]: But I was listening to the city council.

[Roy Belson]: And while I was listening to the city council, I heard them talk about the lack of communication about things.

[Roy Belson]: They didn't know about this.

[Roy Belson]: And they didn't know about that.

[Roy Belson]: So I don't think it's an unreasonable salary.

[Roy Belson]: If you bought a car, it was $3,500.

[Roy Belson]: Things are different today.

[Roy Belson]: You want to be competitive.

[Roy Belson]: They're going to share that one.

[Roy Belson]: The librarian will work both buildings, but the assistant will also work both buildings.

[Roy Belson]: I know I'm not- Principal's given multiple options, and we could have adjusted a teaching schedule to do that.

[Roy Belson]: She chose not to do that.

[Roy Belson]: We added it at the half point of the year.

[Roy Belson]: So it varies with regard to the type of class.

[Roy Belson]: A regular education class, it's in the contract with the Teachers Association.

[Roy Belson]: It's pretty high.

[Roy Belson]: So it's, you know, I'm not sure off the top of my head, but it's in the high 20s.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: And then, you know, it would be because remember, this idea of really small class size, relatively new.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: There were years when, you know, class sizes were 28, 29, 30, and so on and so forth.

[Roy Belson]: Our class sizes are a lot lower than what people were used to.

[Roy Belson]: So when these contracts were written, they were written with upper 20s as being the example for regular classes.

[Roy Belson]: Now in special ed, it depends on the type of class.

[Roy Belson]: If a special ed youngster is in a classroom that's self-contained, it's one to eight.

[Roy Belson]: If it goes beyond that, there would be another pair required.

[Roy Belson]: If it's less than that, it may just simply be on the severity of the type of classroom it is.

[Roy Belson]: It's by regulation.

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: Yep.

[Roy Belson]: We receive money from the Department of Public Health.

[Roy Belson]: It's a school health services grant that we have had for many years.

[Roy Belson]: This pays for part of the salary of one nurse.

[Roy Belson]: It doesn't pay the total salary.

[Roy Belson]: It pays a portion of that salary.

[Roy Belson]: So a portion of the salary is in the grant section, and a portion is in the health services section.

[Roy Belson]: Right.

[Roy Belson]: We bill to both accounts, and we keep a record so that it can be audited.

[Roy Belson]: The individual is Molly Layden.

[Roy Belson]: The individual has been and continues to be the person who gets the grant for the National Science Foundation for $1.2 million.

[Roy Belson]: And some of her salary is offset

[Roy Belson]: by the grant.

[Roy Belson]: So once again, we take some grant money to pay a portion of the individual's salary.

[Roy Belson]: We list it in the grant section.

[Roy Belson]: We also list her in the regular budget.

[Roy Belson]: And her salary was approved through the negotiations with the Administrators Association in the last round of negotiations that we did.

[Roy Belson]: So tri-tech is the organization that is a, let's say an offspring of Medford, Malden and Everett.

[Roy Belson]: And it is a,

[Roy Belson]: It was founded initially when the technology park was being developed, was being thought about.

[Roy Belson]: And it's continued for that time and has brought us millions of dollars through different grants over a period of time.

[Roy Belson]: Dr. Cindy Fadusha was the original executive director of that particular program.

[Roy Belson]: When she left to take a position with the Harvard Medical School and the physicians group over there, Molly Layden moved up into that position, and Molly Layden

[Roy Belson]: runs that program as well as our program.

[Roy Belson]: But the reality is that the program that she presented the other evening with regard to the youngsters developing applications at the middle school level was funded by the National Science Foundation.

[Roy Belson]: So we're allowed to charge a portion of her salary off to that foundation, to that grant.

[Roy Belson]: So that's the way we split it out so we can track it properly.

[Roy Belson]: And we audit it properly so that we can report to the feds.

[Roy Belson]: Tritech is the recipient of the grant.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result, Tritech exists as a holding company, if you will, to receive the grant.

[Roy Belson]: And this is the grant that comes in through Tritech, through that 501c3, which allows us to then

[Roy Belson]: rebuild it to this with the University of Lowell.

[Roy Belson]: No, because her portion of her salary, the part that she does for the grant, is paid for by the National Science Foundation.

[Roy Belson]: The rest of it is work she does for us directly.

[Roy Belson]: It's a function.

[Roy Belson]: It's a function of

[Roy Belson]: division of funding, not a function of two positions.

[Roy Belson]: She's a projects director, and the funding source is just like the nurse's position.

[Roy Belson]: It comes from two different sources.

[Roy Belson]: That's all.

[Roy Belson]: It's just paid for differently.

[Roy Belson]: If we didn't do that, we would be picking up the tab for lots of grants.

[Roy Belson]: So we use as much offset as we can, and we're allowed to charge to both the federal and the state, in some cases, and this.

[Roy Belson]: The same thing would be true of kindergarten aids.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, which we just did because some of it's going to come from the state and some of it's going to come from us.

[Roy Belson]: So it's a normal procedure.

[Roy Belson]: It's one position, but it's a normal procedure funded with two sources.

[Roy Belson]: Which one is that?

[Roy Belson]: Let me take a look and I'll be a little bit more tuned to that.

[Roy Belson]: Akira Kamiya is the person who is the primary director and runner of the National Science Foundation grant.

[Roy Belson]: The grant comes to us.

[Roy Belson]: He is located in Medford.

[Roy Belson]: And that's his salary.

[Roy Belson]: And it's paid to us by the grant through the University of Massachusetts at Lowell.

[Roy Belson]: They're our partner in that.

[Roy Belson]: And that's a direct salary.

[Roy Belson]: And he works for us and the project.

[Roy Belson]: So if I... It's a million two over three years.

[Roy Belson]: And those funds are allocated to these two people's salary and then... These two people's salaries and stipends to teachers working with students for equipment, materials, software, and give you a whole breakdown.

[Roy Belson]: If you go to the grants breakdown on the early part of the book, you'll see what's actually allocated to that grant and how it's broken down on a yearly basis.

[Roy Belson]: So if you go to the front of the book in the section that's given to grants, you will see it.

[Roy Belson]: Here it is.

[Roy Belson]: It's page, I don't have a page number on it, but I'll.

[Roy Belson]: Can you see it?

[Roy Belson]: Federal grants.

[Roy Belson]: Pat, go ahead.

[Roy Belson]: OK?

[Roy Belson]: OK.

[Roy Belson]: I'll provide it to you.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to say it again.

[Roy Belson]: In the last two months, we have given you every document on every outside community schools and all these things.

[Roy Belson]: And we can give it to you at the budget time.

[Roy Belson]: You asked for it earlier.

[Roy Belson]: I'm going to say it very clearly.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: And I want to make it very clear to everyone here.

[Roy Belson]: A report asked by an individual member is not a report that superintendent responds to.

[Roy Belson]: A report voted by the school committee is a report that the superintendent will respond to.

[Roy Belson]: I cannot and my staff cannot keep doing individual reports every time somebody wants something different.

[Roy Belson]: It takes a lot of time.

[Roy Belson]: Pat worked overtime and overtime to get those reports to you at that point in time.

[Roy Belson]: And I think it's disingenuous, quite frankly, to keep asking for the same thing.

[Roy Belson]: You want it at budget time next year, you can have it.

[Roy Belson]: The committee voted to get it quarterly, we'll do it.

[Roy Belson]: But let's not keep creating these kinds of report situations, because all it does is take us off what we're trying to do for the education of the kids.

[Roy Belson]: And the other thing you need to keep in mind is just what we're talking about state and federal grants.

[Roy Belson]: We don't have the allocations yet.

[Roy Belson]: So I can't tell you what that account is going to look like going forward.

[Roy Belson]: I can only tell you what it's been in a given year because the state budget isn't even approved yet.

[Roy Belson]: And the federal budget won't get delivered to us until the summer.

[Roy Belson]: And all that stuff has something to do with the way we allocate money.

[Roy Belson]: We have to use projections all year long to see what's coming in and to balance one account off against the other.

[Roy Belson]: So, yes, we can give you projections.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, we can give you, you know, revolving accounts at a point in time, as a snapshot in time, like the end of the third quarter going into budget, which would be typical.

[Roy Belson]: But to give you a projection, what's going to be true in August are going to be true in September.

[Roy Belson]: is all speculation.

[Roy Belson]: No, we put them in the budget.

[Roy Belson]: There are three additional full-time AIDS at the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: That's the addition.

[Roy Belson]: Everything else stays in place.

[Roy Belson]: At this point in time, no.

[Roy Belson]: Just the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: Just the Roberts.

[Roy Belson]: To approve the budget.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to make another statement about something.

[Roy Belson]: Tomorrow night, I go to the city council.

[Roy Belson]: This is the school committee budget.

[Roy Belson]: I expect that the school committee supports its own budget because when I go to that

[Roy Belson]: council, I don't want to go in there and find that the budget that the school committee voted is not approved and not supported by the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to make that very clear.

[Roy Belson]: That's very strong.

[Roy Belson]: In my opinion, you vote as a committee, you stand as a committee, the superintendent represents you as a committee.

[Roy Belson]: So, Madam Mayor, can I just want to say one thing.

[Roy Belson]: My comment was not that people can't vote against the budget.

[Roy Belson]: Majority rules.

[Roy Belson]: It's 5-2.

[Roy Belson]: It's a vote for the budget.

[Roy Belson]: It's fine.

[Roy Belson]: I've been in enough meetings in the course of my career to know that they don't always get a unanimous vote for things.

[Roy Belson]: So that's not the issue.

[Roy Belson]: The issue I raised is when I go to the council tomorrow night, I want the committee to honor the fact that the committee voted.

[Roy Belson]: And I said that before, when I was talking about reports, I don't want to go to the council and find that individual members go there and argue against the budget.

[Roy Belson]: That's what I'm saying, because the budget is what this committee voted up or down.

[Roy Belson]: You're a committee, you're not individuals.

[Roy Belson]: You've been told many times that as an individual you have no authority.

[Roy Belson]: It's only when you're in session and as a group that you have authority to act on behalf of the city and the school system.

[Roy Belson]: And so all I'm trying to do is make it clear that I don't want to go in there with a divided camp tomorrow night and find that people will argue against me from my own committee because you voted this budget by majority.

[Roy Belson]: And you could have voted the other way.

[Roy Belson]: Or you could have voted for anything else you wanted.

[Roy Belson]: But you voted it.

[Roy Belson]: Up or down, whether you're on the majority side or the minority side, it is the school committee budget.

[Roy Belson]: And that's what the superintendent will represent tomorrow night.

[Roy Belson]: And if I'm asked about other people's opinions, I will say the school committee voted this budget.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to make that clear.

[Roy Belson]: That's why I said what I said.

[Roy Belson]: I don't have a problem with dissent.

[Roy Belson]: People want to dissent, that's business.

[Roy Belson]: I understand that.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee, we're going to call upon our Director of Mathematics and Science to come up and introduce the robotics team and their successful competition recently, which put them into a very favorable company in New England Regional Robotics Tournament.

[Roy Belson]: So Carolyn Joy is going to come up and we have some presentations for them as well.

[Roy Belson]: If I could ask the superintendent.

[Roy Belson]: So we've met with DSAC, and you know, we've worked with them before, and we'll continue to work with them.

[Roy Belson]: There are, you know, different assistances they can provide at different times, and it really depends on, you know, what we identify as being most significant.

[Roy Belson]: But I think that one of the things that

[Roy Belson]: What we probably should do is, since Kathy can't be here tonight, and Kathy had some additional things she wanted to say, is why don't we schedule a session in the Committee of the Whole sometime before the year's out, and we can have a good give and take on where we're going.

[Roy Belson]: I think we'll have a, you know, obviously there's a lot of things going on as, as Melanie points out, the early childhood rate is way up.

[Roy Belson]: If you combine the partial with the full inclusion, the rate is that much more substantial.

[Roy Belson]: So the question is, how do we get it more full inclusion?

[Roy Belson]: The pay structure?

[Roy Belson]: We'll work that in.

[Roy Belson]: I just, you know, I was hoping that we'd have something to you before the next school committee meeting.

[Roy Belson]: So that's the policy.

[Roy Belson]: And you know, sometimes you have a policy and not everybody implements it the same way.

[Roy Belson]: And that's the problem.

[Roy Belson]: This was a discussion we had at a curriculum subcommittee not that long ago, and I think you attended this.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, you were there.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, we had that discussion at that time.

[Roy Belson]: And, you know, we went back out to the buildings and we told them that policy is our policy and follow it.

[Roy Belson]: And that there are some teachers who feel like, you know, they're hamstrung when a youngster is misbehaving or work is not coming in.

[Roy Belson]: And they misuse that policy.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to stop it.

[Roy Belson]: We don't want them to do it.

[Roy Belson]: The whole issue of recess is not a new topic.

[Roy Belson]: We've talked about it many times.

[Roy Belson]: We're hamstrung a little bit by time and learning requirements.

[Roy Belson]: The Medford school day is not as long as some other places.

[Roy Belson]: And we need to meet that 900-hour requirement from the state.

[Roy Belson]: And recess doesn't count.

[Roy Belson]: That's something that, you know, we're up against the wall on.

[Roy Belson]: But there are other ways to promote exercise, and there are other ways to do things that perhaps we can look into, and we certainly will.

[Roy Belson]: And maybe there are ways that active learning can take place when youngsters are moving around.

[Roy Belson]: There's a book out not that long ago called Spark.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know if you've seen it, which youngsters are up and moving while they're learning.

[Roy Belson]: And that's a good way to get some exercise in as well.

[Roy Belson]: But recess is an important topic.

[Roy Belson]: No one wants to deny that.

[Roy Belson]: But there are some issues that we have to sort through.

[Roy Belson]: And we do not want our faculty to use it as a punishment.

[Roy Belson]: We had the same issue years ago in writing, where

[Roy Belson]: Some faculty members assign writing as a punishment.

[Roy Belson]: And we said we don't want kids to think of writing as a punishment.

[Roy Belson]: We want people to think of writing as something you enjoy doing and like to do.

[Roy Belson]: So we're going to work at it.

[Roy Belson]: We certainly need to have a little more discussion on it.

[Roy Belson]: And I'll take, obviously, the input.

[Roy Belson]: And let's see if we can't, during our administrative meetings, come up with something that might further the issue that Mrs. Kline's raising.

[Roy Belson]: Well, you know, we certainly have it on the web page.

[Roy Belson]: We'll just make it more prominent.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll, once again, reinforce it with our principals during the administrative meetings.

[Roy Belson]: And that will take place at the close of school.

[Roy Belson]: And we'll make it more of a

[Roy Belson]: definitive priority to people that's not going to be taken lightly if people abuse that policy.

[Roy Belson]: That's as much as we can do with regard to the policy.

[Roy Belson]: Now, with regard to other measures, that's a whole discussion unto itself.

[Roy Belson]: We need to think about what we can do about that given the time and learning constraints and all the other things that we have to meet with regard to state requirements.

[Roy Belson]: Mr. Superintendent members of the committee, um, the Medford public schools has been awarded a $15,000 grant from the Massachusetts department of public health.

[Roy Belson]: With us this evening is our supervisor of health services, Tony Vento, who can come up and explain the grant and explain what we're going to do with it and why we want to implement it next year.

[Roy Belson]: Good afternoon members of the committee.

[Roy Belson]: The governor proposed a 2017 budget.

[Roy Belson]: The House and the Senate then passed their versions and the budget now is in conference committee.

[Roy Belson]: The conference committee has to reconcile the legislative differences between the two chambers, and when the conference committee reports out, and generally they'll take a good part of this month to do it, there'll be an up and down vote in each chamber.

[Roy Belson]: If passed by both chambers, they can't make modifications once it comes out of conference committee.

[Roy Belson]: It will go to the governor, and he'll certainly veto a few line items based on his preferences.

[Roy Belson]: It will then go back to the legislature for possible veto overrides, which is typical.

[Roy Belson]: And a final version will then be sent to the governor for enactment.

[Roy Belson]: This process probably won't be completed until towards the end of June.

[Roy Belson]: You need to be realistic about how that takes place.

[Roy Belson]: It's a typical process in the state.

[Roy Belson]: It usually doesn't happen any sooner than the last week in June, if that at all.

[Roy Belson]: So negotiations begin amid uncertainty over the 2016 revenues.

[Roy Belson]: Now, when I wrote this report, there was $260 million behind projections.

[Roy Belson]: As of the other day, that projection went up to $311 million behind projections.

[Roy Belson]: Now, Kristen Lepore, who's the Secretary of Administration and Finance, has indicated that they could handle that at the state level.

[Roy Belson]: But it does dampen the kind of thinking that goes on in the legislative chambers, because they're saying to themselves, well, if we're $311 million behind now, what will we be in June?

[Roy Belson]: What does that mean for carryover money into fiscal 17?

[Roy Belson]: So we just don't know how that's going to play out just yet.

[Roy Belson]: The overall budget levels filed so far as follows.

[Roy Belson]: The governor is at $39,553,000.

[Roy Belson]: The House is at $39,539,000 below the governor.

[Roy Belson]: And the Senate is at $39,558,000.

[Roy Belson]: So the Senate's usually higher.

[Roy Belson]: And generally, it comes in somewhere between the House and the Senate.

[Roy Belson]: The overall increase is about 3.59%.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate is the highest.

[Roy Belson]: According to the Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation, the original projection rate for revenue was going to be 4.3%.

[Roy Belson]: However, right now through April, it's only 1.9%.

[Roy Belson]: That's quite a gap in revenue that the state is expecting to have.

[Roy Belson]: Overall, the House and the Senate provide similar support for K-12 education.

[Roy Belson]: But there are differences among the 30 line items that need to be reconciled.

[Roy Belson]: And I'm going to give you some representative differences because I think they do affect us as we prepare our budget and as we go forward.

[Roy Belson]: So one that I know you're all interested in, the house appropriation for kindergarten is $18.5 million.

[Roy Belson]: That's level funding from this year.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate is, that's a mistake, the Senate is at $2 million.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sorry.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate is at $2 million.

[Roy Belson]: Any reduction in this level will affect direct funding coming to Medford for kindergarten.

[Roy Belson]: This could be as much as $150,000.

[Roy Belson]: If the Senate level carries or something lower than what we're getting, we could lose as much as $150,000.

[Roy Belson]: That's not good.

[Roy Belson]: Charter school funding is still well below the formula entitlement offset local costs for both branches.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate is 5 million higher than the House.

[Roy Belson]: but neither really addresses the actual gap which could approach $50 million in underfunded entitlement dollars.

[Roy Belson]: Medford is projected, based on the early returns, to have less students in charters, but we could end up paying more in the current year, because that's the way the funding works.

[Roy Belson]: And if the reimbursement goes down, that's a problem.

[Roy Belson]: Non-resident pupil transportation would be funded at $1.8 million by the Senate, which is $1.5 million more than the House.

[Roy Belson]: The funding line helps to offset the cost of the Minuteman bus.

[Roy Belson]: Now, we're working on a less expensive cost for that particular vehicle because we have less youngsters going.

[Roy Belson]: We might be able to use a smaller vehicle and pay less for it.

[Roy Belson]: But in the meantime, we would like to get that reimbursement because that obviously helps to offset the cost.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate version puts $350,000 into a new line item that would support the development of alternative assessments of student performance beyond test scores.

[Roy Belson]: That's aspirational.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know that we're going to see much from that, but it's an interesting proposal.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate has used the budget process, if you will, to legislate policy issues, which the House has not.

[Roy Belson]: It's a real tricky slope because that means the Senate has to convince the House that it should be legislating policy through budget.

[Roy Belson]: The governor has eschewed that at this particular point in time.

[Roy Belson]: So let's see what happens.

[Roy Belson]: The Senate version of the SPED circuit breaker is about $5 million more than the House and approximately $10 million more than the Governor.

[Roy Belson]: This funding line offsets extraordinary special ed costs.

[Roy Belson]: We're projecting that we need somewhere around $283 million in the state to offset the cost to get to 75% reimbursement.

[Roy Belson]: That's worth somewhere in the vicinity of $1.45 to $1.5 million to us every year as it's currently coming to us.

[Roy Belson]: If that goes down, that's money we have to find in our budget.

[Roy Belson]: We don't think it's going to go down, we just don't know if it's going to meet the 75% because every year more and more youngsters require care, costs of these placements may go up, and the gap could increase.

[Roy Belson]: So those are the main differences affecting Medford.

[Roy Belson]: Both the House and the Senate provided $55 per pupil minimum additional aid to schools under Chapter 70.

[Roy Belson]: This is $35 per pupil higher than the governor's.

[Roy Belson]: It's $30 per pupil higher than last year.

[Roy Belson]: This overall funding goes in directly into the city treasury and is used, obviously, for a number of reasons that the city needs to cover its expenses, including health care, pensions, and other matters that affect schools, but may not be something that you see on a regular basis in our budget.

[Roy Belson]: Homeless transportation is level funded from FY 2016.

[Roy Belson]: This is well below the need.

[Roy Belson]: Pat and I are projecting right now that we could have $140,000 in costs next year based on past experience.

[Roy Belson]: And we're not getting anywhere near that in reimbursement.

[Roy Belson]: And that was supposedly an unfunded mandate that the state auditor said would be funded, but it hasn't met its expectations at this time.

[Roy Belson]: So we call the legislators up on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: I was up the state house today for some time and spoke to some of our people again, but quite frankly, you know, it's hard to know what's happening in the conference committee until they really get serious and what the trade offs are going to be, because there's so many line items in the state budget.

[Roy Belson]: If somebody gets one thing, they may give away in something else, but they know what we want.

[Roy Belson]: They certainly know what we want.

[Roy Belson]: And, uh, we certainly have,

[Roy Belson]: the support of other school districts who have the same needs as we do.

[Roy Belson]: So that's an update so far on the state budget.

[Roy Belson]: It certainly affects how we plan our budget because we won't know some of these answers when our budget comes up.

[Roy Belson]: So it may be that we have to defer making certain decisions until we know what the actual state funding will be for certain items.

[Roy Belson]: We do that at the end of the year.

[Roy Belson]: We're a single appropriation.

[Roy Belson]: as opposed to the council, which has individual line items.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, we always give you that at the end.

[Roy Belson]: And once everything's reconciled, but it takes a while for it to reconcile because things come in during the summer, they're encumbered, they're held over until they're actually paid utility bills, things of that type.

[Roy Belson]: So until we actually see the actual numbers, you don't want to make a million changes just simply on the fly.
