[Roy Belson]: So last Friday, pardon me?

[Roy Belson]: So on last Friday, the governor signed the public records bill.

[Roy Belson]: that the legislature finally put together over the last several months.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not going to go through the whole thing.

[Roy Belson]: There's a lot here.

[Roy Belson]: Obviously, we need to go through it more carefully, but there are new enforcement procedures in this, and there are new requirements under the public records law, which means that we've got to be that much more attuned to when people make certain requests.

[Roy Belson]: And obviously, you know, there is a need to

[Roy Belson]: to rethink electronic records versus paper records, who's the custodian of these things, and what constitutes a public record versus what constitutes something that's exempt.

[Roy Belson]: There are multiple exemptions from the public records law.

[Roy Belson]: The Secretary of State has yet, obviously just got passed, to issue regulations.

[Roy Belson]: When he issues those regulations, that will be another

[Roy Belson]: step forward.

[Roy Belson]: But this is scheduled to go into effect on January of 2017.

[Roy Belson]: So over the next several months, we'll be watching very closely to see what the regulatory requirements are and how that fleshes out the requirements of the law.

[Roy Belson]: But please read it, go over it, and we'll pay attention to it as well and keep you informed so that if these matters come up, we can handle them appropriately.

[Roy Belson]: I would say one thing that you've got to be aware of, your email is a public record.

[Roy Belson]: Your email is a public record, so if you say something you don't want to say in your email, it could be discovered.

[Roy Belson]: So you need to think about that a little bit because sometimes, you know, you say something in a sort of out there way and you don't really want to broadcast that.

[Roy Belson]: It's set by law.

[Roy Belson]: It's set now.

[Roy Belson]: All right.

[Roy Belson]: So Madam Mayor and members of the committee,

[Roy Belson]: As you previously had reported, Kevin Andrews is leaving to take a position as principal of the Nahant Elementary School.

[Roy Belson]: So on Wednesday, June 1st, I met with the faculty, along with Diane Caldwell, over at the Brooks, and then I met with the parent leadership team to hear their viewpoints on a succession plan.

[Roy Belson]: Both meetings were very informative, but the conclusions were very identical.

[Roy Belson]: There's virtually unanimous consensus to appoint an internal person to the position.

[Roy Belson]: There's a strong desire for continuity.

[Roy Belson]: And there's a significant confidence in the current assistant principal.

[Roy Belson]: The superintendent concurs with that expression of support.

[Roy Belson]: So unless the school committee really wants to go through a process that's different, I really don't want to run a pony show for anybody.

[Roy Belson]: I don't want to bring people in and pretend that we're having real interviews when I really believe that

[Roy Belson]: it could very well be something that we'll have a known conclusion before we even get started.

[Roy Belson]: Naturally, I'll speak to the unions about posting issues, but I would like to obviously, um, know that let allow the Brooks community to know the result before they go home, uh, the summer and also to allow for planning to continue.

[Roy Belson]: And it also will inform the budget process as well, because if I make moves internally, uh, that has some cost savings associated with it, which I think is a distinct advantage to us.

[Roy Belson]: given this year's budget.

[Roy Belson]: So I'm bringing it to your attention.

[Roy Belson]: I want to get some feedback from you.

[Roy Belson]: And obviously someone wants to speak on it.

[Roy Belson]: So I'd be happy to hear what people have to say, but that's my thinking on it right now.

[Roy Belson]: We'll appoint an assistant principal afterwards, but one step at a time.

[Roy Belson]: Well, we'll first look internally.

[Roy Belson]: And the reason we look internally is because we'd like to give our people opportunity, one, but two, is also a distinct budget advantage.

[Roy Belson]: If I have a senior member of the faculty who is qualified to be an assistant principal, it certainly helps to replace that person with a lower salary and recapture some budget funds.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a couple of advantages to going internally, but if that didn't come to pass and it wasn't something that worked out, then we would do what we have to do.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sorry?

[Roy Belson]: We're working on a solution there too and I really don't want to speak to that right now because I have to talk to Paul DeLeva in the morning.

[Roy Belson]: But again, I'm very budget conscious right now and I'm looking internally as much as I can because obviously anything I can save allows you to have a little bit more in other areas that you

[Roy Belson]: I might have some interest.

[Roy Belson]: It's OK.

[Roy Belson]: I'll take it.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: Oh, I'd make it permanent.

[Roy Belson]: I'd make it permanent.

[Roy Belson]: I'd give the person the, you know, I would want that person to have the authority level.

[Roy Belson]: I wouldn't want someone to think, well, you know, this is maybe, you know, something that could change rapidly.

[Roy Belson]: You know, I want that person to have the authority level and be able to move forward.

[Roy Belson]: West Foote was the foreman carpenter of the public schools for many, many years.

[Roy Belson]: And West was a very gentle soul, big man, very strong and very, you know, impressive kind of guy, very quiet.

[Roy Belson]: His wife Connie was one of the key people in the payroll office, and the two of them, you know, would see each other because they were basically both part of the central office.

[Roy Belson]: And Wes was very, very skilled.

[Roy Belson]: You didn't have to, you know, explain to Wes how to make something happen.

[Roy Belson]: You know how to make it happen.

[Roy Belson]: And the Foote family was very active in the community for many, many years.

[Roy Belson]: His daughter, Linda, and daughter-in-law, Linda, and his son, Wes, Jr.

[Roy Belson]: So very close to them, very good people, you know, and 95 years old.

[Roy Belson]: 95 years old.

[Roy Belson]: God bless him.

[Roy Belson]: He was a great player, and I can still see Wes coming through the corridor.

[Roy Belson]: looking with Ernie Demon.

[Roy Belson]: I don't know if you remember Ernie Demon at all.

[Roy Belson]: Ernie Demon, the two of them.

[Roy Belson]: Ernie being the character in the crowd and Wes being the straight shooter.

[Roy Belson]: And it was really kind of funny because Ernie would say something and Wes would say, oh, Ernie, stop that.

[Roy Belson]: But really good, really highly skilled people.

[Roy Belson]: And they could do a lot of things.

[Roy Belson]: Back then, we had several carpenters.

[Roy Belson]: And they really did some really nice things in school to keep them up and running.

[Roy Belson]: And very fond memories of Wes.

[Roy Belson]: Good guy.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee and ladies and gentlemen,

[Roy Belson]: Tonight we're distinctly privileged and honored to have with us the Medford Middle School String Ensemble, which was founded in 2009 by Medford teacher Sophia Chang to encourage the development of musical excellence.

[Roy Belson]: Miss Chang is serving her 13th year as orchestra director at McGlynn Middle School.

[Roy Belson]: Since 2011, the ensemble has received six consecutive gold medals at the Concert Festival Conference.

[Roy Belson]: The string ensemble performed at Boston Symphony Hall and Mechanics Hall in Worcester.

[Roy Belson]: Many of her former students continue to pursue musicianship at the Tufts Youth Philharmonic, the NEC Youth Orchestra, the Boston Philharmonic Youth Orchestra, and among others.

[Roy Belson]: Mrs. Chang is committed to foster broader appreciation for classical music to young people.

[Roy Belson]: Tonight, we are privileged to hear them perform at least two selections, Cakewalk from Serenade for String Orchestra by Norman Leiden, and Lullaby by William Huffeld.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, let's welcome our middle school orchestra.

[Roy Belson]: I'll just be in front.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you, Madam Mayor.

[Roy Belson]: So,

[Roy Belson]: I've been here 21 years now as superintendent, 48 years as a public educator in the city of Medford.

[Roy Belson]: I grew up in the community.

[Roy Belson]: I went to the schools.

[Roy Belson]: I went to the Forest Park.

[Roy Belson]: I went to the Roberts Junior High School.

[Roy Belson]: I went to Medford High School.

[Roy Belson]: So this is my community.

[Roy Belson]: I care about it.

[Roy Belson]: And as I've said before, I never intend or would never intend to make a decision that would leave my community

[Roy Belson]: in the lurch.

[Roy Belson]: Now, having said that, we have had a process of evaluation and decision-making that has gone back well before my term as superintendent, and it's always been transparent.

[Roy Belson]: My self-evaluation will come to the committee this week.

[Roy Belson]: You'll have it.

[Roy Belson]: You'll have more than two weeks to go over it.

[Roy Belson]: That's a pretty substantial period of time to look at the document, which takes me time,

[Roy Belson]: to produce and review given all the other responsibilities that we have in the school district.

[Roy Belson]: The process will be in public.

[Roy Belson]: It always is.

[Roy Belson]: Open session.

[Roy Belson]: It's not an executive session.

[Roy Belson]: It's not away from anyone.

[Roy Belson]: It's open and every committee member has an opportunity to say what they feel and make whatever ratings they want to make.

[Roy Belson]: So far they've been good.

[Roy Belson]: I'm sure that there may be some things that people would like to see me do better, or the school system do better.

[Roy Belson]: But clearly, it's been an open process.

[Roy Belson]: And as you can tell, people come to the rail all the time and make statements, give their opinions, come into meetings, some of them in support, and some of them critical.

[Roy Belson]: But that's a balancing act.

[Roy Belson]: Wherever we are, that's what takes place.

[Roy Belson]: What does concern me is this, and I say this in a very sincere way, and that's simply this.

[Roy Belson]: Whether I stay or go, when I go, if an outside individual is going to consider the Medford Public Schools as his or her home, as superintendent, they are going to evaluate the environment.

[Roy Belson]: And if they feel the environment is hostile, they're not coming here.

[Roy Belson]: They're not coming here because it's a tough enough job not to be in a situation where people are divided and split along many issues.

[Roy Belson]: So it's our responsibility to have a decent dialogue, to make an appropriate decision, but to keep it intelligent and to keep it

[Roy Belson]: welcoming, so that when someone does consider applying for the Medford Public Schools, they say, I want to go there, because that's a good place to be a superintendent of schools.

[Roy Belson]: The people support the administration, they support their school committee, and there's mutual respect.

[Roy Belson]: And so that's really what we've got to strive for.

[Roy Belson]: A decision will be made.

[Roy Belson]: Decision will happen in public session.

[Roy Belson]: Decision will happen after a lot of consultation.

[Roy Belson]: And a lot of the things that we have to decide are based on, am I a person at this point in time able to bring forward our agenda in an intelligent way?

[Roy Belson]: Or is someone else maybe better positioned to do that at this point in time?

[Roy Belson]: That's what it's about.

[Roy Belson]: That's what it's about.

[Roy Belson]: So let's have our process.

[Roy Belson]: Let's respect each other.

[Roy Belson]: Let's continue to work together, and let's make a decision in a timely way on behalf of the community.

[Roy Belson]: Now, superintendent searches vary.

[Roy Belson]: Many of them are done in a lot shorter time than a year.

[Roy Belson]: But if that's the community's wish, then that's something we'd go forward with.

[Roy Belson]: But I've observed a lot of searches over the years, and people call me all the time because I've been around for a long time.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that it's important we go through our process.

[Roy Belson]: It's also informative to go through the process, because the things I will bring to you in the self-evaluation will remind you of things you've done.

[Roy Belson]: Even when I'm writing up the evaluation myself, I'm saying to myself, oh, I forgot we did this.

[Roy Belson]: Oh, I forgot this actually happened.

[Roy Belson]: Oh, this, yes, was a concern.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, we dealt with this.

[Roy Belson]: It's a process of re-educating ourselves about all the things that are going on.

[Roy Belson]: It's also a message that we send to our administration, faculty, and staff.

[Roy Belson]: And it's important that we do it right.

[Roy Belson]: And it's important that we have the right kind of discussion.

[Roy Belson]: And that we not create a leverage situation where decisions are made on the fly, or decisions are made without proper dialogue and discussion and process.

[Roy Belson]: I'm very confident that you will do that.

[Roy Belson]: And I'm very confident that we will have

[Roy Belson]: a good discussion and that a proper appropriate decision will be made.

[Roy Belson]: So thank you for your ongoing support.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you for your interest in perhaps making sure the community has a proper transition.

[Roy Belson]: But at the same time, let's make sure we do it right.

[Roy Belson]: And so you will get my self evaluation at the end of the week.

[Roy Belson]: And by the way, it's important that people respect the fact that you're the elected members of this community.

[Roy Belson]: You have a right to look at this stuff before the rest of the world comments on it.

[Roy Belson]: You work with me all the time.

[Roy Belson]: And conversely, I believe I have a right to make sure that the people who work with me all the time get the first pass at commenting on what goes on.

[Roy Belson]: I think we're in a good place.

[Roy Belson]: I think it will go well.

[Roy Belson]: And I think people will be pleased that a good transparent process has taken place.

[Roy Belson]: That's all we all want.

[Roy Belson]: Prior or by?

[Roy Belson]: Remember, and this is something that was misunderstood, and I heard this at a council meeting, that this is not the RFP.

[Roy Belson]: These are guidelines to the procurement office to develop an RFP.

[Roy Belson]: So they need to flesh out the specifics of security or other things, because if we get too tight right now, in their process, they may not be able to put something together that is appropriate for a vendor.

[Roy Belson]: If you set up a security plan that's around the clock or something like that, they may say that's prohibitive, no one's going to bid on it.

[Roy Belson]: We've got to get something from procurement, let them check with other people as to what's likely to go through.

[Roy Belson]: The same thing is true of other elements of this.

[Roy Belson]: This is guidance to the procurement officer.

[Roy Belson]: Remember, the procurement is going to come back to you.

[Roy Belson]: You're going to see the actual document.

[Roy Belson]: So this is really guidance.

[Roy Belson]: Let the procurement officer actually spell out a little title and you'll be better off.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: All right.

[Roy Belson]: This was the guidelines for the development of an RFP.

[Roy Belson]: That's not true.

[Roy Belson]: We actually have the procedure.

[Roy Belson]: And we actually have the details that they did a deep cleaning on a regular basis.

[Roy Belson]: So I want to make that clear that, you know, some people say things and, you know, they may think it's true, but we have backup information, which I can provide to you at a subsequent time.

[Roy Belson]: which shows that a deep cleaning was actually done, and the process and procedures spelled out as to what a deep cleaning actually is.

[Roy Belson]: The Children's Trust is the premier organization in this state that works to prevent child abuse and works to strengthen families.

[Roy Belson]: Susan Barkley has been very active for many, many years, and it's her goal to take the model created by the Medford Family Network in the early 90s, it's 22 years in existence now, and the work of Marie Cassidy, who's been our lead player in that organization for many years,

[Roy Belson]: to take that statewide.

[Roy Belson]: And basically, the pitch with the speaker was that this is the way you reduce child abuse, this is the way you help DCF meet their challenges, and this is the way you promote good gateway education into the community.

[Roy Belson]: And as the mayor emphasized also, that it was critical that we do these things so that when youngsters come to school, they're ready to learn.

[Roy Belson]: And they have family supports and parents know what's expected of them, and we can move our agenda forward.

[Roy Belson]: This is a requirement that we face every year.

[Roy Belson]: availability of seats.

[Roy Belson]: We find that this is not a productive way to increase enrollment and that we have to notify the State Department by June 1st, so we put this on annually and ask that you approve it so that we can formally notify the State Department of Education.

[Roy Belson]: So, assuming that it doesn't snow.

[Roy Belson]: Or there's anything else that might get in the way of closing.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, after a number of meetings on this matter, because it involves real estate negotiations, the committee went into session to discuss some of the possibilities.

[Roy Belson]: we put this together as a compilation of what you thought was important to be included in specifications.

[Roy Belson]: Should we decide to go forward with a winter season bubble over the elderly field or sometimes referred to as the field of dreams?

[Roy Belson]: Um, so it requires your approval for it to go to an RFP development.

[Roy Belson]: Once the RFP is developed, it would then go out.

[Roy Belson]: And of course, any awarding of a lease of any kind would then come back to the school committee.

[Roy Belson]: uh, before it was actually implemented.

[Roy Belson]: But these are the terms and conditions that we would ask to be put into the, um, RFP.

[Roy Belson]: Uh, and if there's any amendments to them, obviously we would make them this evening if we decided to go forward, uh, with the permission of, uh, mayor, I would read through them for public consumption and also, uh, to allow you some time to reflect on each one so that you may have some thoughts

[Roy Belson]: as we continue our discussion.

[Roy Belson]: Number one, the contract must include a parking lot for an additional 100 cars on the non-turf practice field adjacent to the turf fields paid for by the vendor.

[Roy Belson]: That's the West courtyard field.

[Roy Belson]: Two, the contract must include provisions for a field house with adequate indoor bathroom facilities.

[Roy Belson]: It should have a heater installed since it's going to be used during the winter months.

[Roy Belson]: All costs of installation and maintenance must be borne by the contractor.

[Roy Belson]: Three, the programs operated by the vendor must make substantial provisions for discounting participation fees for Medford youth and residents.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things that in checking with Mr. Scarpelli, who is actively involved in recreational matters in Somerville and is knowledgeable of our facilities as well, in Somerville they look at a 50% discount.

[Roy Belson]: We could change that, add to it,

[Roy Belson]: you know, as, as the case may be, but we could, you know, that's, that's nothing that we have to, uh, uh, decide immediately when we can come back to that.

[Roy Belson]: It should be in the RFP.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: Um, and that would be not only for Medford youth, but also for residents for the hours of operation must be established in such a way as to avoid conflict with Medford programs and to avoid late night impact on a butters.

[Roy Belson]: The contract may not operate programs beyond 11 p.m.

[Roy Belson]: on any evening.

[Roy Belson]: Six, all operational costs associated with the rented program must be borne by the company or vendor.

[Roy Belson]: This would include but not limited to electrical, heating, snow plowing, cleanup, maintenance, parking, staffing, et cetera.

[Roy Belson]: Seven, there should be sufficient insurance coverage borne by the vendor, contractor if you will, to cover any damage or liability.

[Roy Belson]: The city must be held harmless.

[Roy Belson]: All employees of the contractor work on site must be Corey checked.

[Roy Belson]: Appropriate security coverage will be provided by the vendor contractor during the contractor's hours of operation.

[Roy Belson]: Access to the main school building should be limited to emergencies.

[Roy Belson]: Nine promotion and advertising of the facility's purpose and use must be reviewed by the city to ensure that there is no misrepresentations. 10,

[Roy Belson]: There must be monthly reporting of activity and facility conditions to the city to ensure that any emergent situations are dealt with in a timely and effective manner.

[Roy Belson]: 11, the initial contract would be for a term of seven years with the possibility of three year extension after five years of successful performance.

[Roy Belson]: So that means after the fifth year, the committee would then decide whether it wanted to extend the three years.

[Roy Belson]: There must be an out cause in the contract for the city.

[Roy Belson]: If there was a failure to perform,

[Roy Belson]: or there is a transfer of ownership control.

[Roy Belson]: Twelve, substantial non-rental time must be available to the Medford Athletic, Physical Education and Community Schools for educational and recreational programs and activities.

[Roy Belson]: Any subcontractor of the contractor to a third party must be approved in advance by the city of Medford.

[Roy Belson]: So those are the general provisions.

[Roy Belson]: If there's something that we missed as coming out of our meetings, or if there's something that

[Roy Belson]: You want extended or clarified, we should talk about it now.

[Roy Belson]: As you remember from our discussions, that was to put it, it was to go into, I'm sure we left it off for some reason, but that was to go into the, into a fund that would only be used for either debt reduction if necessary.

[Roy Belson]: attention immediately.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee, as you know,

[Roy Belson]: We passed a gender non-discrimination policy in 2013.

[Roy Belson]: And this past period of time, many organizations have come together to support additional legislation in the Massachusetts Statehouse to deal with all public facilities being available to transgender individuals.

[Roy Belson]: public schools are already covered.

[Roy Belson]: However, this issue is critical to us because as our young people go out into society and they go out into the world, we want to make sure that what they learn in school and what they experience in school is available to them in the larger world.

[Roy Belson]: Our current policy is a good one.

[Roy Belson]: So one way to reinforce it is to give our support to the ongoing legislation that is being proffered at the state house.

[Roy Belson]: Additionally,

[Roy Belson]: The site council of the high school, working together with the Gay-Straight Alliance and others, has tried to put forth a survey, and will put forth a survey, to help youngsters identify, it's anonymous and it's voluntary, so that we can better serve them, and we can make sure that we have everything in place that is necessary to accommodate our students.

[Roy Belson]: And that it's important that we also accurately report to the state on the various mandated reports.

[Roy Belson]: You have the survey questions that are here, you have additional information, you have our gender policy from 2013, and you have pieces of the legislation that is at the state house.

[Roy Belson]: So I present this report to you this evening to make sure you're fully aware of what we're doing.

[Roy Belson]: And that we get your support to go forward and to make sure that we can speak with a very clear voice at the state level.

[Roy Belson]: That the Medford School Committee and the city of Medford is in full support of all our youth, including our transgender youth.

[Roy Belson]: So I'd recommend that we approve this this evening.

[Roy Belson]: Okay, a couple of them occurred, okay.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee, at our last meeting, we talked about the substance abuse drug and alcohol policy of the Medford Public Schools and the new legislation, the Opiate Act, if you will, that was passed in the legislature this past month and signed by the governor.

[Roy Belson]: Clearly, all of us are concerned, and at our last meeting, at your request, you asked that we withhold posting it until we brought it to you back to your attention.

[Roy Belson]: This evening, I brought that policy back to you, and I've also added a few things to keep it consistent with the new act, and to clear up a few things that would be inconsistent with the actual act.

[Roy Belson]: For example, eliminate the term CASPAR, which is no longer the program of choice here in the Medford Public Schools.

[Roy Belson]: So I've tried to put this together for you, and with your support, we will post this on our web page.

[Roy Belson]: And we will wait for additional guidance from the state, from DESE, from DBH, and others to further update it based on the deliberations that they have as they go forward in carrying out the legislation.

[Roy Belson]: But in the interim, it's important that we're compliant with the law that I'll be able to post.

[Roy Belson]: And if you have any questions, I'd be happy to answer them.

[Roy Belson]: You can see that I've also attached legal advisories from Murphy, Hesse, Toomey, and Lane, who represents us in various areas of special education.

[Roy Belson]: But they're also an excellent source of information in almost any legal matter.

[Roy Belson]: Yes, and then also we'd be able to post it consistent with the law.

[Roy Belson]: So I know at the high school, we have a very specific form that people sign.

[Roy Belson]: Dr. Perrella can speak to that.

[Roy Belson]: I know that handbooks are turned out to parents at the lower grade schools, and I'm not sure they have to sign off on these things.

[Roy Belson]: It will require that we take a little bit of time and explain, because some people are concerned when they sign something that they don't fully understand it.

[Roy Belson]: So with your permission, we'll do it over the next period of time.

[Roy Belson]: But it takes a little bit of time to explain these things to people, because just to put it in front of them and say, sign your name,

[Roy Belson]: probably wouldn't work with any great degree of, let's say, effectiveness.

[Roy Belson]: So we'd like to sort of do it in small groups with parents and work it through the schools that way so that over the next year everyone signs in.

[Roy Belson]: But I think we need to take our time and make sure that, otherwise we're just going to have people signing their name, they're not going to read it.

[Roy Belson]: Understanding it is probably not going to be a very high either in some cases.

[Roy Belson]: There will be some very diligent people who will, but it won't be widespread.

[Roy Belson]: Currently the policy reach will not be allowed.

[Roy Belson]: We'd like to change it to daytime so that we have some discretion because obviously there are some situations out there that require discretion.

[Roy Belson]: One of the things that, I just want to pontificate for a minute if I can, get away with it, and that's simply this, is that we can't be afraid of having discretion.

[Roy Belson]: Sometimes you make hard and fast rules and they don't apply to everybody.

[Roy Belson]: And then you're stuck with that rule.

[Roy Belson]: So I think it's very important to make it may not so that we can look at a circumstance and make a determination.

[Roy Belson]: Hopefully we're being fair and even handed across the board, but when something becomes so hard and fast, it becomes necessary to enforce it with everyone.

[Roy Belson]: So that's why it may not came in.

[Roy Belson]: As school administrators, we make decisions about young people every day, who get something, who doesn't get it, because we have to.

[Roy Belson]: It's a human enterprise.

[Roy Belson]: abdicate our discretion or abdicate our judgment, we're basically just robots.

[Roy Belson]: We're just following mechanics when it comes to young people.

[Roy Belson]: And it's important to understand the circumstances that young people find themselves in at different times and how they were involved.

[Roy Belson]: A person could be at a site where alcohol is there and then not be a user themselves and might be blamed for it.

[Roy Belson]: Another person could be there and actually be distributing it or distributing drugs.

[Roy Belson]: There are differences.

[Roy Belson]: There are differences.

[Roy Belson]: And so our responsibility as your leadership team and management team is to be able to accept the responsibility of making discretionary judgments and not to abuse it and not to give away anything that isn't deserved or punish people in ways that are inappropriate, but rather to ensure that there is a review.

[Roy Belson]: and there is an understanding, because without that, we're basically on autopilot, and then I don't think we're being fair to our young people and our families.

[Roy Belson]: So I understand the downside, but we make a lot of decisions about what goes on every day, and you need to trust us to do that, because if not, schools can't run.

[Roy Belson]: Dr. Perrella is the headmaster.

[Roy Belson]: If he has doubts, he'll come to me.

[Roy Belson]: If he has a clear understanding, I will respect his judgment.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor, members of the committee, our legal counsel, Howard Greenspan, is here to report on the matter that you referred to him and our committee the whole with regard to rental and school properties.

[Roy Belson]: At this time, I'd like you to welcome Howard Turner.

[Roy Belson]: So researching the issue as well,

[Roy Belson]: I found that, as Mr. Greenspan explained, that in the minutes of the March meeting, we indicated we would post those policies that had been approved of March of 2012.

[Roy Belson]: If you go online, and remember the online policies were posted by MASC based on the fact that we had approved them, and the ones we hadn't approved were still pending.

[Roy Belson]: If you look at the policies online, you will find that the policies, the four policies we're talking about, are not there.

[Roy Belson]: So what it means to me is that we didn't get to it.

[Roy Belson]: We hadn't really dealt with it yet, and that two of the policies that were MA Medford policies were older policies that we had had from older yearbooks that might have been available through hard copy, but they weren't available online.

[Roy Belson]: So as a result,

[Roy Belson]: It's clear to me, at least from my standpoint, you know, concurrent with our attorneys, is that we need to decide what you want to do.

[Roy Belson]: The law doesn't prohibit us, but the four policies either contradict themselves, and they weren't posted by MASC because clearly Jim Hardy, who was our consultant at the time,

[Roy Belson]: didn't get the go-ahead from the committee at that time to post it because we hadn't got that far.

[Roy Belson]: We'd done so much that we wanted to get as much as possible up, but we really didn't get that far.

[Roy Belson]: So in the interim, if I can, just for a little bit more and then certainly take any questions.

[Roy Belson]: In the interim, Pat Bealy has convened a committee with community schools and several of us working on it to come up with a draft policy for your consideration, which obviously you can change, adjust, modify, add to, subtract, as you will.

[Roy Belson]: with a fee structure, and we would hope to present that to you very shortly, probably at our next meeting, so that you can look at it and begin the process of agreeing what you want to be the policy of the Medford Public Schools.

[Roy Belson]: It's much more comprehensive than anything we've ever had, it's much more detailed, and it also reflects a lot of the discussions that you've had in our discussions and meetings as to what you have indicated were concerns that you had.

[Roy Belson]: So, I think we're,

[Roy Belson]: and attract to come up with a new policy, one that you will have obviously the final say over, and whatever you decide, we'll implement.

[Roy Belson]: But as Howard points out in his reference, in going over the issue of revenue, it becomes extremely important that we understand that revenue is key to keeping some of these facilities going.

[Roy Belson]: So we need to understand the balance between

[Roy Belson]: Programs that provide revenue and programs that are simply community oriented, that we are supporting activities within the community.

[Roy Belson]: It's a balancing act.

[Roy Belson]: But having said that, I'll be happy to answer any other questions you have or I'm sure direct them to Mr. Greenspan.

[Roy Belson]: My answer to that is I don't believe any of them.

[Roy Belson]: I believe they all were in discussion.

[Roy Belson]: So, Madam Mayor, you know, we've agreed to do that.

[Roy Belson]: This is not something that, you know, we need to say, oh, we've agreed to do that.

[Roy Belson]: But we first wanted a legal opinion.

[Roy Belson]: We now have a legal opinion.

[Roy Belson]: We told you that we've sat and worked on a comprehensive policy for you to review with a fee structure based on what we think is necessary to sustain the operation of the building.

[Roy Belson]: We will provide you with every renter, every user,

[Roy Belson]: We're also preparing for you a policy with regard to booster organizations, which will require that booster organizations register with the schools so that we have some access to their materials and we can track their materials.

[Roy Belson]: So there's a lot that's coming forward to you.

[Roy Belson]: You know, it just takes a little bit of time.

[Roy Belson]: We pulled it all together to do it right, and we waited for the appropriate legal opinion, and we did our homework.

[Roy Belson]: And I think that over the next month, you're going to see a lot, and you're going to have a chance to do it.

[Roy Belson]: And the reality is, is that going into the summer, into the next school year, you'll have a policy in place, assuming that you approve it.

[Roy Belson]: And that you'll have fees in place, assuming you approve it.

[Roy Belson]: And you have a structure that we believe will answer your questions and the questions of other people, and at the same time allow us to move forward in a constructive way.

[Roy Belson]: So I believe it's happening, and I believe that there's a lot of goodwill here, and I believe everybody wants it to work.

[Roy Belson]: And we certainly want to take any doubt away from anyone about the operation of the schools with regard to

[Roy Belson]: nonprofit, community, and other groups.

[Roy Belson]: It's also important as we go forward that you help us to identify to what extent, if any, you want to allow certain groups to have a pass in terms of the rental or the use of the school facilities, such as community organizations.

[Roy Belson]: How often, how frequently, so that we can fairly distribute them.

[Roy Belson]: This is a very involved process because there are many, many people who see the schools as a place where they can conduct their activities.

[Roy Belson]: So you're going to get a very comprehensive report.

[Roy Belson]: It's going to be very thorough.

[Roy Belson]: And I believe that when we come out of this school year, you're going to have something very, very well thought through and something that you will have had a very strong hand in developing.

[Roy Belson]: Our goal would be to allow our community groups to have access while we are developing things.

[Roy Belson]: Now, going forward, you may decide that there needs to be a modest fee or some type of fee.

[Roy Belson]: But for the short period of time that they would be inside, remember, this is April.

[Roy Belson]: For the short period of time they would have to remain inside, we'd like to sort of not try to construct some sort of artificial fee structure.

[Roy Belson]: Not for the batting cages.

[Roy Belson]: Not for the batting cages.

[Roy Belson]: Insurance liability.

[Roy Belson]: Do you want to discuss anything?

[Roy Belson]: So here's the way it would work, okay?

[Roy Belson]: If you approve it this evening, we will contact the individuals who run these organizations and talk to them about what their schedules they would like to see.

[Roy Belson]: And we will try to work their schedules into times where we have existing supervision in that part of the facility.

[Roy Belson]: To the extent that we don't,

[Roy Belson]: We will calculate as to whether or not the cost of supervision is extraordinary enough to worry about it, or if it's just marginal in order to help community organizations.

[Roy Belson]: If it's small enough, we probably would absorb it under our normal operational costs.

[Roy Belson]: If it were extensive and they wanted to use it, then we would have to say we can't do it unless you're prepared to pay for that supervision.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, we obviously recognize the legitimacy of the concern, but at the same token, we're trying to say we want our community groups to feel wanted, while at the same time, we want to make sure that we understand that this is a temporary measure and that all things will be put in place and we'll ask for their cooperation.

[Roy Belson]: I'm not sure, but I'm sure there are guidelines, and I will ask the athletic director to inform me.

[Roy Belson]: When you say something happens, would we talk about injury?

[Roy Belson]: So if an injury were to happen,

[Roy Belson]: And there's no gross negligence on our part.

[Roy Belson]: We're not responsible.

[Roy Belson]: We're only responsible for gross negligence.

[Roy Belson]: And Mr. Greenspan can comment if, in fact, I miss something.

[Roy Belson]: But with regard to the issue of general negligence and the like, we would expect that the people who are running the program would be responsible and that our supervisor would follow the rules that we set in front of them.

[Roy Belson]: So the answer to that is you can have us do anything you want.

[Roy Belson]: We're just making a suggestion that it might be possible to help out community groups.

[Roy Belson]: We're referring to the youth baseball activities that are in the community.

[Roy Belson]: That's all we're referring to.

[Roy Belson]: We're not referring to outside groups.

[Roy Belson]: We're not referring to anyone.

[Roy Belson]: We're just referring to youth groups.

[Roy Belson]: Well, that's what has to be, you know, worked out in the final analysis.

[Roy Belson]: So when we get to talk to these people, we'd say, I'll call a meeting of them or ask them to come in.

[Roy Belson]: And I'll ask for some scheduling possibilities that they might like to have.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe they don't want to do it.

[Roy Belson]: Maybe they'll turn around and say, you know, it's not worth it.

[Roy Belson]: But, you know, if it's worth it to them, we'll schedule it.

[Roy Belson]: And then we'll determine who's going to open and close and, you know, and supervise.

[Roy Belson]: All I said to you a little bit before was that if it's a small amount of money that's required,

[Roy Belson]: And there's not someone else up there.

[Roy Belson]: Remember, there's three different batting cages.

[Roy Belson]: So if our team is using one of them, somebody can use the other two.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, or whatever the case may be.

[Roy Belson]: So, you know, if we can't cover it with someone who's already going to be there, we'll assess the cost.

[Roy Belson]: And if it's minor, you know, a few hundred dollars, you know, for a few, for a couple weeks, then we'll absorb it.

[Roy Belson]: If it's not, then we'll not allow it or ask them to pay it.

[Roy Belson]: Well, that's an acceptable facility of the school.

[Roy Belson]: So at this point in time, you know, the fire department hasn't found any problem with our use of it.

[Roy Belson]: They've been in the pool.

[Roy Belson]: They've been in that entire area.

[Roy Belson]: And they're aware that students are up there in that area.

[Roy Belson]: At any time, if something were to go wrong, certainly they could come in and change their mind.

[Roy Belson]: But as far as I'm concerned, they've cleared it.

[Roy Belson]: I'll have to check on that with Mr. Malone.

[Roy Belson]: It's already been sent, we call it, to us.

[Roy Belson]: We're going to bring you back a report.

[Roy Belson]: Madam Mayor and members of the committee, at a previous meeting you asked me to draft a letter that to some degree paraphrased the letter sent by the Ludlow School Committee to our legislative delegation with regard to the Charter School cap lift, recommending that the legislature reject that particular item.

[Roy Belson]: Now, specifically, the State Senate,

[Roy Belson]: passed a bill the other day through the Senate.

[Roy Belson]: It isn't legislative, it isn't law, but it passed through the Senate, which is a comprehensive approach to the charter school issues that have been discussed throughout the Commonwealth, much more broadly based than some other discussions have been, and dealing with much more than the charter cap lift.

[Roy Belson]: There's going to be some debate on Beacon Hill.

[Roy Belson]: I don't believe that the Senate bill in its entirety is going to be accepted by the House or approved by the Governor, but there may be elements of it that are acceptable by the House and by the Senate, and maybe even by the Governor down the road.

[Roy Belson]: But certainly, the House and the Senate would probably get together and have a discussion about it.

[Roy Belson]: From our standpoint, I drafted a letter.

[Roy Belson]: which would be consistent with it, but it wasn't done in the context of the Senate's passage of this bill.

[Roy Belson]: I would ask that you study this material, and maybe I would draft another letter since this is going to be a pending discussion going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Because I think that the letter that I originally drafted for you is probably a little bit out of date,

[Roy Belson]: the fact that there is a change in what's going on on Beacon Hill.

[Roy Belson]: So I'll do whatever you want, but I think that there's quite a bit of ferment going on.

[Roy Belson]: And it may be that the Rise Act that is consistent with the charter school legislation is something you want to take into consideration.

[Roy Belson]: The letter that I drafted for you is on the back page, the last page of this.

[Roy Belson]: And if you haven't had a chance to read it, maybe you should take a few seconds and read it.

[Roy Belson]: But it paraphrases or closely paraphrases the letter that was sent from Ludlow with a few changes that reflect more of a Medford issue.

[Roy Belson]: Because since our issues are not totally Ludlow's issues and our numbers are slightly different.

[Roy Belson]: I just want to tell you that the preliminary numbers on charter schools have been posted by the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.

[Roy Belson]: And this year we have 344 students attending charter schools.

[Roy Belson]: Next year the department is projecting we have 315, a substantial reduction of 29 students.

[Roy Belson]: So that's not necessarily a final number, it could be a change up or down.

[Roy Belson]: But it certainly is a trend that we were hoping for because obviously that puts junctures back in our schools and also deals with money as opposed to it going outside of our schools.

[Roy Belson]: So happy to answer any questions you have or continue the discussion.

[Roy Belson]: Okay.

[Roy Belson]: I'd also want to say that, you know, we have a meeting May 2nd, so that I would probably bring it back to you for approval on May 2nd.

[Roy Belson]: that necessarily we're going to get agreement in a short period of time with the legislature and with the governor and everyone else like that.

[Roy Belson]: But I do believe that there are some pieces in the Senate's legislation that we should be supportive of.

[Roy Belson]: I mean, for example, within the Senate's legislation is full funding.

[Roy Belson]: the school districts, as opposed to partial funding that we're getting now.

[Roy Belson]: Within the Senate's piece, there is a piece that calls for a reimbursement formula that's more realistic.

[Roy Belson]: So reality-wise, we should probably want to reference those items.

[Roy Belson]: Now, I'm not going to reference the items about good, bad, or indifferent about charter schools, because that's not what I think you're asking me to do.

[Roy Belson]: I would like to be sure that we're able to be on record as saying is that there is a bill out there that is asking for full funding.

[Roy Belson]: There is a bill that is asking for that.

[Roy Belson]: that there be reporting, that individuals would know who's going and who's not going, that there be better demographics taken across the board.

[Roy Belson]: Not necessarily, some schools have done well, but other schools have not done well.

[Roy Belson]: I think those are things that we should want to be on record and show that we're knowledgeable of the latest things that are being discussed on the Hill, as opposed to being four weeks behind.

[Roy Belson]: So I think that that's, you know, I think that makes us much sound much more intelligent when we present a letter to the Commonwealth saying that we're aware of what's being discussed rather than we wrote something a month ago and still sending it.

[Roy Belson]: So we are scheduling a committee of the whole on April 25th, that's a week sooner.

[Roy Belson]: Yeah, but what I would do is I would send it out to you well in advance.

[Roy Belson]: I'd draft it this week and send it out to you over the vacation period and let you look at it.

[Roy Belson]: And if it came in April 25th, we'd make it a standalone item along with the committee of the whole reports.

[Roy Belson]: And we could go from there, that would be a week earlier.

[Roy Belson]: But I do think you should have some of the latest stuff.

[Roy Belson]: I just don't think you should be talking about things that may not be in play right now going forward.

[Roy Belson]: Please do it soon so I can really reach them and get you in.

[Roy Belson]: I may also mention that I gave you an article this evening, it was in the American Prospect.

[Roy Belson]: The individual who wrote the article used to write for Commonwealth Magazine, now writes as a deputy editor for

[Roy Belson]: American Prospect, which is a very progressive publication out of Washington.

[Roy Belson]: Robert Kuttner, Robert Reich are, you know, part of the editorial board of this particular group.

[Roy Belson]: So it's fairly strong.

[Roy Belson]: magazine, if you will, or commentary.

[Roy Belson]: But it talks about the great diversion.

[Roy Belson]: It talks about the money moving away from the traditional schools.

[Roy Belson]: It's not passing judgment on whether or not charters are good, bad, or indifferent.

[Roy Belson]: It's just asking the question, can you support two school systems with a finite amount of money?

[Roy Belson]: And that's really sort of the harder part of this discussion.

[Roy Belson]: can we really do that?

[Roy Belson]: So I recommend you read it and become familiar because there's a lot of stuff going on that's affecting other communities, not affecting us as much right now, but it could going forward.

[Roy Belson]: And it's the kind of discussion that's going to happen over the next several months, especially if it goes to a ballot question.

[Roy Belson]: So you need to know these things, and it's important that you stay up on it.

[Roy Belson]: We are putting data together for you based on your request.

[Roy Belson]: While we're up, I also heard today that the passing of Linda Houston, who once was a secretary of the school.

[Roy Belson]: She's a member of the DePasquale family.

[Roy Belson]: And I met her, so if you could take another second.

[Roy Belson]: Thank you.

[Roy Belson]: Just a couple of quick things for you.

[Roy Belson]: Again, I'll send you out information on our beginning of the pre-budget season on April 25th.

[Roy Belson]: We'll send out the materials early next week.

[Roy Belson]: So you'll have them to go over and begin to look at various departments and programs to give you a preview of the kinds of concerns we may have going into budget, so you can begin to ask questions about that.

[Roy Belson]: Additionally, in the back of your packet, we have the responses that I sent to the city council based on the various things that they had asked over the last

[Roy Belson]: a few months with regard to security and substance abuse and the like.

[Roy Belson]: So please review that so that if you're asked whether or not we sent that, this used to be, you know, some question as to what we did, we did.

[Roy Belson]: And the other thing is, is that some of you were able to attend, but I do have some information from Robert Brooks, who spoke at the Symposium on Addiction.

[Roy Belson]: I thought it was an excellent program.

[Roy Belson]: I'm glad that some people made it, approximately 80, 90 people there.

[Roy Belson]: We thought some of the things went well.

[Roy Belson]: We would have liked more people to have been there, but I understand that's Saturday, and sometimes it doesn't work, but it's an important activity, and it does continue our efforts to inform the community about these matters and keep them involved.

[Roy Belson]: You all know that the play was this past weekend, and many of you attended, and I know that you've all told me how wonderful it was, and I think that, you know, it's another

[Roy Belson]: It's an important accomplishment of our young people, so I think it's important that we recognize them at some point going forward.
